Although we have been summoned to join the Main Luxembourg Proceedings (as described below), the Main Luxembourg Proceedings and the Intervention Proceedings (as defined below) are currently managed separately by the Luxembourg Court, so that we are currently not requested to actively participate in the Main Luxembourg Proceedings. - Intervention Proceedings Following signing of the Vivacom Acquisition Agreement, we have been summoned to be joined to the Main Luxembourg Proceedings (the “Intervention Proceedings”) for purposes of putting us on notice of the Main ----- Luxembourg Proceedings. No claims have been made against us in the Intervention Proceedings and the Intervention Proceedings are still ongoing. The complainants in the Main Luxembourg Proceedings have in the meantime withdrawn their intervention claim. However, as we have raised doubts as to the formal procedural validity of this withdrawal, the parties are currently in the process of filing briefs on the withdrawal (among other issues). - Second Luxembourg Proceedings In March and April 2020, previous direct and indirect shareholders of the Viva Telecom Former Shareholder initiated new proceedings in Luxembourg (the “Second Luxembourg Proceedings”). Similar to the Main Luxembourg Proceedings, the claimants argue that the 2016 sale of the Viva Telecom Former Shareholder should be unwound, and as a consequence, any subsequent event resulting from that sale, including the Vivacom Acquisition should also be unwound. The parties are currently exchanging written submissions, and given the large number of defendants, the proceedings in Luxembourg are expected to continue for at least the next two to three years.

Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions of local broadband and television operators in Bulgaria
Subsubsection Text: On April 29, 2021, Vivacom acquired local broadband and television operators Net 1 EOOD, ComNet Sofia EAD and Digital Cable Television EOOD. These transactions were approved by the Bulgarian Commission on Protection of Competition (“CPC”). On April 29, 2021, Telenor Bulgaria challenged the CPC’s approval relating to these transactions before the Administrative Court—Sofia District. Vivacom has intervened in support of the CPC’s decision. We believe that the CPC’s decisions were well-reasoned and consistent with Bulgarian competition law. These appeals did not suspend the acquisitions and Vivacom has proceeded with integrating the acquired operators. If the Administrative Court—Sofia District annuls the CPC’s approvals, and the annulment is upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court, the CPC will re-examine the transactions.

Both Viva Telecom and Vivacom are subject to several tax audits. These tax audits and related proceedings are being carried out in a variety of venues and are being challenged as appropriate. The companies have already paid the amounts ascertained by the tax audits, and in the case respective challenges are successful, an amount of up to BGN 12.5 million and associated interest could be recovered.

We are involved in a number of legal proceedings. Other than as discussed below, we do not expect the legal proceedings in which we are involved or with which we have been threatened to have a material adverse effect on our financial position or profitability. The outcome of legal proceedings, however, can be extremely difficult to predict with certainty, and no assurance can be offered in this regard.

Telecommunications operations in Slovenia are subject to the EU framework on telecommunications regulation. The act governing telecommunications in Slovenia is the Electronic Communications Act (Zakon o elektronskih komunikacijah—ZEKom-1), which came into force on January 15, 2013 (as amended). The principal objectives of ZEKom-1 include promoting the development of electronic communications networks and services, including encouraging investment by lowering construction and set up costs of such networks and the development of services in the Republic of Slovenia alongside economic and social development, the establishment of effective competition on the electronic communications market, and consumer protection. The act aims to achieve these objectives principally by governing the conditions for the provision of electronic communication networks and services, effective construction and set up of such networks and shared use of existing physical infrastructure, ensuring competition, determining users’ rights, regulating the security and operation of networks and services in emergency situations, the protection of secrecy and confidentiality of electronic communications and setting forth the responsibilities and tasks of AKOS, which is an independent body that, among other things, regulates and supervises the electronic communications market. _Becoming an Operator_ A legal entity seeking to become an operator is required to notify AKOS about its intent to operate public communication networks or to provide public communication services prior to the beginning of the performance of its activities. The notification must include the required general information about the legal entity (such as the name and address, legal representatives etc.), a short description of the public communication networks or public communication services, as well as a description of the network, network elements, links and the planned date of the beginning of the operation of public communication networks or the provision of public communication services. ----- Within seven days from receipt of the complete notification, AKOS registers the operator in its official register and submits a confirmation notice to the operator (such confirmation is not an administrative decision and does not itself create rights and obligations under the ZEKom-1). Foreign operators that wish to acquire the status of an operator have two options: they can either establish a subsidiary in Slovenia or acquire a Slovenian tax number. _Required Notifications_ An operator must notify AKOS about: - changes to the company’s name, address or headquarters, legal representatives, network or services; AKOS must be notified about these changes within 30 days from their occurrence; - changes to the starting date of the operation of public communication networks or the provision of public communication services or changes to the geographic area in which the network is operated or the services are provided; AKOS must be notified about these changes prior to their occurrence; and - the termination of the operation of public communication networks or the termination of the provision of public communication services; AKOS must be informed in writing and at least 90 days prior to the planned termination. _Annual Fee_ All operators must pay an annual fee to AKOS. The amount of the annual fee under the ZEKom-1 is based on the operator’s revenue that results from the provision of public communication networks or public communication services and is calculated by AKOS. In its decision, the Slovenian Constitutional Court ruled that basing the calculation of the annual fee on revenue is unconstitutional. _Radio Frequency Spectrum_ On the basis of a public tender AKOS, issues decisions on the award of radio frequencies for provision of public communication services to end-users. AKOS issues the decision on award of radio frequencies for a limited time period, taking into account appropriate time for amortization of investment, however not longer than 15 years. The validity of a decision on award of radio frequencies for provision of public communication services to end-users may not be prolonged. The holder of the decision on award of radio frequencies may transfer its right to use such radio frequency to a third-party with a prior consent of AKOS. Operators may not accumulate radio frequencies with the objective of limiting competition on the radio communication market. Such accumulation may be established by the fact that the operator is not using the radio frequency as determined under the award decision or if it is otherwise apparent from the operator’s actions that it acquired the radio frequency with the purpose of limiting competition on the market. AKOS may ex officio change the decision on award of radio frequency in order to ensure effective use of radio frequency spectrum for the public good or for certain other causes as prescribed by law. AKOS may, among other things, annul the decision of awarding radio frequency if the award was acquired on the basis of untrue data, if the holder no longer complies with the requirements laid down in the relevant legislation or the decision itself, does not begin to use the radio frequency within the prescribed time period, transfers the right to a third-party, or if the fee for the use of radio frequency or the fee for effective use of finite commodity have not been paid. The holder of a decision on award of radio frequency must pay an annual usage fee to AKOS. The amount of the annual fee is based on the coverage and density of population; however, it may not restrict or hinder competition or market entry. In order to ensure optimal use of radio frequencies, holders of decisions on award of radio frequencies for provision of public communication services must also pay a fee for effective use of finite commodity. The minimal amount of such payment and terms of payment shall be determined in the decision on the initiation of the public tender procedure on the basis of demand for tendered frequencies, development of the market or amount of payment in other EU member states. The fee should not, however, unduly hinder the provision of innovative services and competition. _Numbering Plan_ AKOS adopts the numbering plan with a general act that determines the type, length, and structure of the numbering elements, their intended use, and manner of use, including numbers for emergency calls and ----- numbers the use of which is harmonized based on EU regulations. This general act must also support number portability and the introduction of new electronic communication services. The operator’s application for the allocation of numbering elements must include: - the company’s name and address, its VAT identification number and the name of its legal representatives; - evidence that the company has the right to be allocated numbering elements; - data on the type and quantity of the numbering elements it wishes to acquire and their intended use; - a project plan and an assessment of needs for the following three years, if the applicant requires a larger block of numbering elements; and - justifications on the basis of which the applicant proves that it will use the allocated quantity of numbering elements in three years. AKOS must reach a decision on the allocation of numbering elements within 21 days from the beginning of the proceedings, provided that a public tender was not carried out. AKOS uses a public invitation to tender procedure only when it is established that efficient use of specific numbering elements (e.g., short numbers) can only be ensured by restricting the number of decisions issued allocating numbering elements. Operators that may allocate the numbering elements they acquire for use to their users under equal, cost oriented and transparent conditions may take part in a public invitation to tender procedure. Other natural person or legal entities may only take part if they can prove that they require numbering resources in order to perform an activity for the public benefit under the relevant legislation or EU regulations. AKOS shall decide on tenders by issuing one or more decisions on allocation of numbering elements, which it must in this case issue and deliver within 42 days of the expiry of the deadline for the submission of tenders. A holder of a decision on allocation of numbering elements must pay an annual fee to AKOS. The amount of the annual fee is based on quantity, length and type of numbering elements; however the amount should not restrict or hinder competition or market entry. Additionally, in the case of numbering elements awarded on the basis of a public tender, payment of a fee for effective use of a finite commodity is also required. The minimal amount of such payment and terms of payment shall be determined in the decision on the initiation of the public tender procedure. _Operators with Significant Market Power_ To prevent operators with significant market power (“OSMP”) from potentially abusing their market power on a relevant market (in particular, the market for public communication networks and the market for public communication services), AKOS may issue decisions designating operators as OSMPs and impose on them suitable measures or regulatory obligations (ex-ante regulation). The purpose of these measures is to regulate the relevant OSMP’s actions vis à vis other operators. The measures or obligations that may be imposed on an OSMP are set forth in ZEKom-1 and include the obligation to ensure transparency and equal treatment, the obligation to ensure operator access to and the use of specific network facilities, price control and cost accounting obligations, the obligation to separate accounting records, the obligation to regulate retail services, etc. The most severe measure envisaged by ZEKom-1 is a functional separation, which means that a vertically integrated OSMP must perform its activities related to operator access in a separate and independent business unit. Under ZEKom-1, an operator is deemed to have significant market power if it itself or together with other undertakings on a relevant market holds a dominant position, i.e., such economic influence as to enable it to exercise a considerable degree of independence in respect of its competitors, users and consumers. In assessing whether an operator has significant market power AKOS, among other things, considers the following criteria: - the market share of the operator on the relevant market and the variation of its market share on the relevant market over a longer period of time; - the existence of barriers to entry and their effect on the potential competition on that market; - the impact of large users on the power of the operator (countervailing purchasing power); - the elasticity of demand; - the stage of development of the relevant market; - technological advantages; - the development of sales and distribution networks; ----- - the achievement of scale or economies of integration; - the level of vertical integration; - the level of product differentiation; - the possibility of access to financial resources; - the control of infrastructure that may not easily be duplicated; and - the interconnection of services. The relevant markets are determined by AKOS taking into account principles of competition law and taking into account the valid European Commission recommendation on relevant product and service markets. The relevant markets listed in the valid European Commission recommendation of October 9, 2014 on relevant product and service markets within the electronic communications sector susceptible to ex-ante regulation in accordance with Directive 2002/21/EC of the European Parliament and of the European Council on a common regulatory framework for electronic communications networks and services (2014/710/EU) are: Market 1: Wholesale call termination on individual public telephone networks provided at a fixed location; Market 2: Wholesale voice call termination on individual mobile networks; Market 3a: Wholesale local access provided at a fixed location; Market 3b: Wholesale central access provided at a fixed location for mass market products; and Market 4: Wholesale high-quality access provided at a fixed location. In December 2020, the European Commission adopted a revised version of the recommendation on relevant product and service markets within the electronic communications sector susceptible to ex-ante regulation, replacing the European Commission recommendation on relevant products and service markets of October 9, 2014, as required by the European Electronic Communications Code. The new recommendation sets out a revised list of markets, which still warrant ex-ante regulation at the EU level, including two wholesale connectivity markets, i.e., Market 1: Wholesale local access provided at a fixed location and Market 2: Wholesale dedicated capacity. Other (previously listed as recommended) markets for wholesale central access as well as fixed and mobile voice call termination (listed in the preceding paragraph as Market 1, Market 2 and Market 3b) are no longer listed as markets susceptible to ex-ante regulation, however national regulatory authorities can always regulate these markets based on national circumstances and provided that the following test is met: (i) high and non-transitory barriers to entry, (ii) a structure that does not tend towards effective competition and (iii) competition law alone is insufficient to adequately address the identified market failures. It has not yet been publicly disclosed whether AKOS will impose ex-ante regulation measures only on the two listed markets, but we have received unofficial indication that AKOS intends to continue imposing ex-ante regulation on other markets as well. _Media Act_ The Media Act (Zakon o medijih—ZMed), which came into force on May 26, 2001 (as amended), prohibits a telecommunications operator from carrying out activities of a TV or radio broadcaster or advertiser, unless it has obtained an approval to perform TV and/or radio broadcasting activities from AKOS. In practice this means that entities engaging in telecommunication operations and entities carrying out activities of a TV or radio broadcaster or advertiser must be structurally separated (but may be under common control).

_General_ Under the Serbian Electronic Communication Act (“ECA”), the main piece of legislation regulating the performance of electronic communication activities and the operation of the networks thereof in Serbia, a company’s general authorization to conduct its business is in most cases sufficient to provide electronic communication services. A sector-specific license is required only if the business involves the exploitation of scarce resources, such as phone numbers or radio frequencies. Therefore, when a company takes up an activity under the general authorization regime, all it needs to do (subject to fulfillment of the imposed general conditions (technical and certain others) and payment of the prescribed fees) is to notify RATEL within 15-days of doing so. In addition, the company is required to act in compliance with general conditions during its operations and to notify RATEL of any important changes in its activities, as well as of their termination. ----- _Significant Market Power Under the ECA_ Under the ECA, an operator is considered to have significant market power (“SMP”), if it has, alone or together with other operators, a dominant position, i.e., a position that enables it to a significant degree to act independently from its competitors, subscribers and customers. Pursuant to the ECA, if RATEL finds the absence of effective competition in a relevant market (and a closely related market), it will designate the operator who, individually or jointly with other operators, has SMP on that market, by taking into account different market conditions. If RATEL reaches a decision designating one or more operators as having SMP, RATEL may impose at least one of the following obligations on the respective entities: - an obligation to publish data from accounting records, technical specifications, network characteristics, terms and conditions for supply and use or validity periods of the offer and prices; - an obligation to only engage in non-discriminatory conduct; - an obligation to keep separate accounts for interconnection and access services; - an obligation to provide access and use of parts of its network infrastructure and associated facilities to third parties; - price controls and cost-based accounting; - an obligation to make available a minimum set of leased lines; - an obligation to offer operator selection and operator pre-selection services; and - regulation of the respective operators’ retail services, including an obligation to unbundle products and services. _Tariffs_ As a general matter, each operator is free to set its own tariffs. However, if RATEL finds an operator to have SMP in a relevant market, the operator may become subject to various restrictions, including price controls, as noted above. If an operator becomes subject to price controls, it must adopt a cost based accounting system for the provision of specific types of interconnection and/or access services. These controls are imposed if, in particular, RATEL determines that the absence of effective competition enables the operator to charge exceedingly high prices or resort to price squeezes to the detriment of end-users. While RATEL has some flexibility in imposing these restrictions, it must take into consideration the previous investments made by the operator while imposing the aforesaid measures, it must encourage further investments and it must allow for a reasonable rate of return on investment in view of the risks involved. The burden of proof that an operator’s prices comply with the above-mentioned restrictions is on the relevant operator. Upon RATEL’s request, the operator in question is required to provide a detailed account of its pricing policy. A description of the operator’s price calculations must be made publicly available and reviewed annually by an independent auditor. _Law on Electronic Media_ Provision of audiovisual media services via electronic communication networks is subject to a license by the media regulator REM. Such license is valid for a period of eight calendar years and may be extended. In order to extend the term of the license, the licensee must submit a request for the extension of the license at least six months before its expiration. The holder of the license must notify REM of any change in its direct or indirect ownership structure for REM’s verification as to whether the change of control may lead to violation of the rules on media concentration (concentration of ownership or management rights in two or more electronic media publishers, or acquisition of more than 50% of share of daily news publishers with circulation of more than 50,000 copies annually, and audio and AVM service providers). Failure to abide by media concentration rules may lead to license revocation.

_Telecommunications Services_ The Bosnian Law on Communications regulates telecommunications, radio, broadcasting (including cable television) and associated services and facilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina as well as the establishment and the activities of the Bosnian Communications Regulatory Agency (“CRA”). ----- The CRA was established on March 2, 2001 and assumed the competences of the Independent Media Commission and the Telecommunications Regulatory Agency. The CRA is responsible for developing rules in the telecommunications and broadcasting sectors, the licensing of operators in these sectors, the planning, management and allocation of the frequency spectrum, the implementation of technical and quality standards and the determination and maintenance of license fees. Telecommunications services through fixed-line and mobile networks or internet services may only be offered if the relevant operator holds a license. A telecommunications operator is required to: - enter into written subscription contracts with its subscribers; - provide (free of charge) a brief and plain summary of the tariffs applicable to its subscribers; - deliver, at the request of the CRA, within a reasonable period of time, business data, network data and traffic data including confidential data; - ensure the proper functioning and good working condition of its system and the timely removal of interferences and failures and notify the CRA without any undue delay of any significant interruption in the telecommunications connections; - set up conditions of operation, a description of services and specify the relevant tariffs, all of which must be presented to the CRA and published in a suitable form; the operator must also publish any changes to the conditions of operations and tariffs at least one month prior to their effective date in a suitable form; any change to the content of a contract entitles the contracting party to terminate its contract with the telecommunications operator within a period of four weeks from the publication of the change; and - offer interconnection services to other operators upon their request; if the relevant parties cannot reach an agreement within a period of six weeks from receipt of the request, each of them may petition the CRA to mediate the dispute. The CRA decides upon the grant of a telecommunications license within two months of receiving an appropriate application. In the event of competitive or comparative selection procedures the CRA may extend the evaluation period for up to four months to ensure that such procedures are fair, reasonable, open, nondiscriminatory and transparent to all interested parties. The CRA will grant a license if the applicant possesses the necessary technical competence and if there is no reason to assume that the applicant will not provide the relevant services in accordance with the license, in particular as regards quality and supply. In reaching its decision, the CRA takes into consideration the applicant’s financial strength, its experience in the telecommunications sector and related sectors as well as its relevant expertise. A licensee may transfer its license in whole or in part only with the consent of the CRA, which defines the conditions for the transfer of the license. _Operators with Significant Market Power_ A telecommunications operator with significant market power must allow third parties to access its public telecommunications network or unbundled parts of such network. The obligation related to interconnection does not apply if the CRA determines, based on evidence provided by the telecommunications operator, that it would be inappropriate to require the operator to open its network. A telecommunications operator with significant market power requires the CRA’s approval to provide (i) voice telephony services via a fixed-line or mobile network and (ii) leased lines. In addition, a telecommunications operator with significant market power in the telecommunications market is required to provide to its competitors open and non-discriminatory access to its services, establish a cost accounting system that assigns costs to all of its services and permits subsequent audits of this system in compliance with the CRA rules and the provisions set out in the licenses, and provide a minimum set of lines for lease to third parties. Such an operator is also prohibited from cross subsidizing services and is subject to accounting separation of interconnection activities. In addition, a provider of public fixed-line telephony services that has been designated as an operator of telecommunications with significant market power on the market of fixed-line public telephony services must enable unbundled access to the local loop and related facilities on the basis of the following principles: objectivity, transparency, non-discrimination and cost orientation and is subject to price control. _Audiovisual Media Services_ The provision of audiovisual media services is subject to a license by the CRA. Such services must be provided on a non-discriminatory basis and in accordance with the law and the terms of the license. A licensee may not restrict access to subscribers based on their nationality, religious beliefs, financial strength or any other ----- grounds nor is it entitled to make a selection of programs in a manner that favors the interests of only one national or religious community in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The licensee is required to offer the services to all citizens in the technical coverage zone and each person that accepts the single and non-discriminatory conditions is entitled to enter into a subscription contract. Prior to the inclusion of any audiovisual media service or a radio media service into a service package, the licensee is required to obtain written consents from the owners of the program content or their authorized representatives. The distribution of such services cannot be launched before the relevant consents have been obtained. A license for the provision of audiovisual media services is valid for a period of ten calendar years and may be extended. In order to extend the term of the license, the licensee must submit a request for extension of the license at least three-months before its expiration. -----

The Issuer was formed as a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) under the laws of the Netherlands. The Issuer has its seat in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and its registered office is Spicalaan 41, 2132 JG Hoofddorp, the Netherlands. The Issuer’s Trade Register number is 58916318. The Issuer is indirectly controlled by the Sponsor. The Issuer’s board of directors is currently composed of four directors. The board of directors is responsible for managing the Issuer in accordance with applicable laws, constitutional documents and resolutions of the shareholders’ meeting. The principal role of the board of directors is to carry out the day-to-day business of the Issuer and to legally represent the Issuer in its dealings with third parties.

Janez Živko. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 48 Director Sašo Cunder . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 46 Director Marjolein Gorissen . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 40 Director Augustinus Gabriels. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 61 Director Janez Živko—Director._ Mr. Živko joined the management team of United Group in March 2015. Prior to joining, Mr. Živko served as the CFO of the Petrol Group, one of the largest companies in Slovenia. He has also served in numerous roles at Gorenje Group over a period of seven years, including Director of Finance and Deputy CFO. Mr. Živko began his career in 1998 as a financial analyst and subsequently became financial controller for European operations at ACT Teleconferencing in Denver, Colorado. He holds an MBA (in Finance) from the University of Denver in Colorado, USA. Sašo Cunder—Director._ Mr. Cunder joined the Group in 2014 as Chief Financial Officer of SBB Serbia. Prior to joining the Group, Mr. Cunder served as chief financial officer of Droga Kolinska, one of the largest regional FMCG companies, and prior to that he was employed by Deutsche Bank in London, working in the CEMA investment banking team. Mr. Cunder has a degree from Ljubljana University, where he graduated from the Faculty of Economics. Mr. Cunder is also a CFA charter holder, as well as one of the founding members of CFA Society Slovenia. Marjolein Gorissen—Director._ Ms. Gorissen is currently managing partner of a corporate service provider in the Netherlands. Prior to that, Ms. Gorissen worked as a lawyer at De Brauw Blackstone Westbroek N.V. She holds a Master of Laws degree from Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, the Netherlands and holds a Bachelor Business Administration degree from HES Amsterdam, The Netherlands. Augustinus Gabriels—Director._ Mr. Gabriels is currently managing director of a corporate service provider in the Netherlands. He has held various leadership positions in financial institutions in the Netherlands. He was also a member of the board of directors of those financial institutions. Mr. Gabriels has a Bachelor’s degree in accountancy with a state certificate from The Netherlands. Dragan Šolak . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 56 Group Executive—Chairman & Founder Victoriya Boklag . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 42 Chief Executive Officer and Group Vice President—Marketing and Media Violeta Vasilijević . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49 Group Vice President—Operations Janez Živko. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 48 Group Vice President—Finance Željko Batistić . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49 Group Vice President—Technology ----- Vladislav Ratajac. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 39 Group Vice President—Corporate Development Dragica Pilipović Chaffey. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 74 Group Vice President—Corporate Affairs Ianis Girgenson. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 44 Group General Counsel Aleksandra Subotić . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 45 Chief Executive Officer—United Media Srdjan Djurdjević . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 41 Chief Executive Officer—United Cloud Milija Zeković. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49 Chief Executive Officer—SBB Serbia and Telemach Montenegro Adrian Ježina . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 48 Chief Executive Officer—Telemach Slovenia and Telemach Croatia Atanas Dobrev . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Chief Executive Officer—Vivacom Admir Drinić . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 47 Chief Executive Officer—Telemach BH Nikola Francetić . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49 Chief Executive Officer—NetTV Plus Dragan Šolak—Founder and Executive Chairman of the Group._ Mr. Šolak founded SBB Serbia in 2000 and has been a member of our management since the Group’s inception. In 2009, Mr. Šolak assumed the role of Group Executive Chairman. In his current role, he continues to be involved in all aspects of the business and is responsible for the overall strategic leadership of the Group. _Victoriya Boklag—Chief Executive Officer of United Group and Group Vice President—Marketing and_ Media._ Ms. Boklag joined the United Group management team shortly after the company’s inception in 2000. Before becoming United Group Chief Executive Officer in 2018, Ms. Boklag held several senior positions in finance and commercial operations, including Chief Executive Officer of SBB Serbia and Group Vice President of Marketing and Media, a role she combines with her current position as CEO. Ms. Boklag is also a member of the board of the SBB Foundation, a charitable organization founded and sponsored by United Group. She holds a Bachelor’s degree in business administration and management from ICU Kiev. Violeta Vasilijević—Group Vice President—Operations._ Ms. Vasiljević has been with the management team since the Group’s inception in 2000. She is currently responsible for the technical and operating support for all of the Group’s administrative functions and products. Ms. Vasiljević holds a degree in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Kragujevac. Željko Batistić—Group Vice President—Technology._ Mr. Batistić first joined the management team in May 2012. Prior to joining, Mr. Batistić was an experienced CATV manager and served at a Croatian cable operator at B.net Croatia from 2007 to 2012. Mr. Batistić holds a Master’s degree in Electrical Engineering from the Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb and an Executive MBA degree from Cotrugli Business School, Zagreb. Vladislav Ratajac—Group Vice President—Corporate Development._ Mr. Ratajac joined the management team in 2011. Mr. Ratajac held positions at Mid Europa Partners from 2008 to 2011 and Deutsche Bank before joining the Group. Mr. Ratajac holds a degree in Economics from Rutgers University in New Jersey, USA. Dragica Pilipović Chaffey—Group Vice President—Corporate Affairs._ Ms. Pilipović Chaffey joined the management team in 2009. Prior to her current role, Ms. Pilipović Chaffey held a number of senior posts within the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) from 2007 to 2009, and the IMF in Washington, D.C. Ms. Pilipović Chaffey holds an MBA from George Washington University, Washington, D.C., and a BA in Economics from the University of Belgrade. Ianis Girgenson—Group General Counsel._ Mr. Girgenson joined the management team in July 2020 as Group General Counsel. Before joining, Mr. Girgenson practiced law in London, Brussels and Paris for over 15 years and served for four years as an Associate General Counsel at VEON in Amsterdam. Mr. Girgenson graduated from the University of Paris (Sorbonne) and obtained a Master of Laws from Harvard Law School. He is a member of Paris and New York bars. Aleksandra Subotić—Chief Executive Officer—United Media._ Ms. Subotić joined the management team in 2014. In addition to her Chief Executive Officer role at United Media, Ms. Subotić is also the Media Content Director at SBB Serbia. Previously, Ms. Subotić was a General Manager at NetTV Plus. Prior to joining us, ----- Ms. Subotić worked as General Manager at Daniel SatTV, a satellite and cable network development company in Serbia, and at Total TV Info, a distribution company in Austria. She holds an MBA degree in Economics from Educons University. Srdjan Djurdjević—Chief Executive Officer—United Cloud._ Mr. Durdević joined the management team in 2020. In addition to his role as Chief Executive Officer at United Cloud, Mr. Durdević is the Research and Development Director of the United Group. Previously, Mr. Durdević held several positions in the technology department, where he actively participated in the digital transformation of the company, and has been a part of the Group since 2002. He holds a Master of Science in Informatics from Union University in Belgrade, Serbia. Adrian Ježina—Chief Executive Officer—Telemach Slovenia and Telemach Croatia._ Mr. Ježina joined the management team in 2017. Prior to joining, Mr. Ježina was the CEO of Siemens Convergence Creators Adria Region. He graduated in 2009 at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering and Naval Architecture in Split. He also holds an Executive MBA degree from the Cotrugli Business School. Atanas Dobrev—Chief Executive Officer—Vivacom._ Mr. Dobrev joined Vivacom as Chief Financial Officer in 2008, taking charge of business planning, financial controlling, fraud prevention, revenue assurance, and customer quality control services. Prior to that, Mr. Dobrev was the Finance and Administration Manager at Oriflame Bulgaria and Chief Financial Officer at Globul. He holds an MBA in Finance and Accounting from Rollins College, Crummer Graduate Schoolof Business, USA and a Masters in International Economic Relations from the University of National and World Economy in Sofia, Bulgaria. Admir Drinić—Chief Executive Officer—Telemach BH._ Mr. Drinić serves as Chief Executive Officer of Telemach Bosnia and Herzegovina, having joined the company in 2013 as Chief Operating Officer. His previous positions include member of the Securitas BiH Board of Directors, Chief Executive Officer of the B.I.G.A. Sarajevo security agency, and Chief Technology Officer of Gama Sigurnost Sarajevo. He holds a bachelor’s degree in economics from the University for Business Studies, Faculty of Economics, in Banja Luka, in 2009. Milija Zeković—Chief Executive Officer—SBB Serbia and Telemach Montenegro._ Mr. Zeković joined the management team in October of 2018. Previously, he was Chief Executive Officer of Crnogorski Telekom from 2016 to 2017. He was also a member of the Executive Management Board of Crnogorski Telekom from 2008 to 2016. He holds a degree in Economics from the University of Montenegro. Nikola Francetić—Chief Executive Officer—NetTV Plus._ Mr. Francetić joined the management team in October of 2018. Previously, he was head of content, broadcasting and media for A1 Telekom Austria Group from 2014 to 2018 and an executive director for content at T HT Croatian Telekom from 2011 to 2014. He holds an MBA from the Bled School of Business in Slovenia and a degree in Experimental Physics from the University of Zagreb. The biography of Janez Živko is provided under “—The Issuer.”

The Group’s current senior management team is composed of the individuals listed below. Most of the current members of senior management indirectly hold ownership interests in United Group. The Company’s board of directors is currently composed of four directors; Janez Živko, Sašo Cunder, Marjolein Gorissen and Augustinus Gabriels. The biographies of these directors are provided under “—The _Issuer.”_

We typically enter into consultancy or advisory agreements with senior management members, primarily through holding companies owned by them, pursuant to which they are entitled to certain consultancy fees, which form part of the aggregate compensation paid to our senior management members. Alternatively, from time to time, we enter into direct employment agreements with senior management members. The aggregate compensation paid in the year ended December 31, 2020 to our directors was €3,960 thousand, consisting of fixed salary, annual consultancy fees and performance related components (which may include certain ESG criteria).

We and our operating subsidiaries follow a global anti-corruption policy, a trade sanctions policy, and an acquisition due diligence policy. These policies are aimed at facilitating our compliance with applicable anticorruption and trade sanctions laws and regulations that apply by virtue of our geographical operations. Our ----- acquisition due diligence policy sets out a framework for anti-corruption, trade sanctions, and anti-money laundering diligence procedures for our add on acquisitions, and we have retained specialist legal counsel on a number of occasions to review proposed acquisitions from a corruption and sanctions perspective. We also have procedures regarding conducting appropriate risk based due diligence before retaining third-party service providers, ranging from catering firms to technical contractors and business consultants. Our policies are maintained by our internal legal department. We also retain specialist counsel to assist with compliance diligence on material acquisitions. Moreover, from time to time when we are considering entering into a roaming agreement or other contract with a service provider in a geography that poses heightened trade sanctions risk, we engage specialist compliance counsel to review the opportunity, consistent with our policies and legal obligations. -----

Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Prior to, 2024, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the New Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the New Notes, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium described in this offering memorandum and accrued and unpaid interest to the redemption date. At any time prior to, 2024, the Issuer may on one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the New Notes, using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount of the New Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption; provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the New Notes (including the principal amount of any additional notes) remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all Notes of such series are redeemed substantially concurrently). In addition, prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem during each calendar year up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the New Notes (calculated after giving effect to the issuance of any additional notes) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest. The Issuer may redeem all or part of the New Notes at any time on or after, 2024, at the redemption prices described under “Description of the New Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption.

Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem the New Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and Additional Amounts, if any, to (but not including) the date of redemption. See “Description of the New _Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . .** If the Company experiences a change of control, as defined in the Indenture, the holders of the New Notes will have the right to require the Issuer to offer to repurchase the New Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to (but not including) the date of repurchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred in respect of the New Notes if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the New Notes—Change of Control.” Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture restricts, among other things, the ability of the Company and its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; ----- - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the New Notes. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description _of_ _the_ _New_ _Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of the New Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurances that the New Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange. Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . .** The New Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the New Notes under the Securities Act (including by way of an exchange offer).

Subsection Title: Absence of a Public Market for the New Notes; No
Subsubsection Text: Registration . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The New Notes will be new securities for which there will be no established trading market. Accordingly, we cannot assure you as to the development or liquidity of any market for the New Notes. Furthermore, the New Notes will not have registration rights under the Securities Act. Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture is, and, the New Notes and the Guarantees, and the rights and duties of the parties thereunder, will be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of New York. The Existing Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law. The respective Security Documents will be (subject to certain exceptions) governed by the applicable law of the jurisdiction under which the security interests are granted. Trustee for the New Notes . . . . .** U.S. Bank Trustees Limited.
Registrar . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Listing Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Carey Olsen Corporate Finance Limited.

Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** UniCredit Bank AG, London Branch, as English security agent and UniCredit Bank Serbia JSC Belgrade, as Serbian security agent. Risk Factors . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Investing in the New Notes involves substantial risks. Please see the “Risk Factors” section for a description of certain of the risks you should carefully consider before investing in the New Notes. -----

_The following summary of the Offering contains basic information about the New Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral. It is not intended to be complete and it is subject to important limitations and exceptions. It may therefore not contain all the information that is important to you. For a more complete understanding of the New Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral, including certain definitions of terms used in this summary, please refer to “Description of the New Notes” and for a more complete understanding of certain other financing arrangements relevant to an investment in the New Notes, including the Intercreditor Agreement, please refer to “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”_ Issuer . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** United Group B.V. (the “Issuer”). Notes Offered . . . . . . . . . . . . .** €300 million in aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “New Notes”). Issue Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .**, 2021. Issue Price . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** %. Maturity Date . . . . . . . . . . . . .**, 2028. Interest Rate . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** % per annum. Interest Payment Dates . . . . . . .** Semi-annually in arrears on each and, commencing, 2022. Form and Denomination: . . . . . .** Global Notes in denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess of €100,000. New Notes in denominations less than €100,000 will not be available. Ranking of the New Notes . . . . .** The New Notes will: - be senior obligations of the Issuer, secured by the Collateral described below under “—Security for the New Notes”on a firstpriority basis (subject to certain exceptions) along with obligations under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (although any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will, and certain future hedging agreements and certain other indebtedness that is secured by the Collateral may, receive priority over the New Notes with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over the Collateral); - be senior in right of payment to any indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the New Notes; - be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the Issuer, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the New Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the New Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Guarantors. Guarantees of the New Notes . . .** Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the New Notes will be guaranteed (the “Guarantees”) on a senior secured basis (i) on the Issue Date by the Company and (ii) within 120 days following (and not including) the Issue Date by the United Group Guarantors and the Vivacom Guarantors (together with the Company and the United Group Guarantors, the “Guarantors”). The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees will be subject to significant limitations, as described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability ----- _of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.” The Guarantors also_ guarantee the obligations under the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement; the Existing Revolving Credit Facility also benefits from guarantees from certain entities organized in Serbia and from security interests over assets located in Serbia. For the three months ended and as of March 31, 2021, (i) the Issuer and the Guarantors generated 46% of the Company’s consolidated revenue and 56% of the Company’s consolidated UG EBITDA, (ii) the Company’s subsidiaries (including the Issuer and the Guarantors) had a profit for the period of €6 million, compared to a consolidated net loss of €10 million for the Company and (iii) the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 40% of the Company’s consolidated total assets (excluding goodwill). Ranking of the Guarantees** . . . . Each Guarantee will, upon the relevant Guarantor having entered into such Guarantee: - be the senior obligations of the relevant Guarantor, which will be secured by the Collateral described below under “—Security _for the New Notes” on a first-priority basis (subject to certain_ exceptions) along with obligations under the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (although any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will, and certain future hedging agreements and other indebtedness that is secured by the Collateral may, receive priority over the Guarantees with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over the Collateral); - be senior in right of payment to any indebtedness of the relevant Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Guarantee; - be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the relevant Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the New Notes; - be senior in right of payment to any existing or future obligations of the relevant Guarantor secured on a basis junior to the New Notes, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the New Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the relevant Guarantor that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Guarantee to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be subject to the limitations described herein. The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to significant limitations, as described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and _the Security Interests.” The Guarantees will be subject to release_ under certain circumstances. See “Description of the New Notes— _Notes Guarantees.”_ Security for the New Notes . . . .** On the Issue Date, the New Notes (and, when granted, the Guarantees) will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens (as defined herein), by: ----- - shares of the Issuer, Adria Serbia Holdco B.V. and Adria Cable B.V.; - certain bank accounts of the Issuer and the Company; and - certain receivables owing to the Issuer (together, the “Issue Date Collateral”). In addition, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens, on the date that is 120 days following (and not including) the Issue Date, the New Notes and the Guarantees are expected to be secured by the following assets: - shares of Adria Media B.V., Slovenia Broadband S.à r.l., Bosnia Broadband S.à r.l., Telemach d.o.o., Telemach UG d.o.o. and Telemach BH d.o.o. Sarajevo; - shares or ownership stakes of Serbia Broadband—Srpske Kablovske Mreže d.o.o. Beograd (Voždovac) owned by Adria Serbia Holdco B.V.; - certain bank accounts of Adria Serbia Holdco B.V., Adria Cable B.V., Adria Media B.V., Slovenia Broadband S.à r.l., Bosnia Broadband S.à r.l. and Telemach BH d.o.o. Sarajevo; - blank signed bills of exchange and bills of exchange authorizations issued by Telemach d.o.o. and Telemach UG d.o.o.; and - certain receivables owing to Adria Cable B.V., Slovenia Broadband S.à r.l., Bosnia Broadband S.à r.l. and Telemach d.o.o. in respect of intercompany loans (together, the “Post-Issue Date Collateral”). Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens, within 120 days following (and not including) the Issue Date, the New Notes and the Guarantees are also expected to be secured by security over the shares of each Vivacom Guarantor (together, the “Vivacom Collateral”). The Issue Date Collateral, the Post-Issue Date Collateral and the Vivacom Collateral, together with any and all other assets from time to time in which a security interest has been or will be granted pursuant to any security document to secure obligations under the Indenture and the New Notes, is collectively referred to herein as the “Collateral,”and such security documents pursuant to which security has been granted to secure obligations under the Indenture and the New Notes, are collectively referred to herein as the “Security Documents.” Notwithstanding the foregoing, certain assets will not be pledged (or the liens not perfected) in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, as described under “Description of the New Notes— _Security—The Collateral.”_ Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . .** Proceeds of the Offering will be used by the Issuer (i) to pay the purchase price for the Optima Telekom Acquisition, (ii) to repay certain obligations outstanding under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, (iii) for general corporate purposes, which may include potential future acquisitions, working capital, capital expenditures and other purposes, and (iv) to pay transaction costs associated with the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds.” Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . .** All payments the Issuer or any Guarantor makes with respect to the New Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes ----- unless required by applicable law. If withholding or deduction for such taxes is required by law to be made in any “relevant taxing jurisdiction” with respect to a payment on the New Notes, subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the New Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of such withholding or deduction. See “Description of the New Notes— _Withholding Taxes.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY OF COMPANY AND GROUP RUN-RATE, VIVACOM, UNAUDITED PRO FORMA AND CERTAIN OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: (1) Homes passed represents all homes (households) ready to be connected directly to our fixed-line network. (2) Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of our cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique subscriber is typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but several RGUs. (3) Cable Pay-TV RGUs includes (i) the sum of our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Slovenia, (ii) our total analog cable Pay-TV RGUs (without separately counting analog cable RGUs that have purchased digital top ups) in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro and (iii) our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Bulgaria. (4) OTT consists of our NetTV Plus and out of footprint EON subscribers. (5) Broadband internet RGUs represents residential broadband internet provided within our network footprint. (6) Fixed-line telephony RGUs represents residential fixed-line telephony provided within our network footprint. (7) Mobile RGUs represents mobile-telephony services provided to customers in Slovenia, where we have operated as an MNO since our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015. Following completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia, and following the completion of the acquisition of Vivacom in July 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria. (8) Other services include multichannel multipoint distribution service-based services, ADSL internet services and B2B services. (9) RGU Penetration represents for cable Pay-TV the number of unique cable subscribers at the end of the relevant period as a percentage of the number of homes passed by our network, and for broadband internet the number of RGUs at the end of the relevant period as a percentage of the number of unique cable subscribers. ----- (10) Blended Cable ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total cable Pay-TV, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony revenues (including fixed-line telephony usage revenues and excluding minor installation fees) for that particular month divided by the average number of unique cable subscribers for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period. Blended Cable ARPU does not include mobile ARPU, which was €10.9 for the year ended December 31, 2018, €10.8 for the year ended December 31, 2019, €9.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020, €11.0 for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and €8.8 for the three months ended March 31, 2021. We calculate mobile ARPU by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total mobile-telephony revenues (excluding revenues generated by customers of other networks roaming on our network and excluding wholesale revenues) for that particular month divided by the average number of mobile RGUs for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period. In addition, following the Vivacom Acquisition, we amended the definition of certain key operating measures (Homes Passed, Unique Cable Subscribers and Blended Cable ARPU) in order to align the calculation methodology across the Group. As a result, Bended Cable ARPU figures were restated for the periods starting from January 1, 2018 onwards. (11) As of January 1, 2019, we changed our reporting methodology in regards to certain key operating measures, which has resulted in immaterial differences as compared to previous periods. For the year ended December 31, 2018, OTT users on our network have been reclassified to Cable and Cable services users on other networks have been reclassified to Other Services from Cable. This change has an immaterial effect on all subscriber, RGU, ARPU and churn data for the year ended December 31, 2018, and such key operating measures have been restated for such periods in line with this new reporting methodology.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure is prepared based on management accounts and not IFRS. For a reconciliation of capital expenditure to UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, see “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data Presented Herein.” Intragroup adjustments relate to unrealized profit on the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB Serbia. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other United Group companies in compliance with applicable transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS, but are not eliminated for the purpose of our management accounts. Assets held for sale relate to programming rights acquired by our Media Group segment for other Group segments which were recognized under IFRS as intangible assets and were invoiced to other Group segments after March 31, 2021. The application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia reflects the additional effect of harmonizing our accounting policy with respect to the capitalization of subscriber acquisition costs for rebinding, upselling and cross-selling (which in the past were not eligible to be capitalized, but under IFRS 15 qualify for capitalization), which were determined subsequent to the preparation of our management accounts. Overflow between periods relates to the fact that our management accounts are closed prior to the closing of our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS. Overflow between periods in any given period reflects the additional capital expenditure incurred between the preparation of our management accounts and our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS for such period. Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents costs and expenses incurred in connection with the Advisory Services Agreement (as defined herein) and certain other items. For more information regarding the Advisory Services Agreement, see “Related Party Transactions—Advisory Services Agreement.” (b) Represents expenses incurred in relation to performance of advisory services by the Group management in their capacity as shareholders of the Group and not as part of their regular management duties, including but not limited to travel expenses and services provided for extraordinary projects. (c) Represents legal and financial due diligence expenses with respect to our acquisitions of target companies during the period presented. (d) Represents certain performance bonus payments to members of management for completion of strategic group projects such as acquisitions, restructurings and information technology implementation. (e) Represents the effect of impairment of trade receivables from disposed companies and terminated contracts with certain customers. (f) Represents unrealized profit for the intragroup sale of end user equipment by SBB Serbia, which is not eliminated for the purpose of our management accounts. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other Group companies in compliance with applicable transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated for purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS. (g) Represents impairment of subscriber acquisition costs for terminated contracts. (h) Represents contributions of the Group to protecting the environment, education, the socially vulnerable and individual donations. (i) Represents certain costs incurred in connection with the development of a new project that started generating revenues in the third quarter of 2020. (j) The other expenses amount comprises a large number of low-value individual items, including other administrative expenses and fees, non-cash charges due to the sale of fixed assets and inventories below book value. Starting from 2021, the Group applied IFRS 16 in its management account reporting. Accordingly, the Group has adjusted the calculation of its UG Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2020 presented in this offering memorandum to enhance comparibility, while in 2019 the calculation remained unchanged. As a result, UG Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019 is presented in accordance with the formula used historically and may not be fully comparable with UG Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2020. Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents costs and expenses incurred in connection with the Advisory Services Agreement (as defined herein) and other items. For more information regarding the Advisory Services Agreement, see “Related Party Transactions—Advisory Services _Agreement.”_ (b) Represents expenses incurred in relation to performance of advisory services by Group management in their capacity as shareholders of the Group and not as part of their regular management duties, including but not limited to travel expenses and services provided for extraordinary projects. (c) Represents legal and financial due diligence expenses with respect to our acquisitions of target companies during the periods presented. (d) Represents impairment of receivables from disposed company. (e) Represents impairment of subscriber acquisition cost for terminated contracts. (f) Represents unrealized profit for the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB Serbia, which is not eliminated for the purpose of our management accounts. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other Group companies in compliance with applicable transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS. (g) Represents non-cash charges due to the sale of fixed assets and inventories below book value in Slovenia. (h) Represents contributions of the Group to protecting the environment, education, the socially vulnerable and individual donations. (i) Represents the impact of the accounting treatment of a Long-term Incentive Scheme (the “LTIS”). Under the LTIS, the shareholders of the Group’s former ultimate holding company, Adria LuxCo S.à r.l., was required to make bonus payments to certain members of our management team following an initial public offering or sale of the Group. Under IFRS 2, we are required to account for the calculation of these bonus payments in our financial results even though the payments will not be made by any Group entity and will not affect the Group’s cash balance. The non-cash impact of this accounting treatment was €21,659 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. (j) Represents the additional effect of the change in default rates which was determined following the preparation of our management report. (k) Represents impairment of a loan provided to a disposed company and other receivables. (l) Represents the effect of IFRS 16 on management accounts. Prior to 2021, UG Adjusted EBITDA was prepared on a preIFRS 16 basis. (m) For the year ended December 31, 2019, operating expenses comprise a large number of low value individual items, including other administrative expenses and fees, non-cash charges due to the sale of fixed assets and inventories below book value. Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents costs and expenses incurred in connection with the Advisory Services Agreement (as defined herein) and other items. For more information regarding the Advisory Services Agreement, see “Related Party Transactions—Advisory Services _Agreement.”_ (b) Represents expenses incurred in relation to performance of advisory services by the Group management in their capacity as shareholders of the Group and not as part of their regular management duties, including but not limited to travel expenses and services provided for extraordinary projects. (c) Represents legal and financial due diligence expenses with respect to our acquisitions of target companies during the periods presented. In addition, for the year ended December 31, 2018, €10.3 million related to transaction costs in connection with the United Group Acquisition. (d) Represents certain performance bonus payments to members of management for completion of strategic group projects such as acquisitions, restructuring and information technology implementation. (e) Represents mainly penalties for copyrights paid to SAZAS (as defined herein) and a tax penalty in Slovenia. (f) Represents impairment of receivables from disposed company. (g) Represents goodwill impairment primarily related to (i) increased programming costs and our assessment of our ability to transfer these increased costs to customers, resulting in decreased revenue growth expectations in our Slovenia segment and our Bosnia and Herzegovina segment and (ii) the closure of our legacy MMDS Pay-TV distribution platform in our Montenegro segment and our assessment of our ability to migrate all customers to our cable or satellite DTH technologies. (h) Represents impairment of subscriber acquisition cost for terminated contracts. (i) Represents unrealized profit for the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB Serbia, which is not eliminated for the purpose of our management accounts. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other Group companies in compliance with applicable transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS. (j) Represents non-cash charges due to the sale of fixed assets and inventories below book value in Slovenia. (k) Represents contributions of the Group to protecting the environment, education, the socially vulnerable and individual donations. (l) Represents the impact of the accounting treatment of a Long-term Incentive Scheme (the “LTIS”). Under the LTIS, the shareholders of the Group’s former ultimate holding company, Adria LuxCo S.à r.l., was required to make bonus payments to certain members of our management team following an initial public offering or sale of the Group. Under IFRS 2, we are required to account for the calculation of these bonus payments in our financial results even though the payments will not be made by any Group entity and will not affect the Group’s cash on hand. The non-cash impact of this accounting treatment was €32,809 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. (m) Other adjustments relate to revenue that was recognized upon signing a new contract with a supplier in March 2018 in our 2018 management accounts. (n) Represents gains realized on disposal of the Croatian DTH subsidiary. ----- (o) Represents the application of new accounting standard IFRS 9 for the period. (p) Represents gains realized on the acquisition of a subsidiary at below net asset value. (q) Represents a change of accounting policy in respect of rebinding costs. (r) For the year ended December 31, 2018, operating expenses comprise a large number of low value individual items, including other administrative expenses and fees, non-cash charges due to the sale of fixed assets and inventories below book value. (4) UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin represents UG Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue. (5) Represents UG Adjusted EBITDA less UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the periods presented. (6) Segment revenue excludes inter segment revenues. In addition to the external revenue generated by our five reporting segments, we had “other” external revenue of €20,572 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2018, €20,208 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2019, €24,759 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2020 and €8,603 thousand in the three months ended March 31, 2021. (7) Amounts shown in euro have been converted from Serbian dinars at a rate of RSD 118.2752 per €1.00 for the year ended December 31, 2018, which was the average rate during that period, converted from Serbian dinar at a rate of RSD 117.8595 per €1.00 for the year ended December 31, 2019, which was the average rate during that period, converted from Serbian dinar at a rate of RSD 117.5777 per €1.00 for the year ended December 31, 2020, which was the average rate during that period, converted from Serbian dinar at a rate of RSD 117.5782 per €1.00 for the three months ended March 31, 2020, which was the average rate during that period, and converted from Serbian dinar at a rate of RSD 117.5677 per €1.00 for the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was the average rate during that period. Amounts shown in euro have been converted from Bosnian marks at a rate equal to BAM 1.9558 per €1.00. The Bosnian mark is pegged to the euro. Amounts shown in euro have been converted from Croatian kune at a rate equal to HRK 7.5331 per €1.00 for the year ended December 31, 2020, which was the average rate during that period and at a rate of HRK 7.56724 per €1.00 for the three months ended March 31, 2021. Amounts shown in euro have been converted from Bulgarian lev at a rate equal to BGN 1.9558 per €1.00. The Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro.
