Section Title: SUMMARY OF COMPANY AND GROUP RUN-RATE, VIVACOM, UNAUDITED PRO FORMA AND CERTAIN OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: Blended mobile ARPU[(6)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5.8 6.4 6.9 Fixed-telephony ARPU[(7)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5.1 5.2 5.2 Fixed broadband ARPU[(8)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4.9 5.2 5.2 Fixed pay-TV ARPU[(9)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 7.8 8.5 8.9 (1) Homes passed represents all homes connected to fiber network, either FTTH or FTTB. (2) Mobile subscribers are reported based on the number of active mobile SIM cards. In line with the prevailing methodology in Bulgaria for calculating post-paid mobile subscribers, post-paid mobile subscribers are counted in the subscriber base as long as they have an active contract, have an active billing status (i.e., subscribers who regularly pay their bills) and have not been disconnected from the network, which includes machine to machine connections. Pre-paid mobile subscribers are counted in the ----- subscriber base in line with the prevailing methodology for doing so in the Bulgarian mobile telecommunications market, whereby pre-paid mobile subscribers are counted in the subscriber base if they have had an activity event (such as outgoing and incoming customer generated usage or recharge) within the last 90 days. (3) Fixed-telephony subscribers are counted in the subscriber base as long as they have an active billing status (i.e., subscribers who regularly pay their bills). Subscribers are counted in channels: PSTN = 1; ISDN BRA = 2; ISDN PRA; and R2D = 30 channels. (4) Fixed broadband subscribers are reported based on technical installations and the number of subscribers who have an active billing status (subscribers who regularly pay their bills). (5) Fixed Pay-TV subscribers are reported based on technical installations and the number of subscribers who have an active billing status (subscribers who regularly pay their bills). (6) Blended mobile ARPU is defined as the sum of the monthly mobile services revenue in the period, divided by the average number of mobile subscribers in the period, divided by the number of months in that period. The average number of mobile subscribers during a period is calculated by adding together the number of active mobile SIM cards at the beginning and end of each month during the period, dividing by two and then averaging the results from all months during the period. For purposes of calculating blended mobile ARPU, mobile services revenue consist of revenue generated from monthly subscription fees, usage fees for services that are incremental to the services allocated with the monthly subscription fees and mobile interconnect revenue (i.e., from fees paid to us by other operators for calls terminated on Vivacom’s mobile network, including roaming charges by Vivacom’s customers) as well as the expired balance revenue for pre-paid SIM cards, but does not include revenue such as revenue generated from mobile handset sales and revenue from roaming charges incurred by customers of other operators using Vivacom’s network. The blended mobile ARPU presented above in euro was converted from Bulgarian levs using the rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, which is the rate at which the Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro. (7) Fixed-telephony ARPU is defined as the sum of the monthly fixed-telephony revenue in the period, divided by the average number of fixed-telephony subscribers in the period, divided by the number of months in that period. The average number of fixedtelephony subscribers in a period is calculated by adding together the number of fixed-telephony subscribers at the beginning and end of each month during the period, dividing by two and then averaging the results from all months during the period. For purposes of calculating fixed-telephony ARPU, fixed-telephony revenue includes revenue generated from monthly subscription fees, usage fees for services that are incremental to the services allocated with monthly subscription fees and landline termination rates (i.e., fees paid by other operators for calls terminated on Vivacom’s landline network), but does not include revenue generated from wholesale voice. The fixed-telephony ARPU presented above in euro was converted from Bulgarian levs using the rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, which is the rate at which the Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro. (8) Fixed broadband ARPU is defined as the sum of the monthly fixed broadband revenue in the period, divided by the average number of fixed broadband subscribers in the period, divided by the number of months in that period. The average number of fixed broadband subscribers in a period is calculated by adding together the number of fixed broadband subscribers at the beginning and end of each month during the period, dividing by two and then averaging the results from all months during the period. For purposes of calculating fixed broadband ARPU, fixed broadband revenue includes revenue generated from monthly subscription fees but does not include dial up revenue, revenue from the sale of customer premises equipment, such as modems and initial set up charges and revenue generated from the provision of business data and connectivity solutions such as VPN and MAN services. The fixed broadband ARPU presented above in euro was converted from Bulgarian levs using the rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, which is the rate at which the Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro. (9) Fixed Pay-TV ARPU is defined as the sum of the monthly fixed Pay-TV revenue in the period (IPTV and DTH), divided by the average number of fixed Pay-TV subscribers (IPTV and DTH) in the period, divided by the number of months in that period. The average number of fixed Pay-TV subscribers in a period is calculated by adding together the number of fixed Pay-TV subscribers at the beginning and end of each month during the period, dividing by two and then averaging the results from all months during the period. For purposes of calculating fixed Pay-TV ARPU, fixed Pay-TV revenue includes revenue generated from monthly subscription fees and packages with additional content. The fixed Pay-TV ARPU presented above in euro was converted from Bulgarian levs using the rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, which is the rate at which the Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro. (10) As of the end of 2018, Vivacom changed its reporting methodology for fixed wireless broadband (Mobix) subscribers, which were reclassified and presented as mobile subscribers. The reclassification has impacted subscribers, RGU and ARPU. Previous periods have been restated in line with this new reporting methodology.

Section Title: SUMMARY OF COMPANY AND GROUP RUN-RATE, VIVACOM, UNAUDITED PRO FORMA AND CERTAIN OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: (a) Cable dismantling costs represent expenses attributable to removal of obsolete copper cables over Vivacom’s historical fixed-line network. (b) Exceptional professional and consultancy fees are mainly related to external services on negotiation of financing facilities, certain litigations and other one-off events over time. (c) Assessment acts represent expenses on tax assessments and other fines and penalties. (d) Termination cost on labor contract are attributable to compensations on terminated contracts of former employees. ----- (e) Net result of joint venture represents the effect of Vivacom’s share in Paytech OOD. On October 7, 2019, Vivacom sold its 50% share in Paytech OOD to Bulgarian American Credit Bank AD. (f) Withholding tax originated from tax gross-up on fees to foreign service providers and SFA loan lenders. (g) Provisions for legal proceedings represent provision for expenses on litigations where loss is probable. (h) Non-recurring payments to key management personnel and governing bodies relating to the acquisition of Vivacom, which was completed in July 2020. (6) Vivacom capital expenditure is comprised of additions to capitalized costs to fulfill a contract and obtaining a contract, intellectual property rights, construction in progress, intangible assets, right-of-use assets, and investment property. Capital expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2018, have been restated to be presented on a consistent basis with the calculation performed for the year ended December 31, 2019. -----

SUMMARY OF COMPANY AND GROUP RUN-RATE, VIVACOM, UNAUDITED PRO FORMA AND CERTAIN OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: (a) Vivacom financial information has been derived from Note 30 to the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. Financial information for the seven months ended July 31, 2020 is derived by taking the financial data for nine months ended September 30, 2020, and subtracting the financial information for the two months ended September 30, 2020 (which has not been reviewed or audited). The financial information is prepared in Bulgarian levs (BGN). (b) Amounts were converted using the BGN/EUR exchange rate of BGN 1.9558 to EUR 1.00, the pegged rate for the period. (c) The adjustments presented have been made to reclassify Vivacom line items to conform to the Company’s basis of preparation. Such adjustments have no effect on profit for the period reported. (d) The purpose of the adjustment is to illustrate the effects of: (i) eliminating the effect of transactions between Vivacom and Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD The Group acquired Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD (formerly, Viva Telecom Bulgaria OOD) in the Vivacom Acquisition. Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD is a holding company of the Vivacom Group but does not itself prepare consolidated financial information. The pro forma financial information of Vivacom included herein is based on the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and therefore certain adjustments are made to eliminate the effect of transactions between Vivacom and Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD. An adjustment was made to eliminate intercompany transactions, comprising an interest income amounting to €6,262 thousand and reversal of impairment cost amounting to €303 thousand and related tax effects. (ii) purchase price allocation The purchase price allocation was finalized as of December 31, 2020 and therefore the Company Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2020, include the fair value adjustments that have been made to acquired assets and liabilities (including any associated deferred tax effects), and differences between total consideration paid for the acquisition and the estimated fair values of the net assets of Vivacom were recorded as goodwill. The Company identified and measured significant identifiable assets such as: trade name, customer base—fixed services, customer base—mobile services, licenses, software and distribution network. The value of the items of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets increased significantly. As a result of the newly identified intangible assets and the significant increase to the value of the existing items of property, plant and equipment, additional amortization and depreciation charges were estimated and added as adjustments to the of Vivacom financial data for the seven months ended July 31, 2020. The amount of additional amortization and depreciation was estimated based on the value allocated to specific assets and the remaining useful life of ----- those assets. The adjustments for the additional amortization and depreciation charges are amounting to €44,382 thousand and related tax benefit amounting to €4,438 thousand. (e) The adjustments presented have been made to align Vivacom’s accounting policies with IFRS as adopted and applied by the Company under its currently applied accounting policies. Vivacom (i) capitalizes subscriber acquisition costs for contracts below one year and (ii) capitalizes portability costs, while such costs are expensed as incurred by the Company and (iii) for related tax effects of the foregoing. Section Title: SUMMARY OF COMPANY AND GROUP RUN-RATE, VIVACOM, UNAUDITED PRO FORMA AND CERTAIN OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: _We present below summary consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries (i) as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020, derived from the 2020 Company Audited Financial Statements, (ii) and as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, and the comparative information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, derived from the 2019 Company Audited Financial Statements, and (iii) unaudited consolidated financial data as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, derived from the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. We also present certain summary financial data for our Serbia Group, Slovenia Group, Bosnia Group, Montenegro Group and Media Group segments (i) for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, which have been derived from the Company Audited Financial Statements, and (ii) for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, which have been derived from the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. We also present certain summary financial data for our Croatia Group segment, our Bulgaria Group segment and our Greece Group segment for the year ended December 31, 2020, and for the three months ended March 31, 2021, which has been derived from the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and represents results of these segments for the periods after we acquired them. We also present unaudited summary consolidated income statement financial data and other financial data for the Company for the last two quarters ended March 31, 2021, which has been derived by subtracting the applicable unaudited financial data for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 (derived from note 39 in the 2020 Company Audited Financial Statements) from the financial data from the for the year ended December 31, 2020 (derived from the 2020 Company Audited Financial Statements) and adding the applicable unaudited financial data for the three months ended March 31, 2021 (derived from the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements). We also present unaudited summary financial data for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021 for certain segments of the Company, which have been derived by subtracting the financial data for the three months ended March 31, 2020 from the financial data for the year ended December 31, 2020 and adding the financial data for the three months ended March 31, 2021. We also present below certain run-rate financial data, which adjusts certain pro forma financial data derived from the other financial information of the Company with the results of Forthnet for the last two quarters ended March 31, 2021, derived from Forthnet’s unaudited management accounts for the month ended October 31, 2020, and the estimated results of Nova BG for the four months ended January 31, 2021, sourced from its unaudited management accounts of Nova BG for the four months ended January 31, 2021, the results of other recently committed or completed acquisitions (see Notes 21 and 36 of the Company’s Unaudited Interim Financial Statements) which have been derived from their management accounts and the results of Optima Telekom which have been derived from its management accounts. Where such run-rate information is labeled as “Annualized”, we have used data for the last two quarters ended March 31, 2021 and multiplied by two. We also present below summary consolidated financial data for BTC and its subsidiaries as of and for (i) the year ended December 31, 2020, derived from the 2020 Vivacom Audited Financial Statements, (ii) for the year ended December 31, 2019, and the comparative information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, derived from the 2019 Vivacom Audited Financial Statements, and (iii) condensed consolidated interim financial data for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, derived from the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. We also present certain summary financial data for Vivacom’s operating segments: fixed-line business, mobile line of business and NURTS business for (i) the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, which have been derived from the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements. We also present below summary unaudited pro forma income statement for the Group derived from of the Unaudited Pro Forma Income Statement and other financial data for the year ended December 31, 2020. The Unaudited Pro Forma Income Statement gives effect to the Vivacom Transactions as if they had occurred on January 1, 2020. For a detailed description of the basis of presentation with respect to the unaudited pro forma consolidated financial data for the Group, see “Presentation of Financial Data” and “Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information.” The summary unaudited pro forma financial data is based on available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable. The summary unaudited pro forma financial data is presented for illustrative purposes_ ----- _only and is not intended to represent or be indicative of the results of operations that we would have reported had the Vivacom Transactions actually occurred during the period presented, and the summary unaudited pro forma financial data does not purport to project our results of operations for any future period. The summary unaudited pro forma financial data has not been prepared in accordance with Article 11 of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act, the EU Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. For more information, please refer to “Presentation of Financial Data” and “Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information.” We also present certain other Non-IFRS Measures below, which are listed in “Presentation of Financial Data— Financial Data Included in This Offering Memorandum—Non-IFRS Financial and Operating Data.” These measures are presented in this offering memorandum because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used in the telecommunications industry as a means of evaluating a company’s operating performance and financing structure. These measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and are not measurements under IFRS or other generally accepted accounting principles, and you should not consider such items as alternatives to net income (loss), operating income or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS, and they may be different from similarly titled measures used by other companies. Our management believes this data, along with comparable IFRS measures, is useful to investors because it provides a basis for measuring the operating performance in the periods presented. These measures are used in the internal management of our business, along with the most directly comparable IFRS financial measures, in evaluating the operating performance. Non-IFRS measures have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our results or any performance measures under IFRS as set forth in the Company Audited Financial Statements, the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements, the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements or the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. For more information, see “Presentation of Financial Data.” Prospective investors should read the summary data presented below in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial Data,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “The Company’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Vivacom’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” the Company Audited Financial Statements, the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements, the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum._ -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The cable television, broadband internet, DTH and telephony markets in the regions in which we operate are highly competitive.
Subsubsection Text: We face significant competition in each of our product and service segments and may face competition from new entrants in the future. The nature and level of the competition we face varies for each of the products and services we offer and by region, but we generally compete on the basis of quality of content, network quality, marketing, product and service portfolio specifications, customer care, sales and marketing services as well as price. Our competitors include, but are not limited to, television providers, including providers using alternative and emerging digital technologies such as Internet Protocol Television (“IPTV”) and OTT content owners; DTH-TV providers; broadband internet and telephony services providers; public switched telephone network (“PSTN”) or fiber connections; and in Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia, other MNOs, including those using LTE technology. In addition, continued consolidation within the media industry may allow more competitors to offer bundles of digital television, fixed-line telephony, mobile-telephony and broadband services, and consolidation by competitors could allow them to benefit from economies of scale that we do not have. As a result, we may compete against companies with easier access to financing, more comprehensive product offerings, greater personnel resources, greater brand name recognition and experience or longer established relationships with regulatory authorities and customers, resulting in fewer regulatory burdens with which they are required to comply. Communications technologies and consumer electronics, as well as the way information, communication and entertainment is offered, are constantly changing, and the impact of such changes can be difficult to predict. Current and future competitors may expand their product and service offering more rapidly or adapt to new or emerging technologies more quickly than us (for example Telekom Srbija in Serbia and M:TEL in Montenegro have quickly upgraded their GPON platforms), or may offer their products and services at a lower price than ours, for example, where our services are priced at the high end of the market, which could cause us to lose subscribers, force us to lower our prices or otherwise adversely affect the margin of profit we are able to achieve from our services. In particular, we face the following risks in relation to each of our product offerings:

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Text: While competition among cable Pay-TV providers in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently low due to minimal cable overbuild, we face competition in the Serbian television market from other methods of television services distribution, such as DTH and IPTV. Our main competitor in Serbia is the state-owned incumbent Telekom Srbija. During 2018 and 2019, Telekom Srbija purchased several independent cable operators, offering Pay-TV, telephony and internet services, as well as the DTH users of Polaris Media, a Serbian DTH platform, strengthening Telekom Srbija’s presence in the Serbian market. Our main Pay-TV competitor in Bosnia and Herzegovina is the incumbent in the ethnic region in which we operate, BH Telecom. Competition in the Pay-TV market in Slovenia is strong, particularly for the provision of Fiber to the Home (“FttH”) services between Telekom Slovenije and T2, especially in metropolitan areas. Our main competitors in the Slovenian Pay-TV market are Telekom Slovenije, T2 and A1. Competition in Montenegro is strong, and the primary competitors are Crnogorski Telekom (IPTV and Fiber to the × (“FTTx”)) and M:TEL (FTTx and HFC). Both operators have a very large market share and a large number of users. Following the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition, we also compete with A1 Bulgaria and Bulsatcom for offering Pay-TV services in Bulgaria. Both of these competitors have larger market shares by number of subscribers than Vivacom, which may make it difficult for us to build our Pay-TV subscriber base. Additionally, we face increased competition from non-traditional television services based on new internet technologies, including OTT television services, which have increased in number and quality over the past few years. OTT television services deliver Pay-TV content “on top” of an existing broadband internet connection directly to a television, PC, laptop, tablet or mobile devices. OTT service providers leverage existing ----- infrastructures and are often not required to implement capital intensive models associated with traditional data providers like us. We cannot rule out that increased availability of OTT content as well as advances in broadband and mobile internet connection speeds will lead to increased competition from OTT providers in the future.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Text: Although we continue to hold stable market shares in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, we face strong competition in these markets from other broadband internet services, such as ADSL and VDSL broadband connections and FttH providers. Our main competitors for broadband internet services are Telekom Srbija in Serbia and BH Telecom and Telecom RS in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In Bulgaria, we also compete with A1 Bulgaria and Bulsatcom. Continued upgrades from DSL based broadband internet service to FttH, such as the optical network that has been constructed in Serbia by Telekom Srbija, and more widespread FttH installations could have a negative impact on our competitive position in the broadband internet market. Due to extensive overbuild and high levels of broadband internet penetration in Slovenia, we face significant competition in the broadband internet market segment from fiber broadband internet providers such as Telekom Slovenije, T2 and A1. In particular, we compete against Telekom Slovenije’s optical network services. Moreover, mobile operators are increasingly able to utilize a combination of powerful handsets and high bandwidth technologies such as 5G and LTE technologies. Additional competition may come from satellite technologies and operators that use microwave access (“WiMax”) technologies. In the Montenegrin broadband internet market, Crnogorski Telekom utilizes FTTx, ADSL and VDSL broadband, and M:TEL currently utilizes HFC, which will soon replace FTTx on its network.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Text: In the liberalized Serbian and Bosnian telephony markets, we compete with the respective state-owned former monopolies, Telekom Srbija in Serbia and BH Telecom and Telecom RS in Bosnia, which dominate the fixedline PSTN telephone market. We believe that the Slovenian telephony market is relatively mature and market share changes are mainly driven by the combination of the price and quality of the services provided by bundled offerings. Our main competitors in Slovenia are Telekom Slovenije, T2, and A1, and our main competitors in Montenegro are the incumbent operator, Crnogorski Telekom, and M: Tel. In addition, in Bulgaria, we compete in the fixed-line telephony market predominantly with A1 Bulgaria, which, in addition to Vivacom, is the only other fully converged telecommunications operator in Bulgaria. Further, we operate in an industry that is affected by fixed-line to mobile-telephony substitution, and as a result there may be decreased demand for our fixed-line telephony services. We may be affected in each of the markets in which we operate by providers of free Voice over Internet Protocol (“VoIP”) services such as Apple’s FaceTime service or WhatsApp which have considerably improved their speech quality over the last few years and can be accessed from any device connected to the internet, including smartphones.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Text: Following our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015, we began providing mobile-telephony services in Slovenia as an MNO, and following completion of the Vivacom Acquisition and Tele2 Croatia Acquisition, we began providing mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria and Croatia, respectively, as an MNO. Accordingly, we face strong competition for subscribers from established competitors, including, in particular, Telekom Slovenije and A1 Telekom Austria in Slovenia, A1 Bulgaria and Telenor in Bulgaria and Croatian Telecom, A1 Croatia and T Mobile Croatia, as well as other mobile telecommunications that may enter the Slovenian, Bulgarian or Croatian mobile markets (such as Hofer Telekom, which recently entered the Slovenian mobile market). Certain competitors have undertaken or announced intentions to undertake acquisitions in the mobile telecommunications markets in which we operate. PPF Group, a private investment group in Europe, completed its acquisition of the telecommunications assets of Telenor Group in Serbia, Montenegro, Hungary and Bulgaria in July 2018. Any other planned acquisitions by competitors, if consummated, could negatively impact our business, such as by reducing our market share or forcing us to undertake more capital expenditure or to lower prices. To the extent we were to lose market share to any competitors, our revenues may decline. If we fail to increase our market share in line with our expectations, we will be less profitable, which will adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In Bulgaria, the mobile market has stabilized as the three main market participants are of roughly equal size and have all shifted to a value for money strategy, which may hinder our ability to differentiate ourselves and our ability to grow our market share. Additionally, ----- in each of the markets in which we compete, our competitors may improve their ability to attract new subscribers, or provide their offerings or services at lower prices to increase their respective market shares, which would make it more difficult for us to retain our current subscribers or expand our subscriber base without us lowering our prices or increasing our subscriber retention cost. In order to compete, we may have to lower prices, which may reduce our margins and/or increase our marketing and promotional expenses, each of which may cause our operating profit to decline significantly.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Text: Customers of video and telecommunications services are increasingly expecting service providers to offer high-quality bundles of television, broadband internet and telephony services. Many of our competitors, including Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija in Serbia, Telecom RS, HT Eronet and BH Telecom in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Crnogorski Telekom and M:TEL in Montenegro, offer bundled packages of services. Several of these bundles include mobile phone services, which we offer in Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia. If our bundled products are not able to compete effectively in the markets in which we operate, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Text: In July 2020, we launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which is currently available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and Slovenia. Shoppster’s key competitors include, among others, e-commerce platforms such as E Kupi in Serbia and Mimovrste, EnaA, Big Bang, Merkur and Piazz in Slovenia, as well as traditional retail stores such as Gigatron and Tehnomanija in Serbia. Increased competition, or any inability to provide cable and DTH Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services at competitive prices, may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Difficult economic conditions may reduce subscriber spending for our pay television, broadband internet, and fixed-line and mobile-telephony services and reduce our rate of growth of subscriber additions.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to grow or maintain our business may be adversely affected by weakening global or domestic economic conditions, wavering consumer confidence and unemployment, including as a result of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the social distancing measures and other restrictions imposed in response by the governments of each of the countries in which we operate. See “—Any outbreak of severe communicable _diseases, including COVID-19, may materially affect our business and results of operations.” In addition, our_ ability to grow or maintain our business may be adversely affected by the impact of state implemented austerity measures. For example, in 2014, the Serbian government implemented austerity measures, including increased rates of taxation and a reduction in public sector wages, which if continued or adopted in our other markets, could continue to have an impact on our customers’disposable income in Serbia or our other markets. As customers may view spending for most of our services, such as Pay-TV, as discretionary, the risks associated with certain segments of our business become more acute in periods of a slowing economy or recession as consumers may delay purchasing decisions or reduce or reallocate their discretionary funds. Current customers may elect to downgrade their packages or move to less costly providers, and new customers may opt to take out our lower end broadband and Pay-TV packages rather than more expensive ones or may opt to become customers of less costly competitors, or not to subscribe to Pay-TV services at all. We are also exposed to risks associated with the potential financial instability of our customers, many of whom may be adversely affected by a general economic downturn. This may lead to a higher number of non-paying subscribers. Suppliers and distributors may also be more cautious in supplying goods to us and may request additional credit enhancements or more restrictive payment terms. While the impact of an economic slowdown on our business is difficult to predict, it could have a material adverse effect on our revenues and our cash flow.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our operating results will be adversely affected if we cannot generate strong advertising sales.
Subsubsection Text: We generate revenue from the sale of advertising on or in our television stations and broadcast and cable networks. Expenditures by advertisers tend to be cyclical, reflecting overall economic conditions, as well as budgeting and buying patterns. A decline in the economic prospects of advertisers or the economy in general, including as a result of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the relevant responses taken by the governments of the countries in which we operate, could alter current or prospective advertisers’ spending priorities as well ----- as advertising pricing. See “—Any outbreak of severe communicable diseases, including COVID-19, may _materially affect our business and results of operations.” For the three months ended March 31, 2021, our_ advertising sales increased by 182% as compared to the same period in 2020 mainly as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic’s impact in the same period in 2020. Demand for our products is also a factor in determining advertising rates. For example, ratings points for our television stations and broadcast and cable networks are factors that are weighed when determining advertising rates, and with respect to our television stations and broadcast and television networks, when determining the affiliate rates received by us. In addition, newer technologies, including new video formats, streaming and downloading capabilities via the internet, video on demand, personal video recorders and other devices and technologies are increasing the number of media and entertainment choices available to audiences. Some of these devices and technologies allow users to view television or films from a remote location or on a time delayed basis and provide users the ability to fast forward, rewind, pause and skip programming and advertisements. These technological developments could affect the attractiveness of our offerings to viewers, advertisers and/or distributors. Failure to effectively anticipate or adapt to emerging technologies or changes in consumer behavior could have an adverse effect on our business. Furthermore, a decrease in advertising expenditures, reduced demand for our offerings or the inability to obtain market ratings that adequately measure demand for our content on personal video recorders and mobile devices could lead to a reduction in pricing and advertising revenue, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have made and may make acquisitions or enter into transactions that may present unforeseen risks, and we may not realize the financial and strategic goals that were contemplated at the time of any transaction and, additionally, there are risks associated with the integration of any acquisitions.
Subsubsection Text: As part of our business strategy, we pursue strategic and opportunistic acquisitions of service providers, content providers and cable assets. Any of these transactions could be material to our financial condition or results of operations. Despite our successful track record, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to continue making such acquisitions and our ability to acquire new businesses may be limited by many factors, including availability of financing, debt covenants, complex ownership structures among potential targets and government regulation and competition from other potential acquirers. In addition, our debt burden may increase if we borrow funds to finance any future acquisition, which could have a negative impact on our cash flows and our ability to finance our overall operations and make cash interest payments on the New Notes. Even if we are successful in acquiring new businesses, the integration of such businesses, including the integration of Vivacom, may prove to be more difficult than we initially anticipated and could create unforeseen operating difficulties and expenditures. Acquisitions pose certain risks, for example, difficulties or delays in consolidating operations and achieving anticipated synergies, cost savings, revenues and cash flow enhancements, growth, operational efficiencies and other benefits; diversion of managerial resources away from our day-to-day business operations; potentially dilutive issuances of equity securities to the extent that we issue new shares to fund an acquisition; and the assumption of unexpected liabilities and undisclosed risks. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we expect to realize certain operational efficiency and cost saving measures. We may not be able to realize these measures, either in the amount or within the timeframe that we currently anticipate, and the costs of achieving these measures may be higher than what we expect. Our ability to realize such operational efficiency and cost savings measures may be affected by a number of factors, including increases in expenses related to the Vivacom Acquisition. In addition, the Vivacom Acquisition has required, and will likely continue to require, substantial time and focus from management, which could adversely affect their ability to operate our business. These factors may offset the expected cost savings from the Vivacom Acquisition. In addition, the Vivacom Acquisition will result in a significant proportion of our operations, assets and revenues deriving from Bulgaria. Bulgaria borders Serbia and North Macedonia, but it has a different language, culture and history compared to the jurisdictions in which we currently operate. We may encounter unexpected difficulties that could impact the successful integration of Vivacom in ways that could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Vivacom and/or its subsidiaries may have liabilities that we failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing due diligence investigations in connection with the Vivacom Acquisition. In addition, the extent of liabilities we discovered in connection after the Vivacom Acquisition may be greater than we expected. There may be unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws and regulations. For example, we could become liable for overdue payables of Vivacom and/or its subsidiaries to suppliers and employees that are not currently known to us, or we could become subject to tax or pension liabilities in respect of historical periods that we are not currently aware of or the amount of ----- which we underestimated, or we could become liable in relation to past or pending disputes involving Vivacom and/or its subsidiaries that are not currently known to us, or we could suffer losses relating to issues in title or required permits for the real estate property owned and/or used by Vivacom and/or its subsidiaries that are not currently known to us. In conducting our due diligence, we were required to rely on resources available to us, including public information, information provided by the seller and third-party consultants and advisers. There can be no assurance that the due diligence we undertook has revealed or highlighted all relevant facts necessary or helpful in evaluating the Vivacom Acquisition. Any such unknown or previously underestimated liabilities, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations and our ability to fulfill our obligations under the New Notes. The Forthnet Acquisition and the integration of Forthnet also involves certain significant risks, in particular since Forthnet, as a MVNO that in general relies on other providers’ networks, is subject to significant regulatory and competitive risks that could impact the results of operations and financial condition of Forthnet and, therefore, our Group. Similarly, the Optima Telekom Acquisition and the integration of Optima Telekom involves certain significant risks. In particular, completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition is subject to various conditions, including the implementation of certain changes in the current Croatian telecommunication legislation relating to vertical integration between pay-TV broadcasters and distributors. There can be no assurance that these legislative changes will be implemented by the Croatian and therefore we may not be able to complete the Optima Telekom Acquisition by the end of 2021 as currently expected or at all. Furthermore, certain contracts of the businesses acquired by us contain “change of control” provisions that require the acquired company to notify the counterparty of a potential change of control, or contain language that could be interpreted as allowing, subject to certain conditions, the counterparty to terminate the contract following a change of control. In particular, the Vivacom Acquisition constitutes a change of control under certain agreements entered into by Vivacom and its subsidiaries, such as commercial agreements with some of its suppliers, and entitles these third parties to terminate their agreements with Vivacom or, in some cases, request adjustments of the terms of the agreements. Nova BG and Optima Telekom are also party to certain agreements with international television content providers which contain change of control clauses. The Optima Telekom Acquisition may also constitute a change of control under certain agreements. Although the agreements governing certain of our acquisitions require the target to use commercially reasonable endeavors to obtain consents or waivers relating to such “change of control” provisions prior to closing of the acquisitions, such consents and waivers are generally not a condition to closing. If a substantial number of these contracts have been, are or will be terminated as a result of our acquisition, we may be forced to enter into new contracts on less favorable terms, or we may be unable to secure replacements. While we strive to mitigate unexpected liabilities and risks though contractual protections in our acquisition documentation, we cannot ensure that such protections will be effective. For example, although the share sale and purchase agreement pursuant to which we acquired Tušmobil contains warranties related to, among other things, compliance with laws, licenses and consents and financial crime, and provides, subject to certain qualifications and limitations, for indemnification from the seller in the event of breach of warranties, we cannot guarantee that we will be successful in any claims that we may bring for breach of warranties based on the agreement or that any recovery made under this agreement would cover the potential losses arising out of any such breach. If we enter into an acquisition agreement, but the acquisition is not consummated, we may be liable for break-up fees or other payments, which may, in some cases, be material. The agreement with respect to the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition does not provide us an indemnity in the event of potential remedies related to any ongoing litigation and investigations resulting from the completion of such acquisition. In connection with the Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, Ascanius Netherlands B.V. has given certain indemnities and customary representations and warranties. In connection with the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition, CME B.V. has given certain customary representations and warranties related to Nova TV Croatia. The Vivacom Acquisition Agreement, the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition Agreement and the agreements for the Forthnet Acquisition, the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition and the Optima Telekom Acquisition also contain certain indemnities and customary representations and warranties. There can be no assurance that we will be able to enforce any claims relating to breaches of such representations and warranties, and CME B.V.’s liability, in respect of the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition, the Vivacom Seller’s liability, with respect to the Vivacom Acquisition, and Tele2 Sverige AB’s liability, with respect to the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition, and the respective sellers for the Forthnet Acquisition, the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition and the Optima Telekom Acquisition, with respect to breaches of their representations and warranties, is limited. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any acquisition we undertake or have undertaken may be subject to regulatory approval or review by competition authorities which could delay, limit or prevent its completion or could prevent us from realizing the benefits from any such acquisition following its completion.
Subsubsection Text: Acquisitions we undertake may require the approval of governmental authorities (at both national and European levels), which can block, impose conditions on, or delay the process which could result in a failure on our part to proceed with announced transactions on a timely basis or at all. Past acquisitions by the Group, including recent acquisitions, are or may become subject to review by competition authorities within the relevant jurisdictions. Such competition authorities may take the position that merger control filings were required, and should we fail to meet such requests or requirements in a timely manner, the relevant governmental authority may impose fines and, if in connection with a merger transaction, may require corrective measures, such as mandatory disposition of assets or divestiture of operations. For example, in the past, relevant competition authorities in Serbia and Slovenia have challenged a number of our acquisitions, in some cases resulting in a requirement of divestiture or the levying of fines, which can be substantial. See “Our Business—Legal Proceedings.” The completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition is subject to a condition relating to the implementation of certain changes in current Croatian telecommunication legislation. We also may be subject to challenges brought by certain of our competitors. For example, on April 29, 2021, Vivacom acquired local broadband and television operators Net 1 EOOD, ComNet Sofia EAD and Digital Cable Television EOOD. These transactions were approved by the Bulgarian Commission on Protection of Competition (“CPC”). On April 29, 2021, however, Telenor Bulgaria challenged the CPC’s approval relating to these transactions before the Administrative Court—Sofia District. Vivacom has intervened in support of the CPC’s decision. If the Administrative Court—Sofia District annuls the CPC’s approvals, and the annulment is upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court, the CPC will re-examine the transactions (which have already been completed). Any risks associated with acquisitions or future acquisitions could have a significant negative impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Acceptance of our content, particularly our television programming, by the public is difficult to predict, which could lead to fluctuations in revenues.
Subsubsection Text: Television production and distribution are uncertain businesses since the revenues derived from the production and distribution of a television series depend primarily upon its acceptance by the public, which is difficult to predict. The commercial success of a television program also depends upon the quality and acceptance of other competing television programming released into the marketplace at or near the same time, the availability of a growing number of alternative forms of entertainment and leisure time activities, general economic conditions and their effects on consumer spending and other tangible and intangible factors, all of which can change and cannot be predicted with certainty. Audience ratings for a television program are generally a key factor in generating revenues from other distribution channels, such as content licensing. Given the production costs that are incurred prior to airing a new television program, the profitability of television production and the recovery of upfront costs depend on the program’s popularity upon and following the initial airing. A decline in the ratings or popularity of our entertainment, sports or news television programming, which could be a result of the loss of talent or rights to certain programming, could adversely affect advertising revenues in the near term and, over a longer period of time, adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We do not have guaranteed access to all of our television content and are dependent on our agreements, relationships and cooperation with content owners, including broadcasters and collective rights associations.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our business depends on, among other things, the quality and variety of the television content delivered to our customers. We depend on our agreements, relationships and cooperation with third parties for the majority of our content. We receive content for our cable and DTH Pay-TV services pursuant to licenses with content owners, including high-quality regional and international television networks such as FOX, ViaSat and Universal channels. Additionally, we produce our own content through our in-house content company. While we intend to negotiate additional access to continue to expand our Pay-TV product range, rights to premium or high definition (“HD”) content may in the future be obtained by our competitors on an exclusive basis and therefore not be available to us. Additionally, we may be unable to secure content on an exclusive ----- basis and may have to share broadcasting rights with our competitors, which could lead to a dilution of our brand name. Furthermore, our competitors may be able to secure content which is more popular than ours, and changes in our subscribers’content preferences could result in a decrease of the popularity of our content and an increase in the popularity of that of our competitors. While we have successfully developed our video on demand and other interactive services as well as our own television content in the past, our ability to source content will be increasingly important and will depend on our ability to maintain relationships and cooperation with content owners and broadcasters for both standard and HD content as well as our ability to accurately predict our customers’ content preferences. Furthermore, our NetTV Plus OTT content platform, which distributes local ethnic content to former Yugoslav expats around the world, relies on the availability of a number of local free-to-air channels and no fee contracts for the distribution of such content. In the past, we have faced difficulties obtaining such local content free of charge or negotiating contracts with local TV channel providers on satisfactory terms, which difficulties have in the past led to the removal of some of these channels. Additionally, from time to time, we face disputes over the rights to certain of the OTT content that we show. If we fail to produce, obtain or retain on satisfactory terms sufficient popular and quality programming for our digital cable and DTH services, or local content for our OTT content platform; if the content we provide is only popular for a short period of time; if our competitors secure content that is more popular than ours; or if the popularity of our content declines, our ability to attract customers from competitors to our services, retain current customers, compete effectively with free TV channel providers or recoup our content production costs may be limited, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, as we depend upon such content owners for the provision of content to attract and retain customers, content owners may have considerable power to renegotiate the license fees we pay them. Most license agreements are renewed on a regular basis, typically every three years. We may be unable to renew such contracts on terms that are similar to those of the current agreements, which could result in an increase in our content costs or, if we are unable to agree on the terms of service, the cancellation of such license contracts. The loss of certain content could, in turn, affect our customer base. Difficulties encountered with content suppliers may result in disruptions in our operations, loss of profitability and damage to our reputation, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any failure to keep pace with technological changes and evolving industry standards could harm our competitive position and, in turn, have a material adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: The broadband internet, television and fixed-line and mobile-telephony services sectors are characterized by rapid and significant changes in technology. We will need to anticipate and react to these changes and develop successful new and enhanced products and services quickly enough to adapt to the changing market. This could result in the need to make substantial investments in new or enhanced technologies, products or services, and we may not be able to adopt such technology due to insufficient capital or for other reasons, such as incompatibilities with our systems. In addition, new technologies, such as 5G or 3D TV, will or may become dominant in the future, rendering our current technologies and systems obsolete. In particular, we expect certain communications technologies that are currently under development or have recently been introduced, namely 5G in the future and 4G LTE currently, which allow for faster data transmission and lower unit cost per gigabyte transferred traffic compared to 3G, to become increasingly important in our market. We currently hold a 4G license in Slovenia and in April 2021 acquired licenses for 5G spectrum frequencies in Slovenia. Vivacom holds a 4G license in Bulgaria and in May 2021, secured a license for 5G spectrum frequencies in Bulgaria after announcing the commercial launch of its 5G network in September 2020. Telemach Croatia holds a 4G license in Croatia and is participating in an auction for 5G spectrum frequencies in Croatia. However, if we are unable to effectively compete in the 4G market or keep pace with technological developments (particularly the development of our 5G network at a pace comparable to that of our competitors and acquire new frequencies) and invest significantly in 5G technologies, or if we are not successful in the Croatian auction for 5G spectrum frequencies, including the auction in respect of the Croatian mobile market, we could lose subscribers or fail to attract new subscribers, which would impact subscriber churn, or incur substantial costs and investments in order to maintain our subscriber base, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The availability of any new features developed for use in our industry can have a significant impact on a subscriber’s initial decision to choose our or a competitor’s products. We may not be able to develop or partner with third-party suppliers to gain access to technical advances before our competitors, match technological innovations by our competitors or design systems that meet subscribers’requirements. Our ability to effectively anticipate and adapt successfully to changes in technology in our industry and provide new or enhanced ----- services in a timely and cost-effective manner, or successfully anticipate the demands of our subscribers, will determine whether we will be able to increase or maintain our subscriber and revenue base. As a result, new or enhanced technologies, services or offerings we introduce may fail to achieve sufficient market acceptance or experience technical difficulties. For example, we do not expect that previously installed internet modems or set-top boxes will be able to support all of the enhancements we may introduce to our broadband internet and television services over time. If we fail to respond adequately to technological changes, we could lose subscribers and experience a decrease in revenues and, as a result, our business, financial condition and results of operations would be materially and adversely affected. Additionally, the cost of implementing emerging and new technologies could be significant and we may fail to obtain the necessary financing. If we are unable to obtain such financing at attractive terms or at all, we might not be able to make the necessary technological changes or upgrades and our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially and adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to significant government regulation and supervision, as a result of which we may be affected by unforeseen changes in regulation and government policy which may increase our costs and otherwise adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to significant governmental regulation and supervision. See “Our Business—Regulatory _Framework.”_ Changes in laws, regulations or governmental policy affecting our activities and those of our competitors could significantly influence how we operate our business, our ability to offer certain products and services and our ability to introduce new products and services. In particular, regulatory changes relating to our activities and those of our competitors, such as changes relating to third-party access to cable networks, the costs of interconnection with other networks or the prices of competing products and services, or any change in policy allowing more favorable conditions for other operators, could adversely affect our ability to set prices, enter new markets or control our costs. In Serbia, we are the subject of various pending regulatory actions, including from the Serbian Tax Authority and RATEL. See “Our Business—Legal Proceedings.” In addition, any change in existing laws, regulations or governmental policies and/or the implementation of any new law, regulation, including sanction regimes, or governmental policy, both at a national or international level, on certain communication technologies that are currently under development or have recently been introduced, namely 5G, in the countries in which we operate, may result in increased costs and logistical complexity for us. For example, the U.S., the UK, Sweden, Poland and Romania have banned technology from Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company, from being used in the development of their 5G networks, which in the UK is expected to delay the development of its 5G network and has compelled UK telecommunications companies to seek alternative suppliers. We have entered into a global frame agreement with Huawei in respect of mobile radio network equipment. For more information, see “Our Business— _Network—Mobile—Mobile Network Evolution—Mobile Radio Network Equipment Agreement.” If a similar_ ban is imposed in Slovenia, Bulgaria Croatia or Greece, or if otherwise obtaining or using Huawei technology is restricted by the governments of the countries in which we operate, this may result in us having to find alternative suppliers for 5G network equipment, which may increase costs for us to develop and maintain our networks and which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our ability to introduce new products and services may also be affected if we cannot predict how existing or future laws, regulations or policies would apply to such products or services. In addition, our business and the industry in which we operate are subject to investigation by regulators, which could lead to enforcement actions, fines and penalties or the assertion of private litigation claims and damages. Any such action could harm our reputation and result in increased costs to the business.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to currency exchange fluctuation and currency instability risks in Europe that could have an adverse impact on our liquidity, financial condition and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: The reporting currency of our business is the euro. While Slovenia and Montenegro use the euro as the official currency, and while the value of the Bosnian mark and Bulgarian lev are pegged to the euro, we collect subscriber fees in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, North Macedonia and Bulgaria in local currencies. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, the three months ended March 31, 2020 and the year ended December 31, 2020, we generated 28%, 48% and 42% of our revenues in Serbian dinar and Croatian kuna. At the same time, the vast majority of our costs to operate our business as well as our capital expenditure are paid in euros. The Serbian dinar has fluctuated in the past (including through inflation), and may fluctuate ----- in the future, resulting in significant and unpredictable foreign exchange losses and gains. Additionally, although the Croatian Kuna has been relatively stable in the past, given our increased exposure following the consummation of the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition, any fluctuations could affect our results of operations, as with the fluctuations of the Serbian Dinar in the past. If the euro appreciated in value against the Serbian dinar, the Bulgarian lev, the Croatian kuna (which will be replaced by the euro on January 1, 2023) or other local currencies, and we are unable to pass through increased costs to our customers or if we are unable to exchange the various local currencies into euros at all, our revenue would decrease which would make it more difficult to generate the cash necessary to continue our operations without disruptions, cover our costs and meet our capital expenditure requirements. Additionally, economic events in recent years affecting European economies have raised a number of questions regarding the stability and overall standing of the European Monetary Union. Credit risk in these countries and in other Eurozone countries, especially in Slovenia, could have a negative impact on our business. Concerns also remain regarding the overall stability and suitability of the euro as a single currency given the diverse economic and political circumstances in individual states which use the euro. The departure or risk of departure from the euro by one or more Eurozone countries or the abandonment of the euro as a currency, or the reintroduction of an individual currency in Slovenia, as well as the de pegging of the Bosnian mark or the Bulgarian lev from the euro, could have major negative effects on our existing contractual relations with our customers, and could adversely affect the economy in Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bulgaria, respectively. In particular, the departure of Slovenia from the euro would increase our exposure to changes in currency rates. Any of these developments could affect our ability to refinance our liabilities and have a significant negative impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any outbreak of severe communicable diseases, including COVID-19, may materially affect our business and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Significant outbreaks of contagious diseases, including the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic or other illnesses, may result in a widespread health crisis that could adversely affect the economies and financial markets of many countries, leading to substantial declines in consumer purchasing power and resulting in an economic downturn that could affect demand for our products and services, our ability to collect against existing trade receivables and our operating results. In particular, in response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, during 2020 and the first half of 2021, governments of the countries in which we conduct our operations implemented several measures, including travel restrictions, lockdowns, quarantines and other social distancing measures, which have had a material adverse impact on the overall economies of such countries and, as a result, could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations, in particular, our revenues generated from advertising, media selling, mobile handsets sales and our mobile international roaming revenues as well as on our ARPUs. For example, from March 2020 until May 2020 and again in October 2020, the Netherlands adopted several social distancing and other restrictive measures, particularly with respect to access to restaurants, shopping centers and other commercial facilities, aimed at mitigating the negative consequences of the pandemic. In compliance with these restrictive measures, during the governmentimposed lockdowns we closed substantially all of our facilities in all of our countries of operation, while maintaining a limited number of employees in business critical functions on-site to operate our data centers and transitioned all of our remaining employees to remote working. As the governments of the countries in which we operate attempt to implement economic recovery measures while managing a resurgence in new infections, significant restrictions and social distancing measures remain in place or may be re imposed, which continue to adversely affect the economies of the countries in which we operate and, in turn, our operations. If a significant portion of our workforce is unable to work effectively due to prolonged illness, quarantines, shelter in place arrangements, government actions, facility closures or other reasons in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, our operations could be materially impacted. We may be unable to perform fully on our contracts and carry out new sales activity, and some of our costs may not be fully recoverable or adequately covered by insurance. In addition, as a result of social distancing measures and restrictions imposed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, our customers may not be able to operate their businesses for a prolonged and indeterminate period of time, which, if realized, will likely impact our operations. Moreover, it is possible that the continued spread of COVID-19, further waves of infection, or a renewed or extended lockdown in one or more of the countries in which we operate, if realized, will cause further disruption in our business operations, cause delay, or limit the ability of, our customers to perform under their existing contracts, including making timely payments to us, and cause other unpredictable events. Customers may experience significant losses due to the COVID-19 outbreak and may terminate their existing contracts or postpone or ultimately cancel future planned orders and contracts due to those losses. Both domestic and international travel may be further ----- restricted to certain areas which may limit our ability to obtain new customers and enter new markets, to provide services in the areas in which our customers are currently located or otherwise conduct our operations as we have done in the past. To the extent our activities are disrupted by restrictions imposed by governments or other authorities to address the risk of transmission of COVID-19, or by changes in customer behavior, this may result in a loss of customers, and our future rate of growth may slow compared to our past growth rates. The general economic impact of COVID-19 restrictions on the communities that we serve may result in customers not being able to continue to pay for our services or deciding to postpone, cancel or reduce their existing subscriptions. This could result in an increase in bad debts and cancellations, as well as a reduction or delay in revenue collection, which could negatively impact our liquidity, cash flow, profitability and attrition rate. In addition, social distancing measures resulting in the cancellation or postponement of certain sporting events have had and may continue to have an adverse impact on the results of our Media Group segment. In particular, as a result of such measures revenues generated from our Media Group segment, excluding the impact of revenues generated by NOVA BG, decreased by 11% in the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to the same period in 2020, due to the strategic decision to provide exclusive sport and other content to United Group companies which led to the non-prolongation of carriage deals with certain pay-TV providers in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The disruptions triggered by COVID-19 in countries where our suppliers and customers are located, may result in a slowdown of their production activities and other disruptions, any of which could have a material impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, in some of the jurisdictions in which we operate we have received certain state supported aid which we may be obliged to return if certain conditions are met, potentially together with interest in arrears from the day of the receipt of the relevant aid. In addition, political repercussions of responses to the COVID-19 outbreak by European Union institutions as well as by other countries in the European Union could have complex and hard to predict consequences for the future, including a destabilization of the European Union or its institutions or a slow down or reversal of European integration. It is unclear whether measures taken by European Union institutions, the governments of the countries in which we operate to contain the COVID-19 outbreak are adequate and will be effective in achieving their goals. It is unclear when, if at all, the COVID-19 outbreak will be contained. We cannot guarantee that COVID-19 or any future outbreak of another virus or other contagious disease will not have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations. The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic negatively affects our business, results of operations and financial condition depends on several factors, such as the duration and severity of the COVID-19 pandemic, any additional periods of lockdown in the countries in which our customers are located, and the pace at which demand, pricing and, in general, economic and operating conditions will stabilize and recover in the countries where we operate. Any future developments are highly uncertain and cannot be predicted, including the scope and duration of the pandemic and actions taken by governmental authorities and other third parties in response to the pandemic. To the extent the COVID-19 pandemic adversely affects our business, results of operation, financial condition and prospects, as well as our ability to perform our obligations under the New Notes, it may also have the effect of heightening many of the other risks described in this “Risk Factors” section.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Legal, political and economic uncertainty in the Eurozone, including the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union and the European sovereign debt crisis, may adversely impact current trading arrangements, be a source of instability in international markets and create significant currency fluctuations, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: The United Kingdom (“UK”) held a referendum on June 23, 2016, to determine whether the UK should leave the EU or remain as a Member State, and the outcome of that referendum was in favor of leaving the EU. While the EU and the UK agreed a comprehensive, zero- tariff, zero-quota free trade agreement on December 24, 2020, which was ratified by the UK parliament on December 30, 2020 and came into force on January 1, 2021, the end of the transition period has led to increased customs, health and safety checks at the border, which could delay or disrupt the movement of goods between the EU and the UK, undermine bilateral cooperation in key policy areas, significantly disrupt trade between the UK and the EU and cause political and economic instability in other countries of the EU. Additionally, the UK has ceased to be a member of the EU single market, which has ended the free movement of services and workers between the UK and the EU and may make it more difficult for our UK operations to do business with customers or suppliers that are based in the EU. The impact of the UK-EU trade agreement and the resulting effects on the political and economic future of the UK remain uncertain. Economic instability and uncertainty in Europe, has and may continue to adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. ----- Due to the size and importance of the UK economy, the uncertainty and unpredictability concerning the UK’s legal, political and economic relationship with Europe may continue to be a source of instability in the international markets, create significant currency fluctuations, and/or otherwise adversely affect trading agreements or similar cross border cooperation arrangements (whether economic, tax, fiscal, legal, regulatory or otherwise) for the foreseeable future. It is also possible that the exit of the UK from the EU will lead other EU Member States to consider leaving the EU, which could be an additional source of instability in the international markets. Further, other EU Member States within the Eurozone could decide to discontinue their use of the euro as their functional currency. The exit of the UK (or the possible exit of any other country) from the EU, the potential withdrawal of Scotland from the UK, or prolonged periods of uncertainty relating to any of these possibilities, could result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, further decreases in global stock exchange indices, increased foreign exchange volatility (in particular a further weakening of the pound sterling and euro against other leading currencies), and decreased GDP in the EU or other markets in which we operate. In addition, there are increasing concerns that these events could push the UK or Eurozone into an economic recession and/or worsen the economic recession caused by the global COVID-19 pandemic, any of which, were they to occur, would further destabilize the global financial markets. Our operations are also subject to risks from high levels of sovereign debt in certain European countries, which combined with weak economic growth and high unemployment, could lead to fiscal reforms (including austerity measures), sovereign debt restructurings, higher levels of volatility and potential disruptions in the credit and equity markets, in particular as a result of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. With regard to currency instability issues, concerns exist in the Eurozone with respect to individual macro fundamentals on a country by country basis, as well as with respect to the overall stability of the European Monetary Union and the suitability of a single currency to appropriately deal with specific fiscal management and sovereign debt issues in individual Eurozone countries. The realization of these concerns could lead to the exit of one or more countries from the European Monetary Union and the re-introduction of individual currencies in these countries or, in more extreme circumstances, the possible dissolution of the European Monetary Union entirely. The capital market disruption that would likely accompany any such event could have a material adverse impact on our liquidity and financial condition. Furthermore, any redenomination event would likely be accompanied by significant economic dislocation, particularly within the Eurozone countries, which in turn could have an adverse impact on demand for our products, and accordingly, on our revenue and cash flows. As we generate revenue in a number of different currencies, including the euro, Serbian dinar, Bosnian mark, Bulgarian lev and Croatian kuna, increased currency fluctuation could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations. See “—We are exposed to currency exchange fluctuation and currency instability _risks in Europe that could have an adverse impact on our liquidity, financial condition and cash flows.”_ For these reasons, legal, political and economic uncertainty in the Eurozone could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
