See “Description of the New Notes—Certain Definitions—Specified Change of Control Event.” In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the New Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third-party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the relevant Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third-party will have the right to redeem the New Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to other holders of Notes. See “Description of the _New Notes—Optional Redemption.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the New Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The term “all or substantially all” in the context of a change of control has no clearly established meaning under relevant law and is subject to judicial interpretation such that it may not be certain that a change of control has occurred or will occur.
Subsubsection Text: The definition of “Change of Control” in the Indenture includes (with certain exceptions) a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Company and its restricted subsidiaries, taken as a whole, to any person. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” there is no precise established definition of the phrase under applicable law, varies according to the facts and circumstances of the subject transaction and is subject to judicial interpretation. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of “all or substantially all” of the assets of the Company and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a change of control has occurred and whether the Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the New Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the New Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the New Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The New Notes will be denominated and payable in euros. If investors measure their investment returns by reference to a currency other than euros, an investment in the New Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the New Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to investors when the return on the New Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which the investors measure the return on their investments. Investments in the New Notes, which are denominated in a currency other than U.S. dollars, by U.S. Holders (as defined in “Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) may also have important tax consequences as a result of foreign exchange gains or losses, if any. See “Tax _Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the New Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the New Notes may have adverse tax consequences in the event of an IPO Pushdown.
Subsubsection Text: Under certain circumstances, we may undertake an IPO Pushdown (as described under “Description of the _New Notes—IPO Pushdown”). Upon consummation of the IPO Pushdown references to the Company and_ the Restricted Subsidiaries (and all related provisions) in the Indenture shall apply only to the IPO Pushdown Entity and its Restricted Subsidiaries from time to time, although the Issuer shall remain the same entity. In such event, each holding company of the IPO Pushdown Entity would be released from its obligations under the Indenture. Such a modification to the terms of the New Notes could be treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a deemed exchange of (i) the New Notes as in place prior to such modifications for (ii) modified New Notes as in place after such modifications (“Modified Notes”). If such modifications resulted in a deemed exchange, such a deemed exchange could be treated as a taxable transaction for U.S. federal income tax purposes in which certain beneficial owners of the New Notes could be required to recognize gain or loss. ----- Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the Modified Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange could be treated as issued with original issue discount (“OID”). In such event, U.S. Holders (as defined under “Certain Tax Consequences—Certain U.S. federal income tax considerations”) would be required to include that original issue discount in their income as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash corresponding to such income. U.S. Holders should consult their own tax advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating to modification of the New Notes in connection with the IPO Pushdown, including the U.S. federal income tax considerations of a deemed exchange and resulting OID, if any. -----

_You should carefully consider the risks described below as well as the other information contained in this offering memorandum before making an investment decision. Any of the following risks may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows, and as a result you may lose all or part of your original investment. The risks described below are not the only risks we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be immaterial may also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows._

(d) The purpose of the adjustment is to illustrate the effects of: (i) eliminating the effect of transactions between Vivacom and Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD The Group acquired Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD (formerly, Viva Telecom Bulgaria OOD) in the Vivacom Acquisition. Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD is a holding company of the Vivacom Group but does not itself prepare consolidated financial information. The pro forma financial information of Vivacom included herein is based on the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and therefore certain adjustments are made to eliminate the effect of transactions between Vivacom and Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD. An adjustment was made to eliminate intercompany transactions, comprising an interest income amounting to €6,262 thousand and reversal of impairment cost amounting to €303 thousand and related tax effects. (ii) purchase price allocation The purchase price allocation was finalized as of December 31, 2020 and therefore the Company Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2020, include the fair value adjustments that have been made to acquired assets and liabilities (including any associated deferred tax effects), and differences between total consideration paid for the acquisition and the estimated fair values of the net assets of Vivacom were recorded as goodwill. The Company identified and measured significant identifiable assets such as: trade name, customer base—fixed services, customer base—mobile services, licenses, software and distribution network. The value of the items of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets increased significantly. As a result of the newly identified intangible assets and the significant increase to the value of the existing items of property, plant and equipment, additional amortization and depreciation charges were estimated and added as adjustments to the of Vivacom financial data for the seven months ended July 31, 2020. The amount of additional amortization and depreciation was estimated based on the value allocated to specific assets and the remaining useful life of ----- those assets. The adjustments for the additional amortization and depreciation charges are amounting to €44,382 thousand and related tax benefit amounting to €4,438 thousand. (e) The adjustments presented have been made to align Vivacom’s accounting policies with IFRS as adopted and applied by the Company under its currently applied accounting policies. Vivacom (i) capitalizes subscriber acquisition costs for contracts below one year and (ii) capitalizes portability costs, while such costs are expensed as incurred by the Company and (iii) for related tax effects of the foregoing. _We present herein certain unaudited pro forma financial information (the “Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information”) comprising the unaudited pro forma income statement of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2020. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is based on and derived from, and should be read in conjunction with, the Company Audited Financial Statements, the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information gives effect to the (i) Vivacom Acquisition (which completed on August 3, 2020) and (ii) the issuance of the Existing 2026 FRNs, Existing 2026 SSNs and Existing 2028 SSNs (the “2020 Notes Financing”), which were partially used to finance the Vivacom Acquisition and, partially, to refinance certain debt facilities existing at the issue date of the Existing 2026 SSNs, Existing 2026 FRNs and Existing 2028 SSNs (the “2020 Notes Issue Date”) (collectively, the “Vivacom Transactions”), as if they had been completed on January 1, 2020. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is based on available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable. The assumptions and estimates underlying the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information are described in the accompanying notes thereto. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is presented for illustrative purposes only and is not intended to represent or be indicative of the financial results of operations that we would have reported had the Vivacom Transactions actually occurred during the period presented, and the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information does not purport to project our results of operations for any future period. Neither the assumptions underlying the pro forma adjustments, nor the resulting Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information has not been prepared in accordance with Article 11 of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act, the EU Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information has been prepared in accordance with the basis of preparation described below in the footnotes thereto. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is presented in thousands of euros unless otherwise indicated. Vivacom historical financial information is presented in thousands of Bulgarian lev. For the purposes of the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information, financial information reported in Bulgarian lev has been translated to euros on the basis stated in relevant footnotes to the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information includes unaudited pro forma adjustments that are factually supportable and directly attributable to the Vivacom Transactions. In addition to the Vivacom Acquisition, the Company also: (i) acquired Tele2 d.o.o. za telekomunikacijske usluge (now trading as Telemach Hrvatska d.o.o.) and has consolidated its results from March 2020; (ii) the Company obtained control over Forthnet on November 12, 2020 (for more information, please refer to Note 23 in the Company Audited Financial Statements); (iii) acquired Nova Broadcasting Group and has consolidated its results from January 22, 2021; and (iv) has completed certain other acquisitions in 2021, as described elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The Company Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information does not include adjustments with respect to the acquisitions referred to above. Prospective investors should read the information presented below in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial Data”, “The Company’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, “Vivacom’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, the Company Audited Financial Statements (and the related notes thereto) and the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements (and the related notes thereto), included elsewhere in this offering memorandum._ -----

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading cable and media player in Southeastern Europe, providing services to approximately 3.7 million homes as of March 31, 2021. We are the leading distributor of Pay-TV in our core markets of Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the number two distributor in Montenegro. As of March 31, 2021, we provided services to approximately 10.9 million RGUs and analog and digital cable Pay-TV services to approximately 1.9 million unique subscribers. United Group’s revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2021 was €439.4 million and UG Adjusted EBITDA was €179.2 million. The Group had Run-Rate Revenue for the annualized last two quarters ended March 31, 2021 of €1,916.4 million and Run-Rate Last Two Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021 was €706.3 million. The Combined Group is the clear multi-play leader in its footprint, with market leading positions in Pay-TV, broadband internet and fixed-line and mobile-telephony in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, following the Forthnet Acquisition, Greece. The Combined Group’s addressable market comprised 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020. We have grown rapidly through both acquisitions and organic growth. In July 2020, we acquired Vivacom, the market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria, based on total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, which is the leading operator in fixed-line telephony services and broadband services, the number three provider of mobile-telephony services and the number three provider of Pay-TV, in each case, by number of subscribers as of March 31, 2021. The Vivacom Acquisition increased our addressable market by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than doubled our existing subscriber base. In March 2020, we also acquired Tele2 Croatia, the third largest telecommunications operator in Croatia, based on mobile revenues as of March 31, 2021, through which we offer mobile services in Croatia. In November 2020, we completed the acquisition of a controlling interest in Forthnet S.A., a prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece, which marked our entry into the Greek market and will strengthen our position as an industry leader in Southeastern Europe. In January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova Broadcasting Group EOOD, from Advance Media Group EAD, providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria. In July 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in Optima Telekom, a Croatian telecom operator offering a broad range of fixed internet and pay-TV services. Subject to its completion, the Optima Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our presence in the Croatian market and offer a full range of telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through our existing infrastructure in the country. We offer a diverse and differentiated line of products and services. We are the leading distributor of satellite (“DTH”) Pay-TV across Southeastern Europe, with Pay-TV product and service offerings in each of Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia and Montenegro, where we use our Total TV platform to serve subscribers both inside and outside of our cable footprint to deliver content across the entire region, including rural areas. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we also provide Pay-TV services in Bulgaria and are the leading IPTV provider in Bulgaria, while the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition strengthened our content offering in Bulgaria. Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also provide cable and DTH services in Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services, we offer mobile-telephony services in Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia. We provide 4G LTE coverage to almost the entire population in each of these countries, and we are rolling out 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021 ----- secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction in Croatia this year. Our core telecommunications business is also complemented by our two OTT distribution platforms that customers can access through internet based streaming: EON, our regional OTT platform, which enables customers connected to our competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels, and NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which delivers ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more than 20 popular product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for children and kitchen appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and Slovenia. Through our in-house content business, we produce distinctive and attractive in-house media content for our Pay-TV channels across multiple key genres that have historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. These channels include Southeastern Europe’s most popular family of branded Pay-TV sports channels, as well as popular movie channels, children’s channels, a 24/7 news channel, music channels and other specialized channels, which we continue to expand both organically and through acquisitions. We currently produce over 40% of the total content in our national (terrestrial) and cable operations, and our programs typically receive ratings of between 30% to 60% in the markets in which they are available. The Group also has in-house media and content production in Greece. We believe that our market leading content portfolio differentiates us from our competitors, has enabled strong growth in our business and provides us with predictable third-party carriage fees. As part of our media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution. Our Nova TV Croatia channel has strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share of 40% and market share by advertising revenue of 50%. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such as popular national team football events until 2022, such as the Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup qualifiers and League of Nations. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering high-quality local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality international productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition makes us a major content player in Bulgaria by adding Nova BG’s media platform comprising ten television channels, including NOVA TV, which broadcasts throughout Bulgaria, Bulgaria’s largest online platform, Net Info, which reaches on average 80% of the Bulgarian population each month, and four radio stations. In addition to our own content, as a result of our pan regional presence and well established distribution network, we are a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content owners, such as Discovery/Eurosport, Viacom, AXN, CNN, HBO, Fox and Universal, and sports rights owners, such as the English Premier League, Spanish Football League LaLiga, 2020 UEFA European Championship qualifiers, 2020 UEFA European Championship, 2022 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, UEFA League of Nations, ATP, Formula 1, Euroleague, and Moto GP, which we believe allows us to consistently obtain high-quality content and attractive payment terms. Nova BG holds licenses to offer compelling content in Bulgaria through distributors such as CBS Intenrational, the Walt Disney Company, Columbia Pictures and Paramount Pictures, as well as popular sports content such as the English Premier League football, Euro Cup qualifiers and the Euro Cup and Formula One racing. We believe these providers partner with us because of our well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe. We operate most of our business across eight countries in Southeastern Europe: Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Greece. These countries have a combined population of approximately 40 million, distributed across approximately 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020, and represent the second-largest CEE market after Poland. Despite economic differences, many of these countries share a joint history and form a single market in which small local differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the region and are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are currently underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets. We are the leading multi-play provider in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bulgaria, where we combine our services into packages, or bundles, which offer subscribers the convenience of being able to purchase television, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider, and provides us with significant opportunities to cross-sell our products. ----- We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain our market leading positions in the Pay-TV and cable broadband internet markets in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to further increase our market shares, as we differentiate our product offerings through one of the highest download speeds in our broadband markets, access to desirable media content, a well invested network and high-quality customer service, which has led to relatively low churn rates which we believe demonstrate customer loyalty. We also believe that we are well-positioned to continue to grow in our region, and build on our expansion into Bulgaria and Greece. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For example, during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in providing connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and spent significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our voice and data traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data traffic increased at rates between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and 85%, depending on the country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30% and 40%, depending on the country. Traffic levels decreased during the summer months and started increasing again as new lockdowns were implemented in various countries. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than many of our competitors.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results are impacted by our product mix as well as our ability to introduce new products and upgrades and successfully sell those products and upgrades to increase our RGUs and ARPUs. We continually evaluate the suite of products and services we provide to our subscribers to ensure that we remain competitive with other providers in our markets and have an opportunity to increase our subscriber base and the number of products we sell to our subscribers. We accomplish this through product innovation, investments in technology and acquisitions of complementary businesses. For example, we have expanded our product offering by introducing fixed-line services to offer multi-play packages in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, including pay television, broadband internet access, fixed-line telephony, as well as mobiletelephony services in Slovenia and following the completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, in Croatia. Following completion of the Vivacom Acquisition in July 2020, we also offer pay television, broadband internet access, fixed-line telephony, and mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria. Following the Forthnet Acquisition in November 2020, we also offer telecommunications and Pay-TV services in Greece. We believe that media and communications services customers will increasingly choose bundled products because of the convenience and enhanced value resulting from obtaining TV, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider for one price. As of March 31, 2021, 85% of our customer base in Slovenia, 79% of our customer base in Serbia, 87% of our customer base in Bosnia and Herzegovina and 54% of our customer base in Bulgaria subscribed for one of our multi-play packages (our customer base is calculated based on unique cable subscribers by bundle). We seek to be the leader in our markets in pay television content and have entered into long-term strategic partnerships with key international and regional content owners. We have also acquired leading regional content owners in key television sub-segments (sports, lifestyle, children and films), such as providers of the Sport Klub family of channels (which includes Sport Klub, Golf Klub and our fishing and hunting channels), N1, Fight Channel, Pikaboo and Cinemania. Our ability to maintain the quality of our content impacts our ability to sell our pay television offerings, as well as bundled packages. Our product mix can also impact our margins. For example, our mobile-telephony business and our content business generally have lower margins compared to our cable-based business. Our success in growing these businesses may impact our product mix and therefore may affect UG Adjusted EBITDA margins.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Pricing of Our Products and Services
Subsubsection Text: Increasing demand for attractive content and higher broadband speeds allows us to increase the prices at which we provide these services while maintaining relatively low churn rates. We regularly review the prices of ----- our products and services, however, and in the past have adjusted our subscription fees as necessary in line with inflation, changes in foreign exchange rates or in response to market conditions and content costs. Changes in the pricing of our products and services will impact the revenues and margins that we generate from these products and services and impact our ability to attract new customers. For example, our multi-play bundles offer subscribers higher value in terms of channels, speeds functionality and add on features. The pricing of all our services, including our multi-play bundles, is dependent on market conditions, pricing by competitors with similar offerings and the perceived quality of our products versus other products. In relation to our Basic TV package, we were also subject to price regulation in Serbia until January 2017. From January 2017, the price of our Basic TV package in Serbia is no longer subject to price regulation. However, such price regulation might be reinstated in the future, and we regularly monitor the media market in Serbia to stay aware of market conditions which may lead to price regulation.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The television, broadband internet and telephony industries exhibit churn as a result of high levels of competition. In addition to competitive alternatives, churn levels may be affected by changes in our prices or our competitors’ prices, our level of subscriber satisfaction, subscriber mortality and the relocation of subscribers, as well as from the termination of agreements. An increase in churn may lead to increased costs and reduced revenues when subscribers cancel our services as we incur additional marketing and advertising costs to find new subscribers. Increasing demand for attractive content and higher broadband speeds allows us to increase the prices at which we provide these services while maintaining relatively low churn rates. We believe our relatively low churn rates provide us with recurring cash flows and visibility with respect to future revenues. We have historically experienced low churn rates in our television, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony businesses, and the churn we have experienced in these businesses has primarily been driven by customers moving outside of our current geographic area of services as well as termination of services due to their inability to pay, with only a limited amount of churn driven by competition. We believe that launching telephony in our markets, further driving digitization, providing our subscribers with multi-play packages (including quad-play in Slovenia, as described in more detail below), expanding our cable footprint to broaden our geographic reach and benefiting from increasing disposable incomes in the region (reducing the likelihood of customers’ bad debt), will allow us to maintain low churn rates for cable Pay-TV. In addition, we believe that as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, our churn rates will likely decrease as customers are unlikely or unable to easily migrate to another provider during the pandemic. The churn rates for our mobile post-paid subscribers are higher than the churn rates for our fixed-line telephony services, as it is easier for mobile subscribers to switch to our competitors as there are no infrastructure limitations. Similarly, the churn rate of mobile prepaid subscribers is relatively higher because of the non-contractual nature of the relationship with such subscribers. We believe, however, that we have developed an attractive suite of fixed mobile convergence services in Slovenia which, among other things, has had the effect of reducing the churn of our mobile post-paid subscribers in Slovenia. Following the consummation of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, we are leveraging on our experience and the lessons learned from integrating Tušmobil to guide our integration of Tele2 Croatia. Since our acquisition of Tušmobil, our number of quad-play subscribers in Slovenia has increased to 38% of our subscribers in Slovenia as of March 31, 2021, from 1% of our subscribers in Slovenia prior to the acquisition. The blended annual churn rate of Telemach Slovenia’s mobile post-paid subscribers as of March 31, 2021, was 11.5%, compared to 11.2% as of January 31, 2017. We define blended annual churn as net lost subscribers (the number of customers that either on a voluntary or involuntary basis no longer subscribe for a certain service) divided by the number of all unique cable subscribers at the beginning of period, which result is then annualized. We have been using the principles learned through our acquisition of Tušmobil and our experience providing mobile services in Slovenia to inform the operation of our mobile-telephony business in Bulgaria following the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition in July 2020 and in Croatia following the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition completed in March 2021.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our most significant costs include (i) carriage fees which we pay to international and regional broadcasters such as Fox, Discovery and Pink, in order to carry their programs on our distribution network, (ii) licensing fees payable to sports rights owners such as UEFA, the English Premier League, Spanish Primera League, ATP and Formula 1, in order to develop content for our own channels, (iii) satellite capacity costs, (iv) payroll costs, (v) internet and interconnection fees, (vi) costs of materials used to connect subscribers to our network ----- and (vii) costs for marketing and sales. Most of our costs, such as a portion of our network operations, customer care, billing and administration costs, are relatively fixed, while a portion of our marketing and customer services cost is variable. Our content acquisition costs are mostly fixed and a decreasing portion of these costs are subscriber based. Where possible, we aim to negotiate fixed rate content costs. This approach allows us to anticipate the input price of our content and price our products accordingly. The costs associated with the growth of our business, such as RGU acquisition costs, which are primarily comprised of campaign costs and sales costs for attracting new subscribers, are variable costs. A large portion of our costs is content costs, accounting for 18% of our operating expenses (not including depreciation and amortization of intangible assets) for the three months ended March 31, 2021. While we own a portion of our content, we are dependent on broadcasters and other content owners for most of our programming. We pay license fees to several regional and international broadcasters in order to broadcast their programs. For on demand content purchased by our subscribers, we generally pay a revenue share of the retail price, subject, for certain on demand content, to fixed minimum guarantees. For packaged on demand content (subscription video on demand), we pay on a per subscriber basis, sometimes with minimum guarantees. We generally expect that our content costs (above the minimum amounts) will increase in line with increased revenues from digital Pay-TV and on demand content. In the past we have successfully obtained rebates and discounts for our content, but these may not continue in the future. We pay fees to satellite operators to uplink and transmit our content to our DTH subscribers, and we also use other network operators to connect telephone calls of our customers to customers of their respective networks (interconnection). Generally, the amount we pay in interconnection fees in any period will depend on the level of usage of our services. Our staff cost is impacted by the number of personnel we employ, the experience levels at which such persons are employed and increases in salaries and bonuses due to performance factors. Labor costs of technicians, spent on the construction and upgrade of our network and acquisition of subscribers, are capitalized as tangible and intangible assets. RGU acquisition costs include campaign costs and sales costs. We aim to recover RGU acquisition costs over the duration of the service contract. Factors that contribute to successful recovery of RGU acquisition costs include our operational efficiency, the density of our subscriber base and our direct relationships with our subscribers, which enables us not to rely on intermediaries to interact with our customers.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to provide new high definition and on demand digital TV services, broadband internet access at higher speeds and telephony services to subscribers depends, in part, on our ability to upgrade and maintain our network. We incur capital expenditure charges in periods over which these upgrades are made, with the aim of recouping these investments through increased revenues and profitability. In particular, we expect certain communications technologies that are currently under development, 5G technology in particular, to become increasingly important in our markets. We successfully tested and are rolling out our next generation 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. In Slovenia, 5G 3600 MHz deployment and commercial launch began in June 2021, following a successful frequency auction result in April 2021. In Bulgaria, 5G has been launched commercially using 4G 1900 MHz spectrum in September 2020, which was the first available 5G service in the market, and in May 2021, Vivacom has secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. In Croatia, the first deployment of the 5G C-Band is expected during the third or fourth quarters of 2021, and Telemach Croatia is participating in the 5G spectrum auction in Croatia. We believe that significant investments in 5G technology will be critical to remain competitive in the mobile market and meet our customers’ needs. Our ability to compete effectively and maintain or increase our customer base depends on our ability to anticipate and react quickly to technological developments and evolving industry standards and develop successful new and enhanced products and services to adapt to changes in our market. We invest in new or enhanced technologies, products or services in periods over which industry standards change, or to upgrade our technologies proactively. Additionally, we incur capital expenditure costs relating to the replacement of existing equipment. We expect to incur substantial capital expenditure costs in the future relating to new 4G and 5G frequencies and the installation of new equipment.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We operate across Southeastern Europe, generating revenues in many local currencies, which fluctuate from time to time in relation to the euro. Our revenues in Slovenia, Montenegro and Greece are generated in euro. ----- SBB Serbia and Telemach BH record their financial results in the Serbian dinar and the Bosnian and Herzegovinian mark, respectively, which are then translated into euros in preparing our consolidated financial statements. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, 72% of our revenue was generated in euros or currencies pegged to the euro, with 15% of our revenue generated in Serbian dinars and 13% of revenue generated in Croatian kuna. While the Bosnian and Herzegovinian mark is pegged against the euro at a fixed exchange rate of BAM 1.9558 per €1.00 and the Bulgarian lev is pegged against the euro at a fixed exchange rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, the Serbian dinar freely fluctuates against the euro. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, the value of the Serbian dinar remained stable relative to the euro. However, due to the historic indexation of the Serbian dinar against the German mark, which was replaced by the euro in 2002, we believe the Serbian consumer price index closely tracks the depreciation of the Serbian dinar against the euro which has historically allowed us to “pass through”a portion of the impact of the depreciation of the dinar to our customers. We believe that our pricing strategy reflects this “pass through” principle. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, the value of the Croatian kuna increased approximately 1% relative to the euro compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. We present our consolidated financial statements in euro. As a result, we must translate the assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses of all of our operations with a functional currency other than the euro into euros at then applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of these currencies against the euro may affect the value of our assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses with respect to our non-euro businesses in our consolidated financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency. These translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods and result in significant changes to the carrying value of our assets, liabilities and stockholders’ equity. Additionally, certain of our expenses, primarily content and satellite costs, are denominated in euros and U.S. dollars. Where we are unable to match sales received in foreign currencies with costs paid in the same currency, our results of operations are impacted by currency exchange rate fluctuations. A substantial portion of our indebtedness is denominated in euros. Based on our lack of any material change in exposure to the U.S. dollar in the three months ended March 31, 2021, we did not enter into any additional currency hedge agreements during the three months ended March 31, 2021.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Three of our key markets—Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro—are generally characterized by lower internet broadband household penetration rates compared to elsewhere in Western Europe and the CEE region and both Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have lower pay television household penetration rates compared to elsewhere in Western Europe and the CEE region. As a result, growth in our markets has been higher than in certain CEE and Western Europe jurisdictions. We believe this is primarily due to the increasing importance of high-quality broadband internet and an increasing convergence of our regions with the EU. Slovenia is a more mature market, with subscriber rates similar to the CEE region, and as a result, growth in that market will depend more on our ability to effectively compete with other market participants and to continue to offer high-quality customer propositions. Following the completion of the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition in March 2020, we also have operations in Croatia. As a member of the EU with relatively high GDP per capita and growth rates, Croatia is an attractive market for our continued expansion. The Croatian mobile market is characterized by high market stability, as it has a low level of fragmentation and disruption, with only three MNOs in the market (including Telemach Croatia), and the country’s telecommunications infrastructure is highly dependent on mobile access, with one of the highest mobile ARPU among CEE countries. We believe that our growth in this market will depend on several factors, such as the ability to expand our territorial coverage as well as improve the quality of our network and customer support services, including through investments to increase our capacity and quality levels and through the continued development of our digital and sales channels. In addition, following the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition in July 2020, we also have operations in Bulgaria. Bulgaria experienced relatively strong GDP growth at an average rate of 3.3% per year between 2017 and 2019 (according to the BNSI), but faces economic and political challenges in sustaining this growth. Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also have operations in Greece. The Greek telecommunications market is characterized by intense competition. The market is concentrated among four main operators with a focus on fixed-mobile convergent offerings. The total fixed-line market, comprised of approximately 4.8 million subscribers, has stable with limited fixed-to-mobile substitution, while the broadband market, comprised of approximately 4.2 million subscribers continues to grow at the expense of voice-only lines. NGA subscribers (those with broadband speeds of greater than 30 Mbps) comprise approximately one-third of total broadband subscribers, but this level remains low compared with the EU average of over 60%. Pay-TV penetration is also ----- low compared to EU averages, with 26% of Greek households subscribing to Pay-TV. In Greece, the majority of Pay-TV subscribers are served through DTH technology, while the remainder is served through IPTV. In each of the aforementioned markets, a number of factors will impact the rate of growth of pay television, broadband internet and telephony industries, including economic conditions, political stability, increases in infrastructure and an increased distribution of wealth. Furthermore, these industries may not grow at the same rate as they have in the past.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are subject to various regulations in Europe and in our regional markets. We are generally free from retail price regulation other than, prior to January 2017, with respect to our Basic TV package in Serbia, due to SBB Serbia’s prior SMP in the Serbian Pay-TV market. Since January 2017, we are no longer considered a significant market participant in the Pay-TV market in Serbia, thus our Basic TV package is no longer subject to price regulation, although this may change in the future, and we regularly monitor the market to stay aware of market conditions which may lead to price regulation. In Croatia, we are currently subject to price regulation only with respect to fixed and mobile termination rates charged by operators to each other for interconnection services, which are regulated in the whole European Union. In addition, in Serbia we are subject to price regulation only to the extent we are required to provide access to our wholesale network. SBB Serbia is, however, currently deemed to have SMP on the wholesale market for call termination in public telephone networks and the wholesale market of central access at a fixed location for mass market products, which imposes certain regulatory obligations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—We may become subject to more extensive regulation due to our scale.” We also implemented price_ increases in January 2018, which the Serbian Commission for Protection of Competition investigated, but ultimately accepted. In addition, we may be subject to conditions imposed in connection with competition authority clearances as we continue to expand our business through bolt on, value accretive acquisitions and we may be subject to market power analysis from the relevant regulators, which could force us to adjust our prices or sell various parts of our businesses. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—We may become subject to more extensive regulation due to our scale” and “Our Business— Regulatory Framework.”_

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The results of our operations depend on our tax treatment under the tax laws and regulations of local jurisdictions. For instance, in Serbia, taxable income can be reduced in the same proportion as capital expenditure for the year in Serbia divided by the carrying amount of assets in Serbia. Due to our significant capital expenditure in Serbia in 2016, we believe we have satisfied the requirements to be granted a ten year tax beneficial status, expiring in 2025, and we recorded beneficial tax treatment for our SBB Serbia segment for the years ending December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021. Additionally, under thin capitalization rules in Serbia, interest and related costs under intercompany loans are recognized as deductible expenses to the extent the intercompany loans do not exceed four times the borrower’s equity. In 2017 and 2018, SBB Serbia did not capitalize any intercompany loans. On December 27, 2018, the Serbian Tax Authority notified United Group that it had begun a tax investigation of SBB Serbia for the year ended December 31, 2012. The Serbian Tax Authority issued a decision in March 2019 that it had recharacterized interest payments made by SBB Serbia under an intragroup loan agreement (and certain debt and equity conversions) as dividends, which would have been subject to a 5% withholding tax, and found a total contingent liability in respect of this decision amounting to €21 million, including late interest. On October 12, 2020, the Serbian Ministry of Finance annulled the Serbian Tax Authority’s decision and instructed the Serbian Tax Authority to restart the procedure, taking into account the arguments provided in SSB Serbia’s appeal. The Serbian Tax Authority has also informed SBB Serbia that it is opening a tax review for the years 2013 through 2016. SBB Serbia intends to continue contesting the Serbian Tax Authority’s findings. For more information, see “Our Business—Legal Proceedings—Investigation by the Serbian Tax Authority.” Furthermore, in Slovenia, Telemach Slovenia may use a tax allowance for investment in equipment and intangible assets (available for investments made after January 1, 2008), whereby the tax allowance is limited to 40% of the value of the assets, up to the amount of the tax base. In 2018, 2019 and 2020, Telemach Slovenia used the tax allowance for investments in the amount of €11.5 million, €10.5 million and €9.3 million, respectively. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, a taxpayer who invests more than BAM 20.0 million (€10.2 million) in production assets (property, plant and equipment) within the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina for five ----- consecutive years is relieved from 50% of taxation on such investments for a period of five years, starting from the first year in which it has invested at least BAM 4 million (€2.0 million). Pursuant to this provision, in 2018, 2019 and 2020, Telemach BH received a tax allowance for investments in the amount of BAM 6.1 million (€3.1 million), BAM 6.8 million (€3.5 million) and BAM 2.7 million (€1.4 million), respectively. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, a taxpayer receives a tax allowance when it employs certain types of employees, and in 2018, 2019 and 2020, Telemach BH received a tax allowance for certain new employees in the amount of BAM 1.3 million (€0.7 million), BAM 2.0 million (€1.0 million) and BAM 2.9 million (€1.5 million), respectively. In Greece, the corporate income tax rate was set at 24% in 2019. From January 1, 2020, withholding taxes on dividends were reduced from 10% to 5%, and on July 1, 2020, Greece implemented a participation exemption for capital gains from the sale of Greek and EU subsidiaries. For internet services, customers are charged a 5% tax on top of internet subscriptions (in addition to VAT of 24%). In addition, a 10% tax on top of Pay-TV subscriptions for Greek operators (in addition to VAT of 24%) has been imposed, although this has been suspended until September 2021.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Implementation of Accounting Policies and Accounting Updates
Subsubsection Text: _IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers_ IFRS 15 establishes a comprehensive framework for determining whether, how much and when revenue is recognized. While IFRS 15 became effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2018, with early adoption permitted, we commenced the recognition of revenue broadly in line with IFRS 15 for periods starting January 1, 2016 as debundling of services was applied beginning on January 1, 2016. Other standards in compliance with IFRS 15 were applied from January 1, 2018. There were two primary changes that we implemented in accordance with IFRS 15. First, with respect to handset sales that are subsidized by ongoing service fees, we used to recognize revenue only in the amount of cash received for such mobile phones. However, under the new standard, we allocate a contract’s transaction price based on the relative stand-alone selling price of the mobile phone. More revenue is recognized upfront as a result. As a result of implementing this policy in 2016, we have not seen a material impact on our reported financial results for periods that commenced after January 1, 2018 when IFRS 15 was fully implemented. Concurrently, we corrected an accounting policy regarding discounts to contracts. Contracts where a customer pays for equipment, such as handsets, in installments over a period of more than one year (in addition to ongoing services) may be deemed to have a significant financing component, particularly in the case of discounts during the first few months of a contract. The majority of new or renewed contracts provide for discounts during the first few months of a contract. Under IFRS, such a discount during the first few months is ignored, and the total price of the contract is spread out over the entire contract period. Furthermore, revenue is adjusted to reflect the time value of money. Second, we charge non-refundable service activation fees to all new customers at the beginning of their contract. These fees do not transfer goods or services to the customer, but are more administrative in nature and do not render a service or provide a benefit to the customer. Under IFRS 15, such fees should be spread over the entire contract period as they are related to the performance obligation of providing a mobile service, which results in a contractual liability at the beginning of the contract on the balance sheet. _IFRS 9 Financial Instruments_ IFRS 9 replaces the existing guidance in IAS 39 (Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement) that relates to the recognition, classification and measurement of financial assets and financial liabilities, derecognition of financial instruments, impairment of financial assets and hedge accounting. IFRS 9 also includes revised guidance on the classification and measurement of financial instruments, including a new expected credit loss model for calculating impairment on financial assets and the new general hedge accounting requirements. Most IAS 39 requirements concerning classification and measurement of financial liabilities and de recognition of financial instruments were transferred to IFRS 9 unchanged. The standard introduces the following categories of financial assets: measured at amortized cost, measured at fair value through profit and loss and measured at fair value through other comprehensive income. Classification is performed on initial recognition and depends on the business model for managing of financial assets adopted by the Group and on the characteristics of the contractual cash flows from such instruments. ----- The adoption of IFRS 9 from January 1, 2018 resulted in changes in accounting policies and adjustments to the amounts recognized in our accumulated loss. _IFRS 16 Leases_ IFRS 16 introduced for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019 a single, on balance sheet lease accounting model for lessees. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low value items available on a voluntary basis. Lessor accounting remains similar to the previous standard—i.e., lessors continue to classify leases as finance or operating leases. Under IFRS 16, we recognize new assets and liabilities for our operating leases of satellite capacity, office facilities, parts of our infrastructure and base stations and the right-of-use of water and land. The nature of expenses related to those leases changed because we recognized a depreciation charge for right-of-use assets and interest expense on lease liabilities. Previously, we recognized operating lease expense on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease, and recognized assets and liabilities only to the extent that there was a timing difference between actual lease payments and the expense recognized. There has been no significant impact for our finance leases in which we are the lessor. We applied the simplified transition approach and did not restate comparative amounts for the year prior to first adoption. Right-of-use assets for property leases were measured on transition as if the new rules had always been applied. All other right-of-use assets have been measured at the amount of the lease liability on adoption (adjusted for any prepaid or accrued lease expenses). _IFRIC 23_ In June 2017, the IFRS Interpretation Committee issued IFRIC 23, which clarifies the accounting treatment of uncertainties in income taxes, specifically in relation to taxable profit or loss, tax bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits and tax rates, when there is uncertainty over income tax treatments under IAS 12. IFRIC 23 states that an entity should assume that the applicable taxation authority will have full knowledge of all relevant information when examining amounts reported to it. An entity therefore has to consider whether it is probable that the applicable authority will accept a certain tax treatment in the entity’s income tax filing and either adopt an approach consistent with the tax treatment in its income tax filings or use the expected value of the tax treatment when determining taxable profit or loss, tax bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits and tax rates. IFRIC 23 is applicable for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019 with early adoption permitted. In adopting IFRIC 23, we applied a modified retrospective approach whereby the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRIC 23, if any, should be recognized in opening equity at the date of initial application. As part of our adoption of IFRIC 23, we have not identified any additional material income tax uncertainties for which we would be required to recognize a related tax liability. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, we have also applied certain other amendments to existing accounting standards that did not have any impact on the amounts recognized in prior periods and that are not expected to significantly affect current or future periods.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The performance of our businesses, our results of operations and the key operating measures discussed below have been, and will continue to be, affected by a variety of factors. Certain of these factors are discussed below.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Since January 1, 2017, we have expanded our business by acquiring and integrating the following cable TV operators, mobile-telephony service providers, B2B service providers and ISPs: In 2017, we acquired: - Fight Channel, a specialized martial arts channel in Croatia offering a range of mixed martial arts sports, kickboxing and boxing, which has provided us with an extension of our program content and contributed to an increase in our number of subscribers, for a total consideration of €2.5 million. The transaction closed on April 5, 2017; - Ikom, a cable operator in Serbia with 93 thousand unique cable subscribers, which has provided us with an increased share of the cable market in Serbia through access to Ikom’s customer database, for a total consideration of €45 million. The transaction closed on April 20, 2017 (subject to conditions from the ----- CPC, as described in “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We have made and may _make acquisitions or enter into transactions that may present unforeseen risks, and we may not realize the financial and strategic goals that were contemplated at the time of any transaction and, additionally, there are risks associated with the integration of any acquisitions”);_ - 51% of IDJ Digital Holding Limited, a digital distributor of music and online video content based in Malta, which has provided us with expansion of our business activities into digital distribution, for a total consideration of €0.6 million. The transaction closed on April 20, 2017; - ASK, a cable operator is Bosnia and Herzegovina with approximately 2,000 subscribers, and which has increased our share of the cable market in such market, for a total consideration of €0.6 million. The transaction closed on October 9, 2017; - D.o.o. Kabel Group 85 Čačak, a cable operator in Serbia with approximately 3,805 subscribers and which has since been merged with SBB Serbia, and which has increased our share of the cable market in such market, for a total consideration of €2.1 million. The transaction closed on October 18, 2017; and - Teleing, d.o.o., a cable operator in Slovenia with approximately 14,000 subscribers, and which has increased our share of the cable market in such market, for a total consideration of €10 million. The transaction closed in December 2017. In 2018, we acquired: - Nova TV d.d., a provider of full format, general entertainment flagship stations geared towards mainstream audiences as well as a range of thematic channels, from CME B.V. in the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition, which acquisition completed on July 31, 2018, for a total consideration of €86.4 million (including net working capital adjustments); and - 100% of the outstanding shares (excluding treasury shares) in Direct Media, a leading media buying agency in Serbia, which acquisition completed on September 4, 2018. The transaction included Direct Media’s operations in Serbia, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Albania, as well as the company’s terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and Pink Montenegro (which we have rebranded Nova BH and Nova M, respectively). Direct Media is a full service media agency, offering integrated communication, advertising and media services to local and international partners. In 2018, we sold our Total TV operations in Croatia in connection with the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition. The total consideration was €3 million, and the transaction closed on January 12, 2018. In connection with the sale, we entered into a one year transitional support agreement. In 2019, we acquired: - Netlogic d.o.o. Beograd, a Serbian IT services company, for a total consideration of €2.0 million. The transaction closed on April 1, 2019; - Skyline Kabel d.o.o., a Slovenian telecommunications company, for a total consideration of €1.1 million. The transaction closed on November 1, 2019; and - FMC Datacenter d.o.o., a Slovenian web hosting company, for a total consideration of €0.6 million. The transaction closed on December 31, 2019. In 2020, we acquired: - Tele2 Croatia, the third largest MNO in Croatia, for cash consideration of €126.0 million. We financed the acquisition through the issuance of €207.0 million in aggregate principal amount of additional Existing 2024 SSNs. The acquisition closed on March 3, 2020. - Vivacom, the largest telecommunications operator in Bulgaria by revenue, for cash consideration of €937.8 million. We financed the acquisition of Vivacom through the issuance of the Existing 2026 SSNs, the Existing 2026 FRNs and additional Existing PIK Notes. Following approval by the European Commission in April 2020, the acquisition was consummated on July 31, 2020. Expansion in Bulgaria increased our addressable market by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than doubled our existing subscriber base and included three million mobile subscribers, 541 thousand fixed-telephony subscribers, 472 thousand fixed broadband subscribers and 508 thousand fixed Pay-TV subscribers. Following the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition, we increased our commitments in respect of our Existing Revolving Credit Facility to €250 million. In September 2020, we completed the acquisition of a significant minority interest in Forthnet, a prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece for a cash consideration of €44 million. Forthnet provides ----- home entertainment and communications services to nearly 1.4 million RGUs. In November 2020, we acquired a controlling interest in Forthnet. Our acquisition of Forthnet marked our entry into the Greek market and is expected to strengthen our position as an industry leader in Southeastern Europe. In July 2020, we agreed to acquire the remaining 49% of Grand Production, and in addition, during the course of 2020, we acquired, or signed binding offers to acquire, stakes in several companies in Serbia and Slovenia for a total preliminary consideration of approximately €23 million. These transactions were completed in March 2021. In January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova BG, from Advance Media Group EAD for a consideration of €290.6 million. Nova BG’s operations comprise 10 television channels, including NOVA TV which broadcasts throughout Bulgaria, Bulgaria’s largest online platform, Net Info, that reaches on average 80% of the Bulgarian population each month, and four radio stations. Nova BG had estimated last two quarters annualized revenue and adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021, of approximately €152 million and €57 million, respectively. In March 2021, we acquired Serbian newspaper Dan Graf (operating under the brand Danas) in order to increase our footprint in print and digital media in the Serbian market. Between April and June 2021, we signed agreements to acquire, or completed the acquisition of, the entire share capital or stakes in various other companies, including local internet and TV operators Net 1 EOOD and ComNet Sofia EAD, Digital Cable Television EOOD (N3), Serbian distribution company D Express, local internet and TV operators Networx-Bulgaria EOOD, TVN Distribution Bulgaria EOOD and Telco Infrastructures EOOD in Bulgaria, as well as Mainstream in Serbia. On July 9, 2021, we announced that we reached an agreement to acquire a majority interest of 54.31% in Croatian telecom operation Optima Telekom, based on an enterprise value of HRK 639 million. Optima Telekom offers a broad range of fixed broadband internet services to approximately 117 thousand subscribers and pay-TV services to approximately 57 thousand subscribers in Croatia. Completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition is expected for the end of 2021 and is subject to customary conditions as well as the implementation of certain changes in the current Croatian telecommunication legislation relating to vertical integration between pay-TV broadcasters and distributors, and thus there can be no assurance that the acquisition will be completed by such expected date or at all. Once completed, the acquisition of Optima Telekom will allow us to further expand our presence in the Croatian market enabling Telemach Croatia to offer a full range of telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through its existing infrastructure. Optima Telekom had estimated last two quarters annualized revenue and adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021 of €60.1 million and €16.8 million, respectively. Following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, we expect to be required to undertake a tender offer for the remaining shares of Optima Telekom not yet acquired. Acquisitions affect our results of operations in a variety of ways. Our results for the period during which an acquisition takes place are affected by the inclusion or exclusion of the results of the acquired or disposed of business in our consolidated results. In addition, the results of the acquired businesses after their acquisition may be impacted positively by synergies. Additionally, we may experience an increase in operating expenses, including staff cost, as we integrate the acquired business into our network. Acquisitions may also result in higher levels of depreciation and amortization expense. Also, because acquired entities are consolidated from the date of their acquisition and disposed of entities are no longer consolidated from the date of their disposition, the full impact of an acquisition or disposition is only reflected in our financial statements in the subsequent periods. As a result, the historical results of operations for the periods presented in this offering memorandum may not be comparable with each other. See “Our Business—History” for a discussion of these acquisitions.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We are a pan regional distribution platform of cable and satellite Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services with various offerings in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Greece. Our business has grown substantially in terms of scale, geographic reach and service offering during the period under review through both organic growth and acquisitions. In addition, the corporate organization of our business has changed during this period as our business has grown and been integrated. As a consequence of these changes, our Group-level financial reporting has evolved during the last several years. In order to provide a meaningful analysis of our results of operations during the period under review, in addition to a discussion of our Group-level consolidated results of operations based on IFRS measures, we ----- also present a discussion of revenues, UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure of our business segments for the three months ended March 31, 2021, the three months ended March 31, 2020 and the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020. Under IFRS 8 “Operating Segments,” we present our segment data in the notes to the Company Audited Financial Statements. In Note 7 to the 2020 Company Audited Financial Statements, we separately report segment results for nine business segments: - Serbia Group. This segment includes the results of cable services in Serbia and DTH operations in Serbia and North Macedonia, including the results of Ikom (acquired in April 2017). This segment also includes the results of Absolut Solutions, (although these results are not reflected in the statutory consolidated results of SBB Serbia); - Slovenia Group. This segment includes the results of our cable and mobile services and DTH operations in Slovenia; - Bosnia Group. This segment includes the results of our cable and DTH operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina; - Montenegro Group. This segment includes the results of our cable and DTH business in Montenegro; - Media Group. This segment includes the results of our media and content business in Southeastern Europe including the results of N1, Sport Klub, Grand Production, Pikaboo, IDJ Nova TV, Nova M and Nova BH as well as Direct Media and Nova BG (from January 22, 2021); - Croatia Group. This segment includes the results of Telemach Croatia from March 3, 2020; - Bulgaria Group. This segment includes the results of Vivacom from July 31, 2020; - Greece Group. This segment includes the results of Forthnet’s telecommunications operations from November 12, 2020; - Other segments. This includes our other operating business, Solford Trading Ltd. (which operates NetTV Plus) and Shoppster, and our non-operating holding companies (United Group B.V., Adria Cable B.V., Adria Serbia Holdco B.V. and Slovenia Broadband S.à r.l.). Revenue reported under “Other” is mainly generated by Solford Trading Ltd. Our Media Group segment presents results for Nova BG (acquired on January 21, 2021) and Dan Graf (acquired on March 10, 2021) from the respective date of consolidation with the Group’s results for the three months ended March 31, 2021.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure represents capital expenditure, as adjusted by intragroup adjustments, the application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia, assets held for sale and overflow between periods. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure is prepared based on management accounts and not IFRS. Intragroup adjustments relate to unrealized profit on the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB Serbia. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other Group companies in compliance with applicable transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS, but are not eliminated for the purpose of our management accounts. The application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia reflects the additional effect of harmonizing our accounting policy with respect to the capitalization of subscriber acquisition costs for rebinding, upselling and cross-selling (which in the past were not eligible to be capitalized, but under IFRS 15 qualify for capitalization), which were determined subsequent to the preparation of our management accounts. Assets held for sale relate to programming rights acquired by Media Group for other Group Segments which were recognized under IFRS as intangible assets and were invoiced to other Group segments after March 31, 2021. Overflow between periods relates to the fact that our management accounts are closed prior to the closing of our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS. Overflow between periods in any given period reflects the additional capital expenditure incurred between the preparation of our management accounts and our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS for such period. ----- In this offering memorandum, we present UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the Company and for each of the Company’s business segments for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021. See “Summary of Company and Group Run-Rate, Vivacom, _Unaudited Pro Forma and Certain Other Financial Data” and “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data Presented Herein.” A reconciliation between the Company’s capital expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital_ Expenditure for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and the three months ended March 31, 2021 is included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, under “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data _Presented Herein.” In addition, for informational purposes only, we describe our anticipated UG Adjusted_ Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2021 based on management estimates, which may vary from our actual Group level capital expenditure data when it is prepared in accordance with IFRS. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and future UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure estimates are prepared based on management accounts rather than IFRS. One example of a difference in methodology used in preparing the management account financial data (as compared to IFRS financial data) is that when determining UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure relating to set-top boxes purchased by group companies, the expenditure is treated as inventory until such set-top box is activated by the end-user, at which time it is treated as a fixed asset. Under IFRS, however, this expenditure is required to be accounted for as a fixed asset from the moment such set-top box is purchased. As a result, when presenting our segment level UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and our anticipated UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the periods presented in this offering memorandum, we classify our expenditures relating to set-top boxes as inventory until such set-top boxes are activated by the end-user.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of our cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique subscriber is typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but several RGUs. DTH subscribers represent the number of individuals across the six Southeastern European markets (Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Montenegro and North Macedonia) who have subscribed to our DTH Pay-TV services. We believe that most of these subscribers are outside of our cable footprint. Typically, DTH subscribers are only able to subscribe to DTH based Pay-TV services and represent a single RGU. However, we are re selling ADSL services purchased from our competitors in the respective markets to DTH subscribers. Average monthly revenue per user, or ARPU, is a measure we use to evaluate how effectively we are realizing potential revenues from subscribers. ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total subscription related revenues for that particular month divided by the average number of subscribers for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period.
