Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use several key operating measures, including homes passed, unique subscribers, RGUs and ARPU, to track the performance of our business. None of these terms are measures of financial performance under IFRS, nor have these measures been reviewed by an outside auditor, consultant or expert. These measures are derived from management information systems. As these terms are defined by our management, they may not be comparable to similar terms used by other companies.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Homes passed represents all homes (households) ready to be connected directly to our fixed-line network. (2) Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of our cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique subscriber is typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but several RGUs. (3) Cable Pay-TV RGUs includes (i) the sum of our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Slovenia, (ii) our total analog cable Pay-TV RGUs (without separately counting analog cable RGUs that have purchased digital top ups) in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro and (iii) our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Bulgaria. (4) OTT consists of our NetTV Plus and out of footprint EON subscribers. (5) Broadband internet RGUs represents residential broadband internet provided within our network footprint. (6) Fixed-line telephony RGUs represents residential fixed-line telephony provided within our network footprint. (7) Mobile RGUs represents mobile-telephony services provided to customers in Slovenia, where we have operated as an MNO since our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015. Following completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia, and following the completion of the acquisition of Vivacom in July 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria. (8) Other services include multichannel multipoint distribution service-based services, ADSL internet services and B2B services. (9) RGU Penetration represents for cable Pay-TV the number of unique cable subscribers at the end of the relevant period as a percentage of the number of homes passed by our network, and for broadband internet the number of RGUs at the end of the relevant period as a percentage of the number of unique cable subscribers. (10) Blended Cable ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total cable Pay-TV, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony revenues (including fixed-line telephony usage revenues and excluding minor installation fees) for that particular month divided by the average number of unique cable subscribers for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period. Blended Cable ARPU does not include mobile ARPU, which was €10.9 for the year ended December 31, 2018, €10.8 for the year ended December 31, 2019, €9.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020 and €8.8 for the three months ended March 31, 2021. We calculate mobile ARPU by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total mobile-telephony revenues (excluding revenues generated by customers of other networks roaming on our network and excluding wholesale revenues) for that particular month divided by the average number of mobile RGUs for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period. In addition, following the Vivacom Acquisition, we amended the definition of certain key operating measures (Homes Passed, Unique Cable Subscribers and Blended Cable ARPU) in order to align the calculation methodology across the Group. As a result, Bended Cable ARPU figures were restated for the periods starting from January 1, 2018 onwards. (11) As of January 1, 2019, we changed our reporting methodology in regards to certain key operating measures, which has resulted in immaterial differences as compared to previous periods. For the year ended December 31, 2018, OTT users on our network have been reclassified to Cable and Cable services users on other networks have been reclassified to Other Services from Cable. This change has an immaterial effect on all subscriber, RGU, ARPU and churn data for the year ended December 31, 2018, and such key operating measures have been restated for such periods in line with this new reporting methodology. ----- The following table provides a breakdown of our key operating measures for our Telemach Slovenia segment, SBB Serbia segment, Telemach BH segment, Telemach MNE segment, Telemach Croatia segment Vivacom Bulgaria segment and Forthnet Greece segment as of the dates and for the periods indicated:

Subsubsection Text: (1) Figures for the three months ended March 31, 2020 for our Croatia, Bulgaria and Greece segments are derived from management accounts and are included for presentation purposes only, as the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia, the acquisition of Vivacom and the acquisition of Forthnet were completed on March 3, 2020, July 31, 2020 and November 22, 2020, respectively. (2) Homes passed represents all homes (households) ready to be connected directly to our fixed-line network. (3) Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of our cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique subscriber is typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but several RGUs. (4) RGUs, or revenue generating units. Total RGUs are not equal to the total number of subscribers. For example, one subscriber who receives cable Pay-TV and telephony services over our network is counted as two RGUs, and our subscriber who receives cable Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services over our network is counted as three RGUs. (5) Mobile RGUs represents mobile-telephony services provided to customers in Slovenia, where we have operated as an MNO since our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015. Following completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia, and following completion of the acquisition of Vivacom in July 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria. (6) Other services include multichannel multipoint distribution service-based services, ADSL internet services and B2B services. _Group—Three Months Ended March 31, 2021 Compared to the Three Months Ended March 31, 2020_ Homes passed increased by 1,858 thousand, or 100%, from 1,866 thousand as of March 31, 2020, to 3,724 thousand as of March 31, 2021, primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom and organic network expansion. As of March 31, 2020, we had 1,479 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 307 thousand compared to 1,172 thousand as of March 31, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom and organic growth. The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 991 thousand as of March 31, 2021, a 121% increase year-on-year, primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Forthnet. As of March 31, 2021, we had 1,396 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase of 60%, compared to 871 thousand as of March 31, 2020. This is primarily attributable to the acquisition of Vivacom, an increase in multi-play subscriptions over this period and organic subscriber growth. The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs increased to 1,269 thousand as of March 31, 2021, an increase of 80% compared to 704 thousand as of March 31, 2020. This positive trend is primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom, an increase in multi-play subscriptions over this period and organic subscriber growth. ----- Our OTT RGUs as of March 31, 2021 decreased by 1% to 127 thousand, compared to 128 thousand as of March 31, 2020. Our mobile service RGUs increased from 1,495 thousand as of March 31, 2020 to 4,473 thousand as of March 31, 2021. This is an increase of 2,977 thousand, or 199%, which was due to the acquisition of Vivacom (2,938 thousand mobile RGUs) and organic growth. Our total RGUs increased by 122%, from 4,902 thousand as of March 31, 2020 to 10,890 thousand as of March 31, 2021. RGUs added over this period were mainly the result of the acquisition of Vivacom (4,461 thousand total RGUs) and Forthnet (1,375 thousand RGUs), as well as organic growth of cable Pay-TV and mobile services and a growing proportion of multi-play subscribers. _Group—Year Ended December 31, 2020 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2019_ Homes passed increased by 1,834 thousand, or 99%, from 1,852 thousand as of December 31, 2019 to 3,686 thousand as of December 31, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom (1,750 thousand) and organic network expansion. As of December 31, 2020, we had 1,476 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 308 thousand compared to 1,168 thousand as of December 31, 2019, as a result of the acquisition of Vivacom and organic growth. The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 999 thousand as of December 31, 2020, a 124% decrease as compared to December 31, 2019, primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Forthnet. As of December 31, 2020, we had 1,389 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase of 62%, compared to 856 thousand at December 31, 2019. This is primarily attributable to the acquisition of Vivacom, an increase in multi-play subscriptions and organic subscriber growth. The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs increased to 1,270 thousand as of December 31, 2020, an increase of 83%, compared to 695 thousand as of December 31, 2019. This is primarily the result of the acquisition of Vivacom, as well as an increase in multi-play subscriptions over this period and organic subscriber growth. Our OTT RGUs as of December 31, 2020 increased by 4% to 129 thousand, compared to 124 thousand as of December 31, 2018. Our mobile service RGUs increased from 550 thousand as of December 31, 2019 to 4,483 thousand as of December 31, 2020. This is an increase of 3,933 thousand, or 715%, driven by the acquisition of Vivacom and Telemach Croatia (2,938 thousand and 937 thousand mobile RGUs, respectively) and organic growth in Slovenia. Our total RGUs increased by 178%, from 3,917 thousand as of December 31, 2019 to 10,897 thousand as of December 31, 2020. RGUs added over this period were mainly the result of the acquisitions of Vivacom (4,461 thousand RGUs), Telemach Croatia (937 thousand mobile RGUs) and Forthnet (1,375 thousand RGUs), as well as organic growth of cable Pay-TV and mobile services and a growing proportion of multiplay subscribers. _Group—Year Ended December 31, 2019 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2018_ Homes passed increased by 19 thousand, or 1%, from 1,833 thousand as of December 31, 2018 to 1,852 thousand as of December 31, 2019, primarily due to organic network expansion. As of December 31, 2019, we had 1,168 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 3 thousand compared to 1,166 thousand as of December 31, 2018, primarily due to organic growth. The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 446 thousand as of December 31, 2019, a 4% decrease as compared to 463 as of December 31, 2018, primarily due to increased competition, migration from DTH to our cable services (due to expansion of our network) and subscriber base cleaning. As of December 31, 2019, we had 856 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase of 4%, compared to 822 thousand at December 31, 2018. This is primarily attributable to an increase in multi-play subscriptions and organic subscriber growth. The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs increased to 695 thousand as of December 31, 2019, an increase of 8%, compared to 644 thousand as of December 31, 2018. This positive trend is primarily due to an increase in multi-play subscriptions and organic subscriber growth. Our fixed-line telephony RGUs as of December 31, 2018 have been restated by 17 thousand RGUs, from 661 thousand RGUs to 644 thousand RGUs, due to the ----- reclassification of fixed-line telephony RGUs outside our network footprint to Other services. This reclassification mainly involved Telemach Slovenia, affecting 14 thousand fixed-line telephony RGUs. Our OTT RGUs as of December 31, 2019 increased by 2% to 124 thousand, compared to 122 thousand as of December 31, 2018, primarily due to new content offered to customers. This figure includes 13 thousand OTT RGUs in Serbia and Slovenia. Our mobile service RGUs increased from 512 thousand as of December 31, 2018 to 550 thousand as of December 31, 2019. This is an increase of 38 thousand, or 7%, driven by organic growth in Slovenia. Our total RGUs increased by 3%, from 3,788 thousand as of December 31, 2018 to 3,917 thousand as of December 31, 2019. RGUs added over this period were a result of the organic growth of cable Pay-TV, telephony, mobile, internet and other services, as well as a growing proportion of multi-play subscribers. Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue._** Revenues are generated from the following services: cable television, broadband internet, DTHTV, value added services (such as OTT), telephony subscriptions and telephony usage, content and other sources (primarily related to the sale of end-user equipment). Revenues generated from our bundle subscriptions are allocated to the individual products of standard cable, broadband internet and telephony subscriptions based on the individual product prices for each product as a percentage of the sum of the individual product prices. Revenue for these services is charged and recognized in the period in which these services are provided. We recognize revenues for connection fees upon delivery of installation and we defer and amortize connection fees over the average remaining useful life of the customer relationship. Other income._** Other income arises mainly from subventions, reversal of provision for legal cases, charged legal cases and other activities nor related to the ordinary course of business. Content costs._** Content costs include author rights and royalties we pay to procure our content, and include fees paid to channel providers, primarily related to foreign television channels. Our content fees are predominantly determined on a flat monthly amount and to a lesser extent on a per subscriber basis. Satellite capacity costs._** Satellite capacity costs relate to the lease of satellite capacity from third-party providers, which currently is EUTELSAT. These costs are impacted by the type and amount of commercial discounts obtained from satellite providers. With effect from January 1, 2019, satellite capacity costs are presented under depreciation (right-of-use assets) and finance costs due to the adoption of IFRS 16. Link and interconnection costs._** These costs relate to fees payable in order to transfer data over third-party networks. Internet connection links are leased from various parties. Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs._** Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs includes costs to procure set-top boxes, other products, such as telephones and routers, and materials used to connect subscribers to our network. Prior to January 1, 2020, these costs were recorded under the line item “Material costs.” Staff cost._** Staff cost includes wages and salaries, social security costs, pension costs and other postemployment benefits and the cost of temporary and external personnel, adjusted for own work capitalized based on direct labor hours spent on projects which are capitalized. ----- Media buying._** Media buying includes expenses incurred by Direct Media in the territories of Serbia, Montenegro, Albania and North Macedonia. As a leading media network in Southeastern Europe, Direct Media provides international and local partners with integrated communication, advertising and media services. Depreciation cost._** Depreciation cost relates to the depreciation and impairment of our property, plant and equipment over their useful lives. Amortization of intangible assets._** Amortization of intangible assets relates to the amortization and impairment of our intangible assets over their useful lives. Our intangible assets include our customer base and direct subscriber acquisition costs, which, for our cable and DTH customers, are capitalized and amortized over the estimated useful life of the customer relationship. For our mobile customers, subscriber acquisition costs are capitalized and amortized over a twenty four month period (the estimated life of the post-paid customer contract), while our mobile customer base is capitalized and amortized over its estimated useful life. Intangible assets also include goodwill, computer software, licenses and content such as sport rights. Amortization of right-of-use assets._** Amortization of right-of-use assets relates to depreciation of right-ofuse assets over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term on a straight-line basis. Other operating expenses._** Other operating expenses include rent of premises, poles and ducts, marketing and promotion expenses, legal and administrative fees and maintenance costs and other costs. With effect from January 1, 2019, other operating expenses excludes media buying expenses, which are included under the separate line item “Media buying.” Operating income._** Operating income represents the amount of profit from business operations, and includes total revenues less total operating expenses (which contains cost of goods sold, personnel expenses, contracted work, materials and logistics, marketing and sales, office expenses, other operating expenses, amortization, depreciation and impairments). Finance income._** Finance income includes interest income on funds invested (including short-term bank deposits) and foreign currency gains. Finance costs._** Finance costs include interest expense on borrowings and foreign currency losses. Income tax credit/(expense)._** Income tax credit/(expense) comprises current and deferred income tax and is recognized in our statement of comprehensive income, except to the extent that such expense or benefit relates to an item that is recognized as equity in our balance sheet or in our statement of other comprehensive income.

Subsubsection Title: Three Months Ended March 31, 2021 Compared to the Three Months Ended March 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: We present and discuss in the following section the Company’s consolidated financial data for the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the three months ended March 31, 2020.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In this “The Company’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations,” we have presented:_ - unaudited consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to the unaudited consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2020; - audited consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the audited consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019; and - audited consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the audited consolidated financial data for the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, derived from the comparative 2018 data included in the 2019 Company Audited Financial Statements. See “Presentation of Financial Data—Financial Data Included in this Offering Memorandum—Company _Consolidated Historical Financial Data.”_ -----

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year Ended December 31, 2020 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2019
Subsubsection Text: We present and discuss in the following section the Company’s consolidated financial data for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the year ended December 31, 2019.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Figures for the three months ended March 31, 2021 are for the period following completion of the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition, the Vivacom Acquisition and the Forthnet Acquisition, as applicable. ----- Slovenia Group segment._ Revenue for our Slovenia Group segment increased by €3,321 thousand, or 6%, to €61,191 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €57,870 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was due to higher mobile revenues as a result of an increased number of subscribers, price increases in March and October 2020, higher internet revenues (successful upselling and migration from legacy EON packages with higher internet ARPU) and higher mobile handset revenues. Serbia Group segment._ Revenue for our Serbia Group segment decreased by €689 thousand, or 1%, to €56,052 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €56,741 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the negative accounting impact from the implementation of IFRS 15 on video and internet services. Bosnia Group segment._ Revenue for our Bosnia Group segment decreased by €736 thousand, or 4%, to €18,052 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €18,788 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the negative accounting impact from the implementation of IFRS 15 on video and internet services of €989 thousand, partially offset by higher DTH video and internet subscription revenues. Montenegro Group segment._ Revenue for our Montenegro Group segment decreased by €171 thousand, or 5%, to €3,194 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €3,365 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to a continued decline in the number DTH subscribers. Croatia Group segment._ Revenue for our Croatia Group segment was €43,770 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021. Tele2 Croatia was acquired and consolidated into United Group as of March 2020. _Bulgaria Group segment. Revenue for our Bulgaria Group segment was €129,604 thousand for the_ three months ended March 31, 2021. Vivacom was acquired and consolidated into United Group as of July 2020. Greece Group segment._ Revenue for our Greece Group segment was €62,122 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021. Forthnet was acquired and consolidated into United Group as of November 2020. Media Group segment._ External revenue for our Media Group segment increased by 53% to €56,769 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to €37,169 thousand in the three months ended March 31, 2020, mainly due to the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition, which was completed in January 2021. Total revenues of the Media Group segment (including intercompany revenues) increased by 36% year-on-year, to €84,646 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021. Other._ Revenue from our Other segment increased €4,024 thousand, or 88%, to €8,603 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €4,579 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the launch of the Shoppster e-commerce platform during 2020. Other income._ Other income increased by €73 thousand, or 4%, to €1,796 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €1,723 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. Content costs._ Content costs increased by €19,615 thousand, or 69%, to €48,166 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €28,551 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the content costs of newly acquired channels. Link and interconnection costs._ Link and interconnection costs increased by €33,226 thousand, or 291%, to €44,660 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €11,434 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2 Croatia. Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs._ Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs increased by €31,010 thousand, or 183%, to €47,974 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €16,964 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to higher cost of sales for mobile handsets (mainly due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Tele2 Croatia), the higher cost of end-user equipment, higher energy and fuel costs mainly as a result of acquisitions, as well as higher costs of goods sold (mainly relating to goods sold by Shoppster, which started operations in 2020). Staff cost._ Staff cost increased by €33,805 thousand, or 157%, to €55,342 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €21,537 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was mainly the result of the increase in staff cost due to the higher number of employees resulting from acquisitions in 2020 and 2021. ----- Media buying._ Media buying costs increased by €473 thousand, or 6%, to €8,417 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €7,944 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was mainly a result of the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition, which offset the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic (that is, which led to lower media buying volumes by Direct Media due to decreased overall advertising spend). Depreciation._ Depreciation increased by €30,448 thousand, or 112%, to €57,574 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €27,126 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the addition of tangible assets as a result of the acquisitions in 2020 and 2021. Depreciation (right-of-use assets)._ Depreciation (rights of use assets) increased by €10,249 thousand, or 185%, to €15,799 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €5,550 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was due to the acquisitions completed in 2020 and 2021. Amortization of intangible assets._ Amortization of intangible assets increased by €43,893 thousand, or 197%, to €66,147 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €22,254 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the addition of intangible assets through the acquisitions completed in 2020 and 2021. Other operating expenses._ Other operating expenses increased by €32,480 thousand, or 106%, to €63,110 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €30,630 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. While all cost categories saw an increase, the largest increases were in maintenance, license fee and marketing and promotion costs. Net finance costs._ Net finance costs increased by €4,189 thousand, or 13%, to €37,562 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €33,373 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to higher interest expense related to new bond issuances. Loss before tax._ Loss before tax decreased by €4,712 thousand, or 39%, to €7,233 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €11,945 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This change was primarily due to increased operating profit, which partially offset the higher net finance costs. Income tax expense._ Income tax expense increased by €1,254 thousand, or 88%, to €2,687 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €1,433 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €94,570 thousand, or 112%, to €179,164 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €84,594 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the impact of the acquisitions of Tele2 Croatia, Vivacom and Forthnet, which were completed in March 2020, July 2020 and November 2020, respectively, as well as due to the organic growth of our subscriber base, price increases, continued successful cross-selling, migration of subscribers to multiplay packages and effective cost discipline. UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased to 41% for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from 44% for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the contribution of Telemach Croatia and Vivacom which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin as compared to our other segments, as well as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDA by segment for the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. Slovenia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €1,284 thousand, or 6%, to €23,114 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €21,830 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the organic growth of fixed and mobile RGUs, price increases in March 2020 (of mobile services) and October 2020 (of both mobile and fixed services) as well as the acquisition of 12 thousand unique video subscribers in the year ended December 31, 2020. Serbia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €1,509 thousand, or 5%, to €31,041 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €32,550 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the negative accounting impact on our revenues from the implementation of IFRS 15. Bosnia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €645 thousand, or 10%, to €7,123 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €6,478 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to lower programming costs resulting from the non-renewal of our contract ----- with Arenasport, which generated estimated cost savings of €1,299 thousand. This increase was partly offset by the negative accounting impact on our revenues from the implementation of IFRS 15. Montenegro Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €73 thousand, or 10%, to €809 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €736 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to 13 lower direct costs and lower operational costs, which more than offset the 5% decrease in revenues due to the negative accounting impact from the implementation of IFRS 15. Media Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €6,567 thousand, or 36%, to €24,928 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €18,361 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the integration of Nova BG in the Media Group segment, following its acquisition in February 2021, which was partially offset by a decrease in revenues due to the non-extension of certain carriage fee arrangements in Slovenia and Bosnia and increased costs relating to the enhancement of our content offering in those markets. Croatia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA for the three months ended March 31, 2021 was €15,089 thousand. Bulgaria Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA for the three months ended March 31, 2021 was €61,488 thousand. Greece segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA for the three months ended March 31, 2021 was €18,136 thousand.

Subsubsection Title: Year Ended December 31, 2019 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2018
Subsubsection Text: We present and discuss in the following section the Company’s consolidated financial data for the year ended December 31, 2019 and the year ended December 31, 2018.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Slovenia Group segment._ Revenue for our Slovenia Group segment increased by €7,567 thousand, or 3%, to €237,129 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €229,562 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to an increase in internet revenues (a result of successful upselling and migration from legacy to EON packages with higher internet ARPU), higher mobile revenues as a result of an increased number of subscribers and price increases in March and October 2020 and higher mobile handset and other revenues (taking into account the effects of IFRS 15 and COVID-19-related government subsidies). Serbia Group segment._ Revenue for our Serbia Group segment increased by €3,698 thousand, or 2%, to €223,697 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €219,999 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to growth in the number of subscribers and and multiplay packages (particularly through successful cross-selling). Bosnia Group segment._ Revenue for our Bosnia Group segment decreased by €115 thousand, to €72,537 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €72,652 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the accounting impact from the implementation of IFRS 15 (primarily in relation to video and internet services). Montenegro Group segment._ Revenue for our Montenegro Group segment decreased by €992 thousand, or 7%, to €13,307 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €14,299 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was mainly due to a lower number of DTH subscribers in 2020. Media Group segment._ External revenue for our Media Group decreased by €26,206 thousand, or 14%, to €158,886 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €185,092 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was due to the COVID-19 pandemic, primarily in the advertising and media selling businesses. Total revenues of the Media Group segment (including intercompany revenues) decreased by 5.3% year-on-year to €267,187 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2020. Other income._ Other income decreased by €1,508 thousand, or 17%, to €7,406 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €8,914 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. Content costs._ Content costs increased by €6,321 thousand, or 5%, to €130,533 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €124,212 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the content costs of newly acquired channels. Link and interconnection costs._ Link and interconnection costs increased by €53,406 thousand, or 140%, to €91,557 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €38,151 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher mobile link and interconnection costs due to acquisitions in the period. Cost of end-user equipment and other material cost._ Material costs increased by €95,512 thousand, or 190%, to €145,781 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €50,269 thousand for the year ended ----- December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the higher cost of sales for mobile handsets (mainly due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Tele2 Croatia), higher cost of goods sold (mainly in relation to goods sold by Shoppster, which started operations in 2020) and higher energy and fuel costs mainly as a result of acquisitions. Staff cost._ Staff cost increased by €32,712 thousand, or 32%, to €134,820 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €102,108 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the impact of additional staff costs from acquired companies. Staff costs in 2019 were impacted by a one-time non-charge of €21,659 thousand resulting from the application of IFRS 2 in relation to a long-term incentive scheme (LTIS). Media buying._ Media buying costs decreased by €1,513 thousand, or 4%, to €38,168 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €39,681 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to generally lower advertising expenditures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Depreciation._ Depreciation increased by €54,891 thousand, or 51%, to €161,719 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €106,828 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisition of new tangible assets as a result of the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2 Croatia. Depreciation (right-of-use assets)._ Depreciation (right-of-use assets) was €42,793 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to €17,972 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of €24,821, or 138%. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2 Croatia. _Amortization of intangible assets. Amortization of intangible assets increased by €60,998 thousand, or 74%,_ to €143,278 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €82,280 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the addition of intangible assets of acquired companies. Other operating expenses._ Other operating expenses increased by €79,819 thousand, or 67%, to €199,221 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €119,402 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to higher legal and advisory fees (including related to acquisition-related activities) and higher maintenance and license fee costs which mainly resulted from the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2 Croatia. Net finance costs._ Net finance costs increased by €28,736 thousand, or 28%, to €133,005 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €104,269 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher interest expense related to new bond issuances . Loss before tax._ Loss before tax increased by €11,914 thousand, or 23%, to €64,536 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €52,622 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased net finance costs, which more than offset the operating profit increase of €16,822 thousand. Income tax expense._ Income tax expense increased by €476 thousand, or 6%, to €7,890 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €7,414 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €185,944 thousand, or 63%, to €481,338 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €295,394 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to an increase in revenues as a result of acquisitions completed in 2020, the organic growth of our subscribers, price increases, continued cross-selling as well as effective cost discipline. UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin increased to 41% for the year ended December 31, 2020, from 40% for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to the impact of the Media Group segment which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin in 2019 as compared to 2018, largely as a result of Telemach Croatia and Vivacom which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin as compared to our other segments, as well as the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDA by segment for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. Slovenia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €15,295 thousand, or 21%, to €89,399 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €74,104 thousand for the year ended ----- December 31, 2019, primarily due to the organic growth of fixed and mobile RGUs and the price increase of mobile services in March and October 2020 and fixed services in October 2020. Serbia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €10,064 thousand, or 9%, to €127,007 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €116,943 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to higher revenues from the organic growth of our subscriber base through cross-selling and strict cost control, which was partially offset by increased programming costs. Bosnia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €2,420 thousand, or 9%, to €23,993 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €26,413 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to higher programming costs resulting from the introduction of the new channel Nova BH, with an annual cost of €2,474 thousand and increased costs for our Sportklub channels. The increase in programming costs was partly offset by savings achieved on other operating expenses. Montenegro Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €487 thousand, or 15%, to €2,732 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €3,219 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to a 7% decrease in revenues, which was only partially offset by decreased costs and operating expenses. Media Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €2,255 thousand, or 3%, to €77,874 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €80,129 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to the decrease in total revenues as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, primarily in the advertising and media selling businesses.

Subsubsection Text: ----- (1) We were required to adopt IFRS 9 (Financial Instruments) and IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) effective as of January 1, 2018. IFRS 15 was adopted through the modified retrospective method of adoption and IFRS 9 was adopted in accordance with IAS 8, with no restatement of comparatives. The difference between carrying amounts and those determined under IFRS 9 are included under our opening balance of accumulated loss for the relevant period. (2) With effect from January 1, 2019, other operating expenses exclude media buying expenses, which are included under the separate line item “Media buying.” Revenue._ Revenue increased by €106,185 thousand, or 17%, to €741,812 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €635,627 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to continued cross-selling and price increases and the contribution and improved performance of companies acquired in 2018 and 2019. _Revenue by Segment_

Subsection Title: Revenue For the year ended December 31, 2018 For the year ended December 31, 2019 (in € thousands)
Subsubsection Text: Slovenia Group segment . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 219,469 229,562 Serbia Group segment . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 205,134 219,999 Bosnia Group segment . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 67,741 72,652 Montenegro Group segment . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 13,702 14,299 Media Group segment . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 109,009 185,092 Slovenia Group segment._ Revenue for our Slovenia Group segment increased by €10,093 thousand, or 5%, to €229,562 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €219,469 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increased number of mobile-telephony subscribers, increased mobile handset sales and price increases in February 2019 in fixed-telephony. Serbia Group segment._ Revenue for our Serbia Group segment increased by €14,865 thousand, or 7%, to €219,999 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €205,134 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to growth in the number of subscribers and RGUs (particularly through cross-selling) and the implementation of a price increase in January 2019. Bosnia Group segment._ Revenue for our Bosnia Group segment increased by €4,911 thousand, or 7%, to €72,652 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €67,741 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to organic growth, an increase in the number of subscribers for our multi-play offering (digital TV, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony), and price increases in April 2019. Montenegro Group segment._ Revenue for our Montenegro Group segment increased by €597 thousand, or 4%, to €14,299 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €13,702 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the number of multi-play subscribers. Media Group segment._ Revenue for our Media Group increased by €76,083 thousand, or 70%, to €185,092 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €109,009 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the number of multi-play subscribers and organic growth in both carriage fees and advertising, and the contribution from the acquisitions of Direct Media in September 2018 and Nova TV. Other income._ Other income decreased by €6,415 thousand, or 42%, to €8,914 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €15,329 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the divestment of Totalna TV Croatia in the first quarter of 2018. Content costs._ Content costs increased by €20,938 thousand, or 20%, to €124,212 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €103,274 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to United Media’s acquisitions of TV channels (Nova TV in Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina and Montenegro) and increased sports rights costs. Satellite capacity costs._ With effect from January 1, 2019, satellite capacity costs are presented under depreciation and finance costs due to the adoption of IFRS 16. ----- Link and interconnection costs._ Link and interconnection costs decreased by €2,903 thousand, or 7%, to €38,151 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €41,054 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower mobile link and interconnection costs. Cost of end-user equipment and other material cost._ Material costs increased by €4,646 thousand, or 10%, to €50,269 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €45,623 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the higher cost of sales for mobile handsets as a result of increased sales volumes and higher energy and fuel costs. Staff cost._ Staff cost increased by €3,097 thousand, or 3%, to €102,108 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €99,011 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the impact of additional staff costs from acquired companies. Out of the total amount of staff cost in the year ended December 31, 2019, €21,659 thousand related to the non-cash impact of the application of IFRS 2 in relation to an LTIS and was the main driver of increased staff costs, as compared to €32,809 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. On May 16, 2018, the shareholders of our former ultimate holding company, Adria LuxCo S.à r.l. entered into the LTIS for the benefit of certain members of our current and future management team. The LTIS consisted of a payment by the shareholders of Adria LuxCo S.à r.l. following completion of an initial public offering or a sale of the Group. The amount of the payment was calculated as a percentage of the proceeds received by the shareholders of Adria LuxCo S.à r.l. and is based on the accumulated return on investment achieved by such shareholders. In addition, the increase was due in part to our continued expansion, both organic and through acquisitions, of the Group during 2018. Media buying._ Media buying costs increased by €19,661 thousand, or 98%, to €39,681 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €20,020 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the full-year effect of the acquisition of Direct Media in September 2018. Depreciation._ Depreciation increased by €7,186 thousand, or 7%, to €106,828 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €99,642 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the expansion of our cable and mobile networks, increased investment in own produced content and new assets from acquisitions. Depreciation (right-of-use assets)._ Depreciation (right-of-use assets) was €17,972 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to nil for the year ended December 31, 2018. This was due to the result of the implementation of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019. Amortization of intangible assets._ Amortization of intangible assets increased by €13,797 thousand, or 20%, to €82,280 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €68,483 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased investments in programming rights and own production, as well as the addition of intangible assets of acquired companies. Other operating expenses._ Other operating expenses decreased by €4,639 thousand, or 4%, to €119,402 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €124,041 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the implementation of IFRS 16 and lower legal and advisory fees related to M&A activities. Net finance costs._ Net finance costs increased by €40,607 thousand, or 64%, to €104,269 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €63,662 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to higher interest expenses and costs of an early redemption option that was exercised in the January 2020. Loss before tax._ Loss before tax increased by €9,669 thousand, or 23%, to €52,622 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €42,953 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased finance costs. Income tax expense._ Income tax expense increased by €4,368 thousand, or 143%, to €7,414 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €3,046 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to a decrease in deferred tax as a consequence of the merger of SBB with IKOM and a higher level of income tax expense. UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €34,768 thousand, or 13%, to €295,394 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €260,626 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in revenues as a result of the organic growth of our subscribers, price increases, continued cross-selling, effective ----- cost discipline, and the impact of acquisitions of Nova TV (Croatia, Bosnia and Montenegro) and media selling companies (Serbia) in the second half of 2018. UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased to 40% for the year ended December 31, 2019, from 41% for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the impact of the Media Group segment which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin in 2019 as compared to 2018, largely as a result of acquisitions. We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDA by segment for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to the year ended December 31, 2018. Slovenia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €2,674 thousand, or 4%, to €74,104 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €71,430 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the organic growth of mobile RGUs and the price increase of mobile services in December 2018 and fixed services in February 2019. Serbia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €3,919 thousand, or 3%, to €116,943 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €113,024 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to higher revenues from the organic growth of our subscriber base and a price increase in January 2019, which was partially offset by increased programming costs and strict cost control. Bosnia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €2,982 thousand, or 13%, to €26,413 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €23,431 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a revenue increase driven by price increases for subscriptions for the Bosnia Group’s cable platform in April 2018 and April 2019 and satellite platform in January 2019, and an increase in the number of subscribers with higher priced subscriptions. Montenegro Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €107 thousand, or 3%, to €3,219 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €3,326 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to an increase in direct costs and operational expenses which offset the revenue increase resulting from the organic growth of the subscriber base and the increase in the number of multi-play subscribers. Media Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €28,710 thousand, or 56%, to €80,129 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €51,419 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the contribution of the acquisitions of Nova TV (Croatia, Bosnia, and Montenegro) and media selling companies in Serbia in the second half of 2018, offset by organic growth in 2019 due to increased carriage revenues.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity and funds for UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, acquisitions and other investments are operating cash flow, the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, potential additional issuances of debt securities, ancillary and bilateral lending facilities and finance leases. Our ability to generate cash from our operations will depend on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. We maintain cash and cash equivalents to fund the day-to-day requirements of our business. We hold cash primarily in euros as well as Serbian dinars, Bosnian marks, Bulgarian levs and Croatian kuna. Historically, we have relied primarily on our the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and bilateral bank facilities, other debt facilities and cash flow from operations to provide funds required for investments in UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and operations. As of March 31, 2021, we had €166.0 million of cash and cash equivalents. As of March 31, 2021, we had €3,388 million of outstanding indebtedness (excluding lease liabilities) on a historical basis. This included, as of March 31, 2021, €3,300.0 million in aggregate principal amount of Existing Notes (excluding transactions costs and fees related to the issuance thereof) along with the partially drawn Existing Revolving Credit Facility of €73.0 million, a €10.0 million unsecured bilateral revolving credit facility in Serbia, other financial liabilities related to bank secured loans of €2.9 million and finance leases of €2.0 million. This amount excludes €289.7 million of lease liabilities and €287.6 million of lease liabilities that would have been considered operating leases prior to the adoption of IFRS 16. After giving effect to the Existing Revolving Credit Facility 2021 Increase, we expect to have up to €325 million of commitments under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. ----- On an as adjusted basis after giving effect to the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom and the other transactions described under “Capitalization,” as of March 31, 2021, the Company would have had €3,736 million of outstanding indebtedness on a consolidated basis (excluding lease liabilities). The terms of the Indentures permit the Company and its restricted subsidiaries to incur substantial additional indebtedness, including in respect of borrowings by the Company or any of (in the case of the Indentures) its restricted subsidiaries under any Credit Facility (as defined in the Indentures) of up to the greater of €570 million and 100% of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Indenture).

Subsubsection Text: _Existing Revolving Credit Facility_ On July 13, 2017, the Company entered into the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, with, among others, the guarantors named therein as original guarantors or borrowers, the financial institutions named therein as original lenders, UniCredit Bank AG, London Branch, as facility agent and English security agent and UniCredit Bank Serbia JSC Belgrade, as Serbian security agent. In addition, in connection with the 2019 Refinancing, pursuant to an additional facility notice dated May 3, 2019, the Company received additional commitments from certain Existing Revolving Credit Facility Lenders in an aggregate amount equal to €100 million in relation to the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, increasing the commitments under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility from €100 million to €200 million with effect from May 14, 2019. Pursuant to an amendment and restatement agreement to the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement dated July 31, 2020 (with an effective date of August 5, 2020), among other things, (a) the maturity of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility was extended to July 15, 2025 (with such maturity automatically being reduced to (i) February 1, 2024, if the Existing 2024 SSNs are not fully refinanced by such date or (ii) February 15, 2025, if the Existing Floating Rate Notes are not fully refinanced by such date) and (b) the commitments under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement were increased to €250 million. On or about the Issue Date, the Company expects to receive additional commitments from certain lenders in respect of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate amount up to €75 million, increasing the total commitments under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility from €250 million to up to €325 million, in connection with the Existing Revolving Credit Facility 2021 Increase. Subject to certain exceptions, loans may be borrowed, repaid and reborrowed at any time. The interest rate on cash advances under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility is the sum of the applicable margin and LIBOR/EURIBOR (both as defined in the Existing Revolving Credit Facility). The margin may range from 3.00% to 3.50%, or as otherwise determined in accordance with the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. The Existing Revolving Credit Facility will mature on July 15, 2025 (with such maturity automatically being reduced to (i) February 1, 2024, if the Existing 2024 SSNs are not fully refinanced by such date or (ii) February 15, 2025, if the Existing Floating Rate Notes are not fully refinanced by such date). See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.” _Notes and Existing Notes_ Following this Offering, the Issuer expects to have €2,600 million in aggregate principal amount of Fixed Rate Notes outstanding and €1,000 million in aggregate principal amount of Floating Rate Notes outstanding. The 2017 Indenture, the 2019 Indenture, the Indenture and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility contain covenants that, among other things, limit the Company’s ability and the ability of the Company’s restricted subsidiaries to: incur additional indebtedness; pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of capital stock or make certain other restricted payments or investments; enter into agreements that restrict distributions from subsidiaries; sell or otherwise dispose of assets, including capital stock of restricted subsidiaries; enter into transactions with affiliates; create or incur liens; and merge, consolidate or sell substantially all of the Company’s or the Issuer’s assets. These covenants will be subject to important exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the New Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements.” Bilateral Facilities_ From time to time, we enter into bilateral facilities with certain of our local lenders. See “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Bilateral Facilities.” -----

Subsubsection Text: Slovenia Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Slovenia Group segment increased by €3,406 thousand, or 20%, to €20,390 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €16,984 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was mostly due to higher acquisition costs and capitalized inventory, as well as higher investments in IT projects as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. Serbia Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Serbia Group segment decreased by €1,969 thousand, or 13%, to €13,619 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €15,588 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mostly due to lower investments in customer-premises equipment as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. Bosnia Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Bosnia Group segment decreased by €393 thousand, or 8%, to €4,736 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €5,129 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was due to lower investments in IP equipment and customer-premises equipment compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. Montenegro Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Montenegro Group segment decreased by €311 thousand, or 24%, to €979 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €1,290 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was due to lower network investments in IP equipment and customer-premises equipment as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. Croatia Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Croatia Group segment was €11,610 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, and consisted of mobile network and IT related investments, sales commissions, investments for the refurbishment of shops and offices and other investments. Bulgaria Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Bulgaria Group segment was €15,550 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021. This mainly consisted of TV equipment, expenditure on network improvement and expansion, licenses and CPEs, as well as capitalized subscribers’ acquisition costs. Greece Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Greece Group segment was €6,226 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021. This mainly consisted of investments in fixed network additions, sales commissions and other capitalized subscribers’ acquisition costs, as well as in customer premise equipment. Media Group segment._ UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for our Media Group segment increased by €1,161 thousand, or 7%, to €17,383 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €16,222 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was due mainly due to the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition and investments in new production capacity.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure relates primarily to the purchase of property and equipment, including expansion of our network in terms of capacity and new homes connected, purchase of modems and set-top boxes to be installed in customer premises, growth in RGUs and maintenance of our cable and mobile networks and infrastructure, purchase of intangible assets such as content, software, investments in our core infrastructure and systems to facilitate the addition of new services and acquisitions. Therefore, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure is primarily driven by extending, upgrading and maintaining our cable and mobile networks, the installation and in home wiring for new subscribers, the cost of cable modems, including highspeed modems for subscribers to our high-speed broadband internet, and the acquisition of content. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure has also historically included certain investments of a non-recurring nature, as well as costs to integrate acquired businesses. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure also includes increases in intangible assets (except our customer list and brand names) and does not include financial assets. As part of our strategy to focus on UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure improving returns, we implemented measures to ensure a more efficient usage of capital investment. We intend to manage UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure to maintain our well invested asset base. The members of our board of directors review all material UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure programs. For a further description of UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability _of Our Results of Operations—UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure.”_ Over the next several years, we expect that UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure will be largely success and capacity based. Success and capacity based UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure includes UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure related to the expansion of our network footprint to additional homes and existing subscribers, the replacement of set-top boxes, expanding network capacity, new product and service development and expenditure incurred when connecting business subscribers to our network. Success based UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure does not include UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for maintenance, upgrade and replacement of our systems and infrastructure. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure amounted to €91 million, compared to €58 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and included mainly investments in ----- network expansion, customer premise equipment, as well as the purchase of new programming rights and investments in mobile infrastructure. For the year ended December 31, 2020, certain of our primary UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure items included: investments of €40.4 million on customer premise equipment; an investment of €49.9 million on the buildup of our fixed network; investments of €61.7 million on development of media, including acquisition of content and investment in TV equipment; investments of €34.9 million on our mobile infrastructure; an investment of €10.7 million on our IT; investments of €15.9 million on IP equipment; investments of €6.4 million on Video HE equipment; an investment of €7.7 million on certain development costs, including €4.5 million with respect to United.Cloud; and an estimated €41.0 million for the integration of Vivacom; investments of €42.6 million on other capital expenditures, of which acquisition costs represent €21.1 million. For the year ended December 31, 2019, certain of our primary UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure items included: investments of €41.6 million on customer premise equipment; an investment of €40.8 million on the buildup of our fixed network; investments of €44.1 million on development of media, including acquisition of content and investment in TV equipment; investments of €14.3 million on our mobile infrastructure; investments of €12.0 million on customer acquisition; an investment of €3.7 million on our IT; and an investment of €4.5 million on certain development costs, including with respect to United.Cloud. For the year ended December 31, 2018, certain of our primary UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure items included: investments of €37 million in customer premises equipment; an investment of €42.9 million in the buildup of our network; investments of €10 million in mobile infrastructure; and an investment of €3 million in United.Cloud. Out of our UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2018, €5.5 million represented certain investments (€3.5 million for a digitalization project in the city of Belgrade in Serbia and €2.0 million for the modernization of acquired companies’ networks in Bosnia and Herzegovina). For the year ending December 31, 2021, we expect one-off investments to total €133.4 million and include: (i) €8.9 million primarily for upgrades of our fixed fiber networks and data centers and other development projects, including a 1 Ghz/85 Mhz capacity expansion project of the HFC plant and an HFC network upgrade in Slovenia, Bosnia and Serbia; (ii) €93.8 million for the acquisition of 4G and 5G mobile frequencies; (iii) €14.1 million in total for the integration of acquired companies in Croatia (€8.7 million), Bulgaria (€2.7 million) and Slovenia (€2.5 million); (iv) €9.3 million for a national VPN project in Greece (Syzefxis II); and (v) €7.4 million related to transition service agreements and the rebranding of our operations in Croatia and Bulgaria. We do not currently expect core capital expenditure to exceed depreciation and amortization levels on a long-term basis. For the year ending December 31, 2021, we estimate that our capital expenditure (excluding any amounts for Forthnet (estimated at €112.6 million), Nova BG (estimated at €6.5 million) or mobile frequencies (estimated at €93.8 million)) will be between approximately €371 million and €373 million, which we expect will include: - an estimated €50.2 million on customer premise equipment (€40.4 million in 2020); - an estimated €73.6 million on our fixed network (€49.9 million in 2020); - an estimated €66.0 million on our mobile network (€34.9 million in 2020); - an estimated €12.9 million on IT (€10.7 million in 2020); - an estimated €18.9 million on IP equipment (€15.9 million in 2020); - an estimated €6.6 million on Video HE equipment (an estimated €6.4 million in 2020) - an estimated €6.7 million on development costs, including with respect to United.Cloud (€7.7 million in 2020); - an estimated €66.2 million on development of media, including acquisition of content and investment in TV equipment (€61.7 million in 2020); and - an estimated €70.6 million on other capital expenditures (€42.6 million in 2020). These estimates are budgeted amounts and may differ from our actual capital expenditure as our business requirements change.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our income and cash flow from operations are affected by changes in market interest rates. Some items on our balance sheet, such as cash and bank balances, interest bearing investments and borrowings, are exposed to interest rate risk. Borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and the Existing Floating Rate Notes bear interest at varying rates, and as a result we will have interest risk with respect to this debt. Interest rate hedging arrangements are not in place as of the Issue Date with respect to the debt under our Existing Revolving ----- Credit Facility or the Existing Floating Rate Notes. For fixed rate debt, interest rate changes affect the fair market value of such debt, but do not impact earnings or cash flow.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Currency risk arises when future commercial transactions or recognized assets or liabilities are denominated in a currency that is not the functional currency of the Group entity holding the asset or obligation. As a result of our operations in various countries, we generate a significant portion of our sales and incur a significant portion of our expenses in currencies other than the euro. Our primary exposure is to the Serbian dinar. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, 15% of our revenue was denominated in Serbian dinars. The Bosnia and Herzegovinian mark is pegged to the euro, while the Croatian kuna and North Macedonian dinar are relatively stable. In March 2015, we entered into a EUR/USD currency hedge agreement, pursuant to which we hedge our exposure to the U.S. dollar. We entered into an additional EUR/USD currency hedge agreement in May 2016 pursuant to which we hedged the remaining portion of our exposure to the U.S. dollar for 2016. In February 2017, we entered into an additional EUR/USD currency hedge, which hedged most of our 2017 U.S. dollar exposure. Based on our lack of any material change in exposure to the U.S. dollar in the three months ended March 31, 2021, we did not enter into any additional currency hedge agreements during the three months ended March 31, 2021. As the Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro, we do not expect to hedge against exposure to the Bulgarian lev.

Section Title: THE COMPANY’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Translation risk is the risk that the value in euro of the consolidated profit and loss statement and balance sheet will fluctuate due to changes in foreign exchange rates connected with the translation of our subsidiaries that do not have the euro as their functional currency. Since January 1, 2016, almost all our indebtedness has been denominated in euros.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Transaction risk is the risk of exchange losses incurred by us through purchases and sales in currencies other than the local currency of the relevant subsidiaries.

Subsubsection Text: _The following review relates to the Company’s financial condition and results of operations as of and for the periods discussed below. “The Company’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” is based on the historical financial data included in this offering memorandum and should be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial Data,” “Summary of Company and Group Run-Rate, Vivacom, Unaudited Pro Forma and Certain Other Financial Data,” “Selected Company Historical Financial Data,” the Company Audited Financial Statements and the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements included in this offering memorandum.
