Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We acquired Vivacom in the Vivacom Acquisition on July 31, 2020. Since the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition, Vivacom’s results have been consolidated with ours as part of our Bulgaria Group segment. Vivacom is the market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria (based on revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020) offering both fixed and mobile telecommunications services, as well as broadcasting and satellite services, with a market share of 30% in Bulgaria by revenue as of December 31, 2020, according to the CRC. Vivacom provides mobile, broadband, fixed-telephony, and Pay-TV (both DTH and IPTV) services in Bulgaria to residential and business customers. Vivacom is the leading operator of fixed-line telephony services in Bulgaria (60% market share), the leading provider of broadband in Bulgaria (27% market share), the number three provider of mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria (29% market share in the three player mobile market) and the number three provider of Pay-TV in Bulgaria (26% market share), in each case, as of December 31, 2020, based on the number of subscribers, according to the CRC. Vivacom has consistently taken market share across most of its segments in recent years. Vivacom as of March 31, 2021, had 2,961 million mobile subscribers, 573 thousand fixed-line telephony subscribers, 464 thousand fixed broadband subscribers and 489 thousand Pay-TV subscribers. Vivacom operates a well invested, fully owned and integrated fiber backbone network and has an extensive fiber to the home / fiber to the business network in Bulgaria. It also operates the fastest mobile network in Bulgaria, with an award-winning LTE network, covering 99% of the population. The quality of Vivacom’s network, implementation of operational efficiencies and consolidation of services under one brand have led to high customer satisfaction and decreasing churn rates. Bulgaria is a relatively large, economically stable and mostly urban nation of seven million people and three million households. Bulgaria presents an attractive market, with rational and growing mobile markets, with a high and growing share of the market consisting mostly of post-paid mobile subscriptions, with increasing broadband penetration and migration to IPTV. Bulgaria presents a favorable business environment with average real GDP growth of 3.3% each year between 2017 and 2019 (according to the BNSI), compared to the euro area average of 1.9% during the same period, according to the IMF, a flat corporate income tax and low public debt compared to the EU average. The Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro. Vivacom has historically been consistently profitable, with Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA having increased by a CAGR of 9% between 2018 and 2020 and Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA margin (calculated as Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue) was 45% for the year ended December 31, 2020, and cash generative, with an attractive adjusted capital expenditure and adjusted operating free cash flow profile, with Vivacom Operating Free Cash Flow having increased by a CAGR of 24% between 2018 and 2020.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom generates most of its revenue from the provision of mobile services and fixed-line voice telephony and data services (including Pay-TV). Vivacom also provides TV and radio broadcasting services through its NURTS business segment. Vivacom believes that its ability to provide nationwide bundled offerings (“dual play, “triple play” or “quadruple play”) provides an important competitive advantage. ----- The table below sets forth a breakdown of Vivacom’s revenue for the periods indicated.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom generates revenue from access and interconnection fees received from other network operators for calls terminated on its network, and it is required to pay access and interconnection fees to other network operators for calls terminated on their networks, in each case both domestic and international. These access and interconnection fees are based on set termination rates for both fixed-line calls (“FTRs”) and mobile calls, which affect both mobile and fixed-telephony revenues and costs. Termination rates are regulated by the Communications Regulation Commission (“CRC”) in Bulgaria.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Many European countries have faced or are facing an economic slowdown or low rates of GDP growth, including as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which may include a general contraction in consumer spending resulting from, among other factors, reduced consumer confidence, falling gross domestic product, declining populations, rising or stagnating unemployment rates and uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment. Although the general economic climate in Bulgaria has also seen negative effects, the Bulgarian ----- economy has historically demonstrated economic growth and fiscal stability with low levels of government debt. According to the BNSI, Bulgaria’s real GDP grew at an average rate of 3.3% each year between 2017 and 2019. Following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, on March 13, 2020 the Bulgarian parliament declared a state of emergency in Bulgaria and on March 23, 2020, it adopted certain measures and actions aimed at mitigating the negative consequences of the pandemic on citizens and businesses. Subsequently, similar extraordinary measures were introduced, some of which are still in effect since May 14, 2020. The Bulgarian Minister of Healthcare and the Bulgarian parliament adopted several social distancing and other restrictive measures, particularly with respect to access to restaurants, shopping centers and other commercial facilities, aimed at managing the spread of the pandemic, which have had a material adverse impact on the overall economy of Bulgaria. As of the date of this offering memorandum, even though the most restrictive social distancing measures were lifted and the Bulgarian government has implemented economic recovery measures while new infections have decreased, certain restrictions and social distancing measures remain in place, and additional restrictions could be reinstated at any time and at different levels as new variants of the virus spread. Such existing and potential measures may continue to adversely affect the overall economy of Bulgaria and could have a material adverse impact on Vivacom’s results of operations, in particular on its ARPUs and roaming revenues. However, these effects have been partially offset by the decrease in interconnect and roaming expenses. A potential prolonged recession and a deepening economic crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic could impact Vivacom’s growth prospects, customer spending and collection, and may result in assumptions and estimates that could trigger material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in the future. Vivacom operates in the telecommunications sector, for which underlying customer demand has in the past been less cyclical than a number of other areas of consumer spending. However, the general macroeconomic environment could still have an adverse effect on consumer spending. In poor economic conditions, consumers are likely to delay the replacement of their existing mobile phones or may be more likely to disconnect or cancel their services. Generally, weak economic conditions may weigh on the growth prospects of the telecommunications market in Bulgaria, which in turn may negatively impact Vivacom’s number of subscribers and ARPU.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom faces competition from the two other major Bulgarian mobile network operators, A1 Bulgaria and Telenor Bulgaria, each of which holds a greater share of the mobile market than does Vivacom. Vivacom’s mobile service revenue market share was approximately 29% as of December 31, 2020 according to the CRC. Vivacom is the market leader in the fixed broadband market, with a 27% subscriber market share as of December 31, 2020, followed by A1 Bulgaria and Bulsatcom, according to the CRC. In the Bulgarian fixed broadband market, Vivacom competes primarily with A1 Bulgaria, Telenor Bulgaria, Bulsatcom and a significant number of small-scale regional operators. Many of the small-scale operators are considered to operate in the “grey market”as they do not pay taxes or license fees and use illegal aerial cables to deliver their fixed broadband services, which gives them an anticompetitive advantage, as they are able to offer lower priced fixed broadband products. If the enforcement of regulations against “grey market”operators increases, as Vivacom management expects, its penetration rate is expected to increase. Vivacom’s primary competitors have pursued aggressive marketing and pricing strategies to retain and expand their respective market shares which, if further pursued in the future, could reduce Vivacom’s margins, cause Vivacom to increase its marketing and promotional expenses in response to such strategies and result in increased customer churn. In addition, the competitive nature of the market in which Vivacom operates may be exacerbated by new market entrants or the consolidation of some of its primary competitors. Vivacom tries to avoid direct price competition and believes that its revenues and profitability will be supported by continued growth in the number of its subscribers, cross-selling and up selling of services, the launch of innovative new services and the active management of its subscriber acquisition, maintenance and retention costs.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Mobile_ Vivacom’s mobile segment comprises its mobile services, both voice and data, and its other mobile business, which includes among other things, the sale of mobile handsets. Vivacom’s mobile revenue is principally driven by its average number of subscribers and ARPU. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenue generated by Vivacom’s mobile segment comprised 63% of its total revenue. The Bulgarian mobile market is characterized by high penetration rates and high levels of competition. As a result, Vivacom’s mobile subscriber base depends on a number of factors, including pricing, quality of service, availability of new services, overall market growth, the level of competition to obtain new subscribers, retaining existing subscribers, its ability to cause existing subscribers to use their Vivacom SIM card as their primary SIM card (rather than as an alternate SIM card) and general economic conditions in Bulgaria. As a result of more customer favorable tariffs, including minutes to other operators and high data consumption limits, Vivacom believes that mobile subscribers will gradually cease using multiple SIM cards but rather choose one mobile operator. Mobile services ARPU is driven primarily by recurring charges from post-paid subscribers, traffic volume, data services utilization, revenue from interconnection rates and its prices. Vivacom’s prices, in turn, are mainly driven by the level of competition and the increasing demand for mobile data. Ultimately, Vivacom management believes that the increasing demand for mobile data is leading to increasing ARPU due to the higher contributions from data ARPU. _Fixed-line_ Vivacom’s fixed-line segment comprises its fixed voice services, fixed data services, fixed Pay-TV services and other fixed business, which includes its wholesale duct rental business. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenue generated by Vivacom’s fixed-line segment comprised 36% of its total revenue. Fixed-Voice: Fixed-telephony and Other Vivacom’s fixed voice services include fixed-telephony and other fixed voice services. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenues generated by Vivacom’s fixed voice services comprised 7% of its total revenue. Fixed-telephony subscriber levels depend on a number of factors, including pricing, the availability of new services and technologies, Vivacom’s ability to retain existing subscribers and win subscribers from competitors as well as general economic conditions in Bulgaria. Vivacom’s fixed-telephony subscriber numbers are gradually declining due to fixed-to-mobile substitution by customers and mobile operators’ fixedtelephony offerings, which undercut its prices and attract price sensitive customers. Wholesale traffic consists primarily of international transit traffic passing through Vivacom’s network to other national or international operators. Vivacom’s wholesale traffic business has low margins and is susceptible to volume volatility depending on the transit prices it sets, which transit prices change based on its wholesale interconnect expenses. ----- Fixed-Data: Fixed Broadband and Other Fixed data revenue, which includes revenue from fixed broadband and other data services is principally affected by the average number of subscribers and ARPU, which in turn depend on Vivacom’s prices and the speed and quality of connections that it is able to provide to its customers. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenue generated by Vivacom’s fixed data services comprised 9% of its total revenue. Vivacom’s fixed data services comprises its fixed broadband services provided over ADSL, VDSL and FTTx connections to both residential and business customers and other data services, which include complex IP based data solutions for large business customers (including VPN and MAN services) as well as its “legacy” leased lines services that are mainly used by its security conscious business customers, such as financial institutions, who are looking for dedicated data capacity. If the enforcement of regulations against “grey market” operators increases as expected, the penetration rate of fixed data services is likely to grow. Additionally, subscribers are seeking higher broadband speeds and better connection quality, which are priced at a premium. Revenue from other fixed data services is generated from Vivacom’s professional internet, IP VPN and MAN services and complex corporate data solutions offered to business customers, as well as the sale of CPEs. The provision of additional services, nationwide offerings and quality backed service level agreements contribute to Vivacom’s ARPU. Fixed pay-TV Vivacom launched its DTH television service in 2010 and IPTV service in 2012, and is currently positioned as a fully integrated “quadruple play”operator offering nationwide coverage in Bulgaria. Vivacom’s DTH service delivers television content directly to its customers’ homes via satellite while its IPTV service is a fully digitalized platform delivering television content via Internet connectivity, which provides a variety of television channels, video on demand and a range of interactive features, including its over-the-top TV solution, TV GO. Vivacom’s Pay-TV revenue is principally driven by the number of subscribers and the services that they select. Vivacom offers a variety of services through both DTH and IPTV, including packages with over 240 channels that include more than 75 HD channels, exclusive content and other interactive services on its IPTV platform. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenue generated by Vivacom’s fixed Pay-TV services comprised 10% of its total revenue. Fixed-Other Vivacom’s other fixed businesses are comprised of various services. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenues generated by Vivacom’s other fixed business accounted for 11% of its total revenue. These include wholesale services to other licensed telecommunications operations, such as duct rental and collocation of equipment. Various digital and cloud services, including cloud IaaS, managed cloud VPS, shared web and e-mail hosting, SSL certificates, collocation, fleet management platform and others are also offered to business customers. Vivacom’s specific projects under the “VIVA Smart” brand, including smart city, Internet of Things (“IoT”), video surveillance, electronic education and other innovative solutions are also areas of potential expansion.

Subsubsection Text: Penetration rate of mobile service in Bulgaria . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 120% 117% 115% Market share based on number of subscribers[(1)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 28% 28% 29% Source: Bulgarian Communications Regulatory Agency; Vivacom’s estimates for penetration rate in the year ended December 31, 2020. (1) Based on the number of SIM cards in use and does not include subscribers of MVNOs. Vivacom’s mobile subscriber base consists primarily of residential subscribers and, in line with the Bulgarian mobile telecommunications market, the vast majority of its subscribers are post-paid subscribers. As of December 31, 2020, 88% of Vivacom’s total mobile subscriber base consisted of post-paid subscribers. All of Vivacom’s business subscribers are post-paid subscribers. Vivacom’s mobile subscriber base has decreased from 2,985 thousand subscribers as of December 31, 2019 to 2,954 thousand subscribers as of December 31, 2020. The decrease was mainly attributable to the post-paid subscriber base as a result of the ongoing SIM card consolidation trend in the mobile market. Blended mobile ARPU increased by 8% to BGN 13.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020, from BGN 12.5 for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to increased data usage as a result of growing demand for data. Blended mobile ARPU increased by 9% to BGN 12.5 for the year ended December 31, 2019, from BGN 11.4 for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to an increase in data usage as a result of growing smartphone penetration and strong demand for data. According to the CRC, the total number of subscribers in Bulgaria has declined by a CAGR of 2% between December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2019, to 8.1 million subscribers, corresponding to a mobile penetration rate of 117% as of December 31, 2019. This decrease is mainly as a result of the ongoing SIM card consolidation trend in the mobile market.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _IFRS 16 Leases_ Under IFRS 16, a lessee is required to recognize assets and liabilities for principally all leases on its balance sheet. Vivacom adopted the new standard on January 1, 2019 but has not restated comparatives for the 2018 ----- reporting period. The reclassifications and the adjustments arising from the new leasing rules are recognized on Vivacom’s opening balance sheet on January 1, 2019. On transition to IFRS 16, Vivacom recognized an additional BGN 258,676 thousand of right-of-use assets and BGN 259,403 thousand of lease liabilities.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Fixed-telephony subscribers (thousands) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 689 593 524 Fixed-telephony ARPU (BGN) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 9.9 10.1 10.2 Fixed broadband subscribers (thousands) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 444 459 475 Of which FTTx (%) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 65% 69% 72% Fixed broadband ARPU (BGN) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 9.5 10.2 10.1 Homes passed by fiber (thousands) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1,182 1,240 1,266 Fixed pay-TV subscribers (thousands) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 468 490 516 Of which IPTV (%) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49% 53% 55% Fixed pay-TV ARPU (BGN) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 15.2 16.7 17.5 ----- Fixed-telephony Vivacom’s total fixed-telephony subscribers decreased by 12% to 524 thousand as of December 31, 2020, from 593 thousand as of December 31, 2019. The decrease in fixed-telephony subscribers was primarily due to the strong price competition surrounding fixed-telephony services, where such services are being offered at a low price addition to Vivacom’s competitors’ mobile, fixed broadband and Pay-TV services. Vivacom’s total fixed-telephony subscribers decreased by 14% to 593 thousand as of December 31, 2019, from 689 thousand as of December 31, 2018. Both decreases in fixed-telephony subscribers were primarily due to strong price competition for fixed-telephony services, where such services are being offered as a low price addition to Vivacom’s competitors’ mobile, fixed broadband and Pay-TV services. Total fixed-telephony ARPU increased by 1% to BGN 10.2 for the year ended December 31, 2020, from BGN 10.1 for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in total fixed-telephony ARPU was primarily due to increased take-up of more generous tariffs with higher monthly recurring charges. Total fixed-telephony ARPU increased by 2% to BGN 10.1 for the year ended December 31, 2019, from BGN 9.9 for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase in total fixed-telephony ARPU was primarily due to the introduction of more generous tariffs with included minutes by destinations. Fixed Broadband Vivacom’s fixed broadband subscribers increased by 3% to 475 thousand as of December 31, 2020, from 459 thousand as of December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly due to higher FTTx connections driven by growing demand for high-speed bandwidth capacity and reliable broadband service. Vivacom’s total fixed broadband subscribers increased by 3% to 459 thousand as of December 31, 2019, from 444 thousand as at December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly due to higher FTTx connections driven by growing demand for high-speed bandwidth capacity and reliable broadband service. Vivacom’s fixed broadband ARPU decreased by 0.1% to BGN 10.1 for the year ended December 31, 2020, from BGN 10.2 for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to bundling discounts and price competition from other alternative operators, which were partially offset by a growing share of tariffs with high bandwidth capacity. Vivacom’s total fixed broadband ARPU increased by 7% to BGN 10.2 for the year ended December 31, 2019, from BGN 9.5 for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to a growing share of tariffs with high bandwidth capacity, despite bundling discounts and price competition from alternative operators. Fixed Pay-TV Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV subscribers increased by 5% to 516 thousand as of December 31, 2020, from 490 thousand as of December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly due to the increased demand for high-quality services with superior user experience, rich content and HD channels. Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV subscribers also increased 5% to 490 thousand as of December 31, 2019, from 468 thousand as of December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly due to the increased demand for high-quality services with superior user experience, rich content and HD channels. Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV ARPU increased by 5% to BGN 17.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020, from BGN 16.7 for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly attributable to the growing share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees and additional packages with rich content and sports channels. Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV ARPU also increased by 10% to BGN 16.7 for the year ended December 31, 2019, from BGN 15.2 for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly attributable to the growing share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees and additional packages with rich content.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom’s revenue recognition policy comprises all revenues from the ordinary business activities, including not only revenues generated by core businesses, but also other recurring sales of goods or rendering of services, and income from contractual penalties and default interest. Revenues are recognized net of value added tax in accordance with the provision of goods or services. Gains from sales of property, plant and equipment, investment property or intangible assets are not classified as revenue but presented in other gains and losses, net. Following the mandatory implementation of IFRS 15 effective as of January 1, 2018, Vivacom presents its revenues in three main categories. _Services Revenue_ Services revenue is generated from principal activities including provision of mobile and fixed voice and data services, broadband internet access, Pay-TV services (DTH and IPTV), rent of terrestrial network (ducts), TV and radio broadcasting, collocation services, connection and roaming fees billed to other operators. Services revenue is recognized upon rendering of the agreed service. Services are usually billed and paid for on a monthly basis. For service contracts with a continuous service provision, the contractually agreed total consideration is recognized as revenue on a straight-line basis over the minimum contract term, regardless of the payment pattern. _Equipment Revenue_ Equipment revenue comprises the sale or lease of mobile handsets, other telecommunications equipment, and accessories. Revenue associated with the sale of telecommunications equipment and accessories are recognized when the products are delivered, provided there are no unfulfilled obligations that affect the customer’s final acceptance of the arrangement. For telecommunications equipment sold separately, customers pay in full at the point of sale. For devices sold or lease in combination with a term service contract, customers usually pay monthly in equal instalments over a period of 12 or 24 months. _Other Revenue_ Other revenue primarily includes penalties, revenues from marketing activities and revenues from assigned overdue customer receivables, commission fees and rental income.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom’s fixed-line revenue, which is comprised of fixed voice (fixed-telephony and other), fixed data (fixed broadband and other), fixed Pay-TV (IPTV and DTH) and other fixed-line services was BGN 356.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 5.2 million, or 1.5%, from BGN 351.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase was mainly attributable to the increase in fixed Pay-TV revenues due to a growing share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees and additional packages with rich content and sports channels, which was partially offset by strong price competition in fixed-telephony and bundling discounts and price competition from other alternative operators in fixed data. Vivacom’s mobile revenue was BGN 650.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 24.2 million, or 4%, from BGN 626.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in mobile revenue was mainly attributable to higher revenue from mobile data and a growing share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees as a result of our smart “more for more” offerings and the quality of our mobile network. Vivacom’s NURTS revenue was BGN 36.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, An increase of BGN 0.7 million, or 1% from BGN 36.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly attributable to higher revenue from services provided by the NURTS Group. _Interconnect Expense_ Vivacom’s interconnect expense was BGN 82.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 1.4 million, or 2%, from BGN 80.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This was mainly due to higher mobile outbound traffic to other national mobile operators. _Materials and Consumables Expenses_ Vivacom’s materials and consumables expenses were BGN 178.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 11.9 million, or 7%, from BGN 166.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, which was mainly attributable to higher expenses for CPEs, handsets and devices. _Other Operating Expenses_ Vivacom’s other operating expenses were BGN 168.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a decrease of BGN 1.7 million, or 1%, from BGN 169.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to lower other net expenses, professional fees, facilities expenses, license fee expenses and maintenance and repairs expenses, partially offset by higher advertising, customer service, billing and collection and administrative expenses, leased lines and data transmission expenses and vehicles and transports expenses. Higher advertising, customer service and billing and collection expenses was driven by higher content costs for television rights. Administrative expenses increased mainly as a result of non-recurring payments for ----- settlement of legal disputes. Increases in leased lines and data transmission was primarily related to higher costs for international internet access and peering. _Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets_ Vivacom’s net impairment losses on financial and contract assets were BGN 7.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a decrease of BGN 1.8 million, or 18%, from BGN 9.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily as a result of the reversal of previously impaired receivables, partially offset by certain delays in customer payments due to the COVID-19 pandemic reflected in higher expected credit losses. _Staff Costs_ Vivacom’s staff costs were BGN 161.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 22.9 million, or 16.5%, from BGN 138.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly resulting from one-off payments to management personnel and governing bodies. _Depreciation and Amortization_ Vivacom’s depreciation and amortization costs were BGN 250.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 5.9 million, or 2%, from BGN 244.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Depreciation of right-of-use assets amounted to BGN 48.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. _Finance Costs_ Vivacom’s finance costs were BGN 54.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 11.8 million, or 27%, from BGN 43.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase related primarily due to the settlement of Vivacom’s senior facilities agreement and related hedges. _Finance Income_ Vivacom’s finance income was BGN 20.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 11.9 million from BGN 8.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly attributable to interest income on loans granted to related parties, which were fully settled upon completion of the Vivacom Acquisition. _Other Gains and Losses, Net_ Other gains and losses, net were a net loss of BGN 2.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a decrease of BGN 7.0 million from a net gain of BGN 4.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The decrease was attributable to changes in fair value of investment properties and lower sales of non-core assets, mainly non-operational buildings and properties. _Income Tax Expenses_ Income tax expense was BGN 14.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a decrease of BGN 1.3 million, from BGN 15.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, which was driven mainly by a lower current income tax charge. _Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA_ The following table presents a reconciliation of Vivacom EBITDA and Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA from Vivacom’s profit for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom’s fixed-line revenue, which is comprised of fixed voice (fixed-telephony and other), fixed data (fixed broadband and other), fixed Pay-TV (IPTV and DTH) and other fixed-line services was BGN 351.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 16.2 million, or 5%, from BGN 335.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase was mainly attributable to the growth in fixed broadband and fixed Pay-TV revenues, despite the downward pressure of declining fixed voice services. Vivacom’s mobile revenue was BGN 626.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 29.5 million, or 5%, from BGN 596.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase in mobile revenue was mainly attributable to Vivacom’s smart “more for more” offerings and the quality of its mobile network. Vivacom’s NURTS revenue was BGN 36.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 1.6 million, or 4% from BGN 37.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly attributable to lower revenue from services provided by NURTS Group. _Interconnect Expense_ Vivacom’s interconnect expense was BGN 80.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 3.0 million, or 4%, from BGN 77.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This was mainly due to an increase in mobile outbound traffic to other national mobile operators. ----- _Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets_ Vivacom’s net impairment losses on financial and contract assets were BGN 9.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 1.7 million, or 15%, from BGN 11.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 as a result of improved collections reflected in expected credit losses. _Materials and Consumables Expenses_ Vivacom’s materials and consumables expenses were BGN 166.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 5.3 million, or 3%, from BGN 172.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, which was mainly attributable to lower expenses for CPEs and subsidies for handsets. _Other Operating Expenses_ Vivacom’s other operating expenses were BGN 169.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 33.7 million, or 17%, from BGN 203.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to transitional effects related to the implementation of IFRS 16 which was effective as of January 1, 2019. These transitional effects have reflected facilities expenses, vehicles and transports expenses, leased lines and data transmission expenses and advertising, customer service, billing and collection expenses. The effect on facilities expenses was mainly due to rental of commercial properties, technical premises and offices. The effect on vehicles and transport expenses consisted of fleet lease charges. The impact on leased lines and data transmission was due to rented capacity for satellite transmission used for broadcasting services. The effect on advertising, customer service, billing and collection expenses was mainly related to satellite capacity charges for the DTH-TV platform. _Staff Costs_ Vivacom’s staff costs were BGN 138.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 5.9 million, or 4%, from BGN 132.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly resulting from an increase in average salaries. _Depreciation and Amortization_ Vivacom’s depreciation and amortization costs were BGN 244.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 46.0 million, or 23%, from BGN 198.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly due to transitional effects related to the implementation of IFRS 16 and subsequent recognition of right-of-use assets. Depreciation of right-of-use assets amounted to BGN 46.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. _Finance Costs_ Vivacom’s finance costs were BGN 43.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 2.1 million, or 5%, from BGN 40.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase related primarily to the accounting treatment of leases following the adoption of IFRS 16, which was partially offset by lower interest expenses under Vivacom’s €365 million senior facilities agreement. _Finance Income_ Vivacom’s finance income was BGN 8.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 1.4 million, or 18%, from BGN 7.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly attributable to higher interest income on granted loans and income from lease contracts. _Other Gains, Net_ Other gains, net were BGN 4.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 12.8 million, or 73%, from BGN 17.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The higher amount for the year ended December 31, 2018 was due to the one-off effect of a refund for a prepayment to Bulgarian tax authorities. _Income Tax Expenses_ Income tax expense was BGN 15.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of BGN 7.3 million, from BGN 8.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, which was driven mainly by a higher current income tax charge reflecting the higher net profit for the period and a lower deferred tax charge. ----- _Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA_ The following table presents a reconciliation of Vivacom EBITDA and Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA from Vivacom’s profit for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2019.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom’s liquidity requirements arise primarily from the need to fund capital expenditures for the expansion and maintenance of its network operations, both in terms of quality of services and innovative technologies, for working capital and to repay debt. Historically, Vivacom’s principal sources of liquidity have been cash flows from operating activities, which include revenues generated by its mobile and fixed-line subscribers, periodically as supplemented by borrowings under certain debt facilities. Vivacom’s ability to generate cash from operations will depend on its future operating performance, which in turn is dependent on various factors, including but not limited to those described under “—Key Factors _Affecting Results of Operations,”many of which are beyond its control. If Vivacom’s cash flow from operating_ activities is lower than expected, or its capital expenditure requirements exceed its projections, Vivacom may be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. On July 31, 2020, United Group Bulgaria EOOD granted a related party loan to Vivacom with a maturity of ten years and bullet repayment at maturity. With the funds received under such related party loan, Vivacom pre-paid all liabilities under a senior debt facility that was due in 2023. As a result, Vivacom reduced its exposure to long-term third-party financings, which improved the ability to manage its liquidity requirements going forward. Vivacom believes that its operating cash flows and borrowing capacity will be sufficient to meet requirements and commitments for the foreseeable future. Vivacom’s actual financing requirements will depend on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial institutions and capital markets, Vivacom’s liquidity situation, restrictions in the instruments governing its debt, and its general financial performance, the future projects it could undertake and the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic could have on any of such factors. In particular, any prolonged economic crisis or ----- recession caused by the COVID-19 pandemic could negatively impact customer spending and collections and, in turn, have a material adverse effect on Vivacom’s liquidity position. Vivacom maintains cash and cash equivalents to fund the day-to-day requirements of its business. Vivacom holds cash primarily in Bulgarian levs and euros.

For the year ended December 31, 2019, net cash flows from operating activities increased by BGN 120.7 million to BGN 401.3 million, compared to BGN 280.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly as a result of better operating performance and optimization in inventories. For the year ended December 31, 2019, net cash flows used in investing activities decreased by BGN 199.1 million to BGN 192.4 million, from BGN 391.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly due to a lower amount of loans granted to related parties, partially offset by higher acquisitions of property, plant, equipment and intangible assets in line with Vivacom’s capital expenditure investment program but with timing variances in payments pattern. _Net Cash used in Financing Activities_ For the year ended December 31, 2020, net cash flows used in financing activities increased by BGN 99.5 million to BGN 264.9 million, from BGN 165.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 main e to dividends paid and higher payments of lease liabilities, partially offset by lower usage of borrowings. Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) With effect from January 1, 2020, Vivacom no longer reports NURTS (comprising its wholly-owned subsidiaries NURTS Bulgaria EAD and NURTS Digital EAD) as a separate capital expenditure category and the relevant amounts are included under the other respective categories (mainly network). As a result, capital expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2019 were reclassified to remove NURTS as a separate capital expenditure category in line with the change effective from January 1, 2020. (2) The figures for the year ended December 31, 2018 included in the table above were not restated to reflect the adoption of IFRS 16, which was adopted as of January 1, 2019 under the modified retrospective approach, and therefore they may not be comparable with the figures for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 presented therein. For the year months ended December 31, 2020, capital expenditures amounted to BGN 199.8 million, which consisted of: - BGN 98.4 million of capital expenditures relating to network activities, mainly for investment in our mobile radio access network, mobile core and transmission network, fixed core network, TV platform and FTTx roll-out projects; - BGN 27.4 million of capital expenditures relating to IT activities, primarily related to IT infrastructure acquisitions and business support systems; - BGN 45.3 million of capital expenditures relating to commercial and other activities, mainly for CPEs to support Vivacom’s growing Pay-TV, fiber and fixed wireless subscriber base, as well as capitalized contract acquisitions and contract fulfillment costs; - BGN 0.1 million relating to Vivacom’s network infrastructure license fees; - BGN 28.6 million rights of use relating to the acquisition of rental rights and leases treated under IFRS 16. For the year ended December 31, 2019, capital expenditures amounted to BGN 205.3 million, which consisted of: - BGN 119.4 million of capital expenditures relating to network activities, mainly for investment in Vivacom’s mobile radio access network, mobile core and transmission network, fixed core network, TV platform and FTTx and VDSL roll out projects; - BGN 22.0 million of capital expenditures relating to IT activities, primarily related to business support systems and IT infrastructure acquisitions; ----- - BGN 46.1 million of capital expenditures relating to commercial and other activities, mainly for CPEs to support Vivacom’s growing Pay-TV, fiber and fixed wireless subscriber base, as well as capitalized contract acquisition and contract fulfilment costs; - BGN 0.5 million relating to Vivacom’s network infrastructure license fees; and - BGN 17.3 million right-of-use relating to acquisition of rights of use treated under IFRS 16. For the year ended December 31, 2018, capital expenditures amounted to BGN 202.3 million (which includes the impact of IFRS 15), which consisted of: - BGN 129.7 million of capital expenditures relating to network activities, mainly for investment in Vivacom’s mobile radio access network, mobile core and transmission network, fixed core network, TV platform and FTTx and VDSL roll out projects; - BGN 18.5 million of capital expenditures relating to IT activities, primarily related to IT infrastructure acquisitions and business support systems; - BGN 51.6 million of capital expenditures relating to commercial and other activities, mainly for CPEs to support Vivacom’s growing Pay-TV and fiber subscriber base, as well as sales commissions related to long-term contracts; and - BGN 1.9 million of capital expenditures relating to maintenance of NURTS infrastructure. In line with Vivacom’s historical strategy, the amounts it spends and the time at which expenditures are made will depend upon a variety of factors including current and anticipated subscriber demands and Vivacom’s own targets relating to a desired mix of subscriber base, which is determined by its evolving business plan. Vivacom’s capital expenditure plans are also affected by and updated for changing general economic conditions.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2020, Vivacom did not have any off balance sheet arrangements, as disclosed in the notes to the Vivacom Unaudited Interim Financial Statements and summarized in “—Contractual Obligations.”

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom’s foreign exchange rate risk exposure mainly relates to its exposure to U.S. dollars, mainly from committed purchases of certain network equipment, satellite capacity and content. Vivacom manages its foreign currency exchange rate risk related to future supplies denominated in USD by hedging the exposure through forward contracts. All forward contracts are entered into with credible counterparties. When a significant exposure to foreign currency arises, Vivacom takes into account the following factors: - future outlook on the volatility of financial market variables, which are modeled by Vivacom’s treasury department and are in accordance with best practice analytical techniques and economic models; - effect of the given foreign exchange exposure on Vivacom’s financial results; and - the cost of foreign exposure hedging. -----

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk of financial loss arising from Vivacom’s counterparties’ inability to repay or service debt in accordance with the contractual terms. Credit risk includes both the direct risk of default and the risk of a deterioration of creditworthiness, as well as concentration risks. Vivacom believes it has appropriate credit policies, procedures and authorization guidelines in place to manage and monitor credit risk. Vivacom’s credit risk is principally associated with trade and other receivables. Vivacom seeks to minimize credit risk through the application of monthly subscription contracts, initial credit checks, credit limits and credit monitoring procedures. Vivacom also seeks to minimize credit risk by obtaining cash deposits from its retail customers and distributors where it perceives credit risk to exist. Vivacom believes that its implementation of the foregoing procedures has led to experiencing a limited amount of credit losses. Expenses for receivables written off are recognized in other operating expenses in the profit or loss for a given period. For 2018, 2019 and 2020, BGN 174 thousand, BGN 195 thousand and BGN 102 thousand, respectively, of receivables were written off. In addition, Vivacom’s allowance for impairment of receivables in the statement of financial position as of December 31, 2018, December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020 amounted to BGN 105,512 thousand, BGN 97,547 thousand and BGN 40,864 thousand, respectively for all trade and other receivables not written off, including CCB. Furthermore, as a general rule, Vivacom’s has no significant level of credit concentration related to accounts receivable. Credit risk relating to cash and cash equivalents, derivative financial instruments, financial deposits and money market funds arises from the risk that the counterparty becomes insolvent and accordingly is unable to return the deposited funds or execute the obligations under the derivative transactions as a result of the insolvency. To mitigate this risk, wherever possible Vivacom conducts transactions and deposit funds with investment grade rated financial institutions and monitor and limit the concentration of its transactions with any single party. Additionally, due to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, net impairment losses on financial and contract assets increased as a result of delays in customer payments during the second quarter of 2020, resulting respectively in higher expected credit losses rates and an increase in the allowance for impairment of trade and lease receivables measured by applying the IFRS 9 simplified approach. However, on a full-year basis, in the year ended December 31, 2020 both net impairment losses on financial and contract assets and the allowance for impairment of trade and lease receivables decreased compared to 2019. We believe that during the first quarter of 2021, Vivacom’s ability to collect receivables improved and as of March 31, 2021, it has returned to close to pre-COVID-19 levels.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that Vivacom may have difficulty in obtaining funds in order to meet both its day-to-day operating requirements and debt servicing obligations (interest and debt repayments). This arises mostly in connection with the contractual maturity of Vivacom’s monetary assets and liabilities that result from business activities and from the possibility that its trade debtors may not be able to settle their payment obligations within the normal terms of trade. Vivacom monitors its liquidity requirements and aims to mitigate liquidity risk through monitoring cash flows, ensuring the availability of overdraft facilities and preparing daily liquidity reports. Short and medium term cash flow forecasting is performed by its treasury department. These forecasts are monitored to ensure Vivacom’s cash and liquidity requirements are sufficient to meet operational needs and to monitor compliance with borrowing limits and debt covenants on its borrowing facilities. Any prolonged economic crisis or recession due to the COVID-19 pandemic could have a significant impact on Vivacom’s growth prospects. However, Vivacom continues to generate profits and sufficient cash from operations, supporting its activities and contractual commitments.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom is exposed to various market risks, including foreign currency exchange rate and interest rate risk, credit and liquidity risks associated with its underlying assets, liabilities, forecast transactions and firm commitments. Vivacom’s treasury department is responsible for managing exposure to market risks that arise in connection with operations and financial activities, including foreign currency exchange rate, credit and liquidity risk management. These risks are identified, measured and monitored through various control mechanisms so that Vivacom can establish adequate prices for the services it provides, appropriately assess the market circumstances related to its investments and maintain free liquid funds to prevent undue concentration of a particular risk. The following sections discuss Vivacom’s most significant exposures to market risk. The following discussions do not address other risks that Vivacom faces in the normal course of business, including country, political, regulatory and legal risks.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The rapid development of COVID-19 and its social and economic impact in Bulgaria and globally, may result in assumptions and estimates requiring revisions which may lead to material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities within the next financial year. Following a resurgence of COVID-19 infections in late ----- 2020, the government-imposed lockdown measures in November 2020. Infections decreased and certain measures were lifted but most remained in force until the end of January 2021. Vivacom’s operations were not restricted by the lockdown, and the impact on its financial position and performance remained in line with the disclosure in the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020. Any prolonged economic crisis or recession due to the COVID-19 pandemic could impact Vivacom’s growth prospects, customer spending and collection, and may result in assumptions and estimates that could trigger material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in the future. In particular, management expects the assumptions and estimates used in determining impairment of Trade and other receivables, Contract assets, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets, Right-of-use assets and valuation of Investment property, and the related Deferred tax assets and liabilities to be affected. Management is not able to reliably estimate these impact as events are unfolding day by day. The COVID-19 pandemic had a negative impact on Mobile services revenue due to lower roaming revenue, primarily as a result of the COVID-19 related travel restrictions. This was partially offset by a decrease in interconnection and roaming expenses. Further impacts on service revenues are limited by the increased demand for telecom services during the periods in which the COVID-19 related restrictions were implemented. The longer term impact of the COVID-19 pandemic may also affect trading volumes, cash flows and profitability. The COVID-19 pandemic did not have an impact on the other critical accounting estimates and judgements disclosed in the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the years ended December 31, 2020. The discussion and analysis of Vivacom’s results of operations and financial condition are based on the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 disclosed in Note 4 thereof, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS. The preparation of these financial statements requires management to apply accounting methods and policies that are based on difficult or subjective judgments, estimates based on past experience and assumptions determined to be reasonable and realistic based on the related circumstances. The application of these estimates and assumptions affects the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the balance sheet date and the reported amounts of income and expenses during the reporting period. The resulting accounting estimates could differ from the related actual results. All assumptions, expectations and forecasts used as a basis for certain estimates within the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements represent good faith assessments of Vivacom’s future performance for which management believes there is a reasonable basis. Estimates and judgments are continually evaluated and are based on historical experience and other factors, including expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. Detailed information regarding significant accounting policies is provided in Note 2 to the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impairment of Goodwill, Tangible and Intangible Assets
Subsubsection Text: In recent years, Vivacom has been conducting annual impairment testing of its assets, and no need for impairment has been identified. Taking into account the fact that Vivacom has during this period performed in line with its projections, and based on the assessment that no internal or external indicators exist that affect the recoverable amount of assets or trigger the need for annual impairment testing of assets, Vivacom considers that the carrying amount of assets as of December 31, 2019 did not exceed their recoverable amount. Taking into account the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, Vivacom has performed new impairment testing of its assets as of December 31, 2020 and no need for impairment was identified. Based on the analysis performed, there would be no need for impairment even in the event estimated cash flows were 10% lower.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The determination of the useful lives of assets is based on historical experience with similar assets as well as any anticipated technological development and changes in broad economic or industry factors. The appropriateness of the estimated useful lives of assets is reviewed annually, or whenever there is an indication of significant changes in the underlying assumptions. Vivacom believes that the accounting estimate related to the determination of the useful lives of assets is a critical accounting estimate as it involves assumptions about technological development in an innovative industry. Further, due to the significance of depreciable assets as a percentage of Vivacom’s total assets, the impact of any changes in these assumptions could be material to its financial position and results of operations. ----- Were the actual useful lives of the assets to differ by 10% from management’s estimates as of December 31, 2020, the carrying value of the plant and equipment and respectively depreciation and amortization charges would be an estimated BGN 17.2 million higher or lower.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Provisions, Decommissioning Costs and Contingent Liabilities
Subsubsection Text: As set out in Note 28 of the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2019 and and Note 29 of the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2020, Vivacom is a participant in several lawsuits and administrative proceedings. For more information, see “Our _Business—Legal Proceedings.”Vivacom’s treatment of obligations with uncertain timing and amount depends_ on management’s estimation of the amount and timing of the obligation and probability of an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits that will be required to settle the obligation (both legal and constructive). A provision is recognized when Vivacom has a present obligation as a result of past events, it is probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. Contingent liabilities are not recognized because their existence will be confirmed only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events not wholly within Vivacom’s control. Contingent liabilities are assessed continually to determine whether an outflow of resource embodying economic benefits has become probable. If it becomes probable that an outflow of future economic benefits will be required for an item previously dealt with as a contingent liability, a provision is recognized in the financial statements of the period in which the change in probability occurs.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The financial statements have been prepared on a going concern basis, which assumes that Vivacom will continue in operational existence for the foreseeable future. In the year ended December 31, 2020, Vivacom realized a profit of BGN 123,265 thousand, compared to BGN 137,748 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2019 Vivacom’s future viability depends upon the business environment as well as upon the continuing support of its existing and potential owners and providers of finance. Vivacom’s directors, in light of their assessment of expected future cash flows, are satisfied that it is appropriate for the financial statements to be prepared on a going concern basis.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Revenue Recognition, Contract Assets and Liabilities
Subsubsection Text: Multiple element arrangements involving the delivery or provision of multiple products or services are assessed to determine whether it is necessary to separate the different identifiable components and apply the corresponding revenue recognition policy to each element. The transaction price for the entire multiple element arrangement is allocated among the identified elements based on their respective standalone selling prices. Determining standalone selling prices for each identified element requires estimates that are complex due to the nature of the business. A change in estimates of standalone selling prices could affect the allocation of revenue among the elements and, as a result, the timing of recognition of revenues and the carrying amount of contract assets and liabilities.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Allowance for Impairment of Trade and Other Receivables, Leases and Contract Assets
Subsubsection Text: An allowance for impairment of trade and other receivables is established for estimated losses resulting from the inability of customers to make their payments due. When evaluating the adequacy of an allowance for doubtful accounts, management bases its estimates on the aging of accounts receivable balances and historical write-off experience, customer creditworthiness and estimated probability of default. If the financial condition of customers were to deteriorate, actual write-offs might be higher than expected.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Vivacom is subject to income taxes in the Bulgarian tax jurisdiction. Significant judgment is required in determining the provision for income taxes. Vivacom recognizes liabilities for anticipated tax due based on management estimates. Where the final tax outcome of these matters is different from the amounts that were initially recorded, such differences will impact the income tax and deferred tax provisions in the period in which such determination is made.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Assignment of receivables on cash deposits
Subsubsection Text: The transactions for assignment of receivables on cash deposits in Corporate Commercial Bank AD—in bankruptcy (CCB), were executed in 2014 as per the provisions of the applicable law. ----- In August 2015, two of the transactions concluded in 2014 for the assignment of cash deposits in CCB were terminated and as a result the assignments were cancelled with retroactive effect where Vivacom became a titleholder of the assigned receivables in the amount of BGN 53,033 thousand (BGN 9,970 thousand, net of impairment as of 31 December 2019). Despite of the validly executed transactions, the receivers of CCB have not included the cancelled assignments in the list of accepted receivables of CCB creditors. In 2020, remaining receivables representing cash and cash equivalents at CCB were assigned to InterV Investment S.à r.l. for cash consideration equal to their net book value.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Fair value is the price that is assumed would be received in the sale of an asset or paid to transfer a liability in a common transaction between independent market participants at the measurement date. Fair value assumes that such a transaction will take place in the principal market where such assets and liabilities are traded or, in the absence of such principal market or, in case of lack of access to such market by Vivacom, in the market where such a transaction would be most advantageous. For the purposes of financial reporting, certain of Vivacom’s assets and liabilities are valued and presented at fair value. Such assets and liabilities presented at fair value are (a) on a recurring (annual) basis: financial assets through other comprehensive income, financial assets through profit or loss, investment property, loans granted or borrowings received to/from third or related parties, certain trade and other receivables and payables, finance lease receivables and payables, and (b) on a non-recurring (period basis): non-financial assets such as property, plant and equipment.

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Determining the lease term and the incremental borrowing rate
Subsubsection Text: In determining the lease term, management considers all facts and circumstances that create an economic incentive to exercise an extension option, or not exercise a termination option. Extension options (or periods after termination options) are only included in the lease term if the lease is reasonably certain to be extended (or not terminated). If there are significant penalties to terminate (or not extend), or any leasehold improvements are expected to have a significant remaining value, Vivacom is typically reasonably certain to extend (or not terminate). Other factors including historical lease durations and the costs and business disruption required to replace the leased asset are also considered. For lease contracts with indefinite term or short-term technical site rentals the Vivacom estimates the length of the contract to be equal to the economic useful life of non-current assets located in the leased property. To determine the incremental borrowing rate, the Vivacom uses a buildup approach that starts with a risk free interest rate adjusted for credit risk for the country and the company and makes adjustments specific to the lease, e.g. term, currency and security. -----

Section Title: VIVACOM’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following review relates to Vivacom’s historical financial condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020. “Vivacom’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” is based on the historical financial data included in this offering memorandum and should be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial Data,” “Summary of Company and Group Run-Rate, Vivacom, Unaudited Pro Forma and Certain Other Financial Data,” “and the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Prospective investors should read the entire offering memorandum and not just rely on the information set out below. The following discussion of Vivacom’s results of operations and financial condition contains forward-looking statements. Vivacom’s actual results could differ materially from those that are discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include those discussed below and elsewhere in this offering memorandum, particularly under “Risk Factors” and “Forward-looking Statements.”_

We operate most of our business across the following eight countries in South Eastern Europe: Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina (“B&H”), Montenegro and North Macedonia. These countries have a combined population of approximately 37 million people, distributed across approximately 15 million households. Despite economic differences, these countries share a joint history and form a single market in which small local differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the region. As a result, this region is one of the three largest markets in CEE, along with Poland and Romania. The following table provides an overview of our countries of operations:

_Residential Segment (Fixed) Pay-TV Overview_ The Pay-TV market in South Eastern Europe is characterized by relatively low service penetration rates compared to certain countries in Western Europe, which we believe provides cable Pay-TV players with attractive growth opportunities in the future. -----

Subsubsection Title: Pay-TV Penetration Benchmark (% of Total Households), 2020
Subsubsection Text: 89% 77% _Avg: 79%_ 68% 58% Source: Ampere 95% 89% 90% Between 2018 and 2020, overall Pay-TV market penetration increased from 73% to 87% in Serbia, 76% to 77% in Slovenia and stable at 68% in Bulgaria. This translated into substantial growth in subscribers at CAGRs of 10.1% (from 1,781 thousand to 2,160 thousand), 1.0% (from 637 thousand to 650 thousand) and (0.5%) (from 2,014 thousand to 1,993 thousand) during the corresponding period in Serbia, Slovenia and Bulgaria, respectively. The growth occurred primarily due to availability of increasingly attractive content, improving output quality (mainly as a result of increasing digitalization rates), increased product functionality (e.g. video on demand and CatchUp TV) and higher disposable income per household across the region. The positive growth in the number of Pay-TV subscribers is expected to continue in Serbia and initiate in Bulgaria, with estimated penetration rates in 2024 of 90% and 72%, respectively. The positive growth in Serbia and Slovenia is expected to be driven by increasing demand for digital TV and other value add services that can be delivered through digital TV platforms, such as VoD and CatchUp TV.

BGN EUR RSD EUR EUR BAM EUR MKD Source: IHS, Ampere Over the past fifteen years, our eight countries of operations have implemented significant political and economic reforms aimed at, among other things, reducing economic and structural imbalances, increasing the flexibility of their respective economies (including liberalization of the media and telecommunications sectors), and creating a business friendly environment that is conducive to foreign investment. As a result of such reforms, Slovenia and Croatia were admitted to the European Union in 2004 and 2013, respectively. Bulgaria joined the European Union in 2007 and Greece in 1981 (and adopted the euro in 2001). Serbia officially applied for European Union membership in 2009, received full candidate status in 2012 and in January 2014, the first accession negotiations took place. Negotiations are ongoing with several Chapters having been opened up for discussion and review. Montenegro was granted candidate status in 2010 and the accession negotiations started in June 2012. North Macedonia has been a candidate for accession to the European Union since 2005, and in 2009 the European Commission recommended that accession negotiations be opened. Bosnia and Herzegovina formally applied for EU membership in February 2016 and in December 2016 and has received the accession questionnaire from the European Commission. The macroeconomic environment is improving in our four core countries (Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia and Slovenia). Real GDP growth in our four core countries is and will continue to be the key driver of private consumption and disposable income growth. Bulgaria’s economy has experienced a slightly negative growth for the period from 2018 to 2020, with real GDP decreasing by 0.2% from 2018 to 2020. However, real GDP per capita from 2018 to 2020 increased by 0.5%. Furthermore, in 2020, unemployment rate increased by 0.9 percentage points, driven by COVID-19. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 0.6 percentage points. In Greece, positive growth in disposable personal income is expected to continue, supported by expanding employment, wage growth and a stable inflow of worker remittances. Unemployment rate dropped by 0.8 percentage points in 2020. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 2.9 percentage points. ----- In Serbia, the growth in real GDP per capita is expected to continue, driven by monetary policy relaxation, structural reforms and supported by expanding employment. Unemployment rate dropped by 1.5 percentage points in 2020. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 3.8 percentage points. Growth is further driven by solid expansion in household spending as well as a trade surplus. Capacity utilization levels in industry and services have reached their highest level since 2007 and conditions for investment (e.g. high profits and low interest rates) remain favorable, which could potentially drive capital spending growth. Higher than expected employment and rising disposable income has led to healthy private consumption growth. Strong fiscal performance could support gradual reduction of public debt as a share of GDP. Eurozone membership allows the country to benefit from the credibility of the European Central Bank’s monetary policy and access to the Economic and Monetary Union’s highly developed capital markets. In Slovenia, the economy has been significantly hit by the COVID-19 pandemic, with real GDP and real GDP per capita decreasing by 6.1 percentage points. However, the country has experienced an increase in disposable personal income (+5.7% YoY in 2020). Unemployment rate increased by 0.5 percentage points in 2020, while from 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 0.1 percentage points.
