The Serbian dinar depreciated against the Euro. Historically, Serbian consumer price index (“CPI”) inflation has tended to more than offset depreciation of the Serbian dinar against the Euro, leading to a constant “pass through” of the impact of the depreciation of the dinar to the consumer. We believe that our pricing strategy reflects the “pass through” principle outlined above. With respect to the Croatian kuna, the long-time policy of the Croatian National Bank has been to keep the exchange rate fluctuation of the kuna against the Euro within a relatively stable range.

Subsubsection Title: Pay-TV Subscribers (% of Total Subscribers) by Infrastructure, 2020

Subsubsection Text: Cable TV . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 26% 56% 39% IPTV . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 28% 29% 56% DTH . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 46% 16% 5% Others . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 0% 0% 0% Source: Ampere - Cable Cable Pay-TV is characterized by easy to use technology, quick installation of customer equipment and reliability of signal delivered directly to the home. Population density is a key factor for cable operators when deciding whether to invest in extending their existing cable network. A higher population density reduces the overall cost associated with the deployment, operation and maintenance of cable infrastructure and allows for mass marketing. Cable operators that operate in urban areas with high population density benefit from easier access to customers and more cost effective network upgrades and maintenance expenditures. As a result, cable networks in South Eastern Europe are mainly concentrated across metropolitan regions in Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia. As of December 2020, approximately 26% of households in Bulgaria, approximately 56% in Serbia and approximately 39% in Slovenia received their Pay-TV content via cable. The popularity of cable Pay-TV in Serbia is a result of the attractive content available on cable television, the high service quality and the capability to deliver interactive services such as VoD and CatchUp TV. - IPTV As a consequence of improvements in broadband internet technology, IPTV is increasingly being used for the distribution of television services and has traditionally been the second most commonly used distribution medium for television services across South Eastern Europe. In Slovenia, IPTV has recently become the most used distribution medium (56% of all households as of December 2020), supported by EU investment in shared open fiber networks, which are accessible to all operators for a fee. However, as these shared open fiber networks have been built with the objective of making high quality services available in rural parts of Slovenia, these networks have traditionally had a limited impact on our cable footprint, which typically covers urban and high population density areas. The principal providers of IPTV are Telekom Slovenije and T2 in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija (who regularly offers IPTV at a significant discount to attract subscribers) in Serbia and Bulsatcom in Bulgaria. ----- - DTH-TV DTH has traditionally been the third most commonly used distribution network medium for television services in South Eastern Europe region after cable and IPTV. Pay-TV content owners can penetrate rural areas more cost efficiently through DTH than through fixed line cable networks which are economically unviable to develop because of low population density in rural areas. Satellite operators, such as our own Total TV and competitors, such as Digi and Max TV, distribute digital signals via satellite directly to television viewers. To receive DTH, viewers need a satellite dish and a set top box. Depending on the service provider, viewers may also require a smart card for the subscription based and premium television services distributed via satellite. As of December 2020, approximately 46% of households in Bulgaria that had subscribed to Pay-TV services received their content via DTH, compared to approximately 16% in Serbia and approximately 5% in Slovenia. We believe that the majority of DTH Pay-TV subscribers live in rural areas without access to a cable network, which limits the overlap between our cable Pay-TV and DTH Pay-TV offerings. - OTT Another emerging technology is the delivery of television content “over-the-top” of an existing broadband internet network, which allows Pay-TV distributors to reach customers through the internet. We operate two of our own OTT content platforms: our regional OTT platform (which operates under the EON brand of products and services) and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus. Our regional OTT platform offers customers of our broadband internet competitors within the region access to our full digital Pay-TV channel offering. As a result, EON subscribers can watch all of our digital Pay-TV channels on their TV screens, computers, tablets, mobiles or other internet enabled devices. Through NetTV Plus, we deliver extensive local and regional content, to the entire former Yugoslav expatriate community worldwide. Like EON, our subscribers can watch Net TV Plus directly on their TV screens, computers, tablets, mobiles or other internet enabled devices. We are a leading provider of Pay-TV services across our three core markets. We mainly compete with local incumbents in our three core markets (Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija in Serbia and Bulsatcom in Bulgaria), as well as with other local players (T2 in Slovenia, Telekom Srpske, HT Eronet and A1 Bulgaria in Bulgaria, among others). We have managed to maintain our leadership and grow our market shares across our three core markets due to high quality content offering, excellent customer care, positive brand perception and better value and product propositions. Cable . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 14% 50% 30% DSL . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6% 37% 28% FttH . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 59% 14% 41% Others . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 22% 0% 2% Source: Ampere - DSL DSL uses basic telephone infrastructure to access the internet. DSL technology leverages the fact that copper wires used in telephone networks have a much higher bandwidth (7 MHz) than that required for normal voice conversation (0 3.4 KHz). DSL utilizes the extra bandwidth to provide broadband internet connections. The most commonly used variant of DSL is ADSL which assumes that internet users normally receive or download significant more information than they would send or upload. Hence, ADSL connections normally have three to four times more bandwidth for downloading. However, as copper is a distance sensitive medium, access speeds for DSL technology decrease substantially as the distance from DSL hubs increases. The maximum download speed of DSL networks has to be shared between all services: television, broadband internet and telephony. Under currently available technology, DSL based multi-play providers can therefore not provide broadband internet and television services of comparable quality to those provided over cable networks. Another variant of DSL is VDSL, a DSL technology that provides a faster data transfer rate than ADSL technologies. It is an access technology that exploits the existing infrastructure of copper wires that were originally deployed for traditional telephone service as a way of delivering very high speed internet access. ----- Historically, DSL has been distribution platform and accounted for approximately 6% of all internet connections in Bulgaria, 37% in Serbia and 28% in Slovenia at the end of 2020. However, its market share has been consistently eroded by upgraded cable networks which offer higher quality service and higher speed as well as by the steady development of fiber based networks. - Cable Cable networks have been designed for the transmission of large amounts of analogue TV and radio signals and are able to deliver consistent speeds irrespective of the distance to the customer, unlike DSL. United Group companies are leading cable providers in the region with fully bi directional network, largely EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled and offering up to 220 Mbps download speeds, with the upgrade path up to 1.2 Gbps. Furthermore, the deployment of EuroDOCSIS 3.1 technology will allow cable operators to provide data download speeds as high as 10 Gbps and data upload speeds as high as 2 Gbps over existing hybrid fiber/coax (“HFC”) lines (with full duplex EuroDOCSIS 3.1, upstream capacity will also be as high as 10 Gbps). EuroDOCSIS 3.1 when deployed enables us to compete head on with fiber networks. In addition to faster download and upload speeds, EuroDOCSIS 3.1 also offers other tangible benefits, such as higher bandwidth capacity, better operational efficiencies, higher quality control, real time performance analysis and lower costs. All these other tangible benefits should be available without necessarily upgrading existing HFC networks or adding more fiber lines. EuroDOCSIS 3.1 is also backward compatible with Euro DOCSIS 3.0, which allows us to roll out the new specifications seamlessly, on an incremental basis. In 2020, cable distribution accounted for 14%, 50% and 30% of all broadband infrastructure in Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia, respectively. - FttH FttH is based on optical fiber cables and is the only infrastructure that offers similar speeds. Currently, FttH broadband internet connections play a very limited role in Serbia. FttH had a broadband market share in Slovenia of approximately 41% as of December 31, 2020, compared to approximately 35% in 2018. The main providers of FttH in Slovenia are Telekom Slovenije and T2. The increase in the FttH broadband market share is primarily due to extensive fiber roll out by Telekom Slovenije and T2 in 2009, as well as EU investment in municipally owned open fiber networks. As fiber roll out is more expensive than cable and the open fiber networks have traditionally been built with the objective of making high speed broadband internet and IPTV services accessible in rural areas, we believe that any competitive impact on cable operators will be limited, as these operators traditionally provide services in more urban and high density areas (i.e. no overlap). FttH is the technology of choice by United Group for greenfield expansion and new buildings in adjacent areas. - Other Broadband Internet We also compete with service providers that use other alternative technologies for broadband internet access, such as satellite technologies or mobile standards such as WiMax, universal mobile telecommunications system (“UMTS”) and high speed packet access (“HSPA”). These mobile broadband internet access technologies may allow both incumbent and new broadband internet access providers the ability to provide high speed connection services for voice, data, video and television. We estimate that only a small portion of households were using UMTS/HSPA for primary broadband internet access via laptops or PCs in 2014. We believe that the majority of mobile broadband internet users presently use mobile internet services to complement, rather than to replace, fixed line broadband internet. ----- _Competition_ We are the leading provider of broadband services within our footprint with 22%, 33% and 29% of the market share in Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia, respectively, as of 2020:

Subsubsection Title: Broadband Penetration Rates (% of Total Households)[(1)], 2020
Subsubsection Text: 102% 99% Avg: 95%_ 96% 93% 86% 72% 75% 66% Source: Fitch Solutions (1) Broadband penetration is calculated over total households; does not include mobile broadband services. Fixed broadband internet household penetration rates in Bulgaria grew from approximately 65% in 2018 to 72% in 2020, in Serbia from approximately 59% in 2018 to 66% in 2020 and in Slovenia from approximately 73% in 2018 to 75% in 2020. This translated into substantial growth in the number of subscribers at CAGRs of 5.3% (from 1,904 thousand to 2,113 thousand) in Bulgaria, 5.6% (from 1,447 thousand to 1,613 thousand) in Serbia and 2.2% (from 607 thousand to 634 thousand) in Slovenia during the same period. At the same time, fixed broadband penetration rates lag behind the penetration rates of more developed European markets, such as France, UK and the Netherlands. We believe that the positive growth in the broadband internet market in our three core markets also stems from the overall increasing importance of the internet as the primary communication medium of choice as well as from a decrease in end user equipment costs, leading to increasing usage of personal computers and smartphones. By 2024, broadband internet penetration rates are expected to reach 82%, or 2,351 thousand, of households in Bulgaria, 73%, or 1,765 thousand, of households in Serbia and 84%, or 722 thousand, of households in Slovenia. As data consumption demand grows in households, the penetration rate of high speed broadband (lines capable of providing at least 30 Mbps) is expected to increase rapidly in Slovenia and Serbia in the coming years. The Serbian “Strategy for the Development of Broadband and Networks and Service,” adopted in 2014, established a target of 100% coverage with 30 Mbps by 2020 and 50% coverage for 100 Mpbs in an effort to align with EU targets. -----

Subsubsection Text: 139% Source: Ampere 147% 136% There has been a continuous decline in Slovenian mobile termination rates (“MTR”) since 2008. MTR asymmetry in the Slovenian market was eliminated as of January 1, 2013, when MTR for all operators became €0.0324 per minute. In July 2014, the Slovenian regulator, AKOS, announced a significant reduction in MTRs to €0.0114 per minute and implemented this rate for all Slovenian operators with effect from September 1, 2014. Following this reduction, Slovenian MTR was brought closer in line with the target EU benchmark of €0.01 per minute, indicating limited further downside. _Licenses_ - Spectrum Licenses The first ever spectrum auction in Slovenia was completed in April 2014 with the award of several frequency bands to three mobile operators: Telekom Slovenije, Si.mobil (now A1) and Tušmobil (Telemach Slovenia). Three of the four MNOs (T 2 did not participate) acquired the following bands: A1 acquired total of 90 MHz on paired 800, 900, 1800 and 2600 MHz and a total of 45 MHz on unpaired 2100 and 2600 MHz; Telekom Slovenije acquired a total of 85 MHz on paired 800, 900, 1800 MHz and a total of 25 MHz on unpaired 2600 MHz band, Telemach Slovenia acquired a paired spectrum of 5 MHz on 900, 10 MHz on 1800 as well as 10 ----- MHz in the 800 MHz band which is widely recognized as the most efficient band for 4G LTE roll out. The licenses were awarded for a long term tenure of 15 years which we believe represents a significant barrier to entry for a potential fifth MNO. In July 2016, AKOS announced its decision to conduct an auction for various mobile spectrum bands in Slovenia that remained unallocated. These included frequencies in the 1800 MHz band and the 2100 MHz band. AKOS set the reserve price at €2.6 million for each block of 2x5 MHz in the 1800 MHz frequency band, two blocks of which were available for auction, and €1.3 million for the block of 2x5MHz in the 2100 MHz band, one block of which was available for auction. On August 5, 2016, we submitted our tender for these frequencies. On August 29, 2016, AKOS issued a decision in our favor on the allocation of two blocks of 2x5 MHz in the 1800 MHz frequency band and one block of 2x5 MHz in the 2100 MHz frequency band for an aggregate amount of €6.6 million. Telemach Slovenia’s license for the frequencies in the 1800 MHz band is valid through January 2031, and for the frequencies in the 2100 MHz band is valid through September 2021. Telemach Slovenia currently possesses 60% less spectrum compared to its main two competitors. In April 2021, we secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We believe additional frequencies will be needed to be able to address our growing mobile business, especially in the domain of mobile broadband. On September 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria and, to that end, in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. _Competition_ Telekom Slovenije is the largest mobile operator in the market, with a market share of 40% as of December 31, 2020. Telemach Slovenia had a market share of 24% as of December 31, 2020. The mobile markets in Bulgaria and Serbia are led by incumbents as well as mobile players that are part of international groups. Historically, international groups have invested in mobile operations only in Serbia, and we believe the limited focus of international groups in the rest of our core region is set to continue, potentially offering interesting acquisition opportunities for us.

##### Slovenia Slovenia_ Others 3% 5% 5% 6% 7% 29% 29% 29% 29% 44% 42% 40% 44% 19% 21% 23% 24% 2017 2018 2019 2020 Source: Ampere Bundles Customers in our three core markets increasingly seek to receive their multimedia and communications services in a bundled offer from one provider. In response, service providers are providing television, broadband internet and fixed line and mobile telephony services in bundled offerings; such bundled offerings are marketed as the best value for money. We believe that bundled offerings allow media and ----- telecommunication service providers to better meet customers’ communication and entertainment demands, increase average revenue per customer while also increasing customer loyalty and attract new customers via an enhanced value proposition. As of December 31, 2018, approximately 81% of unique fixed line customers are bundled customers in Telemach Slovenia. Fixed and mobile convergence was approximately 43% as of December 31, 2018 with 1.9 SIMs per customer on average. As of December 31, 2018, SBB Serbia and Telemach BH had bundle penetration of 80% and 74% respectively. While such convergence has occurred at a relatively fast pace in a number of Western and Eastern European markets, notably in Slovenia, a series of regulations, including those limiting alternative operators other than the incumbent service providers from providing telephony services in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, have historically prevented such convergence to occur in our three core markets. However, the relatively recent liberalization of the Serbian and Bosnian fixed line telephony markets is accelerating the convergence in our three core markets. The ability to bundle products and services plays an important role in our three core markets, and we believe cable operators will be well positioned to benefit from this.

Almost all businesses in our three core markets (Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia) have internet/broadband connections. Large companies and small and medium enterprises can receive the following services from telecommunications companies: infrastructure and transport (dark fiber, wavelengths and synchronous digital hierarchy), co-location, enterprise connectivity (including internet access, Ethernet and multiprotocol label switching, virtual private network/wide area network, security and managed services), hosting & cloud storage (including infrastructure as a service and platform as a service) and voice. According to Solon, business fixed data spending (which includes internet access (comprising connection charges and monthly fees, excluding equipment costs), Ethernet (installation and monthly services charges), internet protocol virtual private networks (costs of underlying broadband and dedicated connections, excluding dial line rental and usage charges), very high bandwidth services (upfront connection and monthly service charges on optical and dark fiber services) and legacy data services (digital leased line, Frame Relay and asynchronous transfer mode connections)). We expect the business fixed data spending to remain relatively stable. In more developed markets, additional spending for co-location, hosting & cloud storage is typically around three times the amount of fixed data spending.

As of 31 December 2020, Nova BG is the 2[nd] player in the Greek market, with Cosmote being the clear leader with 48% market share. ----- Broadband _Overview_ The broadband internet market in our core markets is characterized by continued growth and increasing demand for high speed broadband internet services, which ultimately contributes to increasing internet service penetration rates: Others A1 Slovenia_ Others _Bulgaria_ Others A1 2017 2018 2019 2020 Source: Ampere 2017 2018 2019 2020 2017 2018 2019 2020 Due to material overbuild in metropolitan areas in Slovenia, we face competition from other Slovenian broadband internet providers, such as T2 and Telekom Slovenije who both offer FttH and, Telekom Slovenije, Amis and T2 who each offer VDSL. In Serbia, we believe that cable overbuild is relatively low and largely concentrated in Belgrade. The Serbian cable market remains relatively fragmented and we believe that due to our scale in the market as well as our acquisition history, we are well positioned to continue consolidating the Serbian cable market and thereby increasing our overall market share. Similar to Serbia, cable overbuild is relatively low in Bosnia and Herzegovina (mainly in the Sarajevo region) and our primary competitors are the incumbents in the ethnic regions in which we operate, BH Telecom, Telekom Srpske and HT Eronet, as well as regional cable operators, who all offer multi-play bundles at discounted prices. However, we believe we have a competitive advantage due to our attractive content offering and high broadband internet speed. The Bosnian cable market remains relatively fragmented and we also believe that we are well positioned in the market to continue consolidating the Bosnian cable market and thereby increasing our overall market share. Fixed Telephony _Overview_ Similar to the rest of Europe, fixed line penetration rates in our three core markets has been decreasing recently and this trend is expected to continue: Others _Slovenia_ _Bulgaria_ 10% 11% 13% 14% 7% 6% 6% 6% 15% 16% 16% 17% 10% 10% 10% 11% 84% 83% 81% 79% 46% 44% 42% 39% 90% 90% 90% 89% 22% 23% 22% 24% 16% 17% 19% 21% 2017 2018 2019 2020 2017 2018 2019 2020 Source: Ampere 2017 2018 2019 2020 We believe that consumers increasingly select fixed line telephony providers by the quality of the accompanying Pay-TV and broadband internet offerings or total bundle value, and we believe that cable ----- operators are well positioned to take advantage of this consumer preference. We offer attractive VoIP packages in Slovenia which include free calls to all fixed phone subscribers within our network, including to Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. We believe this offering is particularly attractive because a number of Slovenian residents have family in Serbia or Bosnia and Herzegovina who they can reach at no additional charge through our packages. Since late 2012, we have become the second largest provider of fixed line telephone services in Serbia, behind the incumbent Telekom Srbija. Moreover, largely due to the introduction of full telephone number portability in April 2014, we have significantly increased the number of our fixed line telephony subscribers in Serbia. We expect this trend to continue. Similarly, in Bosnia and Herzegovina we offer VoIP telephony services as part of our cable and television bundle. Residential Segment (Mobile) _Slovenian Mobile Market Overview_ Following our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015, we provide mobile telephony services in Slovenia as an MNO. There were approximately 2.5 million mobile subscribers in Slovenia as of December 31, 2018, which resulted in a penetration rate of 119%, below the average mobile penetration rate in Europe. The number of mobile subscribers in Slovenia grew at a CAGR of approximately 1.5% between 2014 and 2018. We believe mobile penetration in Slovenia is still below the penetration benchmarks provided by certain developed mobile markets in Western Europe, such as Germany and Sweden, supporting continued subscriber growth potential in the market. The Slovenian mobile market is a predominantly contract (post-paid) market.

VoIP technologies place and transmit telephone calls over the internet instead of using the traditional PSTN. Following the liberalization of fixed line telephony markets in Serbia, all telephony markets in our three core markets are now fully liberalized, providing us with significant growth opportunities. Slovenia is one of the few European telephony markets in which VoIP technology accounts for the majority of the fixed line telephony connections. We believe that this increase in VoIP market share was primarily driven by lower prices of VoIP connections compared to PSTN connections which are often offered as part of a competitively priced cable or FttH internet and television bundle. _Competition_ Historically, the respective incumbent (Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija in Serbia) in two of our three core markets, has been the largest provider of fixed line telephony in each respective market. However, following the liberalization of the region’s telephony markets and the introduction of VoIP technologies, which allows customers to make traditional fixed line telephone calls using a standard telephone handset and provides comparable quality to PSTN at lower prices, the respective Bulgarian, Serbian and Slovenian incumbents have generally lost market share to us:

_Overview and Technology_ Television in Slovenia was first introduced in 1958, with the launch of JRT RTV Ljubljana (now RTV Slovenija) as the first TV station. Following the independence from Yugoslavia in 1991, the Mass Media Act which was passed in 1994, laid out the specific model for the privatization of media in Slovenia. The Mass Media Act was revised in 2001 and 2006 to define clear rules for ensuring media pluralism. Today, TV market in Slovenia is operated by both state owned and for profit corporations and is mainly shared between public ----- service RTV Slovenia and private stations Kanal A and Pop TV. Kanal A was the first commercial TV station which launched in 1991, followed by Pop TV which launched in 1995. Television in Serbia was first introduced in 1958 with state owned Television Belgrade, now known as Radio Television of Serbia (“RTS”). The Serbian broadcasting system evolved from a public monopoly into a dual system of public and private stations. The switch over from analogue to digital terrestrial television in the country was completed in 2015. Television in Bosnia and Herzegovina was first introduced in 1956 and since then, it has now developed into a market with both private and public channels. Three public TV stations (BHT1, FTV and RTRS) are operating within the Public Service Broadcasting system and are financed from radio and television fees. Together with private stations, as well as regional public stations, they form the national TV market. The Pay-TV market is significantly fragmented with the majority of private TV stations being locally focused. However, there are a number of players that aim to capture a wider audience throughout the country (for example, N1 of Telemach BH). The process of TV digitalization is still ongoing in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Television in Croatia was first introduced in 1956 with Television Zagreb. Today there are four channels with nationwide coverage. Digital video broadcasting terrestrial signal broadcasting was introduced in 2002, with the full digital switchover being completed by 2010 via gradual ceasing of analogue TV throughout the country.

Across our three core markets, television is the medium of choice for advertising, accounting for approximately 50% of total advertising spent. The internet, as a medium of choice for advertising, is expected to grow at higher rates than television, but will still remain below television in coming years. The average daily viewing time across the three core markets ranges from approximately 3.5 to 5.5 hours demonstrating the importance of TV as medium for information and entertainment. Most importantly, the demand for TV is relatively inelastic. TV continues to offer a unique proposition to advertisers: enormous scale, fast reach, very high quality advertisement inventory and an attractive contextual environment for brand building. As a result, TV advertising should continue to be resilient, with any gradual volume reductions more than offset by price inflation. Television broadcasting in each of our markets is regulated by a governmental authority or agency. For example, privately owned broadcasters in Slovenia are allowed to broadcast advertising for up to 12 minutes in any hour, whereas the public broadcaster, Radiotelevizija Slovenija, is allowed to broadcast advertising for up to 10 minutes per hour given the additional financing from TV licensing fees. Between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m., the advertising time limit is reduced to seven minutes for the public broadcaster. In Serbia, advertising time is regulated on an hourly and daily basis, where commercial broadcasters are restricted to 20% of the daily broadcasts and to 20% per hour of broadcasting. Similarly to Slovenia, in Croatia the permitted advertising time per hour is 12 minutes with no daily limit and direct sales advertising must be at least 15 minutes. The advertising markets in South Eastern Europe have benefitted from robust macro-economic conditions. Advertising spend in our core three countries (Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina) is expected to grow faster than real GDP, with TV channel advertising remaining resilient. The recent decline of advertising spend in Croatia resulted from bankruptcy of one of Croatia’s biggest company, Agrokor, which employed approximately 60 thousand total staff members and its revenues accounted for more than 15% of Croatia’s total GDP. The Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, completed in September 2018, focuses on targeted advertising and specialized Pay-TV and positions us at the forefront of digital advertising in the region. As a result, we acquired the know-how of more than 100 of the best professionals in the region who provide significant synergies with the broader operations of the Group. -----

Despite economic differences, the countries of South Eastern Europe have a joint history and form a single media market in which local differences are compensated by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the region. Television is by far the main source of news and information in our three core markets. Through United Media, we play a significant role in this attractive market and even offer our own content, including some of the region’s most popular sports, news, children and general entertainment channels. We believe that the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition, which includes Nova TV (the most viewed channel in Croatia) enhances our media offering and strengthens our leadership position in Croatia. In September 2018, we completed the Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, a leading media buying agency in Serbia. The Direct Media/Pink Acquisition included its operations in Montenegro, North Macedonia and Albania as well as its terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and Pink Montenegro. On October 22, 2018, we rebranded these channels as Nova BH and Nova M to facilitate synergies with Nova TV in Croatia. In 2019, we also launched Nova S in Serbia, which although a Pay-TV channel, is structured as a full format national TV station with attractive talk shows, sports and own production local fiction series in the market. In January 2021, we acquired Nova BG, the largest Bulgarian multi-platform media company. The acquisition perfectly complements UG’s Vivacom operations, as the leading media group in the country.

We are the leading cable and media player in Southeastern Europe, providing services to approximately 3.7 million homes as of March 31, 2021. We are the leading distributor of Pay-TV in our core markets of Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the number two distributor in Montenegro. As of March 31, 2021, we provided services to approximately 10.9 million RGUs and analog and digital cable Pay-TV services to approximately 1.9 million unique subscribers. United Group’s revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2021 was €439.4 million and UG Adjusted EBITDA was €179.2 million. The Group had Run-Rate Revenue for the annualized last two quarters ended March 31, 2021 of €1,916.4 million and Run-Rate Last Two Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021 was €706.3 million. The Combined Group is the clear multi-play leader in its footprint, with market leading positions in Pay-TV, broadband internet and fixed-line and mobile-telephony in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, following the Forthnet Acquisition, Greece. The Combined Group’s addressable market comprised 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020. We have grown rapidly through both acquisitions and organic growth. In July 2020, we acquired Vivacom, the market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria, based on total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, which is the leading operator in fixed-line telephony services and broadband services, the number three provider of mobile-telephony services and the number three provider of Pay-TV, in each case, by number of subscribers as of March 31, 2021. The Vivacom Acquisition increased our addressable market by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than doubled our existing subscriber base. In March 2020, we also acquired Tele2 Croatia, the third largest telecommunications operator in Croatia, based on mobile revenues as of March 31, 2021, through which we offer mobile services in Croatia. In November 2020, we completed the acquisition of a controlling interest in Forthnet S.A., a prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece, which marked our entry into the Greek market and will strengthen our position as an industry leader in Southeastern Europe. In January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova Broadcasting Group EOOD, from Advance Media Group EAD, providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria. In July 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in Optima Telekom, a Croatian telecom operator offering a broad range of fixed internet and pay-TV services. Subject to its completion, the Optima Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our presence in the Croatian market and offer a full range of telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through our existing infrastructure in the country. We offer a diverse and differentiated line of products and services. We are the leading distributor of satellite (“DTH”) Pay-TV across Southeastern Europe, with Pay-TV product and service offerings in each of Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia and Montenegro, where we use our Total TV platform to serve subscribers both inside and outside of our cable footprint to deliver content across the entire region, including rural areas. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we also provide Pay-TV services in Bulgaria and are the leading IPTV provider in Bulgaria, while the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition strengthened our content offering in Bulgaria. Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also provide cable and DTH services in Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services, we offer mobile-telephony services in Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia. We provide 4G LTE coverage to almost the entire population in each of these countries, and we are rolling out 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021 secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction in Croatia this year. Our core telecommunications business is also complemented by our two OTT distribution platforms that customers can access through internet based streaming: EON, our regional OTT platform, which enables customers connected to our competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels, and NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which delivers ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more than 20 popular product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for children and kitchen appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and Slovenia. ----- Through our in-house content business, we produce distinctive and attractive in-house media content for our Pay-TV channels across multiple key genres that have historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. These channels include Southeastern Europe’s most popular family of branded Pay-TV sports channels, as well as popular movie channels, children’s channels, a 24/7 news channel, music channels and other specialized channels, which we continue to expand both organically and through acquisitions. We currently produce over 40% of the total content in our national (terrestrial) and cable operations, and our programs typically receive ratings of between 30% to 60% in the markets in which they are available. The Group also has in-house media and content production in Greece. We believe that our market leading content portfolio differentiates us from our competitors, has enabled strong growth in our business and provides us with predictable third-party carriage fees. As part of our media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution. Our Nova TV Croatia channel has strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share of 40% and market share by advertising revenue of 50%. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such as popular national team football events until 2022, such as the Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup qualifiers and League of Nations. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering high-quality local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality international productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition makes us a major content player in Bulgaria by adding Nova BG’s media platform comprising ten television channels, including NOVA TV, which broadcasts throughout Bulgaria, Bulgaria’s largest online platform, Net Info, which reaches on average 80% of the Bulgarian population each month, and four radio stations. In addition to our own content, as a result of our pan regional presence and well established distribution network, we are a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content owners, such as Discovery/Eurosport, Viacom, AXN, CNN, HBO, Fox and Universal, and sports rights owners, such as the English Premier League, Spanish Football League LaLiga, 2020 UEFA European Championship qualifiers, 2020 UEFA European Championship, 2022 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, UEFA League of Nations, ATP, Formula 1, Euroleague, and Moto GP, which we believe allows us to consistently obtain high-quality content and attractive payment terms. Nova BG holds licenses to offer compelling content in Bulgaria through distributors such as CBS Intenrational, the Walt Disney Company, Columbia Pictures and Paramount Pictures, as well as popular sports content such as the English Premier League football, Euro Cup qualifiers and the Euro Cup and Formula One racing. We believe these providers partner with us because of our well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe. We operate most of our business across eight countries in Southeastern Europe: Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Greece. These countries have a combined population of approximately 40 million, distributed across approximately 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020, and represent the second-largest CEE market after Poland. Despite economic differences, many of these countries share a joint history and form a single market in which small local differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the region and are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are currently underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets. We are the leading multi-play provider in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bulgaria, where we combine our services into packages, or bundles, which offer subscribers the convenience of being able to purchase television, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider, and provides us with significant opportunities to cross-sell our products. We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain our market leading positions in the Pay-TV and cable broadband internet markets in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to further increase our market shares, as we differentiate our product offerings through one of the highest download speeds in our broadband markets, access to desirable media content, a well invested network and high-quality customer service, which has led to relatively low churn rates which we believe demonstrate customer loyalty. We also believe that we are well-positioned to continue to grow in our region, and build on our expansion into Bulgaria and Greece. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For example, during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in providing connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and spent significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our voice and data traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data traffic increased at rates ----- between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and 85%, depending on the country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30% and 40%, depending on the country. Traffic levels decreased during the summer months and started increasing again as new lockdowns were implemented in various countries. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than many of our competitors.

Subsubsection Title: We are the leading multi-play service provider with a pan regional platform across Southeastern Europe.
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading multi-play telecommunications and media provider in Southeastern Europe, a position which we have strengthened significantly through the Vivacom Acquisition. Specifically, we are the leading provider of Pay-TV in our three core markets of Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the leading provider of broadband in Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each case, based on market share by number of subscribers. We are also the leading provider of broadband and the number three provider of Pay-TV in Bulgaria based on market share by number of subscribers for the year ended December 31, 2020, and the second-largest Pay-TV operator in Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services, we offer mobile-telephony services in Slovenia, in Bulgaria and in Croatia. The acquisitions we have made have delivered significant geographic expansion and diversification of our business into Bulgaria and Greece. The Vivacom Acquisition, for example, increased our addressable market by 35% in terms of population, and doubled our existing customer base. Furthermore, our scale and presence across Southeastern Europe and across our product portfolios allows us to cross-sell our services and expand the number of multi-play packages we provide, creating opportunities to expand our customer base. The table below shows key operating and financial data of the Group as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2021, except where otherwise noted. -----

(3) Company Cable RGUs consist of Pay-TV, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony Company RGUs. Customers of Forthnet are serviced through a local loop unbundling arrangement with the incumbent OTE. We are the pan regional leader for Pay-TV services with 2.6 million unique Pay-TV subscribers as of March 31, 2021, and we have leveraged our complementary cable and DTH platforms to gain a leading Pay-TV market share of 46% in Serbia, as of March 31, 2021, 39% in Slovenia as of December 31, 2020, and 41% in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as of December 31, 2020, 26% in Bulgaria, as of December 31, 2020, and 28% in Greece, as of December 31, 2020, each based on number of subscribers. In addition, we are the largest DTH Pay-TV provider in Montenegro and are among the main providers of DTH Pay-TV in North Macedonia and Croatia. We are the leading high-speed cable broadband internet provider in each of Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina within our footprint in each country and have a large broadband market share overall, behind only the respective incumbents with national footprints. In Bulgaria, we are the market leader in broadband by number of subscribers, with a market share of 33% as of December 31, 2020. We leveraged our Pay-TV and cable broadband internet capabilities to become the second-largest fixed-line telephony provider in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Following the liberalization of the telephony markets in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia, which allowed customers to retain their existing telephone number when switching to our network in 2014, we have substantially grown our fixed-line telephony subscriber numbers. In addition, in Bulgaria, we are the market leader in fixed-line telephony, with a 66% market share by number of subscribers as of September 30, 2020. In mobile-telephony, we are the third largest MNO in Slovenia, with a market share of 24% as of March 31, 2021. We are also the third largest MNO in both Bulgaria, with a market share by number of subscribers of

Subsubsection Title: We benefit from diversified revenue streams within our markets and an improved currency mix.
Subsubsection Text: Due to our leading market positions in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and our position as a pan regional services provider, our business benefits from geographically diversified and product portfolio diversified revenue streams, which we have further diversified following the Vivacom Acquisition and Forthnet Acquisition. In terms of geographic diversity, the table below presents the percentage of revenue derived by jurisdiction (as a percentage of gross revenue, excluding intercompany revenue) for the three months ended March 31, 2021, after giving effect to the Vivacom Acquisition, the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition, the Forthnet Acquisition, the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition and other acquisitions: ++ ++ ++ ++ + [New M&A] (1) CroatiaCroatia companies

Subsubsection Text: ----- 30%, and Croatia, with a market share of 19%, in each case, as of March 31, 2021. Between 2017 and 2019, Vivacom’s mobile revenue grew at a CAGR of 4%, demonstrating Vivacom’s strong momentum in the mobile market. In July 2020, we leveraged our position in both the broadband and Pay-TV markets to launch Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more than 20 popular product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for children and kitchen appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and Slovenia. In Serbia, Shoppster operates as a marketplace using the dropshipping operating model, whereby it does not stock the products it sells. In Slovenia, Shoppster operates as a retailer as a result of an acquisition that we have completed and stores the products it sells in a leased warehouse. Products sold though Shoppster are distributed by third-party delivery couriers in both Serbia and Slovenia. Shoppster is a unique offering which combines the convenience of online-shopping with the audience engagement of television. Products are presented and available for sale on the Shoppster TV channel, which is devoted to home-shopping. Popular TV personalities from Southeastern Europe present offers and products from the many companies that have joined Shoppster. We intend for Shoppster to deliver the simple, reliable and secure e-shopping experience that modern consumers expect.
