In addition, any security the debtor granted under a loan (or under any other legal action that, in economic terms, corresponds to a loan) to an affiliate, provided that such affiliate is not regularly engaged in the business of granting credits or loans, at a time when the debtor was permanently insolvent, or within one year prior to the opening of insolvency proceedings, has no legal effect in the insolvency proceedings. Also, if a debtor has repaid a credit or a loan in the year immediately preceding the opening of insolvency proceedings to an affiliated person which is not regularly engaged in the business of granting credits or loans, the debtor is deemed to have deliberately jeopardized creditors and such repayment may be contested as an intentional damaging of creditors. The court order on the opening of insolvency proceedings has certain consequences. For example, insolvency creditors may satisfy their claims against the debtor only in insolvency proceedings. Undue claims against the insolvency debtor are deemed due as of the date of opening of the insolvency. All judicial proceedings against the insolvent debtor and its assets and all administrative proceedings initiated at the request of the insolvent debtor and the administrative and tax proceedings aimed at establishing a pecuniary obligation on the insolvent debtor are suspended and resume only after the fulfillment of certain conditions. No enforcement proceedings may be conducted against the debtor or its assets for the purpose of settling the claims, except for the enforcement of liabilities of the insolvency estate and expenses of the insolvency proceedings. Enforcement ban can be temporarily lifted for a period of nine months in favor of secured creditors in certain cases, in order to allow them to enforce their claims through the sale of the collateral. The initiation of insolvency proceedings does not result in automatic termination of contracts; but the insolvency administrator may choose to terminate certain executory contracts to avoid the worsening of the financial condition of the company.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Creation, Perfection, Amendment and Enforcement of Pledge on Ownership Stakes in Limited Liability Company
Subsubsection Text: The Secured Transactions Act provides that a pledgee shall acquire the right of pledge by registration in the Pledge Registry (Registar založnog prava) kept with the Serbian Agency for Commercial Registers (Agencija _za privredne registre) (the “Pledge Registry”) . Registration is performed on the basis of a (Stakes) Pledge_ Agreement. The (Stakes) Pledge Agreements must be made in writing. In case of pledge over stakes (i.e., share(s) in limited liability company), the (Stakes) Pledge Agreement also has to be notarized by a notary public. Material amendments to the obligation secured by the (stake) pledge (e.g., legal basis, principal amount, term, interest rate) require amendments to and registration with the competent authorities of a security document ----- (e.g., (Stakes) Pledge Agreement). Under the Secured Transactions Act, any amendment to a security document (e.g., (Stakes) Pledge Agreement) which would alter essential elements of the relevant collateral would affect such collateral, i.e., it would be considered as new collateral and therefore would have the priority as of the day of inscription of such alteration in the Pledge Registry (thus giving rise to a new hardening period), and ranking lower than the collateral registered before the amendments. There is no consistency in the practice of the Serbian courts or the Pledge Registry as to which elements of the security documents should be considered essential elements, but these are generally considered to include the legal basis, principal amount, term and interest rate. Enforcement proceedings may be commenced in court or, if so expressly provided for in the pledge agreement (i.e., (Stakes) Pledge Agreement), out of court (in accordance with the terms and conditions imposed by the law). In case of judicial enforcement, the enforcement title is the relevant excerpt from the competent Pledge Registry and the stakes (i.e., share(s) in limited liability company) can be sold via public auction (direct sale is possible only if the collateral has a current market price, in the case of multiple failure of auction sale or in case the enforcement debtor and enforcement creditor agree so). When enforcement is pursued out of court (when this is permitted by the pledge agreement), the title for enforcement is the relevant excerpt from the Pledge Registry, the stakes can be sold at public auction and in direct sale only if its current market price can be established (unlikely to be the case with the stakes (i.e., share(s) in limited liability company). If the collateral does not have a current market price (as the stakes (i.e., share(s) in limited liability company)), the pledgee can sell it in a manner a reasonable and careful man taking care of the interests of the debtor (and the pledgor, if not the same party as the debtor) would employ.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Limitations Related to Financial Assistance and Corporate Benefit Rules
Subsubsection Text: Certain corporate law limitations stem from the general prohibitions on financial assistance and capital maintenance rules under the Companies Act of FBiH. According to the Companies Act of FBiH, a limited liability company is prohibited from giving loans or providing securities/guarantees for the acquisition of its own shares. The scope of this prohibition of financial assistance is not entirely clear when it comes to its application to the company’s indirect shareholders or to the acquisition of shares of one the company’s direct or indirect shareholders. There are no precedents and therefore some risk remains that the courts could adopt an extensive interpretation of the provision. There is no explicit corporate benefit rule in the context of granting security for the obligations of third parties. However, under the general rules of the Companies Act of FBiH, the management is obliged to act in the company’s best interest and is liable for damages to the company and the shareholders in case of a breach of this duty. Upstream or cross stream guarantee/security may be potentially open to a challenge by way of an actio _pauliana. The rules on action pauliana, found in the Obligations Act, provide that a creditor having a due_ claim may file a lawsuit for avoidance of a transaction undertaken by its debtor, as far as the effects of that transaction on the creditor are concerned, if the transaction is deemed to be to the detriment of the challenging creditor, i.e. if as a result of such a transaction the debtor does not have enough assets to satisfy the creditor’s claim. The court practice concerning the foregoing in the context of third-party guarantees/security and corporate benefit, capital maintenance and financial assistance concepts is undeveloped in FBiH. Theoretically, a third-party guarantee/security given for no consideration can also be challenged for lack of causa (commercial reason underlying the transaction).

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Other Noteworthy Procedural Points Regarding Guarantees/Securities
Subsubsection Text: To secure priority for a pledge and its judicial enforcement, a registration with the Pledges Registry, which is maintained by the Ministry of Justice of Bosnia and Herzegovina, should be performed based on a written pledge agreement. In addition, it should be noted that the Parallel Debt concept has not been tested under the laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Theoretically, the concept can be challenged as simulated contract or for lack of causa. However, a more compelling argument seems to be that if a Parallel Debt concept is enforceable under the law governing the financing documentation, there is no public policy norm of FBiH law that should be able to override this. In Bosnia and Herzegovina there is no comparable structure to the common law trust, due to the principle of accessority where a security may only be validly created in favour of the creditor(s) holding the secured claims The issue is typically solved through the appointment of a security agent, acting as a joint and several creditor (solidarni povjerilac) of each and every obligation of the borrower towards each creditor and/or by employing a Parallel Debt concept. However, the respective structures have not yet been tested before Bosnia and Herzegovina courts, although they are commonly used in cross-border financings. _Pledge Registry Software Platform Deficiencies_ The software of the Pledge Registry does not technically enable pledge registration with the pledgor being a foreign (i.e., non-Bosnian) entity. The web platform for pledge registration technically allows only a Bosnian domiciled pledgor to be recorded. The perfection (i.e., registration) of a share pledge over a Bosnian company’s shares by a non-resident shareholder is therefore practically unavailable and may only be effected with the intentional incorrect inscription of the country of origin of the pledgor (i.e., only by selecting the item “Bosnia and Herzegovina” from the dropdown menu). In practice the parties often opt to conclude the share pledge agreement in a form of notarial deed (notarski obrađena isprava) that constitutes an enforceable instrument (izvršna isprava). Even so, execution of the share pledge agreement in the form of a notarial deed does not constitute the pledge over the shares of the company, but only a pledge in respect of the enforceable deed. In an insolvency scenario, this would mean that such a creditor would not qualify as a secured creditor (razlučni povjerilac).

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Enforcement proceedings are regulated by the Enforcement Proceedings Act of FBiH. ----- According to the Enforcement Proceedings Act, enforcement procedures over property in Bosnia and Herzegovina may be commenced only upon obtaining a valid enforcement title which may be, inter alia, in the form of a notarized agreement. A certificate of registration of the pledge issued by the Pledge Registry is deemed to be an enforcement title, as well.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: The procedure starts with a creditor filing an enforcement motion. The enforcement motion must include information about the enforcement title and the relevant debtor’s assets that are targeted by the procedure. Upon filing the enforcement motion the court has eight days to decide on the motion; however, in practice this deadline is usually extended. If the court considers the motion admissible and justified, it will grant allow enforcement on the basis of a decision on enforcement. The enforcement creditor and the enforcement debtor may object to the court’s decision within eight days from its receipt. If one of the parties files an objection, the other party has three days to submit its response. Upon receipt of the response or the expiration of the three-day period without a response being submitted, the court may decide on the matter or schedule a hearing. The court decides whether the objection is granted or denied or whether it is refused as untimely, incomplete or inadmissible. If the court accepts the objection it dismisses the enforcement completely or partially and revokes the enforcement actions that have previously been conducted. The parties have a right to appeal the court’s decision on the objection within eight days from its receipt, under certain circumstances enumerated in the law. Objections and appeals do not suspend the enforcement proceedings, however, the settlement of debt, if pending, is postponed until the court decides on the objection except when enforcement is on debtor’s transactional bank accounts which may continue.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: According to the Enforcement Proceedings Act, a creditor who applies for enforcement must pay the estimated costs required for the enforcement proceedings in advance and do so within a certain period determined by the court. The court will suspend the enforcement proceedings if the costs are not paid within that period. If an enforcement act depends on the costs being paid in advance and the payment is not made before that date, the relevant enforcement act may not be carried out. The enforcement debtor must compensate the creditor for the costs incurred by it that are necessary to carry out the enforcement and the enforcement creditor must compensate the debtor for any costs it has caused unnecessarily.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Enforcement Procedures in Relation to Pledges
Subsubsection Text: Enforcement of pledge pursuant to Framework Pledge Act of BiH is initiated by the pledgee upon a breach of the pledge agreement by the pledgor. The pledgee must present the pledge contract and the certificate of registration to the competent court. The certificate of registration is the enforcement title, provided that the contents of the registration fully correspond to the contents of the pledge agreement. Upon filing the enforcement motion the court has eight days to decide on the motion. In its enforcement motion the creditor may request either that the court bailiff takes the collateral from the pledgee and sells it or that the court bailiff seizes the security from the debtor and sells it. If the creditor submits a motion proposing the latter, the court bailiff is required to seize the collateral within eight days from the issuance of the court’s decision and then to sell it.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: As of July 2021, the new Insolvency Act provides for a pre-insolvency restructuring process called “preinsolvency procedure” (predstečajni postupak). This pre-insolvency currently exists in addition to the traditional restructuring process and as a part of the insolvency procedure, and similarly to the insolvency procedure, its main steps must be sanctioned by a court. The pre-insolvency procedure under the Insolvency Act may be applied when there is a “threatening illiquidity” (prijeteća platežna nesposobnost), but where the debtor is still not insolvent. The threatening illiquidity is defined as a forecast that the debtor will not be able to satisfy its debt in accordance with its due repayment plan in the following 12 months or if the debtor is in a 60-days default with respect to the fulfillment of its monetary obligations. The debtor or the creditor (with the debtor’s consent) can file an application for the initiation of insolvency proceedings on this ground. Additionally, there are two main reasons for initiating insolvency proceedings—insolvency and threatened insolvency. In general, a debtor is insolvent if (a) it is unable to settle its due obligations for a period of 60 consecutive days, or (b) its bank accounts are blocked for a period of 60 consecutive days. ----- Insolvency proceedings are initiated upon a written petition of an authorized person. Authorized persons include the debtor and all creditors who have a legally recognized interest in the conduct of the proceedings. The creditor is required to demonstrate, by attaching appropriate documentation, that its claim and the inability of the debtor to make payments is probable. Only the insolvency debtor is entitled to initiate insolvency proceedings due to threatened insolvency. Insolvency proceedings are generally conducted in two phases, a preliminary phase and the insolvency proceedings themselves. The preliminary procedure is conducted by the insolvency court, which can also appoint an interim insolvency administrator. The main purpose of the preliminary procedure is to determine in principle whether the conditions for the opening insolvency are satisfied, i.e. whether any of the insolvency grounds exist, whether there is a sufficient basis for the petition, whether there are sufficient funds to cover the costs of the insolvency proceedings and whether the current operations can be maintained and continued without detriment to the debtor, potential insolvency estate and/or creditors. The insolvency proceedings, once opened, are conducted by the insolvency administrator appointed by the court and insolvency judge. An alternative to these two-step proceedings is direct bankruptcy, in cases where (i) a petition is filed by the company’s liquidator or (ii) a creditor files an insolvency petition supported by a final and binding decision on enforcement that is not satisfied for a period of at least 90 days. The general effects of the opening of insolvency proceedings include a stay of pending court and arbitral proceedings involving the insolvency estate, and pro rata satisfaction of creditors upon sale of the debtor’s assets by the administrator, in accordance with their payment ranks. Creditors with a separate satisfaction right (mortgagees, pledgees, creditors to which the debtor transferred rights as security, creditors with retention rights) have payment priority in insolvency proceedings and have the right to separate settlement from the proceeds of the asset serving as collateral. Only the insolvency administrator is authorized to dispose of the debtor’s assets and any disposal by the insolvency debtor is without legal effect, except in the case of disposals to which general rules of legitimate reliance on land registers or other appropriate public registers apply. As of the date of the opening of insolvency proceedings, all bank accounts are closed and the insolvency administrator opens a new bank account onto which all insolvency debtor’s funds from the closed accounts are transferred. There is no provision ensuring that the pledge on closed bank accounts transfers onto the new bank account. Guarantees and other security for third-party debt provided within a certain period preceding the opening of the insolvency proceedings may be challenged if they can be considered as giving preference to certain creditors, as follows: - guarantees and security given within the period of 12 months prior to the submission of the petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings, if at that time the debtor was insolvent or the creditor knew of such insolvency or did not know due to gross negligence; - guarantees and security given after the submission of the petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings if the creditor knew of the debtor’s insolvency or the motion for the opening of the insolvency proceedings at the time or did not know due to gross negligence; - guarantees and security given in the 90-days preceding the petition or after the submission thereof; and - guarantees and security given within the six months preceding the petition for the opening of the insolvency proceedings if the debtor was insolvent at such time. If the creditor is a related party, the awareness of the debtor’s insolvency is presumed. In addition, loans granted in substitution to capital contributions are subordinated to all other claims during the insolvency proceedings. Capital replacing loans are defined as loans that are granted at a critical time for the company, when the company’s shareholders could have been reasonably expected to contribute capital to the company, rather than grant loans. This also includes other legally binding transactions that are economically equivalent to loan. Granting of security for the claim of a company’s shareholder for repayment of a loan (or an equivalent thereof) given at the time when capital contribution should have been provided is voidable if the transaction took place within five years immediately preceding the opening of insolvency proceedings or after the petition. A legally binding transaction settling the claim of a company’s shareholder for repayment of a loan or economically equivalent transaction is voidable if the transaction took place in the three years preceding the opening of proceedings or after the petition. It is unclear whether the loans which fall under this provision are ----- only those given by the direct shareholder or also include loans by indirect shareholders or affiliates controlled by (in)direct shareholders and there is no relevant court practice.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Pursuant to the Financial Dealings Act of FBiH, if illiquidity occurs (as defined under that law), the company cannot execute any payments except those necessary in the ordinary course of business and those aimed at restoring liquidity. The following are deemed payments in the ordinary course of business: (a) procurement of goods and services for ordinary business activities; (b) operational costs of business (energy, water and similar); (c) salaries of workers; (d) VAT, excise duties, social contributions and other taxes that have to be calculated and paid in accordance with the law; (e) costs related to procedures before public bodies; and (f) costs related to documentation needed for commencement and implementation of financial consolidation and restructuring activities. In addition, the Financial Dealings Act prescribes that a company cannot perform any activity that may damage creditors or put certain creditors into unfavorable position, in particular: - diverting cash payments or financial flows to other persons; - lending; - distributing dividends, profits or payment of profits in advance; - transferring rights to third parties, and especially to related companies; and - procuring automobiles or spare parts for such vehicles, payments for business entertainment, accommodation expenses and similar. Accordingly, a company affected by illiquidity cannot make payments under a guarantee while that situation is pending. In addition, pursuant to the Financial Dealings Act, companies are obliged to maintain capital adequacy. Capital inadequacy exists if as of the date of the relevant financial statements, losses, including losses carried forward from earlier financial years, amount to at least 1/2 of the registered capital. In case of capital inadequacy, the management of the company is obliged to implement measures intended for restoring capital adequacy within its competence, such as finding adequate sources of financing, as well as convening a shareholders assembly and proposing to shareholders to take measures within its competence (such as, e.g. reducing registered capital to cover losses).

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Telemach BH is a company organized in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (“FBiH”), which is one of the two entities of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Accordingly, the following discussion is limited to the relevant laws and regulations applicable in FBiH. Pursuant to the Foreign Exchange Act of FBiH (“FBiH FX Act”), cross border payments from and to FBiH are permitted if made in accordance with that law. The FBiH FX Act and related bylaws refer only to the guarantees and security that a Bosnian resident grants for the debt of a non-resident to another non-resident only if granted under a so-called “credit transaction.”Credit transactions between residents and non-residents, according to the FBiH FX Act, comprise credits and loans, whereas “credit transactions” between nonresidents are not specified or separately defined. Transactions with debt and equity securities are a separate category under the FBiH FX Act. It is unlikely that the narrow definition of cross-border guarantees/security under the FBiH FX Act would be interpreted by the competent FBiH authority to mean that guarantee/ security in support of foreign debt originating under bonds could be regarded as prohibited or as contrary to public policy of FBiH, because the FBiH FX Act allows granting of guarantees/security in economically equivalent situations (loans between non-residents). Nonetheless, the issue has not been formally clarified by the competent FBiH authority. Any guarantee or other security granted by a FBiH resident in favor of a non-resident must be registered with the Ministry of Finance of FBiH. The registration application must be made (i) within 15-days from the decision on the issuance of the guarantee is passed by the relevant body of the guarantor if the underlying transaction is concluded between two non-resident entities, or (ii) within 15-days from the date of execution of the underlying transaction documents if concluded between a resident and a non-resident entity. If the underlying transaction is concluded between two non-residents, periodic reports on the status of the guarantee must be provided to the Ministry of Finance of FBiH. In addition, any company based in FBiH that issues a guarantee or provides other security to a non-resident must obtain from non-resident a security instrument that hedges the risk of the guarantee being called. The FBiH FX Act does not contain any further details regarding such a security instrument. Nonetheless, the counter-guarantee instrument is scrutinized by the Ministry of Finance of FBiH, which typically requests presentation of a proof of a liquid security instrument and employs wide discretion when assessing and approving counter-guarantees. The Ministry’s restrictive practice is continually evolving, and varies on a caseby-case basis. Pursuant to article 7(2) of the FBiH FX Act, a commercial bank is prohibited to perform a payment order and from wiring funds abroad if such payment or transfer is in violation of the law, subject to administrative fines. In this context, there is a theoretical risk that a local bank might reject making relevant payments outside Bosnia and Herzegovina without proof that the cross-border guarantee has been approved by the Ministry of Finance of FBiH. -----

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Pursuant to Luxembourg insolvency laws, your ability to receive payment under the New Notes may be more limited than would be the case under U.S. bankruptcy laws. Under Luxembourg law, the following types of proceedings (together referred to as insolvency proceedings) may be initiated against a company incorporated in Luxembourg having its centre of main interests (within the meaning of the E.U. Insolvency Regulation) or an establishment in Luxembourg (in the latter case assuming that the centre of main interests is located in a jurisdiction where the E.U. Insolvency Regulation is applicable): - bankruptcy proceedings (faillite), the opening of which may be requested by the company, by any of its creditors or by the courts ex officio. Following such a request, the Luxembourg courts having jurisdiction may open bankruptcy proceedings if a Luxembourg company: (i) is in a state of cessation of payments (cessation des paiements); and (ii) has lost its commercial creditworthiness (ébranlement de crédit). The main effect of such proceedings is the sale of the assets and allocation of the proceeds of such sale between creditors taking into account their rank of privilege, as well as the suspension of all measures of enforcement against the company, except, subject to certain limited exceptions (please see the below applicable provision of the Luxembourg law dated August 5, 2005 concerning financial collateral arrangements, as amended ----- (the “Financial Collateral Law 2005”)), for enforcement by secured creditors and the payment of the secured creditors in accordance with their rank upon realization of the assets. In addition, the managers or directors of a Luxembourg company that ceases its payments (i.e. is unable to pay its debts as they fall due with normal means of payment) must within a month of them having become aware of the company’s cessation of payments, file a petition for bankruptcy (faillite) with the court clerk of the district court of the company’s registered office. A law of December 19, 2020 (amended on June 30, 2021) has suspended this one month delay until December 31, 2021. If the managers or directors fail to comply with such provision they may be held (i) liable towards the company or any third parties on the basis of principles of managers’ / directors’liability for any loss suffered and (ii) criminally liable for simple bankruptcy (banqueroute simple) in accordance with article 574 of the Luxembourg commercial code. - controlled management proceedings (gestion contrôlée), the opening of which may only be requested by the company and not by its creditors and under which a Luxembourg court may order the provisional stay of enforcement of claims except for secured creditors (please see the below applicable provision of the Financial Collateral Law 2005); or - composition proceedings (concordat préventif de la faillite), the opening of which may only be requested by the company and not by its creditors directly. The Luxembourg court’s decision to admit a company to composition proceedings triggers a provisional stay on enforcement of claims by creditors except, among others, for secured creditors (please see the below applicable provisions of the Financial Collateral Law 2005). - In addition to these proceedings, your ability to receive payment on the New Notes may be affected by a decision of a Luxembourg court to grant a stay on payments (sursis de paiement) or to put a Luxembourg company into judicial liquidation (liquidation judiciaire). Judicial liquidation proceedings may be opened at the request of the public prosecutor against companies pursuing an activity violating criminal laws or that are in serious breach or violation of the Luxembourg commercial code or of the Law 1915. The management of such liquidation proceedings will generally follow similar rules as those applicable to Luxembourg bankruptcy proceedings. Liability of any of the Guarantors existing under the laws of Luxembourg in respect of the relevant Notes will, in the event of a liquidation of the company following bankruptcy or judicial liquidation proceedings, only rank after the cost of liquidation (including any debt incurred for the purpose of such liquidation) and any claims that are preferred under Luxembourg law. Preferential claims under Luxembourg law include, among others: - remuneration owed to employees (last six months’ wages amounting to a maximum of six times the minimum social salary); - employees’ contributions to social security; - certain amounts owed to the Luxembourg Revenue; - employer’s contribution to social security; - landlord, pledgor not under the Financial Collateral Law 2005; and - value added tax and other taxes and duties owed to Luxembourg Customs and Excise. Assets over which a security interest has been granted will in principle not be available for distribution to unsecured and unpreferred creditors (except after enforcement and to the extent a surplus is realized). Favorable rules apply in relation to security interests of claims or financial instruments securing monetary claims (or claims for the delivery of financial instruments) pursuant to the Financial Collateral Law 2005. Article 20 of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides that Luxembourg law financial collateral arrangements (pledges, security assignments and repo agreements) over claims and financial instruments, as well as valuation and enforcement measures agreed upon by the parties are valid and enforceable even if entered into during the pre-bankruptcy preference period (période suspecte) against third parties, commissioners, receivers, liquidators and other similar persons notwithstanding the insolvency proceedings (save in the case of fraud). Article 24 of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides that foreign law security interests over claims or financial instruments granted by a Luxembourg pledgor will be valid and enforceable as a matter of Luxembourg law notwithstanding any Luxembourg insolvency proceedings, if such foreign law security interests are similar in nature to a Luxembourg security interest falling within the scope of the Financial Collateral Law 2005. If article 24 applies, Luxembourg preference period rules are disapplied (save the case of fraud). ----- Article 21(2) of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides that where a financial collateral arrangement has been entered into after the opening of liquidation proceedings or the coming into force of reorganization measures or the entry into force of such measures, such arrangement is enforceable against third parties, administrators, insolvency receivers, liquidators and other similar persons if the collateral taker proves that it was unaware of the fact that such proceedings had been opened or that such measures had been taken or that it could not reasonably be aware of such proceedings, measures or arrangement.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Impact of Luxembourg Insolvency Proceedings on Transactions
Subsubsection Text: During such insolvency proceedings, all enforcement measures by unsecured creditors are suspended. Other than as described above, the ability of certain secured creditors to enforce their security interest may also be limited, in particular in the event of controlled management proceedings expressly providing that the rights of secured creditors are frozen until a final decision has been taken by a Luxembourg court as to the petition for controlled management, and may be affected thereafter by a reorganization order given by the court. A reorganization order requires the prior approval by more than 50% of the creditors representing more than 50% of any of the relevant Guarantor’s liabilities in order to take effect. Furthermore, you should note that declarations of default and subsequent acceleration (such as acceleration upon the occurrence of an event of default) may not be enforceable during controlled management proceedings. However, during such controlled management proceedings a notice of default may still be served. Luxembourg insolvency laws may also affect transactions entered into or payments made by any of the relevant Guarantors incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg during the preference period (période suspecte) which is a maximum of six months preceding the judgment declaring bankruptcy, except that in certain specific situations the court may set the start of the suspect period at an earlier date. In particular: - pursuant to article 445 of the Luxembourg code of commerce (Code de commerce), specified transactions (such as, in particular, the granting of a security interest for antecedent debts save in respect of financial collateral arrangements within the meaning of the Financial Collateral Law 2005; payment of debts which have not fallen due, whether payment is made in cash or by way of assignment, sale, set-off or by any other means; the payment of debts which have fallen due by any means other than in cash or by bill of exchange; the sale of assets without consideration or with substantially inadequate consideration) entered into during the preference period (or the ten days preceding it) must be set aside or declared null and void, if so requested by the insolvency receiver; - pursuant to article 446 of the Luxembourg code of commerce, payments made for matured debts as well as other transactions concluded for consideration during the preference period are subject to cancellation by the court upon proceedings instituted by the insolvency receiver if they were concluded with the knowledge of the bankrupt party’s cessation of payments; and - pursuant to article 448 of the Luxembourg code of commerce and article 1167 of the Luxembourg civil code (action paulienne), the insolvency receiver (acting on behalf of the creditors) has the right to challenge any fraudulent payments and transactions, including the granting of security with an intent to defraud, made prior to the bankruptcy, without any time limit. In principle, a bankruptcy order rendered by a Luxembourg court does not result in the automatic termination of contracts except for employment agreements and powers of attorney. The contracts, therefore, subsist after the bankruptcy order. However, the bankruptcy receiver may choose to terminate certain contracts so as to avoid worsening the financial situation of the company. As of the date of adjudication of bankruptcy, no interest on any unsecured claim will accrue vis à vis the bankruptcy estate. Insolvency proceedings may hence have a material adverse effect on any of the relevant Guarantors’ business and assets and the relevant Guarantors’ respective obligations under the New Notes. Finally, international aspects of Luxembourg bankruptcy, controlled management or composition proceedings may be subject to the E.U. Insolvency Regulation. In particular, rights in rem over assets located in another jurisdiction where the E.U. Insolvency Regulation will not be affected by the opening of insolvency proceedings, without prejudice however to the applicability of rules relating to the voidness, voidability or unenforceability of legal acts detrimental to all the creditors (subject to the application of article 24 of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 as described above and article 16 of the E.U. Insolvency Regulation).

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Under Luxembourg law, contracts are in principle formed by the mere agreement (consentement) between the parties thereto. However, additional steps are required to enforce security interests against third parties. ----- If there are assets located or deemed to be located in Luxembourg, the security interests over such assets will be governed by Luxembourg law and must be created, perfected and enforced in accordance with Luxembourg law. The Financial Collateral Law 2005 governs the creation, validity, perfection and enforcement of pledges over securities, bank account balances and receivables located or deemed to be located in Luxembourg. Security interests such as pledges, and transfer of ownership as a security, granted on financial instruments and claims are governed by the Financial Collateral Law 2005. Pursuant to such law, pledge is effected, not by transfer of title, but by a transfer of possession of the pledged assets to the pledgor or to a third-party acting as depository for the pledgor and the pledgor’s preference rights over the pledged assets only remain in existence as long as the pledgor or the depository remains in possession of such assets. A physical transfer of possession not being possible for intangibles such as monetary claims, the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides for a fictitious transfer of possession which is effected by mechanisms which depend on the nature of the intangibles involved. In case of registered shares, the dispossession is achieved by the entry of the security interest in the share register of the relevant Luxembourg company. In case of claims, dispossession is effected as against the debtor and any third parties by the execution of the relevant pledge agreement. Nonetheless, the debtor of a pledged claim may validly discharge its obligation by performance rendered to the pledgor as long as it has no knowledge of the pledge. Dispossession of cash collateral is achieved by the security interest thereon being notified by the debtor and the acceptance thereof by the debtor of such claims. Absent perfection, the holder of the security interest may have difficulty enforcing his/its rights in the collateral with regard to third parties, including a trustee in bankruptcy and other creditors who claim a security interest in the same collateral. Finally, since the ranking of pledges is determined by the date on which they became enforceable against third parties, a security interest created on a later date over the same collateral, but which come into force for third parties earlier (by way of registration in the appropriate register or by notification) has priority.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: The Law 1915 does not provide for rules governing the ability of a Luxembourg company to guarantee the indebtedness of another entity of the same group. A company may give a guarantee provided the giving of the guarantee is covered by the company’s corporate purpose, corporate benefit and is in the best interest of the company. Although no statutory definition of corporate benefit (intérêt social) exists under Luxembourg law, corporate benefit is widely interpreted and includes any transactions from which the company derives a direct or indirect economic or commercial benefit in return (such as an economic or commercial benefit) and whether the benefit is proportionate to the burden of the assistance. It is generally held that within a group of companies, the corporate interest of each individual corporate entity can include, to a certain extent, the interest of the group, and that the existence of a group interest can in certain cases result in the guarantee being held enforceable even where corporate benefit is not established. In this way, reciprocal assistance from one group company to another does not necessarily conflict with the interest of the assisting company. However, this assistance must be temporary, in proportion to the real financial means of the assisting company (i.e., limited to an aggregate amount not exceeding the assisting company’s own funds (capitaux propres)), the company must receive some benefit or there must be a balance between the respective commitments of all the affiliates and the companies involved must form part of a genuine group operating under a common strategy aimed at a common objective. As a result, the guarantees/security interests granted by a Luxembourg company may be subject to limitations in order to ensure their enforceability. Further, a guarantee or security interest that substantially exceeds the guarantor’s or security provider’s ability to meet its obligations to the beneficiary of the guarantee/security provider and to its other creditors, or from which the Luxembourg company derives no or very limited direct benefit in return, or where no direct or indirect consideration is granted to the company in exchange, would expose its directors or managers to personal liability. In addition to any criminal and civil liability incurred by the directors or managers of the Luxembourg company, in extreme circumstances the guarantee or security interest could itself be held unenforceable, if it is held that it is contrary to public policy (ordre public), in the case of facts consisting of a misuse of corporate assets. Any guarantee granted in connection with the New Notes by Luxembourg companies may be limited to a certain percentage of, among others, the relevant company’s net worth. The Indenture provides for general limitation language to the effect that each guarantee granted therein and each security interest granted as well as any other obligation, liability or indemnification under a security document will be limited to the maximum amount that can be guaranteed/ secured by the relevant guarantor/security provider with respect to the aggregate obligations and exposure of the guarantor/security provider without rendering the relevant guarantee/security interest voidable or otherwise ineffective under Luxembourg and other applicable law. If one or more of these laws and defenses ----- are applicable, a Guarantor may have no liability or decreased liability under its guarantee or the security documents to which it is a party.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: The validity, binding effect and enforceability of guarantees/security interests granted by Bulgarian guarantors may be limited or otherwise be affected by the applicable stabilization or insolvency proceedings against the Bulgarian guarantors, avoidance or similar laws of general application relating to or affecting the enforcement of creditors’ rights and remedies, as well as financial assistance prohibitions. These are reviewed in turn below.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: As of 2017 Bulgarian law also provides for a pre-insolvency restructuring procedure called “stabilization procedure.” It currently exists as an additional procedure to the traditional restructuring as a part of the insolvency procedure, and it is similarly to the insolvency procedure a procedure, the main steps in which must be sanctioned by a court. The stabilization procedure under the Bulgarian Commerce Act may be applied when there is a “threat of insolvency” but where the debtor is still not insolvent. Actually, all court cases since the inception of the new procure have been focused on whether the requirements for launching stabilization were fulfilled and all publicly available judgments so far, the courts held that the debtor was actually insolvent (in most cases over-indebted), so insolvency rather than stabilization procedure had to be opened. We are not aware of any case where the new procedure was applied, and the debtor was successfully restructured to avoid insolvency. In terms of substance, the stabilization procedure provides for a temporary standstill where all court enforcement and out of court enforcement procedures (including those under special pledges) shall be stopped. Further there are rules for partial cram down of the debtor’s liabilities. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Bulgaria has not yet transposed Directive (EU) 2019/1023. Although a draft bill was published on the webpage of the Bulgarian government on February 26, 2021, the legislative implementation process that starts with a submission of a draft bill to the Bulgarian Parliament has not yet been commenced. In addition, since following the parliamentary elections in Bulgaria that took place on April 4, 2021, no government could be formed, new elections took place on July 11, 2021. The results of the new elections were similar to those held in April 2021 and therefore there is uncertainty on whether a government will be formed. As a result, there is a risk that the July 17, 2021 deadline for the implementation of Directive (EU) 2019/1023 in Bulgaria may not be met. However, this Directive is expected to be implemented approximately in the second half of 2021. The exact timing for such implementation will depend on the formation and stability of a new government.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Should a Bulgarian guarantor have its “centre of main interests” (which is presumed to be the case due to their incorporation in Bulgaria, unless something else is proven) they may be subject to Bulgarian insolvency proceedings. The insolvency proceedings do not affect out of court enforcement over Bulgarian special pledges, only if the out of court enforcement was commenced before launching of the insolvency proceedings. Otherwise the pledgee under a special pledge may only satisfy within the insolvency proceedings having a first-ranking priority over the insolvency proceeds from the collateral. A Bulgarian guarantor would be deemed insolvent in any of the following three cases occurs. The first case is one of balance sheet insolvency (over indebtedness). When a creditor claims that a debtor is balance sheet insolvent (as a ground for commencement of insolvency proceedings against the latter) it has to be established that the debtor’s “liabilities exceed his assets.” All liabilities must be compared to all assets for the purpose. This includes all existing liabilities including those that are not yet due (e.g. future payments under an existing contract). Contingent (conditional) liabilities however are not covered. There is no formal requirement that the negative balance for the purposes of over indebtedness should be substantial and though the dominating understanding among scholars is that minor negative balance should not be taken into account where the prospects for the entity are positive, it cannot be ruled out that even a minor negative balance may trigger over indebtedness. The second case is the one of cash flow insolvency. This means a state of inability to pay: (i) a monetary obligation under or in relation to a commercial transaction, or (ii) public law obligation towards the State/municipalities connected with the commercial activity of the entity; or (iii) private law obligation towards the State/municipalities. So, in the cash flow insolvency scenario a creditor must establish both: (i) the existence of a particular payment obligation of any of the three types listed above that was due but was not paid ----- (i.e.—the “First Condition”), and the inability of the debtor to pay (“Second Condition”). The First Condition involves establishment of only factual matters. The Second Condition however requires again a comparison between assets and liabilities of the debtor, although in a more limited manner (compared to the over indebtedness scenario). In particular (according to the case law) in order to determine whether a debtor is unable to pay, the ratio has to be established between the current/short-term assets (i.e. those that can be easily turned into cash) vis à vis short-term liabilities (i.e. existing liabilities with a maturity of up to 1 year in the future). If the ratio is below 1 (meaning that the short-term liabilities exceed the short-term assets), it is normally presumed that the debtor is unable to pay (i.e. the Second Condition is met). The third case where insolvency proceedings should be opened is the one of “concealed insolvency.” This means that an entity is concealing commercial activity behind an insolvent entity, so if that is proven to be case insolvency proceedings must be opened against the former. In general, the opening of insolvency proceedings by a Bulgarian court does not result in the automatic termination of contracts. However, the insolvency administrator may choose to terminate certain contracts as to avoid the worsening of the financial condition of the company. Any power of attorney terminates upon initiation of bankruptcy proceedings provided that the insolvency court has established that the debtor jeopardizes the interests of creditors and that the debtor has been deprived of the right to manage and dispose of the property of the company. Insolvency proceedings may therefore have a material adverse effect on the relevant Vivacom Guarantor’s business and assets and the Vivacom Guarantor’s respective obligations with respect to the New Notes.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Within the insolvency proceedings certain Bulgarian avoidance rule may have to be considered. The general claim that creditors may take recourse to, even if there is no insolvency is Actio Pauliana (павлов иск) under art. 135 of the Obligations and Contracts Act. Under that claim a creditor may request that any act of the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider having a detrimental effect on the creditor be declared void as against the creditor, provided that the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider knew about that detrimental effect at the time of performing the act. In the context of non-gratuitous acts, the plaintiff (creditor) must furthermore prove that counterparty (creditor) to the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider also knew about the detrimental effect of the challenged act on other creditors. This means proof that both the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider and its counterparty knew there were other creditors having valid claims existing before the challenged act and the act in question was detrimental to them. Pure knowledge is sufficient, it is not necessary to prove that there was intention to inflict detrimental effect on the other creditors. However, if the parties intend to defraud the other creditors it is not necessary as a prerequisite for the Actio Pauliana that the respective creditor’s claim should have arisen before the challenged act. The detrimental effect for the purposes of Actio Pauliana exists if the possibility for the creditor to satisfy himself from the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider’s property is reduced, which means that via the challenged act created or increased its state of inability to pay to other creditors. In addition (subject to some technical exceptions) the following acts and transactions may be declared null and void with respect to the insolvency creditors if made by the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider after the initial date of insolvency or over indebtedness and cumulatively—within the timelines—under the following items (i) (iii) before the submission of the application for opening of insolvency proceedings: (i) performance of a monetary obligation that was not yet due (неизискуемо) regardless of the manner of performance made within a one year period; (ii) performance of a monetary obligation that was due (изискуемо) regardless of the manner of performance made within a six month period; and (iii) establishing a pledge, mortgage or personal security (i.e. a guarantee) to secure a previously not secured obligation made within a two year period. In addition to other general statutory rules providing for setting aside of certain acts and transactions, the following acts and transactions carried out by the debtor (within the timeline under items 1 3 below) before the submission of the application for opening of insolvency proceedings may be set aside with respect to the insolvency creditors: (i) establishment of a mortgage, pledge or personal security for another person’s debts, effected within one year, but not earlier than the date of the insolvency or over indebtedness, as the case may be; (ii) establishment of a mortgage, pledge or personal security for another person’s debts to the benefit of a creditor, which is a related party to the debtor, effected within two years; (iii) a transaction that is detrimental to the creditors, a party to which is a person related to the debtor, effected within two years; (iv) a transaction where the consideration provided by the insolvent Bulgarian guarantor/security provider exceeds significantly the consideration granted by its counterparty, effected within 2 years period before the submission of the application for opening of insolvency proceedings but not earlier than the date when the Bulgarian guarantor/ ----- security provider was in a state of inability to pay or over indebtedness; (v) gratuitous transaction made within a two year period (resp. three years if made to a related person). Lastly, the following shall be considered null and void (in accordance with art. 646, par. 1 of the Bulgarian Commerce Act (Търговски закон)) with respect to the insolvency creditors if carried out after the date of the decision on opening of insolvency proceedings and in violation of the insolvency procedures: (i) performance of an obligation that had occurred prior to the date of the decision on opening of insolvency proceedings; (ii) establishing a pledge, or mortgage; (iii) transactions with rights or properties from the insolvency estate.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Limitations with respect to corporate benefit
Subsubsection Text: Bulgarian law does not explicitly require the existence of a corporate benefit upon the grant of security for a third-party debt. However, the grant of the SSN Guarantees and the security interests by the Vivacom SSN Guarantors without benefit or obvious rationale for the Vivacom SSN Guarantors may be interpreted as an act with a detrimental effect and thus subject to certain of the claims set forth in “Avoidance Claims” above, such as: (i) actio pauliana (Павлов иск) within and outside of insolvency and (ii) insolvency avoidance claims within insolvency.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: The obligations of the Vivacom SSN Guarantors are further limited to the extent that they result in (i) over indebtedness (свръхзадлъжнялост) in the meaning of Article 742, paragraph 1 of the Bulgarian Commerce Act (Търговски закон), promulgated in State Gazette No. 48/18.06.1991, effective July 1, 1991, as amended, and (ii) a state of immediate threat of insolvency in the sense of Article 762, paragraph 1 (непосредствена _опасност от неплатежоспособност) of the Bulgarian Commerce Act._

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Limitations with respect to subordination arrangements
Subsubsection Text: The subordination arrangements in the SSN Guarantees assumed by the Vivacom SSN Guarantors (see “SSN Guarantees” above) may not be enforceable against third parties in case of enforcement proceedings against the Vivacom SSN Guarantors in Bulgaria. There is still no court judgement in Bulgaria confirming that the respective public or private bailiff (държавен или частен съдебен изпълнител) or insolvency administrator (синдик) who would be in charge of the distribution among creditors should in case of such arrangements disregard the statutory rules on ranking of creditors and apply instead the contractual subordination arrangements. Certain academic scholars insist that subordination arrangements may not be binding to any third-party different to those under the contract and would in particular would not bind the respective public or private bailiff (държавен или частен съдебен изпълнител) or insolvency administrator (синдик) as the procedural rules for creditors ranking are mandatory in nature.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Validity of guarantees in connection with litigation involving the Vivacom Group
Subsubsection Text: The validity, binding effect and enforceability of guarantees and security interests granted by the Vivacom SSN Guarantors may be limited or otherwise be affected by the litigation described in “Our Business—Legal _Proceedings.”_

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Use of Security Agent and Parallel Debt
Subsubsection Text: Under Bulgarian law, security interests can be granted to a security trustee for the claims of all bondholders only if the security trustee is a bank. Parallel debt arrangements governed by a foreign system of law are also often used, mainly for credit agreements where the Bulgarian security trustee concept is not applicable. We note that parallel debt structures governed by a foreign law under which such arrangements are valid and enforceable have not yet been tested in Bulgarian courts.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Enforcement over Bulgarian Special Pledges—General Rules
Subsubsection Text: Under Bulgarian law, depending on the type of security, certain perfection requirements as set forth below must be satisfied in order for a security to become enforceable. The following enforcement mechanisms are possible: (i) court execution over dematerialized shares in a joint stock company (and sale) pursuant to the statutory provisions on execution and securing of claims (for which a prior writ of execution is required); and (ii) out of court execution over dematerialized shares in a joint stock company or shares (quotas) in a limited liability company through a private sale, pursuant to the currently ----- effective legislation and as of January 2022 (unless extensions are introduced), are required to be carried out under rules involving greater transparency and publicity than the existing rules, whereas the choice between court or out of court execution is at the sole discretion of the pledgor. Regarding collateral enforcement in this section only out of court enforcement of non-possessory special pledges (over going concerns, shares in limited liability companies and joint stock companies) under Bulgarian law will be considered. The term “out of court” refers to an extra judicial summary procedure for the seizure and sale of the collateral (i.e., a procedure without court involvement), pursuant to the rules set out in the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. Under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act, such out of court enforcement (i) does not require a prior Bulgarian, or any other court judgment, arbitral award, writ of execution or other judicial ruling; (ii) may be undertaken without acceleration of the New Notes for the amount outstanding and payable under the New Notes at the date of enforcement; and (iii) may be carried out simultaneously, independently and irrespective of any insolvency proceedings that may be opened with respect to the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider. This out of court Collateral enforcement is in effect a “fast track” recovery procedure irrespective of any other pending or contemplated actions or litigation proceedings. The enforcement starts with a notification of the commencement of out of court pledge enforcement to the Bulgarian Central Register of Special Pledges or another register depending on the type of collateral by the Trustee, on behalf and at the direction of holders of the New Notes. This does not require the assistance or the consent of the respective Bulgarian pledgor. The Trustee shall notify the respective pledgor of the commencement of the out of court enforcement proceeding, specifying, amongst other information, the nature of the default, the outstanding amount due and payable, and the collateral subject to sale. This notification may be served on the pledgee immediately following the notification to the respective register. Upon service of the above-mentioned notifications to the register and the applicable pledgor the Trustee is entitled to take possession of the Collateral that is the subject of enforcement. In the event the pledgor refuses to voluntarily surrender such Collateral, the Trustee may seek the intervention of and engage a bailiff (public or private enforcement officer) at the expense of the pledgor. On the basis of a certificate from the register confirming that enforcement has been initiated, such bailiff is entitled to force the pledgor to surrender the collateral, with police assistance, as necessary. The collateral sale may occur after expiry of a 2 week grace period from the notification to the register, to enable making voluntary payment before the collateral is sold. During this grace period, the Trustee may nevertheless organize the collateral sale (take possession of the collateral, engage the depository (as defined below), identify creditors, and so on). The collateral sale must be undertaken by and in the name of the Trustee. The Trustee must make reasonable efforts to achieve the best price for the collateral and there are some specific requirements to publicize the terms of the sale in advance by registration with the register. The Trustee may engage the pledgee, assuming it is cooperative, as its agent to manage the actual collateral sale process. The Trustee shall appoint a professional accountant or a bailiff (the “Depository”) who will administer the proceeds collected from the collateral sale. Amongst other things, the Depository shall (i) identify the creditors who have rights to the collateral that is subject to enforcement (“Qualified Creditors”) and notify the Qualified Creditors, who have two weeks to comment, after which the definitive list of Qualified Creditors is finalized and is not subject to challenge, (ii) open a special purpose depository bank account in the name of the Depository for the collection of sale proceeds, (iii) provide information on the contemplated distribution of proceed to the creditor(s) (which will be only the Trustee as creditor on behalf of the Bondholders), and (iv) if there are no objections or challenges, distribute such proceeds to the creditors (which will be only the Trustee as creditor on behalf of the Bondholders).

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Specifics regarding Pledge over Shares in Joint Stock Companies (such as BTC) and Enforcement over such Shares
Subsubsection Text: Shares in a joint stock company, existing in a dematerialized form (such as the shares in BTC) may be pledged under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. This requires an agreement in writing and registration with the Bulgarian Central Depository which is the institution in whose databases dematerialized shares exist in a legal form. Enforcement over such shares requires respectively that the commencement of enforcement should be registered with the Central Depository AD. The enforcement may take place by an out of court transfer of the pledged shares so that the pledgee may satisfy the secured debt directly from its sale proceeds.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Title: Specifics regarding Pledge over Shares in Limited Liability Companies (such as Viva Telecom and United Group Bulgaria) and Enforcement over such Shares
Subsubsection Text: Shares in a limited liability company (such as Viva Telecom and United Group Bulgaria) may be pledged under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. This requires an agreement in writing with notarized signatures and ----- registration with the Bulgarian Commerce Register. Enforcement over such shares requires respectively that the commencement of enforcement should be registered with the Bulgarian Commerce Register. The pledgee will be restricted in its options in case of enforcement only to enforcement through a liquidation of the company the shares in which are pledged, and the pledgee may satisfy the secured debt only out of the liquidation quota for the pledgor whose quota, in turn, may only be formed after voluntary liquidation proceedings. In particular, the general possibility under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act to sell the pledged property out of court is inapplicable when it comes to enforcement over shares in a limited liability company. The attempts of some lawyers nevertheless to effect such an enforcement sale of shares in a limited liability company are regularly dismissed by the authorities in Bulgaria.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: Except for bank guarantees, under Bulgarian law there are no provisions regulating abstract guarantees that are independent of the novation or replacement of the guaranteed debt or of any changes to the creditors and the debtors under the guaranteed debt. Thus, even if a guarantee is valid under the applicable law, the Vivacom SSN Guarantors may oppose its validity based on certain Bulgarian law principles claiming that they are rules of overriding nature that should be applied regardless of the foreign applicable law. Although the overriding nature of the local rules has been confirmed by court practice with regard to certain of the limitations set forth below, there is no conclusive case law evidencing that the remaining rules would not be considered as overriding mandatory rules and/or rules of public policy. Such rules are as follows: (i) a guarantee will terminate upon novation (including by way of change of the parties or replacement of the debt) or transfer of the guaranteed debt, unless the relevant Bulgarian guarantor expressly agrees that the guarantee extends to the novated or transferred obligations; (ii) a Bulgarian guarantor will not be liable for any increased amount of the guaranteed debt, unless it has expressly agreed to such liability, and the extension of maturity of the guaranteed debt in relation to the debtor is not effective in relation to the Bulgarian guarantor, unless the Bulgarian guarantor has expressly agreed to such extension; (iii) a Bulgarian guarantor will not remain liable under the guarantee after the due date for repayment of the debt, unless the creditor has claimed repayment from the principal debtor within six months as of that repayment date; and (iv) since under Bulgarian law a guarantee would be considered as an accessory personal security, the waiver of the right to refer to the personal defenses of the respective debtor as well as to the set-off right of the respective debtor may not be enforceable under mandatory Bulgarian law and therefore the Bulgarian guarantor can avail itself of such personal defenses and set-off rights. For the same reason, the valid existence and the scope of the guarantee depends on the valid existence and the scope of the guaranteed debt. -----

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS
Subsubsection Text: _Set out below is a summary of certain limitations on the enforceability of the Guarantees and the security interests in some of the jurisdictions in which the Guarantees or Collateral are being provided. It is a summary only and does not purport to be complete or to discuss all the limitations and considerations, and bankruptcy or insolvency proceedings or similar events could be initiated in any of these jurisdictions as well as in any jurisdiction of organization of a future guarantor of the New Notes. The application of these various laws in multiple jurisdictions could trigger disputes over which jurisdiction’s law should apply to a given situation and could adversely affect your ability to enforce your rights and to collect payment in full under the New Notes, the Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral. Prospective investors in the New Notes should consult their own legal advisors in this respect. Also set forth below is a brief description of certain aspects of insolvency law in the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Slovenia and Bulgaria._

The Issuer has been advised by the Initial Purchasers that the Initial Purchasers intend to make a market in the New Notes but are not obligated to do so and may discontinue market making at any time without notice. We do not intend to apply for listing of the New Notes on any national securities exchange or for inclusion of the New Notes on any automated dealer quotation system, except that application will be made, through the Listing Agent, to the Authority for the New Notes to be admitted to the Official List of the Exchange. We cannot assure you that this application will be approved or that, if approved, such listing will be maintained. No assurance can be given as to the liquidity of the trading market for the New Notes. If an active trading market for the New Notes does not develop, the market price and liquidity of the New Notes may be adversely affected. If the New Notes are traded, they may trade at a discount from their initial offering price, depending on prevailing interest rates, the market for similar securities, the Group’s operating performance and financial condition, general economic conditions and other factors. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the New Notes, _the Guarantees and the Collateral—There may not be an active trading market for the New Notes, in which case your ability to sell the New Notes may be limited.”_

The Stabilizing Manager may engage in over-allotment, stabilizing transactions and covering transactions in accordance with Regulation M under the Exchange Act. Over-allotment involves sales in excess of the offering size, which creates a short position for the Stabilizing Manager. Stabilizing transactions permit bidders to purchase the underlying security so long as the stabilizing bids do not exceed a specified maximum. Covering ----- transactions involve purchases of the New Notes in the open market after the distribution has been completed in order to cover short positions. The Stabilizing Manager is not required to engage in these activities, and may end these activities at any time. Accordingly, no assurance can be given as to the liquidity of, or trading markets for, the New Notes. These stabilizing transactions and covering transactions may cause the price of the New Notes to be higher than it would otherwise be in the absence of these transactions.

In connection with the offering of the New Notes, the Initial Purchasers may purchase and sell the New Notes in the open market. These transactions may include short sales, stabilizing transactions and purchases to cover positions created by short sales. Short sales involve the sale by the Stabilizing Manager of a greater number of Notes than they are required to purchase in the offering of the New Notes. Stabilizing transactions consist of certain bids or purchases made for the purpose of preventing or retarding a decline in the market price of the New Notes while the offering of the New Notes is in progress. These activities by the Stabilizing Manager, as well as other purchases by the Initial Purchasers for their own accounts, may stabilize, maintain or otherwise affect the market price of the New Notes. As a result, the price of the New Notes may be higher than the price that otherwise might exist in the open market. If these activities are commenced, they may be discontinued by the Initial Purchasers at any time. These transactions may be effected in the over the counter market or otherwise. Persons who purchase New Notes from the Initial Purchasers may be required to pay stamp duty, taxes, and other charges in accordance with the laws and practice of the country of purchase in addition to the offering price set forth on the cover page hereof.

The New Notes (including the Guarantees) have not been and will not be registered under the Securities Act and may not be offered or sold within the United States except to qualified institutional buyers in reliance on Rule 144A and to non-U.S. persons in offshore transactions in reliance on Regulation S. Until 40-days after the later of (i) the commencement of the Offering and (ii) the Issue Date of the New Notes, an offer or sale of the New Notes initially sold in reliance on Regulation S within the United States by a dealer (whether or not participating in the Offering) may violate the registration requirements of the Securities Act if such offer or sale is made otherwise than in accordance with Rule 144A under the Securities Act. Terms used in this paragraph have the meanings given to them by Regulation S. Resales of the New Notes are restricted as described under “Transfer Restrictions.” Each Initial Purchaser has represented, warranted and agreed that it: - has only communicated or caused to be communicated and will only communicate or cause to be communicated any invitation or inducement to engage in investment activity (within the meaning of section 21 of the FSMA) received by it in connection with the issue or sale of any Notes in circumstances in which section 21(1) of the FSMA does not apply to the Issuer or the Guarantors; and - has complied and will comply with all applicable provisions of the FSMA with respect to anything done by it in relation to the New Notes in, from or otherwise involving the United Kingdom. Any offer or sale in the United States will be made by affiliates of the Initial Purchasers who are broker dealers registered under the Exchange Act.

The Issuer expects that delivery of the New Notes will be made to investors on or about the date specified on the cover page of this offering memorandum, which is business days following the date of this offering memorandum (such settlement being referred to as “T+ ”). Under Rule 15(c)6-1 under the Exchange Act, trades in the secondary market are required to settle in two business days, unless the parties to any such trade expressly agree otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish to trade the New Notes on the date of pricing or the next succeeding business days will be required, by virtue of the fact that the New Notes will initially settle business days following the date of pricing of the New Notes, to specify an alternative settlement cycle at the time of such trade to prevent a failed settlement. Purchasers of the New Notes who wish to make such trades should consult their own advisors. -----

The Initial Purchasers and their respective affiliates are full service financial institutions engaged in various activities, which may include securities trading, commercial and investment banking, financial advisory, investment management, principal investment, hedging, financing and brokerage activities. The Initial Purchasers and their respective affiliates have, from time to time, performed, and may in the future perform, various financial advisory and investment banking services for United Group, certain direct and indirect shareholders of United Group, and their respective affiliates, for which they received or will receive customary fees and expenses. In addition, certain of the Initial Purchasers are arrangers and lenders under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, a portion of which will be repaid with the proceeds of the Offering. In the ordinary course of their business activities, the Initial Purchasers and their affiliates may make or hold a broad array of investments and actively trade debt and equity securities (or related derivative securities) and financial instruments (including bank loans) for their own account and for the accounts of their customers. Such investments and securities activities may involve securities and instruments of ours or our affiliates. If the Initial Purchasers or their affiliates have a lending relationship with us, they routinely hedge their credit exposure to us consistent with their customary risk management policies. Typically, the Initial Purchasers and their affiliates would hedge such exposure by entering into transactions which consist of either the purchase of credit default swaps or the creation of short positions in our securities, including potentially the New Notes offered hereby. Any such short positions could adversely affect future trading prices of the New Notes. The Initial Purchasers and their affiliates may also make investment recommendations and publish or express independent research views in respect of such securities or financial instruments and may hold, or recommend to clients that they acquire, long and/or short positions in such securities and instruments.
