The objective of the Group to keep Net leverage ratio below 5x as of the reporting date. There is no change in respect of the capital management compared to consolidated financial statements as at 31 December 2019. The Group’s objectives when managing capital are to safeguard the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern in order to provide returns for investors and to maintain an optimal liquidity position.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue recognition under IFRS 15 necessitates the collation and processing of very large amounts of data, use of management judgements and estimates to produce financial information. The most significant accounting judgements and source of estimation uncertainty are disclosed below. 6.1.1. Gross versus net presentation The Group is the principal in the sale to the customer if the Group has control of the goods and services when they are delivered to a customer; otherwise the Group is acting as an agent. Whether the Group is considered to be the principal or an agent in the transaction depends on analysis by management of both the legal form and substance of the agreement between the Group and its business partners; such judgements impact the amount of reported revenue and operating expenses (see notes 8 and 9) but do not impact reported assets, liabilities or cash flows. Scenarios requiring judgement to determine whether the Group is a principal or an agent include, for example, those where the Group delivers advertising and media selling services. Please refer to sections 8.3 and 8.4 for accounting policy. 6.1.2. Allocation of revenue to goods and services provided to customers The Group is determining and allocating the transaction prices to separate performance obligations in the contract; the allocation is based on the reference to their relative standalone selling prices that could be obtained if the promised goods and services were sold individually in a separate transaction. The standalone -----

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: When the Group completes a business combination, the fair values of the identifiable assets and liabilities acquired, including intangible assets, are recognised. The determination of the fair values of acquired assets and liabilities is based, to a considerable extent, on management’s judgement. If the purchase consideration exceeds the fair value of the net assets acquired then the incremental amount paid is recognised as goodwill. If the purchase price consideration is lower than the fair value of the assets acquired then the difference is recorded as a gain in the income statement. Allocation of the purchase price between property, plant and equipment, intangible assets and goodwill affects the subsequent results of the Group as finite lived assets are amortised, whereas goodwill is not. Please refer to note 23 for further information.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: IFRS requires management to perform impairment tests annually for indefinite lived assets, for finite lived assets and for equity accounted investments, if events or changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amounts may not be recoverable. Impairment testing requires management to judge whether the carrying value of assets can be supported by the net present value of future cash flows that they generate. Calculating the net present value of the future cash flows requires estimates to be made in respect of highly uncertain matters including management’s expectations of: - growth in Adjusted EBITDA (as defined in note 7), - timing and amount of future capital expenditure; - long-term growth rates; and - discount rates to reflect the risks involved. Management prepares formal five-year budget for the Group’s operations, which are used to estimate their value in use. Changing the assumptions selected by management, in particular the adjusted EBITDA and growth rate assumptions used in the cash flow projections, could significantly affect the Group’s impairment evaluation and hence reported assets and profits or losses (note 19).

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Group tests annually useful life of customer relationships based on management assumptions on customer churn rates. An increase in churn rates may lead to a reduction in the estimated useful life and an increase in the amortisation charge.

Judgement is necessary to assess the likelihood that a pending claim will succeed, or a liability will arise.

Details of expected credit loss measurement methodology are disclosed in note 4 Expected credit losses. In the calculation of the default rate, the Group’s models predominantly use historical information which is derived from the Group’s systems of market data.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Group is a pan regional distribution platform of cable and satellite Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services with various offerings in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, Montenegro and North Macedonia. Its business has grown substantially in terms of scale, geographic reach and service offering during the period under review through both organic growth and acquisitions. In addition, the corporate organization of the Group’s business has changed during this period as business has grown and been integrated. Segment information is provided partially on the basis of geographic areas and partially based on an organizational structure, being the basis on which the Group manages its operations.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: An operating segment is a component of the Group: - that engages in business activities from which it may earn revenues and incur expenses that relate to transactions with any of the Group’s other components, - whose operating results are regularly reviewed by the Group’s Chief Operating Decision Makers (CODM) and - for which discrete financial information is available. Operating segments are reported in a manner consistent with the internal reporting provided to the CODM. CODM is responsible for allocating resources and assessing performance of the operating segments. Operating segments are components that engage in business activities that may earn revenues or incur expenses as a result of the services provided. Operating results of segments are regularly reviewed by the CODM and discrete financial information is available on that level. Revenue in telco segments is attributed to a country based on the location of the sub-group reporting the revenue. The functions of CODM are performed by the Managing directors of the Group. The Group has seven operating segments in telecom and one in media business line, which are the Group’s strategic divisions. Telecom strategic divisions for each of key markets, offer similar services and are managed jointly since they have unified service development and marketing strategy. Media segment represents content operating. For each of the strategic divisions, the CODM reviews internal management reports on at least monthly basis. The reportable segments equal the operating segments thus no aggregation of operating segments was performed for the reporting purposes. ----- A contract is, or contains, a lease if the contract conveys a right to control the use of an identified asset for a period of time in exchange of consideration. Leases are recorded as a right-of-use asset and a corresponding liability at the date at which the leased asset is available for use by the Group. Assets and liabilities arising from a lease are initially measured on a present value basis. Lease liabilities include the net present value of the following lease payments for the right of use the underlying asset during the lease term: - Fixed payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentive receivable; - Variable lease payment that are based on an index or a rate; - Amounts expected to be payable by the lessee under residual value guarantees; - The exercise price of a purchase option if the lessee is reasonably certain to exercise that option; - Payment of penalties for terminating the lease, if the lease term reflects the lessee exercising that option. The lease payments are discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease, if that rate can be determined, otherwise the Group’s incremental borrowing rate is applied. Weighted average incremental borrowing rates used in 2020 was 5.2%. There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low-value items available on the voluntary basis. The Group has elected to apply those exemption therefore the payments associated with all short-term leases and leases of a low-value assets are recognised on a straight-line basis as an expense in profit or loss. Short term leases are leases with a lease term of 12 months or less. Low-value assets comprise IT-equipment, computers, mobile phones etc. Right-of-use assets are measured initially comprising the following: - The amount of the initial measurement of lease liability, - Any lease payments made at or before the commencement date less any lease incentive received, - Any initial direct costs, - Restoration costs. Subsequently, the right-of-use asset measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment losses, and adjusted for reassessment of the lease liability due to reassessment or lease modifications. The right-of-use asset is depreciated over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term on a straight-line basis. ----- Inventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. The cost of inventories includes the cost of purchase, transport and expenses (including direct labour costs) incurred in bringing the inventory to its ----- Trade receivables should initially be measured at their transaction price unless they have a significant financing component. Carrying value of trade receivables reduced by allowances for estimated credit losses Individual balances are written off when management deems them not to be collectible. The Group’s contract assets are classified at amortised cost unless stated otherwise and are measured after allowances for future expected credit losses (see note 4.1.3 for more information on credit risk). The Group has recognized the following revenue-related contract assets and liabilities: Cash and cash equivalents include cash in hand, deposits held at call with banks, and other short-term highly liquid investments with original maturities of three months or less. Cash and cash equivalents are measured at amortized cost less the loss allowances determined applying the expected credit losses model descried above in section Financial assets impairment—credit loss allowance for expected credit loss. A subsidiary is an entity controlled by the company. Control is achieved where the Company has existing rights that give it the current ability to direct the activities that affect the Company’s returns and exposure or rights to variable returns from the entity. The results of subsidiaries acquired or disposed of during the year are included in the consolidated income statement from the effective date of acquisition or up to the effective date of disposal, as appropriate. Where necessary, adjustments are made to the financial statements of subsidiaries to bring their accounting policies into line with those used by the Group. All intra-group transactions, balances, income and expenses are eliminated on consolidation. Non-controlling interests in the net assets of consolidated subsidiaries are identified separately from the Group’s equity therein. Non-controlling interests consist of the amount of those interests at the date of the original business combination and the non-controlling shareholder’s share of changes in equity since the date of the combination. Total comprehensive income is attributed to non-controlling interests even if this results in the non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. The Group applies the economic entity model to account for transactions with owners of non-controlling interest in transactions that do not result in a loss of control. Any difference between the purchase consideration and the carrying amount of non-controlling interest acquired is recorded as a capital transaction directly in equity. The Group recognises the difference between sales consideration and the carrying amount of non-controlling interest sold as a capital transaction in the statement of changes in equity.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 7.** **Operating segments (continued)
Subsubsection Text: The following summary describes the operations in each of the Group’s reportable segments. - Serbia Group includes cable operations in Serbia and DTH (satellite TV) operations in Macedonia. Satellite operations in Macedonia account for minor part of the overall operations of Serbia Group segment, - Bulgaria Group includes telecom operations in Bulgaria, - Slovenia Group includes cable and DTH operations and mobile telephony services in Slovenia (note 23), - Greece Group includes telecom and media operations in Greece (note 23), - Bosnia Group includes cable and DTH operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina, - Montenegro Group includes cable and DTH operations in Montenegro, - Croatia Group includes mobile telephony services in Croatia (note 23), - Media Group includes media (including advertising) and content operations in the region. This segment includes the results of our media and content business in the former Yugoslav region including the results of N1 Info, Grand Production, Orlando Kids, Nova TV, Nova M and Nova BH, as well as Direct Media. - Other segments include our other operating business, such as Solford, Shoppster and non-operating holding companies (United Group B.V., Adria Cable B.V., Adria Serbia Holdco B.V., Slovenia Broadband S.A.R.L.). Revenue reported in other is mainly generated by Solford and Shoppster. In 2020, the Group completed following acquisitions which represent separate segments: - Telemach Hrvatska d.o.o., mobile operator in Croatia which represents separate segment Croatia Group. - VIVACOM Group, telco operator in Bulgaria which represents Bulgaria Group. - Forthnet Group, telco and media operator in Greece which represents Greece Group. There were no changes in relation to composition of segments and measurement of segment profit/loss comparing to consolidated financial statements for 2019. Information regarding the results of each reportable segment is included below. Performance is measured based on segment earnings before net finance cost, tax, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) and Adjusted EBITDA, as included in the internal management reports that are reviewed by the Group’s management. EBITDA is a supplemental measure of financial performance that is not required by, or presented in accordance with IFRS. “EBITDA” is defined by the Group as Profit/(Loss) for the period plus income tax (benefit)/expense, depreciation, amortization of intangible assets and net finance costs and share of profit/ loss of equity-accounted investee. Adjusted EBITDA represents EBITDA adjusted for shareholder-related costs, legal and advisory—M&A related costs, group restructuring costs, income from the disposal of companies, impairment charges for obsolete equipment in Slovenia, other management-related costs, specific penalties, additional impact of application of new standards (just for transitory period) and other non-core operating expenses, which Group views as non-operating and not recurring to the operations of the Group (note 17). Segment Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (note 17) is used to measure performance as management believes that such information is the most relevant in evaluating the results of certain segments relative to other entities that operate within these industries. Video service include provision of TV channel mix and IP Video streaming services, which is marketed into basic, extended and premium packages. TV mix range from 60 to over 100 TV channels. Data service comprise internet packages for residential and business customers, as well as various supplementary services for business customers (connectivity and managed services, data centre and cloud services). Voice service relates to fixed line services to residential and business customers. Mobile phone services relate to post-paid, prepaid, roaming and wholesale services provided to customers. United Media is the leading media company in South East Europe, broadcasting more than 30 channels available for terrestrial, cable, DTH, OTT and IPTV platforms. Content operations are driven by carriage fee revenues which are coming from sales of pay-tv channel to cable operators across Adriatic region and advertising revenue from both terrestrial TV stations and pay-TV stations. The Group is the owner of pay-tv channels including flagship brands like “Sport Klub”, regional news channel ‘N1’, general entertainment channel Nova S, movie channel “Cinemania”, children channels “Pikaboo” and “Vavoom” and music channels “Grand” and “IDJ”, as well as terrestrial TV stations Nova TV and Doma TV in Croatia, Nova M in Montenegro and Nova BH in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Recently, United Media started to invest heavily in its digital portfolio, out of which the most prominent web portals are dnevnik.hr (number 1 portal in Croatia), n1info.com and nova.rs. In addition to this, Direct Media group, a leading media-buying agency, provides advertising and media services to companies in the region.

Subsection Title: 7.3. Measurement of operating segment profit or loss
Subsubsection Text: The CODM reviews financial information prepared based on IFRS adjusted to meet the requirements of internal reporting. Such financial information differs in certain aspects from IFRS: - Management consolidation adjustments can differ from the ones required by IFRS; - non-IFRS profit measures (such as earnings before income tax, depreciation and amortization—EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted Capital Expenditure (Adjusted CAPEX)) are also included in the segment report. Adjusted CAPEX represents purchases of tangible and intangible assets, consisting primarily of set top box purchases and other customer capital expenditure, installations (including capitalized labour costs), cable and mobile network build out, upgrades, maintenance and other investments, computer hardware and software and content rights. CODM evaluates performance of each segment based on revenue, Adjusted EBITDA, EBITDA and other key performance indicators (e.g. average revenue per user, CAPEX) and does not regularly review assets and liabilities of the segments.

Subsubsection Text: In determining the transaction price, the Group shall adjust the promised amount of consideration for the effects of the time value of money if the timing of payments agreed to by the parties to the contract (either explicitly or implicitly) provides the customer or the entity with a significant benefit of financing the transfer of goods or services to the customer. In those circumstances, the contract contains a significant financing component. However, based on the management analysis and considered factors noted in IFRS 15.61, at present, the financing component is considered to be immaterial of handset and would not materially change the amount of revenue that should be recognized in relation to a contract with a customer and thus, there is no need to determine the present value of future cash flows from handset to calculate the initial value of the contract asset. The Group will continue to monitor contract offerings and mobile business models. customers net of value added tax and any rebates granted, which is highly probable that it will not be reversed. Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from subscription services consists primarily of monthly fees paid by subscribers for provision of telecommunication service. These revenues are recognized within the profit or loss in proportion to the length service provided (subscription fee) over time in the period when related services are rendered. The Group generates following main subscription-based service revenue streams which are recognized in the period when the service is provided: Cable TV (CATV), Digital TV (D3), cable and fibre Internet service, satellite TV (Direct to Home—DTH) and mobile telephony service. Revenues from the rendered services relate to mobile services containing amounts charged to post-paid plan customers for monthly service fees, which includes: voice, data and SMS. Based on IFRS 15, revenue should follow performance and not timing of payment, as the Group has obligation to provide service to the customer. The revenue is recognized over time and only to the extent of provided service, and remaining of the consideration received is deferred. Mobile phone service is a “stand ready obligation” and the obligation is satisfied by passage of time so the fixed monthly fee is spread straight line over the time of the contract. The fee charged additionally for telephone conversation and SMS is a variable consideration which is recognized as revenue when the even usage giving rise to such fee occurs. Handsets subsidized represents a distinct performance obligation and realization of revenues to each performance obligation on a relative stand-alone selling price basis is required. The subsidy of the hardware leads to the recognition of a contract asset under IFRS 15. The total consideration allocated to this performance obligation based on the relative stand- alone selling prices of performance obligations within this contract and amount accrued at this point is recognised as contract asset. The IFRS 15 adjustment results in revenue recognition from the sale of hardware at the contract inception and the recognition of contract asset in the balance sheet. During the minimum contract duration (e.g. two years) contract asset is settled from the monthly service fee paid by the customer. The Group uses the practical expedient under IFRS 15 and recognizes fee from voice, data and SMS in the amount to which the Group has a right to invoice.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Carriage fee revenue relates to sales of pay-tv channel to other cable operators. The Group is the owner of pay-tv channels including brands like “Sport Klub”, regional news channel ‘N1’, general entertainment channel Nova S, movie channel “Cinemania”, children channels “Pikaboo” and “Vavoom” and music channels “Grand” and “IDJ”, as well as terrestrial TV stations Nova TV and Doma TV in Croatia, Nova M in Montenegro and Nova BH in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Revenue is recognized over the time, depending on a contract, either on straight-line basis over the sales contract period when the fixed fee is contracted or number of subscribers multiplied by agreed price per user.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue from sale of end user equipment is recognized at point in time when the control is transferred to the buyer which usually is the moment when the customer obtains the end user equipment. End user equipment mainly relates to handsets.

Subsubsection Text: Finance income comprises interest income on funds invested (including short-term bank deposits), and foreign currency gains. Interest income is recognized as it accrues in profit or loss. Finance costs comprise interest expense on borrowings and foreign currency losses. Borrowing costs that are not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognized in profit or loss using the effective interest method. Out of total interest expense for year ended 31 December 2020, amount of EUR 107,128 thousand (2019: EUR 80,572 thousand) relates to bond interest. Out of total amount of other finance cost EUR 15,985 thousand in in 2020, amount of EUR 12,500 thousand relates to bridge loan commitment fees for acquisition of Tele2 d.o.o. and VIVACOM Group. Out of total amount of other finance cost EUR 18,629 thousand in 2019, amount of EUR 12,578 thousand relates to loss on redemption fee option and represents the change of the carrying value of the bonds as a consequence of estimated cash flow revision due to the early redemption option exercised in the January 2020 (note 33). -----

Subsubsection Text: Income tax expense comprises current and deferred tax. It is recognized in profit or loss except to the extent that it relates to items recognized directly in equity or in other comprehensive income. Current tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable in respect of previous years. Current tax payable also includes any tax liability arising from the declaration of dividends. The prevailing corporate tax rates are:

The Group determines whether to consider each uncertain tax treatment separately or together with one or more other uncertain tax treatments based on which approach better predicts the resolution of the uncertainty. In determining the approach that better predicts the resolution of the uncertainty, an entity might consider, for example, (a) how it prepares its income tax filings and supports tax treatments; or (b) how the entity expects the taxation authority to make its examination and resolve issues that might arise from that examination. In assessing whether and how an uncertain tax treatment affects the determination of taxable profit (tax loss), tax bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits and tax rates, the Group assumes that a taxation authority will examine amounts it has a right to examine and have full knowledge of all related information when making those examinations. When the Group concludes it is probable that the taxation authority will accept an -----

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 16. Income tax (continued)
Subsubsection Text: uncertain tax treatment, the entity shall determine the taxable profit (tax loss), tax bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits or tax rates consistently with the tax treatment used or planned to be used in its income tax filings. When the Group concludes it is not probable that the taxation authority will accept an uncertain tax treatment, the Group reflects the effect of uncertainty in determining the related taxable profit (tax loss), tax bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits or tax rates. The Group reflects the effect of uncertainty for each uncertain tax treatment by using either of the following methods, depending on which method the entity expects to better predict the resolution of the uncertainty: - the most likely amount—the single most likely amount in a range of possible outcomes. The most likely amount may better predict the resolution of the uncertainty if the possible outcomes are binary or are concentrated on one value. - the expected value—the sum of the probability-weighted amounts in a range of possible outcomes. The expected value may better predict the resolution of the uncertainty if there is a range of possible outcomes that are neither binary nor concentrated on one value. When uncertain tax treatment affects current tax and deferred tax (for example, if it affects both taxable profit used to determine current tax and tax bases used to determine deferred tax), the Group makes consistent judgements and estimates for both current tax and deferred tax. SBB is eligible for investment incentives (tax holiday) according to Article 50a to 50i Serbian Corporate Income Tax (CIT). For SBB this is a second use of this type of investment tax credit. The company met required conditions to use an investment tax credit for the second time in 2016. The investment tax credit is applied for ten years. Start of investment in fixed assets for the second investment tax credit is 1 January 2016. Each year the proportion for this investment needs to be calculated. Calculation of this percentage represent the ratio of investment in fixed assets that meet requirements from Serbian CIT art 50a to 50i (certain assets need to be excluded such as aircraft and watercrafts, passenger cars, furniture and assets that hasn’t been paid during the cumulative period) and total investment in fix assets (for period from 1 January 2016—according to invested amount in fixed assets and for previous period according to fixed amount of assets book value). The percentage which can be apply as investment tax credit on calculated CIT is changing every year. Deferred tax assets have not been recognised in respect of tax losses, because it is more likely than not that future taxable profit will not be available against which the Group can use the benefits therefrom. Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: 18. Property, plant and equipment Accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: Property, plant and equipment comprise mainly cable network (coaxial and optical primary and secondary network and backbone) and customer premise equipment (CPE—receivers and modems). Items of property, plant and equipment are measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment losses. Cost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to the acquisition of the asset. The cost of selfconstructed assets includes the cost of materials and direct labour, any other costs directly attributable to bringing the assets to a working condition for their intended use, the costs of dismantling and removing the items and restoring the site on which they are located and capitalized borrowing costs. Purchased software that is integral to the functionality of the related equipment is capitalized as part of that equipment. When parts of an item of property, plant and equipment have different useful lives, they are accounted for as separate items (major components) of property, plant and equipment. The gain or loss on disposal of an item of property, plant and equipment is determined by comparing the proceeds from disposal with the carrying amount of the property, plant and equipment, and is recognized net within other income or other operating expenses in profit or loss. -----

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 18. Property, plant and equipment (continued) 18.1.** **Subsequent costs
Subsubsection Text: Subsequent costs are included in the asset’s carrying amount or recognized as a separate asset, as appropriate, only when it is probable that future economic benefits associated with the item will flow to the Group and the cost of the item can be measured reliably. Cost of replacing major parts or components of property, plant and equipment items are capitalised and depreciated over shorter of remaining useful life of an asset or period until major part are replaced again. Cost of the replaced part is retired. All other repairs and maintenance are recognized in profit or loss during the financial period in which they are incurred.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation is based on the depreciable amount of an asset. Significant components of individual assets are assessed and if a component has a useful life that is different from the remainder of that asset, that component is depreciated separately. Depreciation is recognized in profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of each component of an item of property, plant and equipment. INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of an acquisition (as defined in the note 23) over the fair value of the identifiable net assets of the acquired subsidiary at the date of acquisition. Goodwill is measured at cost less accumulated impairment losses. An impairment loss is recognized for the amount by which the asset’s or CGU’s carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less costs to sell and value in -----

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 19. Goodwill (continued)
Subsubsection Text: use. This impairment test is performed to compare the recoverable amount of each Cash Generating Unit (CGU) or, if necessary in cases of goodwill, CGU to the carrying value of the CGU (including goodwill, if goodwill has been allocated to CGU or group of CGUs). A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets. The value in use of each asset or group of assets is determined as the discounted value of future cash flows (Discounted Cash Flow method (DCF)) by using cash flow projections consistent with the budget of the following year, the most recent forecasts prepared by the operating segments and long-term projections. Applied discount rates are determined by reference to available external sources of information, usually based on financial institutions’ benchmarks, and reflect the current assessment by the Group of the time value of money and risks specific to each asset or group of assets. Perpetual growth rates used for the evaluation of CGUs are those used to prepare budgets for each CGU or group of CGUs, and beyond the period covered, are consistent with growth rates estimated by the business by extrapolating growth rates used in the budgets, without exceeding the long-term average growth rate for the markets in which the group operates. The fair value (less costs to sell) is the price that would be received from the sale of an asset or group of assets in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date, less costs to sell. These values are generally determined on the basis of market data (stock market prices or comparison with similar listed companies, with the value attributed to similar assets or companies in recent transactions) or, in the absence of such data, on the basis of discontinued cash flows. If the recoverable amount is lower than the carrying value of an asset or group of assets, an impairment loss equal to the difference is recognized in statement of profit and loss. In the case of a group of assets, this impairment loss is first recorded against goodwill. Impairment losses recognized in respect of goodwill cannot be reversed at a later date. CGUs are independently defined at each business level, corresponding to the group operating segments. An impairment test of goodwill is performed by the Group for each CGU or group of CGUs, depending on the level at which management measures return on operations. Subsubsection Text: In 2021, the Group tested the value of goodwill allocated to its CGUs or groups of CGUs applying valuation methods consistent with previous years. Results of an impairment test show that the recoverable amount of CGU or groups of CGUs tested exceeded their carrying value (including goodwill), except for the Montenegro Group where the impairment of EUR 890 was recognised. The recoverable amount is determined as the higher of the value in use determined by the discounted value of future cash flows (Discounted Cash Flow method (DCF)) and the fair value (less costs to sell), determined on the basis of market data (stock market prices, comparable listed companies, comparison with the value attributed to similar assets or companies in recent acquisition transactions). Presentation of CGU or groups of CGUs:

The recoverable amount of each operating segment is determined using value-in-use calculations. These calculations use post-tax cash flow projections based on five-year financial budget. Cash flow beyond the five-year period is calculated on a perpetuity basis. The post -tax cash flows were discounted using the posttax rate to ensure consistency. Based on analysis, Montenegro Group would not be able to grow with the growth rates expected in the past. As a result of impairment testing. impairment of goodwill in Montenegro in the amount of EUR 890 thousand was recorded in 2020. -----

Assumptions used for value-in-use calculations (refer to the above table) changed to reflect current business environment as more information became available to the Group. The cash flow projections included specific estimates for five years and a terminal growth rate thereafter, except for Forthnet Group where extended period was included in order to normalize cash flows in years 2026 to 2030 to converge to profitability of the market participant within 5 years. The terminal growth rate was determined based on management’s estimate of the long-term compound annual Adjusted EBITDA growth rate, consistent with the assumptions that a market participant would make. Budgeted Adjusted EBITDA was estimated considering past experience, adjusted as follows: - Revenue growth was projected considering the growth levels over the past three years and market research for the relevant markets, competitive environment and management strategy for the next five years. - Corporate costs not included in individual CGU. Therefore, it shows the cash outflows from the continuing use of the assets.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Property rights relates to rights to radio frequencies for mobile services. The company uses the cost model and thus manages intangible assets at their purchase values less depreciation adjustments following the straightline amortization method. Any intangible assets that meet the conditions for recognition are valued at cost upon initial recognition. Property rights are amortized in a period of 2–10 years. Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only when satisfy the conditions for recognition as an asset. All other expenditure, including expenditure on internally generated goodwill and brands, is recognized in profit or loss as incurred.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Costs associated with maintaining computer software are recognized as an expense as incurred. Software is recognized at cost less accumulated amortization and accumulated impairment. Cost includes expenditure to acquire software and directly attributable costs to prepare it for its intended use. Development costs that are directly attributable to the design and testing of identifiable and unique software products controlled by the Group are recognized as intangible assets when the relevant criteria are satisfied: - the technical feasibility of completing the software so that it will be available for use or sale. - its intention to complete the software and use or sell it. - its ability to use or sell the software. - how the software will generate probable future economic benefits - the availability of adequate technical, financial and other resources to complete the development and to use or sell the software. - its ability to measure reliably the expenditure attributable to the software during its development. Directly attributable costs, capitalized as part of the software product, includes software development employee cost and appropriate portion of relevant overheads. Other development expenditures that do not meet these criteria are recognized as an expense as incurred. Development costs previously recognized as an expense are not recognized as an asset in a subsequent period. Computer software development costs recognized as assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives. -----

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsubsection Text: Subscriber acquisition costs include additional costs associated with entering into sales contracts with new customers, for example commissions paid to internal or external sales personnel. Subscriber acquisition costs are recognized only for costs that are incremental to obtaining the contract.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: When entering into contracts for the acquisition of film, series, shows or sports events, the rights acquired are classified as contractual commitments. The Group assesses each license agreement which span over period longer than one year whether it meets definition of an intangible asset and recognition criteria. They are recorded in the statement of financial position and classified as programming rights as follows: - Programming rights for films and television series are recognized at cost when the program is available for screening and are expensed over their broadcasting period. - Sports rights are recognized at cost at the opening of the broadcasting period of the related sports season start or contract date if season start is not defined in the contract itself. If the licence agreement spans over more than one year, the Group will recognize programming rights only to the level of assets available for broadcasting (e.g. one season). - Own-produced programming rights are capitalized on the balance sheet at cost which are directly related to the project being developed such as direct external development costs, allocated costs of employees and development overhead pool directly attributable to preparing the asset for use and will be amortized based on program viewership forecast method Advance payments for acquired programming assets, prior to licence begin date, are recognized as prepayments for programming assets. Signed and binding contracts for purchase of programming, which do not meet recognition criteria for programming assets are not recognized in the balance sheet and are instead disclosed as contractual commitments in the amount of the outstanding contract liability at the reporting date.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method. The cost of the business combination is measured as the fair value of the aggregate consideration transferred, measured at acquisition date fair value, fair value of any previously held interest and the amount of any non-controlling interest in the acquired entity. For each business combination, any non-controlling interest in the acquired entity is measured either at their proportionate share of the acquired entity’s identifiable net assets at the acquisition date or fair value. Consideration transferred includes any contingent consideration measured at its acquisition date fair value. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognized in the statement of comprehensive income. Subsequent changes to the fair value of the contingent consideration which is deemed to be an asset or liability will be recognized in accordance with IFRS 9 either in profit or loss or as a change to other comprehensive income. Contingent consideration that qualifies for classification as equity is not re-measured until it is finally settled. Acquisition costs incurred are expensed. Any excess of the cost of the acquisition over the identifiable net assets acquired is recognized as goodwill in the consolidated statement of financial position. If the cost is lower than the identifiable net assets acquired, the difference is recognized in profit or loss. Please refer to note 6.2 for information on critical estimates and judgements.

Subsubsection Text: The contract assets arise mainly from: - the sales of the subsidised handsets—the revenue is recognised when the customer obtains the handset whereas the payment is obtained over the period for which the customer has committed the mobile services which usually is two years. - uneven payments relating to discounts provided to customers, including free services rendered for contract commitments (e.g. free add-ons given to customers at contract inception for the duration unequal to minimum contract duration (MCD)). This service is expected to be delivered the customer for the duration agreed at contract inception and represents a dissimilar separate performance obligation which is not delivered concurrently with main services throughout the MCD, - services provided but not billed (accrued revenue at reporting date).The contract assets are transferred to receivables when the rights become unconditional. This usually occurs when the Group issues an invoice to the customer. The contract liability is mainly recognised in relation to advertising, media selling, carriage fee and subscription due to payments received at the inception of the contract whereas the revenue is recognised over time.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: At acquisition date, the Group recognized indemnification asset is relation to Share Purchase Agreement (SPA) for acquisition of VIVACOM Group where seller indemnified the Group against losses up to this amount of EUR 106,046 thousand on the liabilities arising from particular contingencies (note 32). According to the SPA, the Group deposited an amount of EUR 106,046 thousand into Escrow account with the Escrow bank, which can be released only with joint instruction of the Group and the Seller or final and non-appealable decisions of relevant bodies. Until 31 December 2020, total amount of EUR 56,809 thousand was released. The Group recognized an indemnification asset measured on a consistent basis with the measurement of the indemnified contingent liability in the amount of EUR 46,925 thousand (note 32) and deferred tax liability in the amount of EUR 1,677 thousand for the uncertain tax position for which the Seller indemnified the Group. Amount of EUR 635 thousand represents amount paid but not yet reimbursed. The recognized liabilities do not exceed the amount which the Sellers agreed to indemnify to the Group the indemnification asset equals the indemnified liability as at 31 December 2020; if the liability is settled at higher amount, the Group will incur the loss in excess of EUR 49,237 thousand. -----

Subsubsection Text: A provision is a liability recognized in the statement of financial position, when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of past events; it is more likely than not that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation; and the amount can be reliably estimated. Provisions are not recognized for future operating losses. Provisions are measured at the managements’best estimate of the expenditure required to settle the obligation at the reporting date and are discounted to present value where the effect is material. Where the timing of settlement is uncertain amounts are classified as non-current where settlement is expected more than 12 months from the reporting date. The main provisions the Group holds are related to decommissioning costs associated with mobile sites, which include the cost of returning network infrastructure sites to their original condition at the end of the lease and claims for legal and regulatory matter.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: A provision has been recognised for decommissioning costs associated with mobile sites. The provision has been capitalized to the cost of the sites with the amount of the present value of the expected decommissioning obligation after ceasing operation. The discount rates used for 2020 and 2019 were between 0.6% and 1.1%. The associated cash outflows are substantially expected to occur at the dates of decommissioning of the assets to which they relate, and are long term in nature.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Loans and borrowings are recognised initially at fair value, net of transaction costs incurred, and are subsequently carried at amortized cost using the effective interest method. Transaction costs are incremental costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition, issue or disposal of a financial instrument. An incremental cost is one that would not have been incurred if the transaction had not taken place. Transaction costs include fees and commissions paid to agents (including employees acting as selling agents), advisors, brokers and dealers, levies by regulatory agencies and securities exchanges, and transfer taxes and duties. Transaction costs do not include debt premiums or discounts, financing costs or internal administrative or holding costs. The effective interest method is a method of allocating interest income or interest expense over the relevant period, so as to achieve a constant periodic rate of interest (effective interest rate) on the carrying amount. -----

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 33. Borrowings and bonds (continued)
Subsubsection Text: The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments or receipts (excluding future credit losses) through the expected life of the financial instrument or a shorter period, if appropriate, to the gross carrying amount of the financial instrument. The effective interest rate discounts cash flows of variable interest instruments to the next interest repricing date, except for the premium or discount which reflects the credit spread over the floating rate specified in the instrument, or other variables that are not reset to market rates. Such premiums or discounts are amortised over the whole expected life of the instrument. The present value calculation includes all fees paid or received between parties to the contract that are an integral part of the effective interest rate. For assets that are purchased or originated credit impaired (“POCI”) at initial recognition, the effective interest rate is adjusted for credit risk, i.e. it is calculated based on the expected cash flows on initial recognition instead of contractual payments. Upon origination of the bonds and RCF, transaction costs were included in the financial liabilities recognized. Interest expense recorded includes amortization of these transaction costs deferred at initial recognition to maturity amount using the effective interest method. Amortized transaction costs are not presented separately and is included in the carrying values of the borrowings (as a reducing item). The Group does not have qualifying asset for capitalised borrowing costs, therefore no borrowing costs were capitalized to the value of property, plant and equipment as at 31 December 2020. On 17 May 2019, the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 550,000 thousand which matures on 15 May 2025, bears interest rate of 3m EURIBOR+4.125%. Interest is payable on each 15 February, 15 May, 15 August and 15 November. Effective interest rate of 4.454% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. On 4 July 2019, the Group issued bonds in the aggregate amount of EUR 207,000 thousand (including premium) which matures on 1 July 2024, bears interest rate of 4.875 %. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15 July. Effective interest rate of 4.521% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. On 6 February 2020, the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 1,675 million. Bond is issued in three tranches: - First tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 600 million bears interest rate of 3.125% and matures on 15 February 2026. Effective interest rate of 3.421% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. - Second tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 450 million bears floating interest rate of 3M Euribor+3.25% and matures on 15 February 2026. Effective interest rate of 3.565% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. - Third tranche in the amount of EUR 625 million bears interest rate of 3.625% and matures on 15 February 2028. Effective interest rate of 3.871% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. Part of the issued bonds is used for the purpose of acquisition of VIVACOM Group and the other part was used for redemption existing bond of EUR 575 million which matures in 2022 and partial repayment of existing RCF. On 23 November 2020, the Group issued notes in the aggregate amount of EUR 400,000 thousand which matures on 15 November 2027, bears interest rate of 4%. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 May and 15 November. Proceeds were used to repay a portion of the amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility that were used to fund the purchase price for the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition (note 40) and to pay transaction costs associated with the bond offering. 33.1.2. Borrowings In January 2020, the Group agreed on upsizing of existing Senior Secured RCF to EUR 250,000 thousand and extended maturity to 2025, conditioned on completion of the acquisition of VIVACOM Group. The bank loan facilities have been secured by a pledge on 100% of the shares of Adria Midco B.V. and direct subsidiary entities as well as property, plant and equipment, intangible assets, receivables and cash. Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 33. Borrowings and bonds (continued) 33.3.** **Loan covenants
Subsubsection Text: Based on the agreement for revolving credit facility, the Group is required to comply with a leverage ratio to consolidated Adjusted EBITDA for the period most recent four consecutive financial quarters ending prior to the date of determination of the ratio. Leverage ratio is calculated as aggregate outstanding indebtedness of the Group and should not exceed ratio 9:1. Indebtedness is calculated as total financial liabilities decreased by level of cash and cash equivalents as at reporting date. Satisfaction of the covenant is tested quarterly. The Group has been in compliance with the above requirements as at and for the year ended 31 December 2020 and 31 December 2019, and to the date of issuance of this report.

Subsection Title: 34. Deferred operating lease income Accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: Deferred operating lease income refers mainly to network operating lease arrangements with mobile operators. Deferred operating lease income is income for following periods that is received or cash received before services are rendered. Deferred operating lease income is income for which the customer is invoiced in advance of receiving the service. The amount earned within the next 12 months is classified as current, the amount earned after 12 months is classified as long-term. Income is recognized in profit and loss account when it has been earned.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax is not recognized for: - temporary differences on the initial recognition of assets and liabilities in a transaction that is not a business combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss, - temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, associates and joint arrangements to the extent that the Group is able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences and it is probable that they will not reverse in the foreseeable future; and -----

Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated 35. Deferred tax assets and liabilities (continued)
Subsubsection Text: - taxable temporary differences arising on the initial recognition of goodwill. Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses, unused tax credits and deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be utilized. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realized. Deferred tax is measured at the tax rates that are expected to be applied to temporary differences when they reverse, based on the laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the reporting date. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax liabilities and assets, and they relate to income taxes levied by the same tax authority on the same taxable entity, or on different tax entities, but they intend to settle current tax liabilities and assets on a net basis or their tax assets and liabilities will be realized simultaneously. Subsubsection Text: In considering each possible related party relationship, attention is focused on the substance of the relationship, not merely the legal form. Related parties may enter into transactions, which unrelated parties might not, and transactions between related parties may not be affected on the same terms, conditions and amounts as transactions between unrelated parties. Other significant shareholders are those with the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the Group with which they transact, through controlling over 20% of the Group’s voting power. Parties referred to below as “other related parties” are the parties other than the parent, entities with joint control of, or significant influence over, the entity, subsidiaries, associates, joint ventures, key management personnel. Transactions with related parties were entered into during the ordinary course of business on normal commercial terms.

Section Title: INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Group made a loan in an aggregate principal amount of EUR 30,000 thousand to Mr. Šolak, pursuant to a loan agreement dated 15 September 2016 based on arm’s length terms, to enable Mr. Šolak to acquire shares of equivalent value in parent company, Adria Luxco S.à r.l, which he owned indirectly through a company he controlled. These shares in Adria Luxco S.à r.l. acquired by Mr. Šolak have been pledged in favour of the Group to secure the obligations of Mr. Šolak under the loan agreement. Maturity of the loan was defined as earliest of the i) 6 March 2020, ii) Exit or iii) 6 months from the date of written notice to repay the loan. Total amount of the loan and interests was repaid on 4 March 2019.
