Subsubsection Text: - the amount of the bonus payment calculated as a percentage of the proceeds received by the shareholders of Adria Luxco and based on above mentioned accumulated return on invested capital achieved by such shareholders; - the payment of exit proceeds earmarked for the bonus payment is to be made by each shareholder to an intermediary vehicle in cash within 30 days of receipt of such exit proceeds, with no recourse to the Group, including the ultimate holding company Adria Luxco; no stock options or other derivative financial instruments are part of the LTIS Agreement; - no company in the Group, including the ultimate holding company Adria Luxco, has any obligation under the LTIS Agreement to settle the bonus payment to the management. The LTIS is funded/ settled in its entirety by the Group’s external shareholders. - On 27 September 2018, Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners, entered into a share purchase agreement (“SPA”) to acquire the entire share capital (excluding treasury shares) of Adria Topco BV (the “Target”) from Adria Luxco Sarl (the “Seller”). The consummation of the Group Acquisition pursuant to the Group Share Purchase Agreement which was subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including clearance by competition authorities concluded on 4 March 2019. The consummation of the Group acquisition represented an Exit under the LTIS Agreement. - The Group has recognized the effects of the LTIS Agreement in its consolidated financial statements for the period ending 31 December 2019, as equity-settled Group Share-based payment transaction under IFRS 2—Share-based payment—as LTIS Agreement is structured in a Group context where multiple Group entities receive services from employees. It also provides the responsibility of shareholders to settle the bonus (share-based payment) to employees who are providing services to several group companies. - The bonus amount under the LTIS Agreement at closing amounted to EUR 54,468 thousand, which relates to the period of services provided from the LTIS Agreement signing to the grant date when all parties will have shared understanding of key conditions pertaining LTIS Agreement. The service period ended 31 August 2019. The Group recognized in its consolidated financial statements for the period ending 31 December 2019 related expense in the amount of EUR 21,659 thousand, which corresponds to the eligible managers’ period of service from LTIS Agreement signing to the end of the reporting period. - From the perspective of the Group financial performance for the period ending 31 December 2018, the recognition of the transaction resulted in a lower reported net profit of the Group, in the amount of EUR 32,809 thousand. The same amount of EUR 32,809 thousand, as guided by IFRS 2, the Group recognized an increase in equity (Contribution from shareholder). The transaction is a non-cash, no recourse transaction without an impact on the financial position of the Group. - From the perspective of the Group financial performance for the period ending 31 December 2019, the recognition of the transaction resulted in a lower reported net profit of the Group, in the amount of EUR 21,659 thousand. The same amount of EUR 21,659 thousand, as guided by IFRS 2, the Group recognized an increase in equity (Contribution from shareholder). The transaction is a non-cash, no recourse transaction without an impact on the financial position of the Group. The Group believes that this additional payment could be regarded as a short-term employee benefit under IAS 19, however, it is the Group’s accounting policy, where external shareholders have the obligation of settling the payment for such benefits, without recourse from the Group, and absent an IFRS requirement, not to attribute related expense to the consolidated financial statements.

In addition to the LTIS Agreement, the shareholders of Adria Luxco and management have agreed an additional payment in the amount of 49,9 million EUR. The amount of the additional payment was not directly related to the value of the Company’s equity, or that of its ultimate parent, and was not paid in securities, but was determined as a result of negotiations as a discretionary lump sum amount paid in cash to the management at closing. -----

As at 31 December 2019, the Group is involved in a number of legal cases in the total amount claimed of EUR 182,242 thousand (31 December 2018: EUR 119,372 thousand). The Group management recognized provisions for legal cases in the amount of EUR 19,712 thousand representing its assessment of the most likely outcome of the cases (note 31) and believes that any disclosure of the amounts provided on a case-by-case basis could seriously harm the Group’s position, but provides details of the provisions recorded by categories of litigation as reflected below. Ultimate outcome of the cases is inherently uncertain and may differ from the best estimate of the Group management as discussed below.

For disputes for the outcome of which no provisions were created by the Group, the Group management, supported by legal teams, assesses the favourable outcome to be probable (more likely than not). Below are presented litigations which could have significant impact on the Group. 1. In 2016, BS Group d.o.o., Brus raised legal case against the Group. Subject of the dispute is violation of producer’s rights. According to the plaintiff, the Group violated territorial restriction of the contract by broadcasting certain movies on territories which were not listed in the contract. Total value of dispute amounts to EUR 25,000 thousand. The final outcome of the case will depend on the Court’s opinion on legal issues related to the basis of the request and the standing of the parties. The Group assessed that it is not probable that this proceeding will result in a negative outcome that would adversely impact on its financial position, therefore no provision has been recognised. 2. In September 2019, JKP Beogradske elektrane raised legal case against the Group. Subject of the dispute is indemnity for using their infrastructure. Total value of dispute amounts to EUR 10,000 thousand. The Group assessed that it is not probable that this proceeding will result in a negative outcome that would adversely impact on its financial position, therefore no provision has been recognised. 3. In March 2020, EPS Distribucija raised legal case against the Group. Subject of the dispute is indemnity for using their infrastructure. Total value of dispute amounts to EUR 1,000 thousand. The Group assessed that it is not probable that this proceeding will result in a negative outcome that would adversely impact on its financial position, therefore no provision has been recognised. _Investigation of the Serbian Commission for Protection of Competition in Serbia_ In November 2018 the Serbian Commission for Protection of Competition (“CPC”) issued a preliminary notice stating that (i) it believed SBB holds a dominant position in the retail market for distributing media content; (ii) price increases made by SBB were not justified by actual costs; and (iii) as a result, SBB may have abused a dominant position through excessive pricing. On 15 May 2019 CPC issued decision on suspension of further investigation. -----

Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 (Continued) In thousands of EUR (unless otherwise stated) NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 37. Contingent liabilities (continued)
Subsubsection Text: _Investigation of Tax Authority in Serbia_ On 27 December 2017, the Serbian Ministry of Finance Tax Authority (the “Serbian Tax Authority”) started tax investigation of SBB for the year ended 31 December 2012. According to the Serbian Tax Authority’s decision issued in March 2019, it has recharacterized interest payments made by SBB Serbia under an intragroup loan agreement (and certain other transactions) as dividends, which would have been subject to a 5% withholding tax. Total liability determined amounts to EUR 21 million, including the late interest. The management assessment, supported by analysis done by external consultants (both legal and tax experts) is that there is no ground for the claim as it is not substantiated by the evidence and regulation. The Group appealed to this decision and received approval for postponing of payment until resolution of appeal. _Legal cases in Slovenia_ 1. The award of 5 MHz on 2100 MHz spectrum frequency within its 3G licenses in 2008 to Tušmobil (now Telemach Slovenia) is currently subject of judicial review before the Administrative Court against the decision issued by the Slovenian Agency for Communication Networks and Services (“Agency”). In court, Telemach Slovenia is challenging Agency’s decision of May 2019, by which the Agency in the renewed frequencies allotment procedure has rejected Tušmobil’s request for allocation of said radiofrequencies and reversed its allotment decision of 2008, coming into the effect as of 31 December 2019. Based on Telemach Slovenia’s proposal, in June 2019, the Administrative Court issued an interim injunction and therewith stayed the Agency’s decision of May 2019 until the court reaches a final decision on Telemach’s lawsuit against Agency’s decision of May 2019. The procedure before the Administrative Court concerning the Telemach Slovenia’s lawsuit is pending. Loss of the described frequency licence would lead to capacity reduction, which might cause decrease in quality of service in certain areas. However, additional frequencies granted in 2016 (and currently used by Telemach Slovenia) would support the Group to mitigate the impact of any potential loss of 3G frequencies due to a renewal of the licence allocation procedure or other revocation or impairment of the 3G license that was granted in 2008. 2. From 2012 onwards, the Slovenian Association of Composers and Authors (“SAZAS”) commenced many legal proceedings against all cable operators in Slovenia (including Telemach Slovenia) claiming infringement of copyrights and damages for the cable retransmission of musical works. Up to now, SAZAS initiated twenty-eight legal proceedings against Telemach Slovenia claiming copyright remuneration for cable retransmission of music works for periods between October 2010 and December 2015. In eighteen proceedings, courts already issued a final decision awarding SAZAS with monthly remuneration amounting to approx. EUR 0.20 per subscriber for cable retransmission of music works in TV and radio channels. On average, SAZAS was awarded with approx. 30%-40% of its original claim. Telemach already complied with these final judgements and paid the awarded amounts to SAZAS, while filed extraordinary legal means against courts’ final decisions which are for the present being reviewed by the Constitutional Court (in nine cases) and Supreme Court of Slovenia (in one case). In five proceedings, the court of first instance issued judgements, which were all appealed by both litigating parties to the Higher Court, while five proceedings are still pending before the court of first instance. 3. In September 2018, the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency ruled that the Group’s acquisition of United Media Distribution (then IKO Balkan) in 2012 is incompatible with competition rules. The Slovenian Competition Protection Agency (hereinafter—the Agency) ordered the Group to divest the activity of broadcasting Sport Klub (SK) TV channels within nine months and imposed a ban prohibiting the Group from broadcasting sports TV channels in Slovenia for three years from the date of divestment (with the exception of the existing Fight Channel). In October 2018, the Slovenian Supreme Court issued our proposed interim injunction and stayed the implementation of the Agency’s divestment decision until a final decision on the merits of this case has been issued. The lawsuit against the divestment decision is pending. In addition, in a separate misdemeanour proceeding a fine of up to a legal maximum of 10% of annual revenue of the Group could be imposed for each of the next two breaches: (i) filing of concentration notification to the Agency with delay and (ii) breaching of the stand still obligation. In May 2019, the Agency issued decision on misdemeanour procedure by which financial fine in the amount ----- of EUR 3.7 million was imposed. The Group appealed against the decision and seek to annul or change decision in order to abolish the financial fine or at least lower it. 4. In February 2015, the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency initiated a proceeding regarding the abuse of dominant market position by United Media Limited, IKO Balkan (now United Media Distribution) and its Slovenian subsidiary IKO Media PRO d.o.o. (former subsidiary of the IKO Balkan—liquidated in 2016) in the wholesale market for the supply of pay TV sports channels in Slovenia for a period beginning around August 2012. This proceeding is currently still in its initial stages as no statement of objections has been issued by the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency. If the Agency in this procedure ruled that the dominant position existed and was abused a fine of up to the legal maximum of 10% of annual revenue of the previously described companies involved in the procedure could be imposed. The Group management, supported by its legal advisors, at this point assessed that it is likely that fine could be imposed and that level of fine would not have material adverse impact on its financial position. _Legal cases in Bosnia Minority shareholders of HS d.o.o., HKB d.o.o._ As a result of acquisition of subsidiaries in Bosnia, the Group assumed significant number of ongoing court disputes. The disputes are initiated by the minority owners of companies HS d.o.o. and HKB d.o.o. which claimed compensation for damages and cancellation of a share purchase transaction. The cases has been filed against majority owners of HS d.o.o. and HKB d.o.o. for breaching minority shareholders’ rights. The provisional quantum of indemnity sought by the minority shareholders is up to EUR 12,200 thousand (including penalty interest rates and costs of the proceedings), which is determined, according to the Group legal advisors, solely by plaintiffs. Based on the advice from legal advisors, the Group management has set aside funds in escrow account for the purpose of settlement of cases. _Other cases_ In October 2017 claim is raised against Telemach d.o.o. by Swiss non-profit organization AGICOA for unpaid royalties. Telemach and Agicoa were not in the contractual relation for the period covered by the law. Agicoa claims that Telemach is liable for royalties that had been due by the companies Telemach acquired on the Bosnian market. In October 2019 claim is raised against Telemach d.o.o., KT HS d.o.o., HKB Net d.o.o. and M&H Company by UFR for unpaid royalties. Telemach and UFR (Association of filmmakers in Bosnia and Herzegovina) were not in the contractual relation for the period covered by the law. UFR claims that Telemach is liable for royalties that had been due by the companies Telemach acquired on the Bosnian market.

Subsubsection Text: _Acquisition of Tele2_ On 31 May 2019, the Group concluded an agreement to acquire the entire stake in the company Tele2 d.o.o. Croatia for consideration of EUR 196,468 thousand subject to certain adjustments at closing date. The Group has raised finance through issuance of new bonds and paid it to Escrow account in July 2019. The transaction was subject to customary regulatory approvals by the local competition authorities and was closed on 3 March 2020. The identification and valuation of identifiable intangible assets and property, plant and equipment involved management judgment and will be performed with the assistance of valuation experts. -----

Subsection Title: ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 (Continued) In thousands of EUR (unless otherwise stated) NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 40. Subsequent events (continued)
Subsubsection Text: The following schedule summarizes the provisional determination of fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the acquisition date: _Other acquisitions_ The Group concluded agreements or signed binding offers to acquire stakes in following companies: EVJ Elektroprom trgovina, KRS, Elcatel, Ansat Krsko, Panel and Tako lako for total preliminary consideration of EUR 11,8 million subject to certain adjustments at closing dates. The transactions are subject to customary regulatory approvals by the local competition authorities and is expected to be completed in 2020. _COVID-19_ The existence of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) was confirmed in early 2020 and has spread rapidly from mainland China across the globe, causing disruptions to businesses and economic activity. Many governments across the world have imposed travel restrictions, lock downs and social distancing with a view to reducing the spread of the virus and hopefully minimizing the number of fatalities. The Group considers this outbreak to be a non-adjusting post balance sheet event. Whilst inherently uncertain, and the management expects some impact to operations and performance but currently does not believe that the COVID-19 outbreak will directly have a material adverse effect on the Group’s financial condition or liquidity for the foreseeable future such that it is not appropriate to apply the going concern principal to these financial statements. The impact of this outbreak on macroeconomic forecasts and markets are expected to be incorporated into the Group’s estimates of expected credit loss provisions and other impairments assessments in 2020, including but not limited to: Goodwill, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets and programming rights. Please also see disclosures in note 2(c) Going Concern. The Group’s management holds that they are not aware of any other significant post balance sheet events that could affect the consolidated financial statements for 31 December 2019 or require separate disclosure. -----

Goodwill and all assets and liabilities has been measured provisionally, pending completion of an independent valuation. Significant part of goodwill will be allocated to customer relationship and frequencies. Goodwill on acquisition date amount to EUR 126,842 thousand and will be allocated to the new operating segment which represents the lowest level at which it will be managed and monitored. _Acquisition of BTC Group and bond issue_ On 7 November 2019, the Group concluded an agreement to acquire the entire stake in BTC Group Bulgaria for a preliminary contribution of EUR 943 million subject to certain adjustments at closing date. The transaction is subject to customary regulatory approvals by the local competition authorities and is expected to be completed in 2020. In any event of non-satisfaction of the Closing Condition, and if the transaction agreed per the contract is not unwound, break fee up to EUR 20 million shall be applicable (Seller shall be entitled to payment from the Purchaser—for loss of opportunity for the Seller). On 23 January 2020, the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 1,675 million. Bond is issued in three tranches. First tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 600 million bears interest rate of 3.125% and matures on 15 February 2026. Second tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 450 million bears floating interest rate of 3M Euribor+3.25% and matures on 15 February 2026. Third tranche in the amount of EUR 625 million bears interest rate of 3.625% and matures on 15 February 2028. Part of the issued bonds will be used for the purpose of acquisition of BTC Group and the other part was used for redemption existing bond of EUR 575 million which matures in 2022 and partial repayment of existing RCF. After the closing of acquisition of the BTC Group, the Group will have RCF in the total available amount of EUR 250 million. -----

Subsection Title: BULGARIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANY EAD NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONSOLIDATED AND SEPARATE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS For the nine months ended 30 September 2020 All amounts are in thousand BGN, unless otherwise stated 1. General information The Parent Company—Bulgarian Telecommunications Company EAD
Subsubsection Text: Bulgarian Telecommunications Company EAD (“BTC”, the “Parent Company” or the “Company”) with UIC 831642181 registered in the Commercial Register of Bulgaria, is a single owned joint stock company, domiciled in Bulgaria, with its registration address: 115i, Tsarigradsko shose Blvd, 1784 Sofia. BTC’s activities include development, operation and maintenance of the national fixed and mobile network and data system for the Republic of Bulgaria. Until 31 July 2020 the Ultimate Parent Company was Viva Telecom (Luxembourg) S.A. (“VTL”) which through InterV Investment S.à r.l. owned 100% of the equity of Viva Telecom Bulgaria OOD which is the parent of the Company. The largest shareholder in VTL with a 46% stake was Viva Edge Telecom Limited which was ultimately owned by Mr. Spas Roussev. Other minority investors were comprised of entities affiliated with OJSC VTB Bank, Delta Capital Investments OOD (ultimately controlled by Messrs. Milen Velchev, George Velchev and Krassimir Katev), Mr. Michael Tennenbaum and companies managed by Mezzanine Management Central Europe II Limited. On 7 November 2019 it was announced that United Group, the leading telecoms and media business operating in South Eastern Europe, has agreed to acquire Viva Telecom Bulgaria. The European Commission has examined the transaction under the normal merger review procedure and has approved the acquisition on 3 April 2020. The deal was finalized on 31 July 2020 whereas the shares in Viva Telecom Bulgaria were acquired by United Group Bulgaria EOOD As a result, as of 30 September 2020 the ultimate parent of the Company is Summer Parent S.a r.l. (an entity controlled by funds advised by BC Partners) which indirectly through United Group Bulgaria EOOD owns 100% of the equity of Viva Telecom Bulgaria.

As at 30 September 2020 and 31 December 2019 the Group includes the subsidiary entities BTC Net EOOD, NURTS Bulgaria EAD, NURTS Digital EAD and Net Is Sat EOOD. As at 30 September 2019 the Group included the subsidiary entities BTC Net EOOD, NURTS Bulgaria EAD, NURTS Digital EAD and the joint venture Paytech OOD.

Subsection Title: BTC Security EOOD/ Renamed to BTC Net EOOD
Subsubsection Text: The subsidiary was registered in the Register of commercial companies of Sofia City Court on 27 October 2004 with share capital of BGN 5 thousand. Its main activity is provision of security services to BTC AD and the companies controlled by it. BTC is the sole owner of this company. The registered subject of business activity of BTC Net is building and operation of data transfer networks for the provision of domestic and international value added services and sale of telecommunication network facilities, development and exploitation of other telecommunication networks, and provision of other telecommunications services, as well as any other commercial activities. On September 30, 2009 BTC Net EOOD was merged into BTC Security EOOD. The legal merger of the entities was registered in the Commercial Register on October 15, 2009. As a result, BTC Net has ceased to exist as a separate legal entity, by virtue of law BTC Security has become universal legal successor of BTC Net and all assets, rights and obligations of BTC Net have passed to BTC Security automatically as of that date. On October 16, 2009 the successor BTC Security was renamed to BTC Net EOOD. ----- The subsidiary was registered in the Register of commercial companies of Sofia City Court on 27 October 2004 with share capital of BGN 5 thousand. Its main activity is provision of security services to BTC AD and the companies controlled by it. BTC is the sole owner of this company. The registered subject of business activity of BTC Net is building and operation of data transfer networks for the provision of domestic and international value added services and sale of telecommunication network facilities, development and exploitation of other telecommunication networks, and provision of other telecommunications services, as well as any other commercial activities. On September 30, 2009 BTC Net EOOD was merged into BTC Security. The legal merger of the entities was registered in the Commercial Register on October 15, 2009. As a result, BTC Net has ceased to exist as a separate legal entity, by virtue of law BTC Security has become universal legal successor of BTC Net and all assets, rights and obligations of BTC Net have passed to BTC Security automatically as of that date. On October 16, 2009 the successor BTC Security was renamed to BTC Net.

Subsubsection Text: NURTS Bulgaria EAD is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register in 1 April 2010 with subject of business activity: development, operation and maintenance of public electronic communication networks and data systems in Bulgaria, as well as providing telecommunication services through them, including terrestrial broadcasting of television and radio programs, analogue radio-relay and satellite transmission services, collocation services and other commercial activities. The registered share capital amounts to BGN 151,482,310 comprising of shares with nominal value of BGN 1 each.

NURTS Bulgaria EAD owns 100 % of the share capital of NURTS Digital EAD, which is a joint stock company registered in the Commercial Register on 15 April 2009 with principal activity construction, operation and maintenance of public electronic communication networks, equipment and information systems in Bulgaria, as well as providing electronic communications services through them, including terrestrial broadcasting of television and radio programs. The registered share capital amounts to BGN 120,00,000 comprising of shares with nominal value of BGN 500 each.

NET IS SAT is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register in 3 November 1997. Its main activity is offering individual business telecom solutions, including providing optical and wireless Internet access, fixed call service, Virtual Private Networks (VPN), wholesale international VoIP termination services, network and data management. The registered share capital amounts to BGN 3,832,000. NET IS SAT is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register in 3 November 1997. Its main activity is offering individual business telecom solutions, including providing optical and wireless Internet access, fixed call service, Virtual Private Networks (VPN), wholesale international VoIP termination services, network and data management. The registered share capital amounts to BGN 3,832,000.

Paytech is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register on 17 April 2019 as a joint venture between BTC and Bulgarian-American Credit Bank AD. Its main activity is development and provision of mobile payments. BTC held 50% of the registered share capital of the entity, amounting to BGN 1,000,000 for the period 17 April to 7 October 2019. The articles of association stipulated joint management of the entity whereas the joint venture partners had equal representatives in the General Meeting of the Shareholders, the entity was jointly represented by two managers of the Company each nominated by the respective shareholder and any General Meeting matter concerning the entity required joint decision of the shareholders. Based on that BTC treated its investment in Paytech as a joint venture. On 7 October 2019 BTC sold its 50% share in Paytech OOD to Bulgarian-American Credit Bank AD. Paytech is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register on 17 April 2019 as a joint venture between BTC and Bulgarian-American Credit Bank AD. Its main activity is development and provision of mobile payments. BTC held 50% of the registered share capital of the entity, amounting to BGN 1,000,000 for the period 17 April to 7 October 2019. The articles of association stipulated joint management of the entity whereas the joint venture partners had equal representatives in the General Meeting of the Shareholders, the entity was jointly represented by two managers of the Company each nominated by the respective shareholder and any General Meeting matter concerning the entity required joint decision of the shareholders. Based on that BTC treated its investment in Paytech as a joint venture. On 7 October 2019 BTC sold its 50% share in Paytech OOD to Bulgarian-American Credit Bank AD.

Subsection Title: 3.2. Significant events during the reporting period
Subsubsection Text: As a preventive measure against the outburst of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) in Europe, on 13 March 2020 a state of emergency was declared in the territory of Bulgaria. All visits in certain commercial establishments such as restaurants, shopping centres, entertainment and gaming halls, etc. were suspended for two months. On 23 March 2020 Measures and Actions during a State of Emergency Act was adopted, aimed at mitigating the negative consequences of the epidemic on citizens and businesses. While the core activities of the Group were not directly affected by these measures, certain negative impact on its financial position and performance during the reporting period could be largely attributed to the COVID-19 related developments. Though no reasonable estimate of the exact financial effect of the coronavirus outbreak can be made, the impacted items of the profit and loss statement, statement of financial position and accounting estimates and judgments are presented below. Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets increased as a result of delays in customer payments during the second quarter of the year, resulting respectively in higher ECL rates and increase in allowance for impairment of trade and lease receivables measured by applying the IFRS 9 simplified approach. During the third quarter of the year the receivables collectability improved and as at the reporting date and the subsequent periods it is close to pre-coronavirus levels (refer to Note 5). The coronavirus pandemic had a negative impact on the Mobile services revenue due to lower roaming revenue, primarily as a result of coronavirus-induced travel restrictions. This was partially offset by decrease in interconnect and roaming expenses. Further impact on service revenues are limited by the increased demand for telecom services during the periods of coronavirus related restrictions. During the reporting period the incremental borrowing rates applicable to the the Group lease liabilities were reconsidered and no significant changes to the pre-coronavirus rates were determined. The other critical accounting estimates and judgements disclosed in the annual financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 were evaluated as not impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Potential prolonged recession and a deepening crisis could impact on growth prospects, customer spending and collection, and may result in assumptions and estimates that could trigger material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in the future. In particular, management expects the assumptions and estimates used in determining impairment of Trade and other receivables, Contract assets, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets, Right-of-use assets and valuation of Investment property, and the related Deferred tax assets and liabilities to be affected. Nevertheless, at the date of these financial statements the Company continues to generate profits and sufficient cash from operations, supporting its activities. The directors, in light of their assessment of expected future cash flows are satisfied that the Company will be able to meet its obligations as they fall due for a period of at least 12 months from the reporting date. Therefore the Company continues to apply the going concern basis of preparation. On July 31, 2020 United Group Bulgaria EOOD granted to VIVACOM a related party loan with maturity of 10 years and bullet repayment at maturity. With the funds received, VIVACOM has prepaid all liabilities under the SFA. As a result, VIVACOM’s long-term debt obligation to third-party financing institutions stipulating 6-month repayment schedules and finally due in 2023 was replaced by a related party loan due 2030 which enables better liquidity management compared to the previous SFA exposure. -----

Incremental costs of obtaining a contract are additional costs that would have not been incurred had the contract not been concluded. They comprise mainly sales commission paid to employees and third-party retailers. Costs to fulfill a contract are costs relating directly to a contract that are incurred after contract inception and serve the purpose of fulfilling the contract but are incurred prior to fulfillment and cannot be capitalized under any other standard. The capitalized contract costs are recognised in the profit or loss as: 1) depreciation and amortization on a straight-line basis over the minimum enforceable contract period, or 2) other operating expenses when impairment loss is recognized, if their carrying amount exceeds the remaining amount of consideration that the Group expects to receive, less the costs that relate directly to providing the goods or services that have not been recognized as expenses.

As disclosed in note 15 BTC has signed an agreement to secure payments related to the Parent company’s liabilities under the SFA by establishing a pledge on real estate property, which net book value as of 30 September 2020 amounted to BGN 6,850 thousand, and as of 31 December 2019 their net book value was BGN 7,007 thousand.

_Fair value hierarchy_ Land is measured at fair value, in accordance with the revaluation model of IAS 16. The fair value of land was determined as at 31 December 2018 by external, independent property valuers, having appropriate recognized professional qualification and recent experience in the location and category of the property being valued. The fair value measurement for land of BGN 5,361 thousand has been categorised as a Level 3 fair value based on the inputs to the valuation technique used. _Valuation technique and significant unobservable inputs_ The valuation technique used is Market comparison — the fair value is based on the market price of properties with similar location and category. At the date of valuation no active market existed and the market value was determined based on offers to sell similar plots under the assumption that these are the end prices. The offered prices have been adjusted with: discount rate ranging from 10% to 15% to reflect the actual reduction in the offered price, based on the trends of actual transactions; adjustment coefficients, derived on the basis of characteristics of the respective plots like size, environmental and geomorphologic condition, level of development and transport accessibility, and improvements of the land. The estimated fair value of the individual properties would increase/(decrease) had the respective discount rate were lower/(higher) and the adjustments coefficients were higher/(lower). -----

The fair value of the investment properties was determined as at 31 December 2019 by external, independent property valuers, having appropriate recognized professional qualification and experience. The investment properties realized during the reporting period were sold above or close to their fair value in the consolidated financial statements. The Group is regularly monitoring the price trends and transaction volumes on the real estate market. As per the available data from an expert assessment of independent property valuers the fair value of the individual real estates of the Group close to the reporting date varies in the range of 0.85-1.15 compared to their carrying amount. The real estates in big cities, contributing the substantial value of the Group investment property portfolio mark increase in fair value snice the last valuation as of 31 December 2019. Based on the above and considering the publicly available information for the price movements of real estates, and the nature of the owned by the Group investment properties (unique location, property type, etc.), Management believes that COVID pandemic (Note 3.2) has not affected significantly the fair value of the investment property of the Group as at the reporting date. As disclosed in note 15 BTC has signed an agreement to secure payments related to the Parent company’s liabilities under the the SFA by establishing a pledge on real estate properties presented as investment property, which value as of 30 September 2020 amounted to BGN 13,314 thousand in the consolidated financial statements and BGN 1,091 thousand in the separate financial statements (31 December 2019: BGN 13,314 thousand in the consolidated financial statements and BGN 1,078 thousand in the separate financial statements).

Subsection Title: BULGARIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANY EAD NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONSOLIDATED AND SEPARATE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) For the nine months ended 30 September 2020 All amounts are in thousand BGN, unless otherwise stated 15. Borrowings
Subsubsection Text: The debts in the consolidated and separate financial statements are as follows:
including:

In November 2013 BTC announced the successful completion of its debut bond offering of €400 million 6[5]∕8 % Senior Secured Notes due 2018 on the Irish Stock Exchange pursuant to Rule 144A / Regulation S (the “Notes”). The proceeds from the bond offering were used by the Company to repay its existing indebtedness under the amended and restated loan agreement in full. The interest on the Notes was payable semi-annually on May 15 and November 15 of each year, commencing May 15, 2014. In relation to the admission of the Notes the Company received a credit rating of B1 by Moody’s and BB- by Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services. On 29 March 2018 and 16 May 2018 respectively Moody’s upgraded the long-term corporate credit rating of the Company to Ba3 and S&P Global Ratings reconfirmed it as BB- and in November 2019 both agencies placed the corporate credit ratings on review. On 27 March 2020 S&P Global Ratings downgraded the corporate credit rating to B+ and on 30 September 2020 lowered it to B, and withdrew the rating at VIVACOM’s request. BTC underwent a consent solicitation procedure for a waiver of the existing change of control provisions and amendment of certain definitions and ratios applicable to the Notes. The procedure was initiated in relation to the acquisition by VTL of 100% of the shares of InterV Investment S.a.r.l. On 13 June 2016, Vivacom obtained the necessary consent of 87.43% of bondholders. The amendments of Notes’ provisions entered into effect upon the execution of the first supplemental indenture on June 10, 2016 which became operative on 7 September 2016, when all the conditions precedent in the first supplemental indenture were either satisfied or waived. Simultaneously with the bond offering BTC has concluded EUR 35 million Revolving Credit Facility with Societe Generale Expressbank AD under which the Company may borrow funds for the repayment of its debt under the amended and restated loan agreement, financing of its working capital purposes and issue of bank guarantees and letters of credit. The RCF was initially agreed to be available up to 30 November 2016. The interest on the principal amounts owing by the Company under the RCF is payable monthly and was initially agreed to be the aggregate of 1 month EURIBOR plus a margin of 4% per year. Effective from 26 May 2014 the margin was reduced to 3,75% per year and from 14 November 2016 the margin was further reduced to 1,45% per year and the term was extended to 31 May 2018. On 22 December 2017 the Company entered into an up to EUR 365 million Senior Facilities Agreement (SFA) arranged by Citibank N.A., London Branch and VTB Bank (Deutschland) AG (currently VTB Bank (Europe) SE). The purpose of the facility was to refinance all amounts due under the Existing HY Bonds, payment of fees and costs under the facility and capital expenditure in respect of the Company’s investment and development program. The SFA comprised of a term loan Facility A, term loan Facility B, a Short-term -----

Subsection Title: BULGARIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANY EAD NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONSOLIDATED AND SEPARATE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) For the nine months ended 30 September 2020 All amounts are in thousand BGN, unless otherwise stated 15. Borrowings (continued)
Subsubsection Text: Facility and a Revolving Facility. The maximum tenor was 5.25 years after the first Utilization under the SFA, which occurred on 14 April 2018. The interest on the facilities was based on EURIBOR plus a Margin between 1.25 and 3.75 per cent per annum. The liabilities of the Company under the SFA were guaranteed by BTC Net EOOD (subsidiary) and Viva Telecom Bulgaria OOD (parent of the Company) and were further secured by: 1) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act on the going concern of the Company, which included among other receivables of the Company under certain bank accounts, insurance policies, related parties and customer receivables, as well as certain tangible and intangible assets (including trademarks), inventory and real estates of the Company; 2) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the going concern of BTC Net, which included among other assets the receivables of BTC Net under certain bank accounts; 3) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the going concern of Viva Telecom Bulgaria OOD, which included among other assets the receivables of Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD under certain bank accounts and the shares of the Company; 4) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the shares of the Company; 5) a pledge in accordance with the Agreements on Financial Collateral Act over the shares of the Company; 6) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the shares of BTC Net and a possessory pledge over the shares of NURTS Bulgaria EAD. On 19 April 2018 the Company successfully completed the refinancing of its Notes ahead of their maturity date and has delisted the Notes from the Official List and from trading on the Main Securities Market of the Irish Stock Exchange. As of the date of these financial statements the Company has deregistered the relevant securities under the Notes. Simultaneously with the SFA the Company extended the maturity of the Existing EUR 35 million Revolving Credit Facility (RCF)with Societe Generale Expressbank AD to 18 April 2021 and reduced the applicable Margin to between 1.05 and 1.75 per cent per annum. The Company has established the respective securities under the extended RCF on a pari passu basis by the same scope and type of security provided by the Company under the SFA. On 31 July 2020 United Group Bulgaria EOOD granted related party loan to BTC and with the received funds BTC successfully prepaid all liabilities under the SFA and the above referred securities under the SFA are in the course of deregistration. The outstanding principal amount of the related party loan is due in 10 years. The applicable interest is payable quarterly in arrears and is negotiated to be initially equal to 4.65 per cent per annum and following the completion of a third party transfer pricing study — to such per cent per annum determined thereunder. Simultaneously with the repayment of the SFA, BTC also terminated the Revolving Credit Facility which securities are currently in the course of deregistration.
The Group’s lease portfolio mainly consists of administrative and commercial buildings, fixed and mobile site rentals, network infrastructure, software and vehicles. -----

(1,705) 1,412 Deferred tax assets and liabilities for different taxable entities are not offset as they can not be settled on a net basis and it is not expected that the assets will be realised and the liabilities will be settled simultaneously in the future. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The deferred tax assets and liabilities as of 30 September 2020 and 31 December 2019 are calculated in these financial statements at 10% tax rate which has been effective since 1 January 2007. As of 31 December 2019 the last period audited by the tax authorities for BTC was 2013. During the reporting period a tax assessment act has been issued for a tax audit, covering the period January 2017—December 2019 in respect of corporate tax, and no tax liabilities has been assessed. The last period audited by the tax authorities for BTC Net is 2014. The last period audited by the tax authorities for NURTS Bulgaria and NURTS Digital is 2013.

The legal reserve is set up as required by the Bulgarian Commercial Act and equals one tenth of the share capital.
The revaluation reserve relates to the revaluation of Land and Investment property.
The fair value reserve comprises the cumulative net change in the fair value of financial assets at fair value through other comprehensive income until the investments are derecognised or impaired.
The hedging reserve comprises the effective portion of the cumulative net change in the fair value of cash flow hedges related to hedged transactions that have not yet occurred.
The other reserve comprises of the cummulative effect of the remeasurements of retirement benefit obligation and cost of hedging reserves, as summarised below. -----

Management has determined the operating segments based on the reports reviewed by the Managing Board that are used to make strategic decisions. The business, considered on a product perspective is currently organized into three lines of business—Fixed line of business, Mobile line of business and NURTS business. NURTS business represents the acquired in July 2015 company NURTS Bulgaria EAD and its wholly own subsidiary NURTS Digital EAD. Principal activities are as follows: - Fixed line of business—voice and data services over the fixed network and pay TV (both DTH and IPTV); - Mobile line of business—mobile services (GSM, UMTS and LTE Standards); - NURTS business—TV and radio broadcasting, collocation services and maintenance of telecom infrastructure. The Managing Board assesses the performance of the business segments based on a measure of gross margin. Revenue and gross margin information as reviewed by the Managing Board for the nine months ended 30 September 2020 and 2019 is presented below. -----

The balance of the receivable from NURTS Bulgaria EAD in the separate financial statements includes principal and interest on loan provided by BTC to the subsidiary entity. The applicable interest rate as of the reporting date is the aggregate of 12M Euribor plus a margin of 6% p.a. and the total outstanding principal amount and accumulated interest were initially agreed to be fully repaid on 20 May 2016. The loan is secured with first ranking non-possessory pledges in accordance with the Special Pledges Act on the going concerns of NURTS Bulgaria EAD and NURTS Digital EAD, which includes among other certain real estates and other assets of the companies. In November 2015 NURTS Bulgaria failed to repay one of the instalments due to BTC and as a result the Company has appointed a manager of the going concern of NURTS Digital EAD. The interest income recognised for the nine months ended 30 June 2020 in the separate financial statements amounts to BGN 94 thousand (BGN 46 thousand for the nine months ended 30 September 2019). -----

Subsubsection Text: The Company is a participant in several lawsuits and administrative proceedings. On 4 July 2016, Empreno Ventures Limited commenced legal proceedings in Bulgaria, challenging the validity of the first supplemental indenture (as referred in Note 15). Following the review on three instances, the Bulgarian courts finally dismissed the case on 16 March 2017 and the claim was rejected. On 26 August 2016, LIC Telecommunications S.à r.l. commenced legal proceedings in Luxembourg that, among other things, challenge the validity of the first supplemental indenture (as disclosed in Note 15) and claim damages amounting to EUR 62 million. In 2018 and 2019 judgments were rendered by two instance courts in Luxembourg which declared the request of LIC Telecommunications S.à r.l inadmissible and declined jurisdiction, which entered into force during the reporting period. BTC considered the legal proceedings in both Bulgaria and Luxembourg as being unmeritorious and devoid of any proper legal basis. The transactions for assignment of receivables on cash deposits in Corporate Commercial Bank AD—in bankruptcy (CCB), were executed in 2014 as per the provisions of the applicable law. One of the assigned receivables was utilised by NURTS Bulgaria EAD in order to set-off its obligations to CCB under a bond issued by NURTS Bulgaria EAD in 2013. CCB held 25,723 bonds with a nominal of EUR 1,000 each and in September 2014 NURTS Bulgaria EAD has set-off the principal in the amount of BGN 50,310 and applicable interest due to CCB in the amount of BGN 1,350 thousand against its own cash held in CCB accounts and assigned CCB cash receivables from third parties, including BTC. Despite of the validly executed transactions, the receivers of CCB have recognized only partially the set-off from NURTS Bulgaria EAD (BGN 1,543 thousand) where the remaining amount of BGN 50,117 thousand and other owned cash in CCB of BGN 116 thousand is included in the list of accepted receivables of CCB creditors. No financial assets or liabilities in relation to this matter were recognized in these financial statements. On 2 May 2017 NURTS Bulgaria EAD was notified for commencement by CCB of legal proceedings for the challenge of the set-off. On 14 May 2018 the first instance court cast a decision, as a result of which the NURTS set-offs against CCB were declared partially null and void and partially invalid vis-à-vis the creditors of CCB. The decision has not entered into force and has been appealed before the Sofia Court of Appeal. On 12 December 2019 CCB has withdrawn its claim against NURTS and on 20 December 2019 has initiated a procedure for the sale of the bonds held by CCB within which the above-referred issues between CCB and NURTS were finally resolved during the reporting period. Accordingly a provision was recognized by NURTS in 2019. As a consequence, the bonds and NURTS respectively were deregistered from the public register for issuers of securities maintained by the Bulgarian Financial Supervision Commission. After the reporting period Nurts Bulgaria AD was served with documents relating to a case that has been filed by the administrators of CCB against NURTS Bulgaria EAD claiming the return of certain assets originating from CCB. As the purported limitation period for filing such claims has expired and NURTS Bulgaria EAD has already settled all CCB claims, management believes that any chance of transfer of benefits with regards to this case to be remote and no provision has been recognised in these financial statements. Based on the information available, management is satisfied that there is no unprovided liability arising from these lawsuits and administrative proceedings, however there are inherent uncertainties related to the outcome of the cases. The recognised provisions for lawsuits are further disclosed in Note 14. -----

Subsubsection Text: The Group has bank guarantees issued to third parties which amount to BGN 9,615 thousand as of 30 September 2020 (31 December 2019: BGN 2,738 thousand). NURTS Bulgaria EAD was notified by CCB that pursuant to a contract concluded on January 16, 2013 the Company has stepped in as co-debtor in third party’s obligation in the amount of EUR 12,300 thousand. The management of the company is in a process of confirmation of the relevant circumstances, whereas as per the date of the present financial statements no reliable and indisputable evidences were received for the existence of such contingent liability, nor for its exact amount (if such liability exists). Respectively, no liability or provision has been recognized as at December 31, 2019, and contingent liability was disclosed. During the reporting period NURTS Bulgaria EAD has acquired the above referred third party’s obligations towards CCB and thus, any contingent liability is deemed unenforceable and extinguished.

Subsection Title: BULGARIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANY EAD NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED AND SEPARATE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS For the year ended 31 December 2020 All amounts are in thousand BGN, unless otherwise stated 1.** **General information The Parent Company—Bulgarian Telecommunications Company EAD
Subsubsection Text: Bulgarian Telecommunications Company EAD (“BTC”, the “Parent Company” or the “Company”) with UIC 831642181 registered in the Commercial Register of Bulgaria, is a single owned joint stock company, domiciled in Bulgaria, with its registration address: 115i, Tsarigradsko shose Blvd, 1784 Sofia. BTC’s activities include development, operation and maintenance of a national fixed and mobile network and data system for the Republic of Bulgaria. Until 31 July 2020 the Ultimate Parent Company was Viva Telecom (Luxembourg) S.A. (“VTL”) which through InterV Investment S.à r.l. owned 100% of the equity of Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD which is the parent of the Company as at 31 December 2019. The largest shareholder in VTL with a 46% stake was Viva Edge Telecom Limited which is ultimately owned by Mr. Spas Roussev. Other minority investors were comprised of entities affiliated with OJSC VTB Bank, Delta Capital Investments OOD (ultimately controlled by Messrs. Milen Velchev, George Velchev and Krassimir Katev), Mr. Michael Tennenbaum and companies managed by Mezzanine Management Central Europe II Limited. On 7 November 2019 it was announced that United Group, the leading telecoms and media business operating in South Eastern Europe, has agreed to acquire Vivacom group. The European Commission examined the transaction under the normal merger review procedure and approved the acquisition on 3 April 2020. The deal was finalized on 31 July 2020 whereas the shares in Viva Telecom Bulgaria were acquired by United Group Bulgaria EOOD. As a result, as of 31 December 2020 the ultimate parent of the Company is Summer Parent S.a.r.l. (an entity controlled by funds advised by BC Partners) which indirectly through United Group Bulgaria EOOD owns 100% of the equity of Viva Telecom Bulgaria. As of 31 December 2020 and 2019 the Parent company had 5,038 and 5,100 employees, respectively. As of 31 December 2020 and 2019 the Group comprise of BTC and the subsidiary entities—BTC Net EOOD, NURTS Bulgaria EAD, NURTS Digital EAD and Net Is Sat EOOD.

NURTS Bulgaria EAD is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register in 1 April 2010 with subject of business activity: development, operation and maintenance of public electronic communication networks and data systems in Bulgaria, as well as providing telecommunication services through them, including terrestrial broadcasting of television and radio programs, analogue radio-relay and satellite transmission services, collocation services and other commercial activities. The registered share capital amounts to BGN 151,482,310 comprising of shares with nominal value of BGN 1 each. -----

Subsection Title: BULGARIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANY EAD NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED AND SEPARATE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) For the year ended 31 December 2020 All amounts are in thousand BGN, unless otherwise stated 1.** **General information (continued) NURTS Digital EAD
Subsubsection Text: NURTS Bulgaria EAD owns 100 % of the share capital of NURTS Digital EAD, which is a joint stock company registered in the Commercial Register on 15 April 2009 with principal activity construction, operation and maintenance of public electronic communication networks, equipment and information systems in Bulgaria, as well as providing electronic communications services through them, including terrestrial broadcasting of television and radio programs. The registered share capital amounts to BGN 120,000,000 comprising of shares with nominal value of BGN 500 each.

In December 2011 a new Law Amendment of Electronic Communications Act (ECA) was adopted, which implemented the new EU 2009 regulatory framework in the field of electronic communications. According to the procedures set out in ECA and the Methodology for market definition and analysis as at the reporting date the Communications Regulation Commission (CRC) has sent notifications to the European Commission for the following market analyses: - Access to fixed voice telephony services and markets of local, long distance and international calls (first to third round); - Markets for origination and termination in fixed networks (first to fourth round); - Market for termination in mobile networks (first to fourth round); - Markets for wholesale trunk segment and terminating segment of leased lines (first and second round); - Markets for wholesale central access provided at a fixed location (first and second round); - Markets for wholesale local access and wholesale central access provided at a fixed location (first to third round) - Market for transit services in public telephone network (first round). -----

Subsection Title: BULGARIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMPANY EAD NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED AND SEPARATE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued) For the year ended 31 December 2020 All amounts are in thousand BGN, unless otherwise stated 1.** **General information (continued)
Subsubsection Text: In 2020 the following secondary legislation acts were modified: - General requirements for the provision of public electronic communications; - Technical requirements for the operation of terrestrial networks that allow provision of electronic communications services; - Technical requirements for the operation of electronic communications networks and the corresponding radio broadcasting equipment; - Technical requirements for the operation of electronic communications networks of fixed-satellite and mobile-satellite radio services and the corresponding equipment. In March 2018 new legislation involving changes in networks deployment requirements entered into force. The new Law on Electronic Communications Network and Physical Infrastructure (LECNPI) lightens the laying of new cables in the existing duct networks, including in networks of other operators, encouraging the sharing of infrastructure. During 2019 CRC decided to deregulated access to ducts provided by BTC after a transitional period of 1 year as from the publications of the General Terms and conditions according to LECNPI. The General terms and conditions were published on 2nd June 2020 and shall enter into force on 2nd June 2021. At the end of 2020 the EU adopted a Delegate regulation setting single maximum Union-wide voice termination rates. The latter is expected to be promulgated at the beginning of Q2 2021. The single maximum rates will apply from the beginning of H2 2021. - 2120−2125 MHz (total of 5 MHz) for the territory of Bulgaria for transmitting from base stations to end mobile devices; and - 2015−2020 MHz (total of 5 MHz) for the territory of Bulgaria. In 2012 CRC granted BTC AD an additional spectrum of 5 MHz and exchanged the position of previously submitted spectrum. According to the amendment BTC had the right to use the following spectrum: - 1945−1955 MHZ (total of 10 MHz) for the territory of Bulgaria for transmitting from end mobile devices to base stations; - 2135−2145 MHz (total of 10 MHz) for the territory of Bulgaria for transmitting from base stations to end mobile devices; and - 2015−2020 MHz (total of 5 MHz) for the territory of Bulgaria. At the end of July, 2015 BTC’s permission was amended again after replacing the assigned frequency bands and providing additional spectrum BTC was granted the right to use the following spectrum: - 1965−1980 MHz (total of 15 MHz) - 2155−2170 MHz (total of 15 MHz) In Q22016 CRC assigned to BTC additional spectrum of 2x5 MHz in 1800 MHz. Following the procedure of reallocation of the assigned frequencies, currently BTC is entitled to use: - 1740−1755 MHz (total of 15 MHz) - 1835−1850 MHz (total of 15 MHz) An annual fee, calculated based on the annual revenue from telecommunication services provided to the subscribers is paid quarterly. In 2020 and 2019 the annual fee is 0.2% from the annual gross revenue from providing electronic communication networks and/or services, VAT excluded after subtracting the transfer payments to other companies for interconnection of networks and access, transit, roaming, value-added services, as well as costs for authority and related rights for radio and television programmes. For 2020 and 2019 the fees paid for frequency bands in 900, 1800 and 2100 MHz amounted to BGN 7,850 thousand and BGN 7,842 thousand respectively. - TV broadcasting In 2009 CRC has granted NURTS Digital permission for use of resource from radio frequency spectrum via two networks for digital terrestrial broadcasting (DVB-T) which is mandatory for the operation of its core activity. As per decision of the European Court of Justice dated 23 April 2015, the Republic of Bulgaria is found in breach of certain provisions of European directives in relation to the provision of the digital terrestrial broadcasting permission, which has to be remedied. NURTS Digital has complied with all statutory requirements in this regard. In 2019 BTC was granted a permit for use of individually assigned scarce resource—radio frequency spectrum via digital terrestrial broadcasting (DVB-T). As of 1st June 2020, the NURTS Digital permit was terminated and all DVB-T activities were transferred to BTC. Thus, the abovementioned European Court decision is deemed satisfied.

- Fixed line communications On 28 January 2005 the CRC re-issued BTC’s license for usage and development of telecommunications network on the territory of Bulgaria and rendering of telecommunication services through the network. Later, the term of the license was extended until June 2024. An annual license fee, calculated on the base of the annual revenue from telecommunication services billed to subscribers is payable quarterly in arrears. During 2020 and 2019 the annual fee is 0.2% of nominal annual revenue from provision of electronic communications networks and/or services without VAT included and after deduction of transferring payments to other companies for interconnection of networks and access, transit, roaming, value added services, as well as expenses for settling copyrights and related rights for radio and television programs. An annual fee is to be paid to the CRC for access to limited frequency resources such as the radio-frequency spectrum. This fee is calculated on the basis of technical data and is payable quarterly in arrears. During 2020 and 2019 the fee was BGN 3,082 thousand and BGN 3,133 thousand, respectively. The fees are regulated by the CRC and relevant Council of Ministers Ordinances. - Mobile telecommunications In June 2004 the Communications Regulation Commission (CRC) granted BTC the license for building, exploitation and maintenance of a cellular mobile telecommunications network under the GSM standard with national coverage. The issued license is valid for the period of 20 years and granted the right of using radio frequency 900 and 1 800 MHz. BTC paid BGN 54,160 thousand for the GSM license. In April 2005 CRC granted BTC EAD the license for building cellular mobile telecommunication network under the UMTS standard with national coverage. The issued license is valid for 20 years and gives the right to use the following radio frequencies: - 1930−1935 MHZ (total of 5 MHz) for the territory of Bulgaria for transmitting from end mobile devices to base stations; -----
